HEADLINE: After Bad Year for A.M.A., Doctors Debate Its Prognosis

BYLINE: By ABIGAIL ZUGER 

 BODY:
THE patient has had a bad year: on that much the doctors all agree. But their opinions on the underlying diagnosis and prognosis differ radically.
Some say the 150-year-old American Medical Association is still very much its old healthy self: the pre-eminent medical association in the country, almost 300,000-strong, devoted to safeguarding the profession's highest moral and ethical principles. 
 "We are the voice of the profession, for the profession and for the patients," said the organization's president-elect, Dr. Nancy W. Dickey.
But other doctors are wondering more vocally than ever whether the association that claims to speak for them still has any real right to do so. The organization's membership is declining; its policy-making body, the House of Delegates, espouses views far to the right of many members, especially younger doctors, and its continuing efforts to protect the turf of American-trained doctors gives support to critics who say it operates more like a trade union than a professional organization.
Only about 40 percent of the country's roughly 700,000 doctors and 55 percent of its medical students are now members, in contrast with the organization's heyday in the 1960's, when about 90 percent of doctors in private practice belonged. Despite a public relations campaign begun several years ago to promote a "new A.M.A." devoted to patient care and public health, it still struggles against a reputation as a reactionary organization dedicated mainly to maintaining doctors' incomes.
Yet even its harshest critics acknowledge that the association can speak for the profession with an eloquence and credibility that none of the hundreds of other medical groups in the country can match.
"It represents the best and the worst of medicine," said Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor in chief emeritus of The New England Journal of Medicine.
Last August, the association announced an exclusive contract with the Sunbeam Corporation to endorse the company's home-health-related appliances in return for anticipated millions in royalty dollars. A week later, facing a torrent of criticism, it withdrew from the deal, dismissed three nonphysician executives and established an ad hoc panel of ethicists and other experts to review all existing relationships with for-profit companies and to establish acceptable guidelines for future ones.
For the doctors who lead the association, that is the end of the story, despite a pending breach-of-contract suit by Sunbeam. "We'll move on," said Dr. Thomas R. Reardon, chairman of the trustees.
Outside the organization, though, the Sunbeam events have crystallized larger questions.
Dr. Relman said, "The recent episode damaged their reputation a good deal, their reputation as an organization promoting professional values and maintaining standards."
Dr. Richard J. Baron, a Philadelphia internist and association member, called the Sunbeam deal a disaster. But he added, "We're in such a bad way as a profession that I'm reluctant to shoot down any medical organization that may offer some vehicle for unifying us."
Certainly no medical association rivals the A.M.A. either in members or financial resources. Even the largest among the others, like the American College of Physicians, have less than half the association's membership. No other group matches the association in operating revenue ($208 million in 1996) or in its ability to play hardball in Washington. Ampac, its political action committee, consistently ranks among the top 10 spenders on Capitol Hill, Federal Election Commission data show. In the 1995-96 election cycle, political spending by the association and its state chapters totaled about $3 million.
The association makes political and other policy decisions not by popular vote but in three interacting bodies of elected and appointed representatives: a House of Delegates seating almost 500, a 19-member executive board and a 9-member ethical and judicial council.
In twice-yearly meetings, the House of Delegates votes on policy issues that include seat belts, infant car seats (for, 1978), tobacco advertising (against, 1985), doctor-assisted suicide (against, 1996) and the criminalization of the late-trimester procedure its critics call "partial birth abortion" (for, 1997).
Yet critics say this elaborate structure stifles the organization's ability to cope with changing times.
They point out that a large percentage of country's medical people remain well outside the association's ranks. The 20 percent of American doctors who are women are underrepresented in the ranks, and even rarer in the House of Delegates. The 3 percent of doctors who are black have been slow to leave the ranks of the National Medical Association, formed in the 19th century when state restrictions in the South effectively barred blacks from the A.M.A. Although more than half of the nation's doctors are in their 20's, 30's and 40's, the average age in the House of Delegates is more than 60.
And the numerous doctors who immigrated to this country after graduating from foreign medical schools are also notably underrepresented. Foreign graduates now account for almost 25 percent of doctors working in this country, but fewer than 30 percent of them belong.
"On any issue pertaining to international medical graduates, it seemed that our biggest obstacle was always the A.M.A.," said Dr. Abraham Verghese, who was born in Ethiopia, received his medical training in India and is now a professor of medicine at the Texas Tech Health Sciences Center in El Paso.
This year, the association is formally soliciting the participation of foreign graduates. Still, the organization's ambivalence toward foreign graduates, who are often felt to take up hospital training slots that Americans might otherwise occupy, remains palpable. A recent xenophobic editorial in American Medical News, the association's official newspaper. began "Land of (too much) opportunity" and argued that foreign doctors who trained in this country's hospitals should "return to their land of origin."
"The changes they are making are cosmetic but not heartfelt," said Dr. Verghese, who is not a member of the association. "I don't think their fundamental position has changed."
Other nonmembers ascribe their disaffection with the association to its century-long advocacy of fee-for-service health care, which they regard as a position inspired by Victorian sanctimony and robber-baron greed that gave rise to today's health care crisis.
"They're responsible for fiddling while Rome burned," said Dr. David Himmelstein, associate professor of medicine at Harvard University and a spokesman for Physicians for a National Health Program, which favors a health care system similar to the Canadian one, in which the government pays for medical care."They spent 80 years devoted to the well-being of the doctors' pocketbooks, to the encouragement of doctors' greed as an overriding concern."
Dr. Himmelstein is not a member of the association.
But Dr. Douglas Robins, a Washington dermatologist who also advocates a single-payer national health insurance system has been a member for 25 years. "I have a lot of respect for the organization," he said. "But the House of Delegates clearly does not reflect the opinions of the rank and file. The population of doctors in the country is changing dramatically, and the A.M.A. represents only part of them."
Last winter, Dr. Robins formally proposed that the organization study the merits of a single-payer plan. The House of Delegates voted him down.
Dr. Robins said he would like to see the organization change, but he predicted instead that "they will lose more members, become less relevant, less effective at lobbying, generally lose credibility."
Dr. John D. Clough, an Ohio doctor who edits The Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine and is also a longstanding member of the association, has similar concerns. He said the organizational structure, in which local, county and state medical societies funnel representatives to a national organization, no longer worked.
"Physicians have diversified to the point where it is very hard to find economic or political issues they all agree on," Dr. Clough said. "But yet these organizations have continued to remain politically active, mostly for conservative causes, so that they wind up working against the interests of some of their members."
Dr. Clough believes that organized medicine has got to evolve, to refocus a little and begin to realize what unites doctors. "There are a lot of altruistic issues that you can bring physicians together on, that focus on the benefit of the patient rather than the benefit of the doctor, on fewer self-serving things," he said. "That's the way it should be."
In fact, the association sponsors a steady stream of initiatives that fit that bill, from how-to pamphlets guiding doctors in the management of family violence, child neglect and sexual assault to a thick annotated code book of medical ethics for general reference. This year the association founded a research center called the Ethics Institute to examine the ethical aspects of managed care, end-of-life care and genetic medicine. An independent entity, the National Patient Safety Foundation, was also begun this year with generous support from the association to study, demystify and reduce the frequency of medical errors.
"Perhaps they are trying to recreate themselves as a moral voice in a world that's crying out for one," said Dr. John Lantos, a pediatrician and ethicist at the University of Chicago. "Could you imagine, for instance, if the A.M.A. went on record saying that every physician has an obligation to care for the poor?"
Like any political party, the association inevitably promotes a continuing personal calculus of compromise among members and nonmembers.
"It's an immense organization with its finger in literally hundreds of issues," Dr. Dickey said. "By its very breadth of interest and action, it creates controversy. You can't have as broad a policy as we do and not have some folks who disagree with you, vehemently in some cases."
"We all get mail," Dr. Seward said. "But its interesting when you look at it -- we probably get as much both pro and anti mail from nonmembers as we do from members."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Toy Story: Not What It Used to Be

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

KIDS' STUFF
Toys and the Changing World of American Childhood
By Gary Cross
283 pages. Harvard University Press. $29.95.
In only a few decades, American toys have undergone a startling metamorphosis. Baby boomers grew up with toys that were supposed to prepare them for the real world: doctor and nurse's kits, model airplane kits, Tonka trucks and Betty Crocker bake sets. Even their make-believe toys -- based on the space craze and the western fad -- were vaguely rooted in America's past and future. The toys that boomers' children covet, in contrast, have almost nothing to do with the real world: there are dinosaurs equipped with laser beams and missiles, pastel-colored ponies with manes and tails to comb and robots that turn into airplanes and cars. 
 Even venerable G.I. Joe changed to keep up with the times: the average soldier (modeled on fathers' experiences in World War II and Korea) was later reincarnated as a high-tech hero, outfitted with laser beams and rocket command vehicles to fight off menacing aliens.
"By the 1980's play was divorced from the constraints of parents and their real worlds," writes Gary Cross in "Kids' Stuff," his fascinating new study of American toys. "Toys that evoked memories of real wars, western adventure or dreams of future space exploration gave way to action figures, combinations of cliches torn from any realistic context. The dolls and play sets that encouraged girls to act out their mothers' roles were replaced by Barbie's fantasies of personal consumption. Preschool play, once the realm of blocks, pull toys and teddy bears, now featured junior versions of fashion and action play. Educational toys were increasingly marginalized. Even Lincoln Logs and Tinkertoys were edged off store shelves by fantasy playthings."
In "Kids' Stuff," Mr. Cross -- a professor of history at Pennsylvania State University -- not only gives the reader a succinct history of toys in America, but also examines the reasons for the sea change that has taken place in the toy industry in recent years. He looks at changing notions of childhood and disparate theories of play, and he assesses the declining popularity of the educational toy as a means of developing a child's creativity and skills.
Although Mr. Cross makes it clear that he is distressed by the increasingly commercialized -- and inane -- toys that have been merchandized in recent years, he has not written a polemic or diatribe, but an intelligently informed analysis that reveals a lot about how our attitudes toward children. and children's attitudes toward the world, have evolved over the last century.
As Mr. Cross sees it, the ascendence of the fantasy-novelty toy began back in the 1930's with celebrity-inspired toys like the Shirley Temple doll and the Buck Rogers pistol, and was later given a huge boost by television, which enabled toy makers to ignore the concerns of parents and appeal directly to children with escapist fare. From the 60's on, more and more toys (like Creepy Crawlers, Garbage Pail Kids and Rat Fink) would be designed to satisfy children's anarchic impulses while irritating their parents.
By the 70's, Mr. Cross observes, this development was accelerated further by many parents' confusion about "appropriate sex roles" and "the proper uses of war and violence in play." "No longer," he writes, "did they buy toys that claimed to prepare girls to be good mothers and wives or boys to become successful men of work and science. Even the toy soldiers that glorified the wars of fathers no longer worked by the late 1960's because of the controversies over Vietnam. Parents were less willing to give children toys that claimed to teach the young to follow in their parents' footsteps. They had lost confidence that they knew what their children's path to maturity should be."
Oddly enough, the new toys that filled the vacuum -- sappy Care Bears and My Little Ponys for girls; violent He Man warriors and Transformers for boys -- did nothing to eliminate traditional sex roles; as Mr. Cross points out, they simply made "male heroism more fantastic and female caring less grounded in reality."
At the same time, mergers and buyouts in the toy business had created a new selling environment in which there was more incentive, in Mr. Cross's words, "to pick winners rather than to meet the developmental needs of children." With the defeat of reformers' efforts to prohibit toy ads on children's television in the late 70's, toy companies found a new way to virtually guarantee a winner: "program-length commercials," that is, cartoon shows like "He-Man and Masters of the Universe," "Care Bears" and "Strawberry Shortcake" that kept a toy and its add-ons and accessories in front of children week after week. By the fall of 1985, Mr. Cross reports, the top 10 best-selling toys all had their own cartoons.
Although the late 80's saw a brief "back to basics movement," television and movie tie-ins surged back again in the 90's with the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers and Spiderman. Indeed the action figure seems to have permanently displaced old-fashioned toys like the teddy bear. As Mr. Cross observes, "the economic advantages of the 'recognizable' toy based on TV fantasy were too great for any alternative to prevail."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Yen on Doubts About Japan's Overhaul Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The dollar surged to its highest level in five and a half years against the yen yesterday on speculation that Japan might not do enough to bail out ailing banks and securities firms.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said yesterday that he would doanything necessary to stabilize the financial system. Yet he also indicated that his first priority would be to protect depositors, not banks. 
 Traders took the remarks as a suggestion that the Government might let weak banks fail and that the worst might not be over for Japan's financial institutions. That is keeping investors wary of buying the yen, which is down 6.5 percent versus the dollar in the last month.
"It's unusual for Japan to take speedy and aggressive solutions to problems," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Baring Capital Markets. "The yen will still weaken."
The yen was also dragged down by fresh signs of economic woes in South Korea. Officials there said the country remained at odds with the International Monetary Fund over how much economic pain it would have to endure in exchange for a bailout plan aimed at helping its debt-ridden financial system.
Questions over the bailout plan hurt the yen because South Korea is one of Japan's biggest trading partners and biggest debtors.
"Korea is the 800-pound gorilla for Japan," said Bob Near, an institutional currency salesman at Bank of New York. "What's happening with Korea puts pressure on Japan."
The Korean won fell to a record low yesterday, pushing the dollar up to 1,187 won.
The dollar rose as high as 129.32 yen before settling in New York late yesterday at 128.91 yen, up from 127.82 yen on Friday. The dollar rose to 1.7771 marks, from 1.7645 marks on Friday -- its highest against the mark since Oct. 22. The pound fell to $1.6846 from $1.6886.
Against the mark, the dollar rose on expectations that Germany's economy was not expanding fast enough to prompt the Bundesbank to raise interest rates any time soon.
The mark was also hurt by signs of weakness in Russia, where stocks fell to a seven-month low. Problems in Russia can weaken the mark since Germany is Russia's biggest trading partner and lender.

HEADLINE: Asian Pact Endorses I.M.F.-Led Bailouts

BYLINE: Dow Jones

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Finance ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations endorsed a plan today for dealing with future Asian financial crises that gave the leading role to the International Monetary Fund.
And they failed to push forward a proposal by Malaysia's Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, to create a special Asian standby facility to supplement I.M.F. lending. 
 In a statement issued on the first day of a meeting here -- which also included discussions with senior finance officials of Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, China, Australia and the United States -- the ministers said that "Asean countries in a position to provide financial assistance would give special consideration to support any member country requiring such assistance."
Rather than setting up a separate Asian standby facility, they confirmed an initiative in Manila that gives the I.M.F. the leading role in organizing more comprehensive surveillance of troubled Asian economies as well as in organizing new sources of emergency financing.
The trigger for any kind of financial assistance for Asian countries will be entry into an I.M.F. program, the Philippine Finance Secretary, Roberto De Ocampo, said.
But Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, seemed displeased with the decision, saying he would have preferred an Asian financing mechanism that was not "merely an appendage" of the I.M.F.
The United States argued that a separate relief mode for Asia would create a "moral hazard," allowing borrowing nations to think that they could get access to money without adopting the tough financial and budgetary steps the I.M.F. requires.
A bailout for Indonesia organized in October, of nearly $40 billion, is seen as the model for the new process. The I.M.F. and other donors are providing $18 billion in exchange for strict economic reforms. Japan, Singapore, the United States and others have pledged "second line" funds if the $18 billion proves insufficient.
Asean's Secretary General, Ajit Singh, said that under the arrangement announced today, additional funds for Asean countries in financial trouble would not be amassed up front, but would be collected when needed on a voluntary basis from participating Asean members.
In fact, Singapore and Brunei are the only Asean nations with substantial reserves. The economies of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand have been ravaged by five months of financial turmoil.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Inch Up as Data Indicate Inflation Stays Mild

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Treasury prices edged up in quiet trading yesterday after a trade association's report suggested that the economy was growing slowly enough to keep inflation at bay.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly manufacturing index posted a bigger-than-expected decline, while its index of prices paid, an inflation gauge, also fell. 
 The report "was positive for bonds," said Garth Nisbet, who manages $750 million in bonds at the Crabbe Huson Group in Portland, Ore. "The numbers being down add to the case for the economy slowing."
Slower growth reduces the likelihood that inflation -- which erodes the value of bonds' fixed payments -- will accelerate.
The report was one of the first major economic indicators to be released after turmoil in Asia roiled stock markets worldwide and sent investors scurrying to the safety of Treasury securities. Traders have also been buying bonds on expectations that the turbulence in Asia will slow the United States economy enough to restrain inflation.
"Now we are getting information that is more current and reflects the new economic realities," said Tony Crescenzi, head Government bond trader at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company. "The data finally takes on importance again and it will matter" to bond investors, he said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 4/32, to 101 7/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent in a shortened session on Friday.
The Treasury sold $14.54 billion of new three-month and six-month bills at its regular weekly auction. The three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.11 percent, down from 5.145 percent last week, and the six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 5.195 percent, the same as last week.
Bond prices also got a lift yesterday from a rally in the dollar, and from declines in oil and gold prices, traders said.
Gold slumped to its lowest levels since March 1985, while crude oil fell to a five-month low. The drop in gold, a traditional hedge against rising prices, suggests that investors are not worried that inflation is about to quicken.
Also, the dollar climbed as high as 129.32 Japanese yen, the most since May 29, 1992. A rising dollar makes dollar-denominated bonds more attractive to investors overseas.
Comments from Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan reduced concern that Japanese banks and Government institutions would resort to selling some holdings of Treasury securities to shore up finances or pay for a bailout.
"People are less concerned about repatriation" of funds by Japanese institutions, said Robert McGee, economist at Tokai Bank.
Among corporate borrowers, BNP U.S. Funding L.L.C., Avon Energy Holdings and Amgen Inc. are a few of the companies planning to sell a combined $2 billion of debt this week.
Companies generally refrained from tapping the corporate bond market last week because demand often dwindles around the holidays.
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Index Shows Activity Cools For Factories

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
A closely watched gauge of manufacturing cooled in November, reflecting slowdowns in new orders and production that suggested factory activity peaked earlier in the year.
The gauge, the National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index, declined to 54.4 last month from 56 in October, the association said today. 
 The index, one of the freshest barometers of the economy's performance, has fallen in three of the last four months after reaching a two- and-a-half-year high in July.
Still, index readings of 50 or above mean factory output continues to expand. Moreover, a separate Commerce Department report today showed that construction spending increased in October for the fourth consecutive month, climbing one-tenth of a percent, to a record $605.5 billion.
"The economy is still very, very strong," said Norbert Ore, chairman of the N.A.P.M. survey committee and an executive at the Sonoco Products Company, a packaging manufacturer in Hartsville, S.C. "Our members continue to be very optimistic," though the economic crisis in Asia is causing businesses to rethink their 1998 prospects, he said.
The purchasing managers' report contributed to a strong rally in the financial markets because it signaled that the economy remained vibrant but not growing at an inflationary pace. The Dow Jones industrial average rose nearly 190 points, or 2.43 percent, to 8,013, its first finish above 8,000 since the big drop in October. Yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond, an indicator of interest rate trends and inflation fears, fell to 6.04 percent.
Components of the purchasing report "are consistent with the view that activity is slowing," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.
The price-index component fell to 51.9 in November from 55.9 during October. The orders index decreased to 54.5 from 59. The production index fell to 58.6 from 60. These indexes do not measure how much factories produced or to what extent prices rose or fell. Instead, they gauge the number of manufacturers surveyed that reported increased production or paid more for raw materials.
With the economic crisis in Asia damping demand for United States exports, overall growth in the current fourth quarter -- as measured by the gross domestic product -- is expected to fall short of the third quarter's 3.3 percent gain.
"There's caution about the economic outlook," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. However, "the economy isn't quite softer yet," she said.
Asia's economic problems could put a damper on the United States because "a lot of companies that had big contracts for infrastructure projects just aren't going to get those sales," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass.

HEADLINE: Jesse Jackson, in Kenya, Links Benefits to Fair Elections

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 1

 BODY:
On his first trip as a United States special envoy, the Rev. Jesse Jackson delivered a strong message to the Kenyan President today, warning that general elections here next month must not be rigged or marred by violence if Kenya hopes for good relations and trade with the United States.
"We hope that by turning the lights on Kenya, that this will definitely help in the process of having open, free, fair, world-class elections," Mr. Jackson said at a news conference this evening after meeting with President Daniel arap Moi. 
 Mr. Jackson, whom President Clinton recently appointed as "special envoy for democracy," arrived in the Kenyan capital late Sunday night for three days of talks with Government officials, clergy and opposition leaders about the elections scheduled to be held on Dec. 29.
He met with Mr. Moi for nearly an hour this morning. During the meeting, diplomats said, the American envoy said he made it clear that Kenya's relations with the United States depended on the elections conducted without fraud. Mr. Jackson told reporters that it was necessary for the region's stability that "people's fears about rigging be allayed."
Mr. Jackson, the most prominent black politician in America and twice a candidate for President, said that changes adopted by the Kenyan Parliament last month, making it easier for challengers to campaign, were steps in the right direction, even if they were incomplete. He said it appeared that opposition politicians were now holding rallies and speaking out in public without interference from the police.
Mr. Moi, the 74-year-old strongman who has been in power in Kenya since 1979, is expected to win the election with little trouble. Though Mr. Moi can command only about 40 percent of the electorate, he faces a splintered opposition, divided along tribal lines and unable to unite behind a single candidate or platform.
Still, the elections are widely seen here as a watershed for Kenya, a test of how far the country has moved toward an open democracy since 1992, when Mr. Moi reluctantly agreed under heavy international pressure to abandon the one-party state and allow multiparty elections. Those elections, however, were marked by widespread ethnic violence and official harassment of opposition leaders.
Mr. Moi's party pushed through several reforms this fall after pro-democracy demonstrations escalated into riots between the police and opposition supporters over the summer, sending the tourist-driven economy into a tailspin and drawing harsh criticism from Western democracies and Japan, which provide millions in aid to Kenya.
To forestall cuts in foreign aid and take the wind out of the reform movement's sails, Mr. Moi last month repealed several colonial-era laws that gave the President broad powers to detain political opponents, control parties, disperse demonstrations and ban publications. The Parliament also expanded the electoral commission, adding more opposition members, and mandated that the state-controlled television and radio give equal time to the opposition.
Mr. Moi's political opponents maintain that the reforms do not go far enough and came too late to help them.

HEADLINE: Clinton Conditionally Supports U.S. Role in Bailout

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the United States was prepared to contribute to the bailout of South Korea, but only if the South Korean Government agreed to the kinds of painful economic changes being demanded by the International Monetary Fund.
Although American participation in the rescue plan has been likely since South Korea agreed to request international financial assistance last month, Mr. Clinton appeared to be using the prospect as a carrot to entice Seoul to give ground in its last-minute negotiations with the I.M.F. 
 Mr. Clinton did not specify how much money the United States might make available, and other Administration officials said they would not determine an amount until the I.M.F. negotiations had been completed. But they said any American financing would be used as a backup to the I.M.F. package and would be offered in conjunction with similar pledges likely to be made by Japan, members of the European Union and other nations.
News reports in South Korea in recent days said the United States and Japan would put up a combined $20 billion to supplement, if necessary, the roughly $20 billion being provided by the I.M.F., plus billions of dollars that would come from other international organizations including the World Bank.
But analysts said the direct American contribution to the bailout was likely to be far smaller than those reports suggested. In a similar package negotiated recently for Indonesia, for example, the United States said it was prepared to use as much as $3 billion to help stabilize that country's currency and halt the spread of financial instability across Asia.
In remarks to reporters at the White House, Mr. Clinton said he expected South Korea to take some "tough medicine," as Mexico did when its economy was rocked three years ago by a devaluation of its currency and widespread weakness in its financial system.
"I favor a strong agreement with the I.M.F. that would actually restore financial stability and confidence in South Korea," Mr. Clinton said. "And if such an agreement could be made, then I would favor the United States participating, along with Japan, much the same way we did in the recent matter involving Indonesia."
The I.M.F., with the support of the United States, has been pressing South Korea to close weak financial institutions, raise interest rates to support the value of its battered currency, sharply cut Government spending and weaken the ties between the Government and some of the country's largest industrial conglomerates.
American officials said they were willing to commit money to the South Korean bailout as a "second line of defense" to be used only if the funds provided by the I.M.F. proved inadequate to stabilize the currency, the won. Only strict trading limits imposed by Seoul have kept the won from free fall in the last few weeks. Mr. Clinton would not seek Congressional authority for the backup financing, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said, but would instead use the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a pool of money set up 60 years ago that can be used at the President's discretion to maintain stability in currency markets.
The fund is a war chest built up over the years, in large part through profitable buying and selling of currencies by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve. Use of the fund does not require any appropriation by Congress.
The same fund was used by Mr. Clinton to advance $12 billion to Mexico when the Republican-controlled Congress balked at approving a broader rescue package. Mexico repaid the loans in full. The stabilization fund would also be the source of the $3 billion committed to Indonesia if I.M.F. financing proves inadequate.
The fund currently has about $40 billion in assets. Of that, about $15 billion is held in dollars, another $15 billion is in German marks and Japanese yen purchased over the years on foreign exchange markets in defense of the dollar, and $10 billion is held in a form of i.o.u. In practical terms, the fund has more than $10 billion immediately available to deal with the situation in South Korea, and more could easily be made available.
However, the Administration's relationship with Republicans in Congress over international financial assistance remains strained. Republicans blocked an Administration request last month to increase the lines of credit extended by the United States to the I.M.F., and they have intermittently tried to place restrictions on the use of the stabilization fund.
Congress is out of session, but Mr. Rubin said that he had kept Congressional leaders up to date about the situation in Asia and that the response to plans for use of the stabilization fund for Indonesia and possibly for South Korea had been "constructive."

HEADLINE: Global Warming Talks Open in Kyoto

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Dec. 1

 BODY:
A conference that is supposed to cap more than two years of negotiations on what to do about global warming opened here today amid widespread concern that too many hard issues remained to allow the completion of an effective agreement before the talks end in nine days.
"This negotiation hasn't matured; it's like new wine, and I don't know if we can ferment it in time," said Melinda Kimble, a senior State Department official who is leading the United States delegation until the higher-level ministerial phase of the talks begins next Monday. 
 Today, however, Ms. Kimble hinted at some flexibility in the American position on setting targets for reduction of gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.
After more than two years of bargaining, delegates from more than 150 countries are meeting for their final session in the high-tech Kyoto International Conference Hall, set among lovely hills, gardens and ponds in this ancient capital and repository of traditional Japanese culture.
Surrounded by thousands of lobbyists and journalists from around the world, the negotiators are trying to agree not just on the amount by which emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide should be cut over the next 10 to 20 years, and on what schedule, but also on how to share the burden, what gases to include and how to structure the immensely complex task.
The job has turned out to be more complicated and difficult than was envisioned in March 1995, when parties to the 1992 Rio treaty on climate change decided that stronger action was needed, say many who are involved. In 1995, it was seen simply as a matter of deciding on a reduction target and a timetable for the industrialized countries. Now it has broadened to include the highly contentious role of developing nations, as well as a number of elaborate mechanisms by which the reductions might be carried out.
As a result, many experts say, there is a distinct possibility that the talks will not be concluded here, at least not fully, and will have to be extended much as were negotiations on setting up the World Trade Organization -- a task that took more than a decade.
But not everyone is pessimistic, and Ms. Kimble today sent a signal that prompted Michael Zammit Cutajar, the Maltese executive secretary of the United Nations climate secretariat, to declare that "the negotiation is on its way."
Ms. Kimble said at the opening session of the conference of parties to the 1992 Rio climate treaty, under which the talks are being held, that the United States would no longer insist on a flat-rate, one-size-fits-all reduction target for all countries. Instead, she said, the Americans were "prepared to consider the possibility of limited, carefully bounded differentiation" of targets among industrialized countries.
Different targets for different countries, tailored to their economic and social profiles, have emerged as a possible way to get around the impasse among rich countries over what targets and timetables for reductions they should adopt. The European Union, Japan and Russia have all proposed variations on the theme of differentiation, but the United States had until today declined to join in what could ultimately be the key to an agreement on one of the talks' two central issues.
On the other central issue -- how soon developing countries should be bound by specific reductions targets and timetables -- Ms. Kimble said they need not take the same form as those of rich nations. Rather, she suggested, the poorer countries might voluntarily, or as a result of future negotiations, adopt emission growth targets.
The Clinton Administration has said it will sign no agreement that does not include all countries, and Ms. Kimble's statement was the clearest indication so far of what sort of participation by developing countries might be acceptable to the United States.
But the developing countries have insisted all along, and reiterated today, that consideration of specific commitments for themselves is out of the question until the richer nations demonstrate that they are actually reducing emissions. The rationale is that since the rich countries got wealthy by burning the coal and oil that emit carbon dioxide and are the biggest emitters of the gas, they should lead the way.
The United States insists that the developing countries should take on additional commitments, beyond a very general injunction to take steps to reduce emissions required by the 1992 treaty, because their emissions will outstrip those of the rich countries early in the next century.
Scientists advising the negotiators say that if emissions are not reduced, the average global surface temperature will rise by 2 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century. This, say the scientists, would cause sea levels to rise, many coastal zones and small island countries to be inundated, climatic zones to shift, rainstorms to become heavier, floods and droughts to become worse, heat waves to become more lethal and some natural ecosystems to disappear.
Any agreement in Kyoto on reductions would be considered a first step, since none of the proposals now on the table for industrialized countries' emission reductions would stop overall greenhouse gas concentrations from continuing to accumulate in the atmosphere; they would merely reduce the rate a bit.
One of the most stringent reduction proposals on the table, advanced by the European Union, would limit overall emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide to 7.5 percent below 1990 levels by 2005 and 15 percent by 2010.
The United States has proposed that levels be stabilized at 1990 levels in the period 2008 through 2112. The Administration says that would trim emissions by 30 percent from what they would be in the absence of any action.
The American proposal diverges from all others under consideration in that it applies to a larger "basket" of six greenhouse gases that also includes hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulfur hexachloride. The Administration argues that this is an environmentally friendlier course, but a harder one that would not allow the Europeans to achieve their proposed goals.
"I do not see a major difference between the U.S. and the E.U.," said Hiroshi Ohki of Japan, who today was elected president of the conference of parties to the 1992 treaty that are meeting here. He said he believed that the industrialized countries could come to an accommodation.
In addition to the developing-country issue, a number of time-consuming and intricate technical problems must also be dealt with. Among these are the question of how to structure an emission-trading system that the United States says would cut the cost of reduction; which greenhouse gases to include in a reduction regime; the degree to which forests (which absorb carbon dioxide) should be considered in giving credit for reductions, and how differentiated targets could be devised and applied.
If time runs out, say some representatives of environmental groups, extending the talks would be better than producing a flawed agreement that pleases no one -- and that might not be ratified by key countries like the United States -- just for the sake of having an accord.
Mr. Zammit Cutajar remained optimistic. "We have a lot of time," he said, "10 whole days and nights."

HEADLINE: Stocks Surge As Fears Ebb About Asia

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING

 BODY:
A sense that Japanese and Southeast Asian officials are moving quickly to address the financial problems in their economies fueled a rally in stock markets around the world yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 2.4 percent to above the 8,000-point level for the first time in more than a month.
Interest rates also fell in the United States, following a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management that its factory index slipped last month. That was taken as a sign that the economy was not racing ahead too fast, and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds slipped to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent on Friday. 
 Lower interest rates helped to spur a rally in bank stocks, which also benefited from lessening concerns about Asian exposure as well as from another big bank merger. The National City Corporation of Cleveland agreed to acquire First of America Bank, based in Michigan, in a stock worth $80.10 a share, or $6.7 billion. National City shares fell 3 15/16, to 62 13/16, while those of First of America leaped 14, to 72 3/4. Citicorp rose 9 1/2, to 129 7/16; J. P. Morgan gained 6 9/16, to 120 3/4, and BankAmerica added 6, to 79.
Asian and European markets were strengthened by reports that the Japanese Government was ready to inject public funds to thwart a widespread financial crisis. They were also encouraged by the South Korean Government's announcement that a bailout package there was imminent, though an agreement with the International Monetary Fund apparently unraveled later in the day. Early today, Japanese stocks were slightly lower, while shares in Hong Kong's Hang Seng index were up more than 3 percent.
"The bad news is you've got this disease, but the good news is you've got this treatment," Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Company International Inc., said of Southeast Asia's financial woes. "These countries do have the right kind of medicine being applied."
The problems of Japan and Southeast Asia's emerging markets will lead to a slower rate of economic growth in that region, but the "feedback to the U.S. will not be that big," Mr. Brusca predicted. Thus, he added, the prospect of the American economy suffering a recession as a result of the Asian problems is unlikely.
"The scenario where Godzilla attacks New York and steps on Manhattan is not very credible," Mr. Brusca said. "I don't think it's time to write horror stories."
After falling 57 points last week, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 189.98 points yesterday, or 2.43 percent, to 8,013.11. The gains pushed the Dow's closing price to more than 8,000-point level for the first time since Oct. 22.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.03 percent, or 19.38 points, to 974.78, its highest close since it peaked Oct. 7 at 983.12.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index also posted strong gains, jumping 30.17 points, to 1,630.72, a gain of 1.88 percent. Microsoft added 2 5/16 a share, to 143 13/16, while Intel rose 3 7/8, to 81 1/2. Xilinx, like Intel a maker of semiconductors, jumped 5 7/8 a share, to 40 7/16.
The American market has also begun to benefit from problems overseas, as some investors here have shunned international investments and channeled cash back into the domestic market, Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker, said.
In addition, declining interest rates are making fixed-income investments less attractive when compared with stocks, he said.
"The message of the rally is relief that some of these concerns have been lessened," Mr. Cripps said, referring to Asian worries. "And there are not a lot of other places to put your money for a return that is greater" than found in stocks.
In plowing into equities, investors initially flocked to larger corporations. As dismay about the international scene lessened, shares of multinationals also rose. Those gains pushed Morgan Stanley's index of the 50 largest multinational companies up 2.3 percent. The index is now up 35.4 percent this year, more even than the robust year-to-date climbs of 24.3 percent for the Dow and 31.5 percent for the S.& P.
"These are the stocks that are supposed to be hurt by a rising dollar," Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal & Company, said of the gains among multinationals. Shares of Coca-Cola rose 2 1/16, to 64 9/16.
Mr. Rice said he believed such stocks were advancing "because basically nothing happened." He added: "None of the currencies collapsed. None of the world markets collapsed. I don't think we've seen the last of the problems, but no bad news is good news."
Still, he warned, any unexpected turmoil could cause the market to tumble. "We're setting ourselves up for the possibility of another correction," Mr. Rice said. "As oversold as we got is as overbought as we're going to get."

HEADLINE: Tiny Turbine: The Next Generator?;
Company Hopes Its Small Unit Will Dominate Power Market

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

DATELINE: TARZANA, Calif.

 BODY:
Paul Craig, president of the Capstone Turbine Corporation, arrived at company headquarters here near dawn last year to find a stranger standing in the parking lot by one of Capstone's test products. Fearing that the man might damage the small power generator, which was whining like a miniature jet engine, Mr. Craig confronted him.
The stranger turned out to be Paolo Citterio, a young Italian food company executive who had recently seen a demonstration of Capstone's technology. "I have been sitting here for an hour watching and listening to your machine," Mr. Citterio said. "It makes my heart sing." 
 Mr. Citterio is not the only one who has fallen in love with the Capstone turbogenerator, which produces 30 kilowatts of electricity -- enough to power a small restaurant or a convenience store -- hot air and virtually no pollutants. Backers of the privately held company include Benjamin Rosen, the venture capitalist who helped found Compaq Computer, Lotus Development and other technology winners; Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, and William H. Gates.
Why would such superstars stray from the digital world to risk money on the stodgy power industry? It's because they believe history just might repeat itself, with the small generator revolutionizing the power industry just as the microprocessor did the computer industry.
"The little turbine engine has the same relationship to large power plants that the PC had to the mainframe," Mr. Rosen said in an interview in his Park Avenue office. "It puts the source of power at the user site."
Not everyone, of course, sees the microturbine as a sure-fire blockbuster, with skeptics saying small-scale generation will never be economical. And even if the turbine is a hit, Capstone's success is not assured, for companies with deeper pockets might seize the market.
With deregulation of electric power beginning in California on Jan. 1, the power industry here has virtually abandoned the idea of continuing to build expensive central power plants that take years to build, require miles of distribution wires and take decades to pay off. Many analysts say future demand will be met by smaller generators that are closer to where the electricity is used.
The small turbine generator, or microturbine, based on the same technology as a jet engine, seems to be a perfect solution. While large turbine generators have been in use for years, the microturbine is quieter, cleaner, relatively maintenance-free and requires no long power lines. It can burn a variety of fuels, including natural gas, diesel, gasoline and methane.
Two dozen companies, mostly utilities, have been testing the Capstone generator, which looks like a small barrel wrapped in a shiny silver space blanket, exposing it to harsh cold in a Canadian gas field and sticky heat in the Florida swamps. Several of the generators, each of which is housed in a refrigerator-size unit, can be joined together to produce higher levels of power. Capstone plans to make its first 300 commercial models by the end of the year, 5,000 more in 1998 and then ramp up production to 25,000 in 1999.
While the generator may be a perfect fit in remote areas like oil rig sites and gas fields, where it can produce electricity from natural gas that is often simply burned off, Capstone and its partners have come up with 300 other applications, from powering supermarkets to making pizza to helping power companies meet peak demand.
In December, Mr. Citterio plans to switch on three test units at one of his family's plants in Freeland, Pa. The hot exhaust will be used to cure hams and sausages. Mr. Citterio, 35, said the cost of the electricity would be the same as the local utility charged, making the heat a bonus worth $7,000 a year for each unit.
Then there is the demand in developing countries, sorely lacking both electricity and capital. "The market is not going to be in North America forever," Mr. Craig said.
To be sure, some people say Capstone may wait a long time before there is a market anywhere for microturbines. "They are cute as hell, like a little puppy," said Dale Simbeck, vice president for technology at SFA Pacific, a consulting firm in Mountain View, Calif. "How much of the promotion becomes reality only time will tell."
Mr. Simbeck says the high fixed costs of many development projects and the relatively low output of the Capstone turbine make its use uneconomical. Other, more efficient generators are becoming cleaner, and he predicted that deregulation in the United States would unleash a glut of electric power capacity that would drive prices down, making it hard for microturbines to find a market.
"There is lots of excess capacity," he said. "Once you deregulate the market, that excess capacity will be able to be moved where needed."
Tony Prophet also expects Capstone to have a tough time but not because there is no future for small turbine generators. Mr. Prophet is president of a division of Allied Signal Inc., which will have its own microturbine by next year.
Mr. Prophet has already made regional distribution deals with the Unicom Corporation, the parent of Commonwealth Edison of Illinois, and Sonat Inc., an oil and natural gas company. Unicom plans to use the Allied Signal turbogenerator to power a McDonald's and a Walgreen.
About a dozen other companies, including the Ingersoll Rand Company and Elliott Energy Systems Inc., are also developing small turbines. Mr. Prophet predicted Capstone would stumble because the market, which he estimated at between $8 billion and $10 billion, would be dominated by a few large, well-capitalized companies like Allied Signal.
Mr. Rosen is not worried, saying the market is so large it can handle a lot of competition. "Nothing is more competitive than the PC business," he explained, using his favorite analogy. He said that Compaq, of which he is chairman, will probably have $24 billion in revenues this year but is planning to be a $50 billion company by 2000. "Even if we had no competition, we probably couldn't grow much faster," he said.
Still, he is aware of the risks. Mr. Rosen first learned about the company five years ago from his brother Harold, a retired rocket scientist who was looking for a way to power an electric car. In November, after spending $24 million of Benjamin Rosen's money, Rosen Motors, which earlier this year successfully tested an automotive power train incorporating the Capstone turbine, ceased operations because it could not persuade a major auto company to invest in further development.
The Rosen brothers thought the power market would allow Capstone to develop its technology and lower its costs before the automotive market took off around 2005. Now, Capstone is not even counting on the automotive market.
"I had no idea that stationary power would grow so fast," Benjamin Rosen said. "That has really become the tail that is wagging the dog."
When Harold Rosen discovered the company that in 1995 would become Capstone, it was called Nomac Energy Systems, after its two founders, James Noe and Robin Mackay, two former employees of Allied Signal. They had the idea of creating a microturbine generator and had received some financing from NASA, the Ford Motor Company and others, but they were struggling.
In 1993, Mr. Rosen arranged for financing from Sevin Rosen Funds and Canaan Partners, another venture capital firm, and strengthened the company's management. But it was not until Mr. Craig signed on the next year as vice president for engineering that many of the technological problems began to be solved.
"The early machines used up more energy going in than came out," said Harold Rosen, who with his brother is on Capstone's board.
The beauty of the Capstone microturbine is that it has only one moving part. Air heated by fuel drives a turbine, a generator and a compressor that spin on a single shaft. Most turbines use oil as lubrication. But the Capstone turbine uses a cushion of air, making the machine virtually maintenance-free.
Such "air bearings" have been around for years, but it was hard to design a stable one for a microturbine because it needs to spin at an extremely high speed -- 96,000 revolutions a minute -- to generate enough power. Mr. Craig spent much of his career designing turbine generators for airplanes and turbochargers for cars and trucks. After much work, he and his team came up with a patented solution. (The Allied Signal microturbine also has a patented air bearing.)
In 1995, after the first prototype was completed, Capstone secured an investment from Fletcher Challenge Ltd., a conglomerate based in New Zealand, which is now Capstone's largest single investor at about 20 percent. Last year, the company raised $50 million in a private placement. Investors included Mr. Allen's Vulcan Northwest and Mr. Gates, who contributed $5 million.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Gates said this "small" investment was made because Mr. Gates believes "it is very interesting technology."
Capstone has now grown to more than 115 employees from just 10 three years ago. It has more than quadrupled the size of its San Fernando Valley headquarters and is building a new factory about 10 miles away that will be ready by the middle of next year.
The new plant will be the first step in increasing production and lowering costs. The first models will sell for about $15,000 each and produce electricity at a cost of 4 1/2 cents to 5 cents a kilowatt-hour, well below the nationwide average of 69/10 cents.
Mr. Craig, who became president and chief executive last year, predicted that the company would be profitable in 1999.
That is important because everyone at Capstone, in addition to its outside public relations agency, has equity. Michael D. Irvine, who has been in the energy and power industry 30 years and is Capstone's vice president for corporate development, said he took a 55 percent pay cut to join the company but bargained for more stock options.
"Very few things like this come along," he said. "It's time to grab for the brass ring."
Benjamin Rosen said Capstone would probably go public within two years. Though he believes the it might ultimately be bigger than Compaq, which is one of the fastest-growing companies, he is reluctant to say it will succeed as quickly.
"We have to show that the Capstone turbine is cost-effective and reliable," he said. "We think it is, but we have to prove it."

HEADLINE: Gore to Join U.S. Team at Global Climate Conference in Japan

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton, concerned that the global climate-change conference now under way in Kyoto, Japan, will adopt more stringent pollution targets than the United States is willing to accept, announced today that he was sending Vice President Al Gore to the meeting to argue the American position forcefully.
The choice of Mr. Gore as the senior United States representative at the conference came after months of intense debate within the Administration and was made public after the 10-day meeting had already begun. Mr. Gore will spend only one day in Kyoto, next Monday, during which he will present the American policy in a speech and meet briefly with members of other delegations before returning to Washington. 
 As recently as last week, Administration officials had said that Mr. Gore would not attend the Kyoto meeting because other Governments would be represented by lower-level officials. But as the momentum for a sweeping declaration from Kyoto for reducing climate-warming emissions as grown in recent days, White House officials decided that Mr. Gore needed to attend to prevent the United States position from being shouted down.
The President said at a White House picture-taking session today that the American policy was "aggressive and achievable," setting realistic targets for reducing gases that trap heat in the atmosphere. He warned delegates from more than 150 nations now meeting in Kyoto against "promising to do something that neither we nor others can do."
Mr. Clinton was alluding to a European position that calls for cuts in production of so-called greenhouse gases far beyond anything that American businesses or the Clinton Administration believe can be achieved in the next 10 to 20 years.
Mr. Gore said he and the President "are perfectly prepared to walk away from an agreement that we don't think will work."
He added, "So it should be crystal clear to all the parties there that we're going to present the U.S. position forcefully and clearly."
Mr. Gore has much at stake in the global-warming debate, having been one of the first American politicians to raise an alarm about the problem. Mr. Gore was a central figure in the Administration debate and only reluctantly accepted the compromise position that is far more modest than the prescriptions he offered while in the Senate and in his book, "Earth in the Balance."
Mr. Gore will not lead the United States delegation to the climate talks, nor will he negotiate with other nations on what commitments the conference will make. Those jobs remain with Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State.
This fall, the Clinton Administration pledged that the United States would cut emissions to 1990 levels in the next 10 to 15 years. This would be achieved with tax incentives, subsidies for clean energy production and conservation, and by trading pollution permits among industries.
Mr. Gore said that the American proposal would bring a 30 percent reduction in greenhouse gases in the United States by the year 2010. He called that a "huge change" that can be achieved without significant economic pain.
And he said, "Whether there is an agreement in Kyoto or not, the United States is prepared under President Clinton's leadership to unilaterally take the steps that we believe should be taken in order to deal with this problem."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

South Korea Resistance Delays I.M.F. Agreement
The Government of South Korea backtracked and reopened negotiations over a bailout plan for its economy after having announced a day earlier that an agreement had been reached.
The International Monetary Fund has demanded the closure of insolvent banks and other strong steps. By this morning, all three South Korean television networks were reporting that the Government had partly capitulated on some bank closures. But South Korea's stocks and currency fell sharply again. Page A1. 

The United States is prepared to contribute to the bailout of South Korea, but only if the South Korean Government agrees to the economic changes demanded by the International Monetary Fund, President Clinton said. D4.
 
Finance ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations endorsed a plan that gives the I.M.F. the leading role in future Asian financial crises. D5.
 
Manufacturing Pace Slows
A closely followed report by American factory purchasing executives showed manufacturing slowed in November, fresh evidence of a cooling economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index has fallen for three of the past four months after reaching a two-and-a-half-year high in July. D2.
 
Treasury prices rose after the National Association of Purchasing Management's report. The bond's yield fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent. D10.
 
F.T.C. Sticks to Its Standards
The Federal Trade Commission decided to preserve a standard a half-century old that requires a product to be "all or virtually all" made in the United States to be labeled as such, a standard often interpreted to mean 98 percent of a product's value. A1.
 
Fight Looms Over Pensions
Retirement advocates warned that a Labor Department plan seriously threatens pension fund accountability. Under the plan, large pension funds would no longer be required to disclose their assets annually. D2.
 
Iraqi Oil Compromise Offered
United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has recommended that the Security Council consider increasing the amount of oil Iraq may sell in return for food and medicine, but he stopped short of proposing a specific figure. The Security Council is expected to maintain current Iraqi oil export levels of $2.1 billion every six months with a promise to consider increases in the future. A13.
 
Crude oil prices fell sharply on the action by the Secretary General and the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise its output ceiling to 27.5 million barrels a day from 25.033 million. On other markets, coffee prices jumped. D19.
 
Global Warming Talks Begin
After more than two years of bargaining, delegates from 150 countries are meeting in Kyoto, Japan, for nine days of talks on what to do about global warming. A10.
 
Workers Are in Short Supply
There is a shortage of workers in the New York metropolitan area, but it is scattered, concentrated in pockets by industry, geography and skill level. A1.
 
Dollar Surges vs. Yen
The dollar surged to its highest level in five and a half years against the yen on speculation that Japan might not do enough to bail out ailing banks and securities firms. The dollar closed at 128.91 yen, up from 127.82 yen on Friday. The dollar rose to 1.7771 marks, from 1.7645 marks. D19.

HEADLINE: Bailout for Korea Is Left Unresolved As Seoul Hesitates

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 2

 BODY:
An agreement for the economic rescue of South Korea unraveled Monday and negotiations began again, as Seoul resisted taking the severe steps, such as closing insolvent banks, that were advocated by the International Monetary Fund.
By this morning, some Government officials were saying that a new agreement had been reached, and a Cabinet meeting was called to discuss the plan. All three major television networks here were reporting that South Korea had partly capitulated, agreeing to close more than half of the 12 banks that are overwhelmed with bad debts. 
 But at a Cabinet meeting, Lim Chang Yuel, the Minister of Finance and Economy, said that there were still issues to be resolved and he did not even present the plan to the meeting, which adjourned after 10 minutes, according to a spokesman for President Kim Young Sam.
Some agreement is still expected this week. But the disarray suggests how difficult biting the bullet is for a nation that has become the world's 11th-largest economy after experiencing breakneck economic growth for three decades.
While the terms of any bailout have not been announced, press reports here have said that about $55 billion may be made available to South Korea by the I.M.F., by nations like the United States and Japan, and by other international organizations like the World Bank. That would make the rescue the largest ever, surpassing the $48 billion allocated for Mexico in 1995 after its currency crisis.
South Korea's stock market and the value of its currency plummeted further this morning, after both fell sharply on Monday. The declines could indicate concern that the conditions set by the I.M.F. would produce a sharper economic slowdown than had been anticipated.
The Finance Ministry ordered nine ailing banks to suspend business today until the end of the year, and the Korea Stock Exchange suspended trading in shares of eight of the banks. The ninth bank's shares are not publicly traded. But it was unclear from the Finance Ministry order whether the business suspensions satisfy I.M.F. demands.
The near-relentless declines in South Korea's stocks and currency since the nation asked for I.M.F. aid on Nov. 21 have come on fears that the conditions set by the lending agency would cause a sharp economic slowdown. But the declines also reflect fears that regardless of how harsh the terms, the measures may not be strong enough to truly overhaul a financial system hobbled by bad debts from reckless bank lending.
By late morning in Seoul, the stock exchange's composite index had plunged 18.90 points, or 4.81 percent, to 374.26, after a 3.6 percent decline on Monday, The drop on Monday took the index below the 400 level for the first time in more than 10 years. The currency, the won, was trading at 1,267 to the dollar, a record low and down more than 6 percent from the record low that was set on Monday.
Korean press reports said the big obstacle in the negotiations was the I.M.F.'s request that South Korea liquidate troubled merchant and commercial banks.
Seoul, worried about increasing unemployment and a possible run on banks, has favored allowing these institutions to be revamped or merged with healthier companies. About 12 of the nation's 30 merchant banks and 3 or so commercial banks are considered candidates for closing. Merchant banks, which are smaller than commercial banks, primarily lend to small businesses.
The two sides were also said to disagree over the target for economic growth next year, though the final figure is likely to be about half of this year's expected growth rate of 6 percent. A smaller growth target would mean higher taxes and less Government spending, costing South Koreans jobs and income.
Mr. Lim, the Finance Minister, had said early Monday that an agreement had been reached. But he never came to a news conference scheduled to disclose details, heading back for more I.M.F. negotiations instead.
I.M.F. officials had said throughout Monday that there was no agreement.
The I.M.F. bailout is intended to reassure international financial markets that Seoul will be able to pay its foreign debts.
"In the short term, it will help gain back international confidence in the Korean economy," said Sakong Il, a former finance minister who is now chairman of the Institute for Global Economics, a research organization. "It will stabilize the foreign exchange market."
Regardless of the terms of an I.M.F. rescue, South Koreans have been bracing for austerity since the Government first agreed to accept aid. "We are all prepared for quite serious recession now," said Park Ungsuh, president of the Samsung Economic Research Institute, part of the nation's largest industrial conglomerate. He said the unemployment rate might double to about 5 percent.
Dr. Park said that the bailout's effects could indirectly hurt even creditworthy companies if banks refused to lendmoney out of fear for their own survival.
Richard Samuelson, director of research for SBC Warburg Dillon Read in Seoul, predicted that the stock market index would eventually drop to 300 and that the won would sink to the point that it would trade at 1,400 to the dollar.
One bright spot for South Korea is that exports are growing, propelled by the weakening of the won, which makes Korean products more competitive overseas.
The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy reported Monday that South Korea had a trade surplus in November of $211 million, only the second monthly surplus in nearly three years and a sharp contrast to the $1.96 billion deficit in November of last year. But the shift came not only from increased exports but also from a steep drop in imports because of the economic woes.
South Korea's deficit in the current account, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, is expected to fall to about $13 billion this year from $23.7 billion last year.
That is good news for South Korea because the huge deficit is one reason it is troubled by foreign debt. However, the rise in exports has raised fears in the United States that South Korea and the other ailing Asian nations will try to export their way out of their economic problems, undercutting American producers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With their nation's financial crisis worsening and a dose of austerity apparently on the way, South Koreans, like this father and son, staged a rally in Seoul yesterday to demonstrate their concern. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. D4)
