HEADLINE: Tight but Quirky Job Market As the New York Area Revives

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
A phenomenon absent from the New York regional economy for nearly a decade, and almost unthinkable through the grim recession years of the early 1990's, has suddenly re-emerged here: a shortage of workers.
From low-wage day laborers in Bridgeport, Conn., to computer programmers on Long Island and in New Jersey, to retail clerks and paralegals here in Stamford, the industries and areas affected are diverse. The shortage is especially acute in the suburbs, particularly here in Fairfield County, where unemployment has fallen to 2.7 percent in and around Stamford and Danbury. 
 At the Stamford Town Center mall, wages have jumped sharply, with clerks now making about $7.50 an hour, or 13 percent more than last year, and the "Now Hiring" sign at Filene's is almost as big as the store's name on the mall entrance. Shaw's Supermarkets has begun a shuttle service, taking new workers from inner-city Bridgeport and New Haven to its stores in the suburbs. Other employers here have begun recruiting in places as far away as South Africa, Poland and Russia.
In many corners of the nation, like Raleigh, N.C., and Des Moines, where unemployment has been low for years, stories like this perhaps no longer qualify as news. But that is not the case in the New York region. Not since the late 1980's, when the last boom economy reached its peak, has the region even remotely glimpsed "full employment" -- which economists generally say occurs when most people who want a job can find one.
But in many important ways this job market is not at all like that of the 1980's boom, or like any of the other job booms that are occurring elsewhere in the country. In the New York region, the labor shortages are spotty and scattered, concentrated in pockets by industry and geography and skill level. Corporate downsizing -- though on a smaller and more subdued scale than a few years ago -- is also continuing as companies shed management jobs. That is creating an environment of winners and losers, and of anxiety amid prosperity. The large numbers of residents of the region leaving welfare for work has also created labor ripples. Fast food outlets, for example, report few shortages in the region, and thus little pressure to raise wages.
And New York City still has one of the highest big-city unemployment rates in the nation, at 9.1 percent -- though that has come down over the last four months from a 10 percent peak in early summer.
Though companies have created tens of thousands of new jobs in fields like financial services, technology and consulting, the numbers of people seeking those jobs has grown even faster, and many unemployed city residents do not have the right skills, employers say. That has kept New York's unemployment rate high, while further driving down the jobless rate in places like Stamford, as many of the new jobs have gone to commuters.
Economists say that the contrast of joblessness amid a hiring frenzy -- as well as the lingering effects of the deep recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's -- have made workers in the New York region more tentative in their wage demands than workers elsewhere in the nation.
"Places like Des Moines, Minneapolis and Dallas have been experiencing tightness for some time -- labor is emboldened there," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting firm. "In Stamford, the tightening is much more recent -- and very recent in cutting across a wide range of industries."
Christopher L. Bergstrom, the director of economic development for the City of Stamford, described the current economy as a "boom with angst."
"Even though it's a tight labor market, people don't necessarily feel all that secure," he said. "People know they can still lose their jobs, even though there aren't enough workers to go around."
Nonetheless, amid the anxiety there are increasing numbers of workers with good jobs, for whom the closing months of 1997 are like the reprise of a song that some thought might never be played in this region again.
"A lot of the things my husband and I have now -- a few years ago I wouldn't have thought were attainable," said Laura Kuck, a 26-year-old paralegal in Stamford who is benefiting from the competition among employers. Mrs. Kuck, who lives about 40 miles north of here in New Fairfield, has changed jobs several times in the last two years, and has seen her income climb by more than $10,000 as a result. Her husband, Eric, a warehouse manager, was recently lured to Stamford by a job offer as well.
The lumpiness of the region's job story can be found within towns and even within companies. Mrs. Kuck's boss, Mark P. Santagata, a partner at the law firm of Cacace Tusch Santagata, said that he and his partners had been searching for a receptionist for six months, and that they had just hired an office manager after an exhaustive search.
But if they wanted to hire another lawyer, they could have their pick. "If I put an ad in the paper looking for an attorney, I'd have 50 resumes on my desk in a day," Mr. Santagata said.
Similarly, some companies that have been having poor luck hiring new college graduates have been reaching out specifically for older workers, checking in at places like Senior Employment Services, a nonprofit agency that works primarily with people age 50 and over.
But Karen Cornwell, the agency's director, said the calls from the newly jobless had not stopped, either. On one recent morning, for instance, a senior executive from Champion International stopped by. Champion, a paper products company with its headquarters here, said in October that it would eliminate about 30 percent of its jobs, and the executive, a woman in her early 40's who had worked for the company since college, was on the layoff list. She was scared and did not want to be identified. "But I told her her prospects were good," Ms. Cornwell said.
Around the region, employers and economists say that job markets have tightened in a kind of rolling wave that has affected some places earlier and more profoundly than others.
"It's been a challenge in New Jersey for the last year; Connecticut started to get tight about nine months ago, and the last six months on Long Island," said Gordon J. Bingham, a senior vice president for marketing with Olsten Staffing Services, the Long Island-based temporary-help agency. "It's difficult to fill the high end and the low," Mr. Bingham added. "The middle is still easier."
Technology is the common thread of most of the jobs that are in high demand. Entry level clerical workers making $18,000 to $35,000 a year who can operate computers have seen their wages jump by about 15 percent this year, said Catherine C. Candland, president of Advantage Staffing Services, an employment agency in Stamford. For highly skilled programmers, Ms. Candland said, there are "no limits" on pay, with many salaries reaching $300,000 a year or more.
Ms. Candland said that some people who lost jobs in the recession as middle managers have returned with technology training and are earning even more than before. Many more, she said, have had a hard time adapting.
Still, the demand for technology skills seems only to increase. At SPC Warburg Dillon Read, a division of the Swiss Bank Corporation that is moving its headquarters to Stamford from Manhattan over the next year, more than half of the 450 to 475 new jobs are in those two hard-to-fill high- and low-end technical categories. The firm has pitched the area's quality of life and amenities like day care as part of its hiring package.
New state and Federal welfare laws aimed at getting welfare recipients into jobs are also having an effect on the labor market. Jonathan A. Mathias, owner of the Corporate Deli and Grille in downtown Bridgeport, said that a year ago he could walk over to the bus depot, a block away, and find five or six people available for a day's work, cleaning up a storage room or basement. Most were welfare recipients, and most have disappeared from the streets, apparently into full-time jobs, Mr. Mathias said.
On one recent morning he stood in his kitchen, hands and arms covered halfway to the elbow with gritty, aromatic brown cooking grease, struggling to fix an old electric grill with a burned-out thermostat.
"A year ago, I would have been supervising," Mr. Mathias said.
The fast-food industry, on the other hand, perhaps because of the influx of former welfare recipients looking for full-time jobs, has reported few shortages -- a stark contrast especially to the late 1980's, when places like McDonald's had to bus workers from the Bronx to staff its restaurants on the Connecticut Turnpike.
Looming behind all the falling unemployment numbers in the region, of course, is the economic force of New York City. Unemployment rates are low in places like Stamford partly because local companies are hiring, but also because New York City companies are hiring as well -- a fact that is obscured by New York's high unemployment rate. New York City jobs that go to suburban commuters and local jobs created in the suburbs have exactly the same effect in pulling down jobless rates in Connecticut, which sends about 33,000 commuters a day to Manhattan for work.
And the city has entered the late fall on a very strong note. In the first 10 months of 1997, New York companies created 53,000 new jobs, more than in any comparable period since 1984. About 43,000 more New Yorkers are working now than just four months ago, according to the New York State Department of Labor.
Some experts fear that a combined and heightened demand -- city and suburbs, big firms and small ones all competing for the same group of workers -- could choke off the region's economy before it really gathers steam.
"Now we've got the jobs, and the question is, can we get the workers?" said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
Companies like Silicon Valley Internet Partners, an 18-month-old Boston-based company that opened its first Manhattan office in September 1996, show the New York City side of the job equation: The firm has grown tenfold in just 14 months, to 60 employees from 6. The target for the foreseeable future is 100 percent growth per year, said Aron Dutta, a vice president and general manager of the New York office. So far, Mr. Dutta said, hiring has not been a problem -- about 30 percent of the staff was stolen away from Wall Street giants like Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.
The world at large represents yet another recruiting possibility. Olsten now recruits and brings into the United States 25 to 40 technically trained foreign nationals every six weeks to fill the demand for computer programmers and software engineers. Many of them, the company says, choose to work in the New York region because the ethnic diversity means they are more likely to find a community or neighborhood of fellow immigrants.
The City of Stamford is also exploring a public-private program to begin recruiting foreign technical workers, under a public-private partnership with local employers. Poland is the first target because of the large local Polish population. The University of Connecticut has also set up a campus here specifically aimed at training technical workers, and Mr. Bergstrom at the city's Economic Development Department dreams of a whole educational overhaul that would offer children from preschool on up a technology-rich experience that he says would prepare them for the future he sees unfolding.
But how hiring and employment will work by the time the future arrives for those children is anybody's guess.
Ebeth Pretorius, a computer software worker from South Africa, took a job in New York in 1992, working for the technical subsidiary of Olsten, just as companies were downsizing. She saw the corridor outside her office in Rockland County empty of workers. Now it is full again, but everything is different. Because of the hiring squeeze, she said, all the technical workers in her office are now, like her, contract workers.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Military Plans Suspected In Libyan Pipe Project
Three engineers working on the Great Man-Made River Project in the Libyan desert said they suspect that the system of underground pipes and reservoirs, which is being built largely with American equipment, has a hidden military purpose. A1 

American Accused of Spying
An engineer for a San Diego-based company was arrested in Russia and charged with spying for the Americans. Ronald L. Bliss, who works for the Qualcomm telecommunications firm, has been accused of importing and using a satellite receiver to conduct topographic measurements illegally. The United States Embassy in Moscow vehemently denied that Mr. Bliss had any connection with the United States Government and said he was not a spy. A5
 
New Estimate on Nazi Gold
Swiss historians said that the amount of gold stolen from concentration camp prisoners and other victims of Nazi Germany was much higher than previously assumed. According to its authors, the study is the first to trace gold transactions by the Nazi Central bank, or Reichbank. It reports that this gold, representing one-sixth of the gold that passed through Nazi coffers, would be worth $1.3 billion today. A6
 
Spain Party Leaders Sentenced
The Supreme Court of Spain sentenced the 23 leaders of the Herri Batasuna party, a leftist Basque political party, to seven years each in jail for collaborating with Basque separatists. The separatist group has been accused of killing nearly 800 people and wounding thousands since 1968 in a violent campaign for an independent homeland. A6
 
Abortion in Ireland Rape Case
The Irish Supreme Court ruled that a 13-year-old girl, who said she was made pregnant by a rapist, would be permitted to travel to Britain to receive an abortion. Abortions are legal in Ireland, but only in limited circumstances, which do not include rape. The Roman Catholic Church decided that it would not try to finance an appeal of the decision. A7
 
Annan Supports More Iraqi Aid
United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan recommended that the Security Council consider allowing Iraq to increase the amount of oil it exports in return for food and medicine. The announcement was a compromise between relief agencies that have been pressing for a doubling of oil exports, and the United States, which warned against leaving an impression of granting concessions to President Saddam Hussein. A13
 
Climate Talks Begin in Japan
A conference on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions began in Kyoto, Japan, where delegates from more than 150 nations are discussing how to share the burden of the complex task. There is concern that too many hard issues remain to allow the completion of an agreement before the talks end. A10
 
President Clinton announced that he was sending Vice President Al Gore to the Kyoto conference to argue the American position on pollution targets. A10
 
NATIONAL A18-27
 
F.B.I. Director Appeals To Reno on Prosecutor
The F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, gave a long memorandum to Attorney General Janet Reno last week in a last-ditch appeal to persuade her to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign finance abuses, law-enforcement officials said. Those who have seen Mr. Freeh's memo say it argued his contention that the conflicts of interest for the Justice Department are so great that Ms. Reno's department cannot credibly investigate the campaign finance issue. Ms. Reno is expected to reject Mr. Freeh's advice today. A1
 
Cloning Gains Acceptance
In the nine months since Dolly the lamb was cloned from a cell taken from an adult sheep, there has been an enormous change in attitudes about cloning people. A handful of fertility centers are conducting experiments with human eggs that lay the groundwork for cloning. Moreover, the Federal Government is supporting new research on the cloning of monkeys, encouraging scientists to perfect techniques that could easily be transferred to humans. A1
 
Student Kills 3 Others
A 14-year-old boy drew a gun and shot eight students who had just ended a prayer meeting at a high school in West Paducah, Ky., killing three girls. The boy, who warned last week that "something big's going to happen," was charged as a juvenile with murder, attempted murder and burglary. A18
 
Disney Pledges Money for Hall
Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney company, announced that the corporation was donating $25 million for the Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles, a major step toward full financing of the project. The ambitious project proposed a decade ago by the Disney family had stalled and almost collapsed because of financial problems. A18
 
Controllers Blamed in Air Chase
Government officials said they found that civilian and military air controllers had failed to adhere to an agreement meant to avoid incidents like one in February in which an Air National Guard fighter gave chase to a Pan Am jet that had "intruded" into space sometimes used for military training. The National Transportation Safety Board made recommendations on how to prevent a recurrence, including better training. A22
 
Court Considers Shipwrecks
The Supreme Court heard arguments on rules for sorting out claims to shipwrecked treasure, an issue made more complicated in recent years by the advancement of technology for recovering sunken goods. The question for the Justices is whether the Abandoned Shipwreck Act, a statute that is both complex and vague, applies to a shipwreck found in 1993, and, if so, how the statute is supposed to work. The company that found the wreck is arguing with the State of California over title and salvage rights. A18
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
Judge Rules Against Giuliani Over Bus Ads
A Federal judge ruled that city and transit officials violated free-speech rights when they pulled bus advertisements that tweaked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's propensity to take credit for all that is good in New York City. The use of his name by New York magazine, the Mayor argued, violated his right to privacy and his right to protect his name from commercial exploitation. But the judge ordered the transit authority to restore the advertisements. "Who would have dreamed that Mayor would object to more publicity?" the judge wrote. A1
 
D'Amato Criticizes Teachers
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato sharply escalated his two-month-old feud with the United Federation of Teachers, telling a breakfast forum that included union leaders that teachers were to blame for lagging reading scores and high drop-out rates in the city schools. B1
 
Unusual House for Sale
The house at 11 East 62d Street is for sale. But this is no ordinary house (it was built by the Vanderbilt family at the turn of the century) and it does not have an ordinary sale price -- $30 million, more than double the highest recorded sale price for a Manhattan town house. But architectural historians and real estate experts say that Fabbri house, as it is known, is set apart by the fact that it has been left alone over the years: it is in original condition. B3

HEADLINE: Disney Concert Hall Gets a Pledge

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Over the past decade, the ambitious dream by Walt Disney's family for a grandiose Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles has turned bleak. Intended to reinvigorate downtown neighborhoods and even transform the entire city, the project stalled and almost collapsed under the weight of financial problems, red tape, bureaucratic bungling and artistic disagreements.
But today, the dream of Disney's widow and family seemed on the verge of reality. 
 Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of The Walt Disney Company, announced that the company planned to donate $25 million for the concert hall, a major step toward full financing of the project.
The concert hall, with a grandiose design by Frank O. Gehry, the renowned architect from Santa Monica, Calif., has been a high priority for the administration of Mayor Richard J. Riordan and business leaders who have sought for years to revitalize downtown Los Angeles, which turns into a dark and eerie enclave at night. Despite several first-rate hotels, restaurants, museums and the Los Angeles Music Center, downtown is rarely visited by residents of outlying neighborhoods, like the monied sections of Beverly Hills, Bel Air and Brentwood, less than 30 minutes away.
The Riordan administration has seen the Disney Concert Hall as a way to turn downtown into an anchor for this sprawling city of 3.5 million people -- in a county of 9.1 million.
The leaders hope the concert hall will also accelerate other major projects, including a planned $300 million sports arena and entertainment center, and a new Roman Catholic cathedral by the Spanish architect Rafael Moneo.
Standing at the Los Angeles County Music Center, across the street from the parking lot where the Disney hall is to be built, Mr. Eisner said, "We think the Disney Concert Hall is an extremely worthwhile project and one that will benefit the citizens of Los Angeles for many years to come."
Mr. Eisner has been criticized in recent years for not pledging money to help build the center in honor of his company's founder. Asked why the contribution was being made now, he said: "I think the Disney hall needed this final push. It was always known that there would be an appropriate time to get in."
The Disney donation is a "challenge gift" that depends on other corporate sponsors donating $25 million more toward construction.
"I am confident funds will be raised to match the Disney company gift and that the building will get under way in 1998," said Andrea L. Van de Kamp, chairwoman of the Los Angeles Music Center and a member of the Disney Hall Oversight Committee.
The 2,350-seat concert hall is scheduled to open in 2001, serving as the home for the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which now performs across the street at the crowded Dorothy Chandler Pavilion.
The concert hall project was begun a decade ago with a $50 million gift from Walt Disney's widow, Lillian B. Disney. Over all, the Disney family has contributed nearly $100 million.
But almost from the outset, the project has been mired in red tape, mismanagement and controversy over its free-flowing design by Mr. Gehry. It has been compared to the hull of a futuristic ship -- "a Matterhorn for music where thousands can gather to take the ride," Herbert Muschamp, the architecture critic for The New York Times, wrote in 1992.
The project was halted in 1995, after escalating costs raised the price to $265 million, from the original estimate of $110 million, though the estimate was later lowered to $220 million. Mr. Gehry's design was attacked as too complicated and costly -- and when an effort was made to restrict his participation in the design of the hall, Mr. Gehry threatened to remove his name from the project.
In recent months, the usually reticent Diane Disney Miller, a daughter of Walt Disney who lives in Napa Valley, has interceded and, by all accounts, played an important role in forging a consensus that has brought Mr. Gehry back into the fold. The project is now being managed by a coalition of nine members who represent a cross-section of opinions about the concert hall. Solidifying Mr. Gehry's position on the project was his new Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, which has received critical acclaim and was brought in on budget.
"I am pleased that everything is resolved and that we are moving ahead in a positive way to get the project completed," Ms. Miller said.
Adding to the momentum for the Disney hall was the appointment last June of Eli Broad, chief executive of SunAmerica, the financial services corporation, and a leading figure in the city, as chairman of the concert hall's oversight committee, which has the responsibility for fund-raising and completion of construction of the hall.
Mr. Broad said that the Disney company's $25 million gift -- plus an additional pledge today of $5 million by Roy E. Disney, vice chairman of the Disney company and a nephew of Walt Disney -- brings the total committed to the project to about $160.4 million, or 73 percent of what is needed to complete the hall.
"Our goal is in sight," Mr. Broad said.
Under the terms of Roy Disney's gift, there will be a performing arts center at the concert hall for students of the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia, which is 25 miles north of Los Angeles.
Mr. Riordan said in a statement, "This concert hall will be a beacon for our city; a symbol of the beauty, culture and excitement that is Los Angeles as we usher in the 21st century."

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
Going Home, American Shoots Film In Vietnam

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
Making the first American movie ever filmed entirely in Vietnam hasn't been a bed of lotus blossoms, say its producers and its young director, Tony Bui, 25.
All of them hope Mr. Bui's "Three Seasons" will create as much excitement when it is released in the spring as "The Quiet American" did nearly 40 years ago. 
 The Vietnamese-American auteur was 2 years old when his parents, with high-level connections to the defeated Government of South Vietnam, fled with the family to the United States. He says he hated every minute of his first visit here five years ago.
But his heart kept pulling him back to the city that used to be known as Saigon, and now he's here shooting his first full-length movie despite obstacles as disparate as a typhoon, Government censors and the constant roar of the motorbikes that are taking over the city two decades after the Communists did.
The film's major supporters include Harvey Keitel, who plays an American veteran in search of the child, now a young woman, he fathered here. But this is not another war movie about American hang-ups on Vietnam.
"From my first visit here in 1992, I knew that what I had to do was to tell the stories about this place that are the least told: the stories of the Vietnamese, from a Vietnamese point of view, and in Vietnamese," Mr. Bui said after shooting a pedicab race scene in the hot sun just after the dry season started.
"Three Seasons" aims to be a sentimental and sensitive exploration of the profound social and cultural changes that have swept the country of his birth since the Communists reunified it by force in 1975.
All the actors but Mr. Keitel are Vietnamese or Vietnamese-Americans, and shooting is being done with a Vietnamese company, state-owned Hang Phim Giai Phong, or Liberation Film Studios. And Government censors are keeping a watchful eye on both script and shooting.
"It's a film with only one known star, but I hope people in France, Germany or Idaho will all recognize the struggles, the hopes and the dreams of the people in this poor third-world country as very similar to their own," said Mr. Bui, who grew up in Sunnyvale and San Jose in California and studied filmmaking at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, graduating in 1995.
The producers are only 34: Jason Kliot, a New Yorker who graduated from the Dalton School and Amherst College, and Joana Vicente, his wife and partner in Open City Films Inc. of New York City.
They all came here to start making the film in September and expect to finish it at the end of December for only $1.5 million, a 10th of what they estimate it would cost to do the shooting in the United States. The film is scheduled for release by October Films, which introduced "Breaking the Waves" and "Secrets and Lies" in the United States and was acquired by Universal Studios last year.
Mr. Bui, an athletic-looking young man with long black hair pulled back in a ponytail, chuckled at the idea of a major studio backing a micro-budget film that will be released in the United States with subtitles, but insisted that the Vietnamese soundtrack was part of the point of view he wanted.
So is this city, a place where giant high-rise hotels, residences for rich expatriates and retail shops with expensive Western goods rise starkly out of seething slums, in a country still run by Communists despite its capitalistic economic policy.
Mr. Keitel, who speaks in English, completed a week of shooting here in mid-November.
The three seasons of the title are the interwoven stories of a pedicab driver and a passenger he eventually rescues from prostitution; Mr. Keitel and a street urchin he meets before he finally finds his daughter, and an elderly Vietnamese housekeeper who loses her job in the city and goes to the countryside to help a Buddhist monk who is dying of leprosy.
The script, written by Mr. Bui and his brother, Timothy Linh Bui, is both sweetly Vietnamese and appealingly American. "Tony believes very strongly in people helping each other in difficult situations," Mr. Kliot, the producer, said.
The crew of 25 Americans and 60 Vietnamese got plenty of practice doing that as soon as shooting began, when Typhoon Linda made a mucky mess of one of one of their outdoor locations, near a bridge over the Saigon River.
The street urchin in the story was plucked from the ranks of the real "dust of life" orphans who still swirl around the knees of foreign tourists and try to sell trinkets, newspapers and cigarettes to eke out a living. The boy, who wears a Woody Woodpecker T-shirt, is called Woody in the script.
Most of the pedicab drivers in the film are not actors but wiry men who really do peddle cyclos, but not Hai, the Vietnamese hero of the film. He is played by Don Duong, an actor with a deep, resonant voice who is well known in Vietnam and is Mr. Bui's uncle.
Through an interpreter on location, Mr. Duong said, "I love this film because it talks about hard-working people who are struggling to make a better life for themselves, and I'm happy to be playing in it."
Playing is not the word for what he was doing in a climactic scene, the cyclo race. The shooting created monumental jams of knotted motorcycles, cyclos and cars in the outlying Thu Duc district as the police held up traffic for the filming. Later, Mr. Duong and his competitors pedaled again and again up and down a red-dirt back street to capture the moment when the two leaders in the race collide and his character, an underdog, pulls ahead to win.
He then uses his $200 prize to hire his streetwalker passenger for a night, not for her services but just to let her sleep in a luxury hotel, wake up alone and enjoy the breakfast in bed she had told him she dreamt of as an escape.
She is played by Zoe Bui, who is not related to the director but, like him, was taken to the United States by her family as a child.
Mr. Duong, who said he was paid $1,500, made only one critical observation. "We get less money than the American stars," he said.
Most of Mr. Keitel's scenes are in the rainy season with the urchin, and in a spontaneous gesture after he finished shooting here, he made a $25,000 donation to the Ho Chi Minh City Child Welfare Foundation.
The Americans say that the two ever-present Vietnamese Government censors on the set, who are both with a mysterious state organization known to the producers only as A-25, are often suspicious about hidden deeper meanings in the script.
The censors, whose approval is required for the film to be shot here and will be needed for its release in Vietnam, are extraordinarily sensitive, the Americans say, to the way prostitution, supposedly a relic of Vietnam's decadent past, is portrayed. They also fretted about whether the ailing monk in the story, who lives near a pagoda that rises out of the center of a small pond and writes poetry, could somehow be a sneaky allusion to President Ho Chi Minh, who lived in a similar place in Hanoi until he died in 1969.
But both director and producers take a philosophical view about official interference, which has seldom been heavy-handed.
"The way I look at it, we're in a Communist country and we have to obey the rules," Mr. Kliot said. "Some of the things we have to worry about in the United States are just as annoying: the constant legal censorship, for instance," he added, explaining that the script originally called the street boy Mickey Mouse.
"We can't use that because of copyright problems," Mr. Kliot said. "We can't put him in a Superman cape in one scene because Warner Brothers owns the Superman rights and said no. Woody Woodpecker is Universal, so that's okay. But Tony has to alter his vision slightly because of legal constraints."
Mr. Bui, whose short film "Yellow Lotus" was critically acclaimed this year, is aware that Dang Nhat Minh, a fellow overseas Vietnamese director, was forbidden to visit Vietnam for three years because of official displeasure over his movie "Cyclo."
But he says he thinks "Three Seasons" will keep official cooperation because of its honest portrayal of Vietnamese society. "If you have the patience to work with the censors, you can talk with them," he said. "I want to show the country in a positive light, but the only way to do that is by being realistic."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 6, 1997, Saturday

An article on Tuesday about the making of an American film in Vietnam misidentified the director of the Vietnamese film "Cyclo." He is Tran Anh Hung, not Dang Nhat Minh.

HEADLINE: Tristan E. Beplat, 85, Banker Who Aided Japan After War

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Tristan E. Beplat, an international banking executive who played an important role in the economic reconstruction of postwar Japan, died on Friday at the Columbia Medical Center in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 85 and lived in Princeton, N.J., and Daytona Beach, Fla.
He died of complications after a fall, his nephew, Raymond E. Beplat, said. 
 A Manhattan native, Mr. Beplat began his banking career in 1937, joining what was then the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
It was during World War II that his involvement with Japan and Asia began. As a first lieutenant in 1944, he was selected to participate on a team to help rebuild the economy of postwar Japan. The team was led by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.
Because of his experience with foreign currency trading, Mr. Benplat was named chief of the foreign exchange operation in the early phase of the United States occupation of Japan after its surrender in 1945.
Mustered out of the Army a year later, Mr. Beplat remained in Japan as a civilian but continued to serve the military in Tokyo as the chief of its money and banking branch and as chairman of the foreign exchange committee.
It was in this capacity that Mr. Baplat helped to forge a policy that set the value of the yen at 360 to the dollar, a sharp devaluation from its prewar value of 2.50 to the dollar.
"We wanted the Japanese to be able to export," Mr. Beplat said in a 1986 interview with Forbes magazine. "We wanted them on our side politically, and figured that 90 percent of Japanese exports could sell at a 300 exchange rate, even though some were profitable at 200. But we didn't want to be wrong on such an important matter."
The program worked so well that Japanese exports rose from $1 billion in 1950 to $24 billion by 1971, when President Richard M. Nixon ended the postwar system of fixed exchange rates.
After being appointed a consultant to the State Department in October 1948, Mr. Beplat opened a representative office in Japan for Manufacturers Hanover, the first such postwar office for an American bank.
He remained in that capacity in Tokyo until he returned to the United States in 1954. The next year, he took charge of the bank's banking relations in Asia, Australia and New Zealand. In 1963 he was named senior vice president. At retirement in 1974, he was senior vice president and deputy general manager of the international division. Manufacturers Hanover later merged with Chemical Banking, which subsequently merged with Chase Manhattan.
Shortly after he left the bank, Mr. Beplat was decorated by the Japanese Government, receiving the Second Order of the Sacred Treasure for his services during the occupation.
From his home in Princeton, N.J., Mr. Beplat used his Asian acquaintances and expertise to consult on international finance and investment after he left Manufacturers Hanover. One of those acquaintances was Ferdinand E. Marcos, the leader of the Philippine Government.
In the mid-1980's, Mr. Beplat's name came up during an investigation by New Jersey officials seeking to untangle the financial web spun in that state by Mr. Marcos.
Mr. Beplat told investigators that Mr. Marcos had asked him to acquire homes in New Jersey for use by the Marcos children while they attended Princeton University. In a deposition, Mr. Beplat said he had been wired almost $500,000 from the Philippine Mission in the final days of the Marcos regime.
Mr. Beplat, who received the Philippine Government's highest civilian award from President Marcos in 1971 for his efforts at financing Philippine infrastructure projects, later served as a consultant to the Philippine Government of President Corazon Aquino.
Mr. Beplat was active in a number of societies promoting business and understanding between Asia and the United States, including the Japan Society, the Ceylon Association and the American-Indonesian Chamber of Commerce.
He is survived by three brothers, James of Cummington, Mass., Raymond of East Northport, N.Y., and Howard of South Jamesport, N.Y., and two sisters, Grace B. King of Slingerlands, N.Y., and Muriel B. Collier of Weems, Va. His wife of 49 years, the former Margaret Mosher, died in 1990.

HEADLINE: Victim Fund Gets Pledges From U.S. And Britain

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
More than 50 years after Hitler's armies plundered Europe of its gold, the United States and Britain today announced modest contributions to a new fund to benefit Holocaust survivors, but many other countries withheld immediate donations.
The fund is supposed to be based on money raised from 5.5 tons of Nazi gold held in the United States and British central banks since World War II. Britain and the United States want the 10 European nations with claims on the gold -- which historians say may include gold stolen from Holocaust victims -- to forego their demands and instead contribute some or all of their share. 
 But, according to Stuart E. Eizenstat, the leader of the American delegation at a 41-nation conference here on Nazi gold, only Argentina and Luxembourg agreed today to make immediate contributions. Other conference participants said that France and the Netherlands -- which both have claims to large parts of the gold, worth some $58 million -- held off from an immediate commitment.
Britain said it would contribute $1.65 million to the fund -- to be held at the United States Federal Reserve -- and the United States said it would make an initial payment of $4 million, rising to $25 million over three years if Congress approved.
The fund, which was to be the centerpiece of this week's gathering, was depicted as a step toward helping some of the estimated 350,000 aging Jews in Eastern and Central Europe who survived the Holocaust only to be deprived of restitution by Communist governments. "I think that the symbolism of the fund is more important than the fund itself," said Elan Steinberg, Executive Director of the World Jewish Congress.
The remaining gold is the last of a stockpile of over 330 tons of gold that the United States, Britain and France seized from Nazi Germany and distributed among European central banks after 1946 in restitution for Nazi looting. The three countries -- grouped in what is called the Tripartite Gold Commission -- always insisted that the bullion did not include gold stolen from individuals, businesses and Holocaust victims.
But at the conference here, Swiss historians and American Jewish groups have put the proportion of this privately owned gold at between 16 and 30 percent of all the gold accumulated by the Third Reich.
The announcement of the fund coincided with what appeared to be a shift by the World Jewish Congress in its campaign for faster restitution efforts from Switzerland -- the recipient of most of the gold shipped out of Nazi Germany.
For two years the World Jewish Congress has pressed Switzerland to atone materially and morally for its wartime relationship with the Nazis and for what it says is Switzerland's postwar indifference to the plight of Holocaust survivors seeking access to deposits in Swiss banks made by relatives who died in death camps.
In response, Switzerland has set up its own $190 million relief fund for Holocaust survivors, promised that a new $4.7 billion foundation could also benefit death-camp survivors and instituted a range of historical and banking inquiries.
Despite those moves, several state and municipal authorities in the United States have imposed economic sanctions on Swiss banks. The New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, has called a meeting of public finance officers for next Monday in New York to consider what to do about dealings with Swiss banks.
But today, in an unusual move, Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, let it be known that he would urge the gathering in New York to impose a moratorium on sanctions -- possibly for three months, American Jewish officials said -- while Swiss efforts to overcome the past were monitored.
Mr. Bronfman told associates that the moratorium would give the Swiss authorities time to consider whether they wanted to negotiate a global settlement of their many disputes with American Jews. At present, Swiss private banks face three class-action suits in New York courts demanding payments totaling $20 billion in compensation for their wartime and postwar behavior.
According to American Jewish officials, Mr. Bronfman has told associates over the past two days that a "global settlement" or "closure" with Switzerland would cost the Swiss "a lot of money." In an interview, Mr. Bronfman declined to specify the kind of settlement he foresaw but insisted that a reference he made at the conference today to a sum of up to $1.6 billion had "nothing to do with our claims."
The Congress's shift seemed to catch Swiss officials off guard. Thomas Borer, the head of the Swiss delegation, said he was "perplexed how you can tell the Swiss that we should pay billions in a final settlement and all will be solved and all the class action suits will be settled."

HEADLINE: Chrysler Reports 4.4% Rise In Auto Sales for November

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation today turned in better-than-expected sales results for November, an increase of 4.4 percent compared with results from the month a year earlier.
"The numbers are stronger than they were hinting at," said David B. Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities. "It is the best year-to-year comparison they've had in several months because of the sales of the new Durango and some strong fleet sales." Chrysler has been slowly increasing the production of its new Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle for the last two months. 
 "Durango was the difference between this year and last year," said Steven A. Torok, Chrysler's executive director for sales and marketing operations. Chrysler sold 6,522 Durangos last month.
The Toyota Motor Corporation said its sales fell 10.1 percent last month compared with sales from a year ago, mostly because it cannot build its most popular cars and trucks fast enough to meet demand. "Industry sales continue to mirror the economy's growth, boosted in particular by sustained consumer confidence," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. "In this environment, our problem has been a shortage of product, especially core products such as the Camry and 4Runner."
The Honda Motor Company said its sales rose 3.7 percent in November, allowing it to reach record sales for 1997 excluding December sales. Honda's redesigned 1998 Accord sedan, along with its small sport utility vehicle, the CR-V, and strong Civic and Acura CL sales propelled the company to the new record. "The response to the new Accords has been phenomenal," said Dick Colliver, executive vice president of the American Honda Motor Company.
For the 12 auto makers reporting results today, combined sales rose 1.4 percent in November compared with figures from a year earlier. All percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 24 selling days last month but 25 in November 1996.
"The month as a whole looks flat versus last year," said Nicholas J. Colas, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. Still, he said, the Big Three's auto dealers in particular had hoped to spur sales in November because they have been worried that the growing weakness of the yen will soon allow their Japanese competitors to lure buyers with more attractive rebates and subsidized lease offerings.
"They wanted November to be a very good month, and they were cutting aggressive deals because they expect the Japanese to put on new incentives," Mr. Colas said.
Other auto makers are due to report their sales on Wednesday. The General Motors Corporation is expected to report a sales increase of as much as 14 percent, mainly because it increased rebates in November and because a strike weakened results in November 1996. The Ford Motor Company is expected to report flat sales.
Foreign auto makers reported mixed results today. Nissan said its sales fell 1.9 percent last month compared with those from November 1996; Mitsubishi fell 8.3 percent; Isuzu 12.8 percent, and Land Rover, a unit of BMW A.G., 21.4 percent.
Others posted stronger showings. Subaru said its sales rose 21.4 percent, helped by sales of its popular new Forester sport utility vehicle; Volvo sales rose 8.3 percent; Hyundai 4 percent; Kia 74.5 percent, and Porsche 87.8 percent.
Chrysler's car sales fell 5 percent, while sales of its sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks rose 8.2 percent in November.
Chrysler's sales have been crimped for the last couple of months by a slow production start for its new Dodge Intrepid and Chrysler Concorde sedans, analysts said. The problems have prompted several analysts to lower their earnings forecasts in recent weeks, and the consensus among analysts now is that Chrysler will earn $1.15 a share in the fourth quarter, down from $1.51 in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises, but Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, after computing companies warned of disappointing profits.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.72 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 8,018.83. But the Nasdaq composite index, packed with computer shares, dropped 24.35, or 1.5 percent, to 1,606.37. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index dropped 3.10, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 971.68. 
 Shares of the disk-drive maker Western Digital and the networking equipment manufacturer Cabletron Systems fell after both said fourth-quarter profits would be below forecasts. Altera fell more than 20 percent after it said sales of its specialty semiconductors were slowing.
"The disappointments are much more severe than people expected," said Phil Schettewi, who oversees $4.1 billion as managing director at Loomis, Sayles in Washington.
More such disappointments await investors today. After the stock market closed yesterday, 3Com said it would report quarterly results far below estimates. It also said that it would sharply reduce the inventory of unsold networking products.
In after-hours trading, 3Com shares fell 13.3 percent, to $30.625. A networking rival, Cisco Systems, fell to 85 1/2, from a close of 86 1/2.
Some investors speculated that the warnings signaled slower growth for a range of computer-related companies, as the economic crisis in Asia takes its toll on companies that sell products around the globe.
"The industry is so diverse now," said Mike Driscoll, senior block trader at Hambrecht & Quist in New York. "Still, there's more to follow out of Asia. There's more to come."
Western Digital fell 1 3/4, to 19 3/8, after the company said it would break even in its fiscal second quarter, before a charge three times the amount previously announced. Analysts expected earnings of 25 cents a share. Western Digital blamed price cuts by competitors.
Cabletron Systems Inc. dropped 7 1/2, to 15 11/16, after the maker of computer networking equipment said it expects to report a third-quarter profit of 8 cents to 12 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 40 cents a share.
Among other issues, Coca-Cola, the world's largest soft-drink company, rose 1 5/16, to 65 7/8, after Douglas Lane, a Merrill Lynch analyst, raised his rating to near-term "accumulate" from near-term "neutral."
"With superior unit growth and strong financials, we view Coca-Cola as a core stock," Mr. Lane wrote.
The mixed performance in stocks came on another quiet day in the bond market. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond edged up 3/32, to 101 10/32. The bond's yield's, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 6.03 percent, from 6.04 percent on Monday.
Bond investors were awaiting Friday's employment report for November and a speech last night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
"The market's looking for something to keep it rallying," said Livingston Douglas, chief investment officer at the Kiewit Investment Management Corporation in Omaha.

HEADLINE: Clinton Gives Hope to Blighted City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Through years of turmoil in its municipal government, which has driven thousands people out of the District of Columbia and annoyed many who stayed, Washington rarely found something to cheer.
Today was different. 
 After five years of virtual isolation from his neighbors, President Clinton met with more than two dozen local leaders, listening to their ideas and offering suggestions for the future. Hours later, he joined 20,000 basketball fans for opening night in a new downtown sports arena, the MCI Center, a nearly $200 million project that is hoped to reawaken the city's moribund commercial district southeast of the White House.
Neither event guaranteed any quick or easy fix to the spectrum of problems plaguing the nation's capital, everything from potholes and poor delivery of services to crumbling school buildings and inadequately trained city workers.
But taken together, they offered the hope that just maybe the worst of the city's ills have passed and that the often-repeated promise of Federal lawmakers, Administration officials and local leaders to turn Washington into a "jewel of a capital" is conceivable after all.
"We hit a few home runs today," Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., said after city officials spent 75 minutes delivering their Christmas list of wants and needs to the President, who had never entertained so large a contingent of officials from the capital. "Now I'm going to the basketball game, and President Clinton is, too."
Before today, smaller groups of District leaders had tramped in and out of the West Wing of the White House with various agendas, and generally emerged with little more than the satisfaction of meeting the President. The result was routinely the same: the District got its annual appropriation, free of the urban policy experiments like public school vouchers, that Republicans often tried attaching to it since winning control of Congress in 1994.
This year, Mr. Clinton also approved a rescue package that turns over to the Federal Government several city functions, like running courts and prisons and paying pension benefits to city employees and most Medicaid benefits. The shift will save the city billions of dollars over the next five years.
But through it all, Mr. Clinton had remained in the background.
Now, as one city official after another said, the President appears prepared to step into a more visible role in Washington's life, starting with a speech planned for Sunday at the Metropolitan Baptist Church. It will be Mr. Clinton's first address to local residents on local issues since he campaigned for President in 1992.
"It is clear we now have an on-going partnership with the city and the White House," said Linda Cropp, chairwoman of the District of Columbia City Council. "It's the first time we have had this kind of relationship."
City officials said they brought up several ways the Federal Government could help the city. For the most part, they said, Mr. Clinton listened and took notes, and then suggested areas in which he felt the Government could help.
The President's ideas included these:
*Drafting legislation to enable the District government to tax income of all who work in Washington, regardless of whether they live in the city.
*Creating partnerships between Federal agencies and their District counterparts, like the Department of Education and the public school system.
*Developing training programs to match under-skilled District workers with high-tech jobs.
Of the three, the tax issue is the thorniest, with Federal lawmakers from the surrounding Congressional districts in Virginia and Maryland steadfastly opposed to shifting their tax revenues to the District.
Andrew F. Brimmer, chairman of Washington's financial control board, said that because of the political opposition, Mr. Clinton "did not respond specifically" to how the shift might be accomplished.
If the meeting today provided a boost to the city's political fortunes, the opening of the MCI Center is hoped to do the same for its economy.
Abandoned by specialty and department stores that moved to the suburbs after the racial rioting of 1968, parts of downtown Washington have become a sea of rutted parking lots, boarded-up buildings and distinctly down-scale shops.
Then two years ago, Abe Pollin, the owner of the region's professional basketball and hockey teams and the building in which they played for 25 years, the US Airways Arena in Landover, Md., a Washington suburb, agreed to build a new arena in downtown Washington.
Completed just in time for tonight's National Basketball Association game between the Washington Wizards (formerly the Bullets) and the Seattle Supersonics, it sits on a five-acre site adjacent to the city's Chinatown and above a subway station served by three lines of the Metro, within blocks of what was once a thriving retail area.
Already, the arena has spurred a wave of new restaurants, bars and shops. But the long-term viability of the surrounding area depends more on the social habits of ticket buyers, and whether they will come early for shopping and stay late for dinner.
With the arena expected to be the site of 250 events a year, city officials say they are convinced the downtown economic retreat will finally turn around.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Criticizes Politics of Small Ideas; White House Fumes

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2

 BODY:
Staking out what he called a new vision for the Democratic Party, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri tonight portrayed the Clinton Administration and leaders of the party's moderate wing as content to govern with small ideas while neglecting the nation's problems.
In a speech at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, Mr. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, did not name President Clinton. But aides said his remarks were intended to chide Mr. Clinton, particularly for boasting of an economic recovery without addressing a growing gap between the wealthy and the working middle class. 
 "So what prevents us from seizing this decisive moment and addressing the great issues, the great challenges, before us today?" Mr. Gephardt asked in a speech that drew restrained applause from several hundred students and faculty members. "Our people have not failed, but our politics is failing our people. Today, the political process has largely become an echo chamber of petty charges, a parade ground for poll-driven maneuvers. Too often, our leaders seem enamored with small ideas that nibble around the edges of big problems."
Mr. Gephardt sought to distinguish himself as a populist alternative as he prepares to compete with Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000 -- at a time when prominent Democrats have talked openly of the party's difficulty settling on an agenda.
But some White House officials said Mr. Gephardt's remarks could hamper efforts by the White House and Congressional Democrats to devise and announce a 1998 agenda.
"For Congressman Gephardt to attack President Clinton while the President is trying hard to unite this party for the '98 elections can only harm our party and prospects," said Rahm Emanuel, a senior Presidential adviser, after he was read passages of Mr. Gephardt's prepared text. "It sounds like politics over principle, especially given his flip-flops on multiple issues."
Mr. Gephardt made no reference to Attorney General Janet Reno's move today to essentially clear Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore of accusations about their campaign finance practices. But, clearly referring to the fund-raising, he said: "We need a Democratic Party that is a movement for change and a movement for values -- and not a money machine."
For more than a year, Mr. Gephardt has established himself as an alternative voice to Mr. Clinton on such major issues as welfare, the budget, taxes and trade. Tonight, he attempted to present his approach as one comprehensive vision.
"These are certainly not the worst of times," Mr. Gephardt said in what sounded like a retort to Mr. Clinton's frequent recitation of indicators that show a major economic recovery. "But they're also not the best of times. In many ways, they're the most stressed of times."
Mr. Gephardt reserved some pointed comments for a group of moderate Democrats he helped found: the Democratic Leadership Council. Since his failed bid for the Presidential nomination in 1988, Mr. Gephardt has campaigned as a liberal while the President has embraced important elements of the council's agenda. Mr. Gephardt warned that a "principled and pragmatic" approach was no longer driving leaders of moderate Democrats.
"This is a different approach from some who now call themselves New Democrats, but who set their compass only off the direction of others," he said, "who talk about the political center, but fail to understand that if it's only defined by others it lacks core values."
He also said Democrats should not be "a slightly more compassionate version of the other side, or a constantly shifting combination of tactics and momentary calculations."
Responding to Mr. Gephardt's comments, Al From, the organization's president, said: "The D.L.C.'s base is broader today than it was when Gephardt was chairman. I just think he's wrong."
Asked by a student whether he was trying to create a gulf in the party to help him challenge Mr. Gore, Mr. Gephardt told him he was making "assumptions that are horribly premature -- I really mean that."

HEADLINE: THE ATTORNEY GENERAL'S DECISION: THE O'LEARY CASE;
Reno Backs Former Energy Secretary's Denials of Wrongdoing

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Attorney General Janet Reno virtually exonerated former Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary today of accusations that she improperly sought a contribution for a charity in return for a meeting with an Asian business group. But Ms. Reno said the actions of some of Mrs. O'Leary's top aides still needed to be investigated.
In supporting Mrs. O'Leary's repeated denials of any wrongdoing, Ms. Reno portrayed a Cabinet official unaware of what her trusted subordinates were doing, including signing her name. The actions of those subordinates -- unnamed in Ms. Reno's official statement -- will be investigated further by the Justice Department, the Attorney General said. 
 At issue are the circumstances of an October 1995 dinner attended by Johnny Chung, a prominent fund-raiser for the Democratic Party; a donation to Mrs. O'Leary's favorite charity, and the apparent use of Mrs. O'Leary's signature without her knowledge.
Mr. Chung has maintained that he made a $25,000 donation to Africare, Mrs. O'Leary's favorite charity, at the suggestion of an Energy Department employee, to gain an audience for a Chinese energy official with Mrs. O'Leary.
Mrs. O'Leary, who left the Cabinet at the end of Mr. Clinton's first term, has denied soliciting a donation or asking others to solicit one. She has said that her meeting with the Chinese official, Hauren Sheng, was entirely appropriate because he managed his country's petrochemical industry and had met with her before, when she visited China the previous February.
Ms. Reno said today that a review of the chain of events had convinced her that "there is no basis for further investigation of Mrs. O'Leary's role." In declining to name an independent counsel to investigate the former Cabinet member, Ms. Reno seemed to support Mrs. O'Leary, who said she was "relieved but not surprised" by the decision.
But it was clear that the investigation is far from over. In addition to Ms. Reno's pledge that the Justice Department will dig deeper, there was confirmation today from the House Committee on Reform and Oversight that Mrs. O'Leary has been summoned to testify before the panel on Dec. 16.
A committee spokesman, Will Dwyer, said the panel headed by Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, will examine among other things the actions of Mrs. O'Leary's top aides.
Ms. Reno said there was no doubt that Mr. Chung had met with Democratic National Committee officials to seek their aid in arranging a meeting between senior Chinese Government officials and Mrs. O'Leary, President Clinton or both. Mr. Chung was then steered to a lobbyist, who in turn put him in touch with a senior Energy Department official.
At that time, Mrs. O'Leary was honorary chairwoman for a dinner to benefit Africare, a relief organization based in Washington, and President Clinton was to attend a reception at the event. Mr. Chung expressed an interest in having the Chinese officials attend the dinner so that they could meet Mr. Clinton.
Ms. Reno said investigators were sure that Mr. Chung had requested a letter signed by Mrs. O'Leary, inviting the delegation to meet with her as well as to attend the dinner. To please Mr. Chung, a senior Energy Department aide and two colleagues faxed an unsigned letter to Mr. Chung, inviting him and the delegation to attend. There was no mention of a donation, the Attorney General said.
Soon thereafter, Mr. Chung requested and got a more formal letter confirming the meeting with Mrs. O'Leary. That letter bore the Secretary's signature -- but a signature executed by a machine of the kind used by public officials whose signature is often required. That letter also carried no mention of the Africare dinner, Ms. Reno said.
At some point, Ms. Reno said, one of the Energy Department employees who had helped to prepare the first letter obtained a $25,000 check, payable to Africare, from Mr. Chung. The donation entitled Mr. Chung and his Chinese guests to attend the reception with the President.
While picking up the check, the Energy Department employee asked a surprised Mr. Chung to give back the first letter that had been faxed to him, Ms. Reno said.
The Attorney General said there was "no evidence whatsoever" that Mrs. O'Leary knew of either letter or the circumstances surrounding the collection and delivery of the $25,000 check and the retrieval of the first letter.
As for the meeting between Mrs. O'Leary and the Chinese energy delegation, Ms. Reno said it was "routine and largely ceremonial."
Ms. Reno noted that Mr. Chung was "the only witness who even suggests that Mrs. O'Leary may have known" of the $25,000 solicitation, and that he has said that his belief that the Secretary had known was based on her signature on the second letter, a signature that Justice Department investigators determined was made by the machine, known as an automatic pen.
The Los Angeles Times has reported that Corlis Moody, long a top O'Leary aide and currently the Energy Department's director of economic impact and diversity, was instrumental in sending both letters to Mr. Chung, and that one of the letters was retrieved after an Energy Department lawyer concluded that there was an appearance of impropriety in the way the invitations were extended by Mrs. O'Leary's aides.
Mr. Dwyer said Ms. Moody's activities will be looked into by the Burton Committee.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Forecasting Gauge Shows Recession Unlikely in 1998
An important measurement of future economic activity suggests the expansion that began halfway through the Bush Administration will reach its seventh anniversary in the early spring and that a recession is unlikely next year.
The Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group, said the index of leading indicators advanced two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the sixth consecutive increase. Page D2. 

Chrysler and Honda Do Well
Chrysler's domestic sales rose 4.4 percent in November and Honda's rose 3.7 percent, benefiting from heavy demand for their most popular vehicles. The main strength for Chrysler was its Dodge Durango, while Honda gained from its redesigned Accord sedan, shown above. D2.
 
Stocks Mixed After Monday Surge
Fear over disappointing profits from computer companies contributed to selling that left stocks mixed yesterday after Wall Street's big rally Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.72 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 8,018.83, one day after it vaulted back over 8,000 for the first time since Oct. 15 with a 2.4 percent gain. But the Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with computer shares, fell 1.5 percent. D8.
 
3Com Shares Drop
Shares of 3Com dropped more than 13 percent in after-hours trading after the company said that it would report quarterly earnings and revenue below Wall Street estimates. D2.
 
Judge Narrows Dow Suit
A Louisiana judge dissolved a breast-implant class action against Dow Chemical, saying the cases of 1,800 women were too dissimilar to group in one lawsuit. A25.
 
Columbia/HCA Seen in Tax Accord
Columbia/HCA Healthcare will pay $71 million to resolve a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over executive pay deductions, people who have seen the settlement papers said. The dispute has been widely watched because of its potential effect on using stock options for executive pay. D4.
 
Russia Upbeat on I.M.F. Loan
Anatoly B. Chubais, Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister, said he had a plan to shore up the battered economy and that it would almost certainly persuade the I.M.F. to approve the next $780 million installment of its $10 billion loan to Russia soon. A13.
 
Patriot American to Buy Hotel Chain
The nation's second-biggest real estate investment trust, Patriot American Hospitality, agreed to buy Interstate Hotels Corp. for $1.3 billion. Interstate is the nation's biggest hotel management company. D4.
 
Another British Bank Pulls Back
National Westminster Bank sold its European equities business to Bankers Trust and sold its United States and Asian equity derivatives operations to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell for a total of $301.7 million. The sale marked a retreat by another British bank. D7.
 
Irradiation of Meat Cleared
The Food and Drug Administration approved the irradiation of red meat, a measure that food safety experts said could nearly eliminate dangerous bacteria that cause food poisoning from the meat supply. A1.
 
Czech Failure Burns Investors
Western investors once viewed the Czech Republic as a promising opportunity in Eastern Europe. But an insular system ingrained from the Communism era, widespread corruption and a scandal that brought down the Cabinet of Prime Minister Vaclev Klaus have roiled the Czech stock market, a reminder that privatization can go awry. Market Place. D8.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Up 6th Month in a Row

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
An important gauge of future economic activity shows the outlook remains bright, suggesting the long expansion that began halfway through the Bush Administration will reach its seventh anniversary in early spring.
Only two postwar expansions have been so long and both by this time were marked by rising inflation, in sharp contrast to the price deceleration that prevails today. 
 In its monthly calculation released today, the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group, said the index of leading indicators advanced two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the sixth consecutive increase and the same as September's.
This gauge, derived mostly from previously published data, is designed to predict cyclical turning points in the economy. But even a change in index direction is not considered meaningful unless it is sizable, persistent and spread among many components. In other words, recession during the first half of 1998 is highly unlikely, analysts said.
"The fundamentals are pretty solid," said Ge Zhou, an economist at Caterpillar Inc., predicting that Asia's economic turmoil would not hurt American growth.
Seven of the 10 component items contributed to the October rise. The main forces were a longer factory work week and increase in the money supply.
Small pluses were higher stock prices, more building permits, rising consumer expectations, higher new orders for nonmilitary capital goods and slightly fewer first-time claims for unemployment insurance.
The largest restraining influence was the interest-rate spread, the difference in the yields on 10-year Treasury bonds and Federal funds, which are overnight loans between banks. The spread, often referred to as the yield curve, is unusually flat now, a situation widely regarded as one of the most reliable predictors of slowing economic activity.
The leading index was also held back by a modest speedup in the time it takes suppliers to deliver orders and by fewer orders to factories for consumer goods.
A separate gauge compiled by the Conference Board, designed to mirror current economic conditions, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October, the 19th consecutive gain. All three available elements of this coincident index advanced -- the number of employees on nonfarm payrolls, personal income and industrial output.
"The coincident index also suggests that the economy should sail smoothly into 1998," said Mark Vitner, economist at the First Union Bank.
The Conference Board's index of lagging indicators, those that move only after the economy's direction is clear, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent after no change in September.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Leading Indicators: Component Analysis" lists components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change from September to October. (Source: The Conference Board)

HEADLINE: From Perestroika to Pizza: Gorbachev Stars in TV Ad

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The last leader of the Soviet Union was unable to prevent the collapse of Communism. So now he has conspicuously taken his place on the winning side.
Mikhail S. Gorbachev, 66, has filmed a commercial endorsement for Pizza Hut. 
 Mr. Gorbachev agreed to sit down at a table with his granddaughter in the Moscow outlet of Pizza Hut and pay tribute to capitalism and its greasiest offshoot: American fast food.
Mr. Gorbachev said he was not exactly sure how much he was being paid, but some reports indicate his fee is close to $1 million.
Explaining that he badly needed the money to finance his foundation, a research institute that bears his name, Mr. Gorbachev said in an interview today that he had declined many other offers to endorse products but made an exception for Pizza Hut.
"I thought that it is a people' s matter -- food," he said. "This is why if my name works for the benefit of consumers, to hell with it -- I can risk it."
The script is deferential; indeed, it could be viewed as Mr. Gorbachev's ultimate fantasy. He arrives by limousine at a Pizza Hut and some patrons notice him. An older man grumbles, "Because of him, we have economic confusion." A younger man disagrees, saying, "Because of him we have opportunity." Patrons continue to argue, until an older woman pipes up, "Because of him we have things like Pizza Hut." The patrons, pizza slices aloft, rise and give a standing ovation to their former leader.
Mr. Gorbachev responds with a dignified smile. He does not actually eat a slice of pizza, but sips coffee as he watches his granddaughter dig in happily.
Though the ad was shot in Moscow last Thursday, there are no plans to broadcast it in Russia. Esteemed in the West as the statesman who ended the cold war, Mr. Gorbachev is extremely unpopular in Russia, where he is blamed for allowing the Soviet Union to fall apart and for not having pushed reform of the command economy far enough. When he ran for the presidency last year -- his first campaign for public office -- he won less than 1 percent of the vote. To put it another way, Mr. Gorbachev's endorsement of Pizza Hut could well cause sales in Moscow to drop dramatically.
"Here in Russia, it will be understood one way," Mr. Gorbachev said of the advertisement, which has already been ridiculed in the Russian press. "In other places, it is nothing unusual. I see my colleagues, former presidents, and your Presidents, too, taking part in campaigns."
Actually, Mr. Gorbachev may be breaking new ground for statesmen. Margaret Thatcher and Helmut Kohl have never made commercials. Even in America, where celebrity endorsements are part of the cultural fabric, no former President has taken quite so bold a step. In 1996, George Bush made an unpaid commercial for the Houston Astros, the baseball team, as a favor to its owner, Drayton McLane. His Vice President, Dan Quayle, did a commercial in 1994 for Frito-Lay potato chips and was paid $50,000.
Gerald R. Ford serves on many corporate boards for substantial compensation, but has not made product endorsements. Mostly, those kinds of ads have been picked up by Presidential or Vice-Presidential also-rans, from Bob Dole, who endorsed Dunkin' Donuts and Visa, to Geraldine Ferraro, who made an advertisement in 1984 for Diet Pepsi.
Since leaving the Kremlin, Mr. Gorbachev has marketed himself as a newspaper columnist, memoirist and highly paid speaker and made a cameo appearance in a Wim Wenders art film, improvising a soliloquy on Dostoyevsky.
Mr. Gorbachev has already made an ad for Apple computers in Germany, but said that by starring in the Pizza Hut commercial he was taking a step he had previously considered "unsuitable" for someone of his standing. He complained that the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, had stripped him of much of the office space he was allotted after he resigned from office on Dec. 25, 1991, and had deliberately thwarted his fund-raising efforts.
"I don't get support from the state," he said. "If you look at the foundations in Germany or France, the state finances them, they find sponsors. Here, we don't have any of that. Sponsors can be found. There were some, but on the next day after meeting with me they were summoned to the presidential headquarters to fix their brains."
Executives at Pizza Hut seemed dismayed that Mr. Gorbachev had spoken about his coming cameo so soon, and would not disclose when the ad is expected to run or provide a still from the video. But one company executive explained Pizza Hut's interest in attaching Mr. Gorbachev's name to its pizza this way: "We are constantly striving to take our advertising to a new edge. And we have a new commercial that the whole world will want to watch."
The commercial was created by the BBDO New York advertising agency, which is known for using celebrities in big-budget spots. Among the commercials from BBDO are a 1996 spot for Visa with Mr. Dole and a 1995 Doritos commercial with Mario M. Cuomo and Ann Richards.
