HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Is Lower Still, and Japanese Exports Cheaper

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Waiting for an elevator at the Keidanren, Japan's influential business association, one can hardly underestimate the importance of the dollar-yen exchange rate. A digital display monitor hanging from the ceiling shows just how many yen it would take to buy a dollar at that moment.
And lately, it takes a lot more yen. 
 Despite complaints from Washington about the rising Japanese trade surplus in the last few months, Japanese exports are getting less expensive. The yen reached 128.64 to the dollar today, the highest dollar value since May 1992.. The dollar has risen nearly 11 percent against the yen this year and nearly 61 percent against the Japanese currency since touching a postwar low just under 80 yen in April 1995.
Japan's exports are likely to become even cheaper, according to some economists and currency traders. By some estimates, the dollar could rise as high as 140 yen, a level last reached in June 1991.
The yen's slide today, which reflects the continued weakness of the Japanese financial system, has been unwelcome in Washington because a buildup of Japanese imports could hurt important American industries. The weakening yen also disturbed Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka.
"I have been concerned about the recent fluctuation of the yen's exchange rate, and its movement today is unacceptable," Mr. Mitsuzuka said, after the yen fell to a rate of 129.30 to the dollar at one point this morning. He said Japan and the United States were prepared to stem the fall if necessary, and hours later, currency traders seemed to take notice as the yen recovered some ground. In New York the dollar settled at 128.64 yen, down from 128.91 yen there late Monday.
 Mr. Mitsuzuka reiterated his concern on Wednesday morning, declaring that "the excessive decline of the yen is undesirable." The Japanese currency moved barely lower, to a rate of 128.67 to the dollar.
But the likely outlook for the yen is for further erosion. Interest rates in Japan are negligible, the economy is weak, and the banking system is burdened with bad loans. Some investors turn a quick profit by buying yen and quickly selling them for a currency with a higher yield.
"The yen should be weaker," said Kazuteru Hasegawa, head of foreign exchange trading at the Bank of America here. "Japan is obviously one of the Asian countries, so I think what's happened in this region recently is likely to damage the yen."
Indeed the currency weaknesses through much of Asia -- brought on for differing reasons in Thailand, Malaysia and South Korea -- have put added pressure on Japan, which relies heavily on exports that compete with goods from some of these countries. Since the beginning of this year, the dollar has risen 61 percent against the Thai baht, nearly 43 percent against the Malaysian ringgit and more than 45 percent against the South Korean won.
Japanese cars, steel and semiconductors, among other things, compete with cars, steel and semiconductors manufactured in those countries, and are looking rather expensive in comparison.
Since the Japanese Government raised taxes last spring, causing already weak consumer demand to slow sharply, the Japanese are more dependent than ever on exports to pull their moribund economy out of its slump. "The Japanese economy is over all stimulated by a weaker yen vis-a-vis the dollar," said Minoru Makihara, president of the Mitsubishi Corporation. "In that sense, and since a trading company's activities are related to the state of the Japanese economy, a weaker yen versus the dollar is not bad news."
At the moment, that would seem to put Japan between a rock and a hard place. If its industries are to stay competitive, the yen must fall. Yet the United States considers any significant decline in the yen unacceptable. "As president of the Japan-America Business Council, I know that despite the strength of the U.S. economy over all, at our next meeting there will be loud voices saying Japan should import more," Mr. Makihara said.
Just in case the message from Washington had not been clear, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers dropped in a couple of weeks ago to see Mr. Mitsuzuka, and since then President Clinton; the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and Thomas S. Foley, the new Ambassador to Japan, have all weighed in sternly on the yen's slide.
But how deep American concerns run is a subject of some debate here. While the exchange rate of the yen is an old bogyman, the United States may be less worried about the yen in particular and more that the recent turmoil in the Asian currency markets will set off a vicious cycle of competitive devaluation in Asia.
Several economists note that with the United States economy poised to hum along at least through next spring and some of the lowest unemployment rates in decades, the Japanese trade surplus is not a hot-button political issue in the United States.
"At the moment, there's only one source of capital for the Democratic Party and that's organized labor," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company here. "So as midterm elections are coming up, you may see Al Gore go out a little to the left and say some tough things about trade.
"But as long as the U. S. economy remains healthy going into the election, which everyone thinks is possible, and unemployment stays low, a tough trade stance isn't going to make much political hay."
In fact, a higher level of imports, along with a stronger dollar, could ease pressure to raise interest rates and mitigate the risk of an increase in inflation, two of the most important elements fueling the American economy.
Plus, a stronger dollar versus the yen makes investment in Japan cheaper for American companies. Every day, American names become more prevalent in Tokyo. Gap Inc. has opened stores in the Hankyu department store. The Starbucks mermaid has begun appearing in tony Tokyo neighborhoods. Merrill Lynch, Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover are capturing increasing amounts of the brokerage business here.
"It's very clear that with the dollar at 135 to 140 yen, increasing the beachhead in the Japanese economy is easier," said Jesper Koll, head of research at J. P. Morgan. "I have no doubt in my mind that certain parts of the American economy -- Detroit, steel -- are going to be noisy, but the new America -- the high-tech industries, the financial services industries -- are going to be delighted."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Urges More Attention Be Paid to Banks Abroad

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called for increased efforts tonight to shore up banks in developing countries, saying that the current crisis in Asia has shown that global markets will ruthlessly batter weak financial systems.
Mr. Greenspan said institutions like the International Monetary Fund should do more to identify and head off banking problems in developing nations. And he said that governments in those countries should stop shielding banks from the forces of market competition, and in particular should stop directing banks to lend to politically connected borrowers and industries singled out for special treatment. 
 In a speech to the Economic Club of New York and in response to questions afterward, Mr. Greenspan touched only briefly on the domestic economy and made no substantive comments on the outlook for interest rates. He focused instead on the lessons that might be gleaned from the financial instability that has spread across Asia and has unsettled markets worldwide.
In response to questions after the speech, Mr. Greenspan said that even a huge war chest of foreign currency reserves would not be enough to protect a nation in the long run from a battering in the markets if its economy was not sound.
Countries with economic or financial troubles might be able to use such reserves to prop up their currencies for a longer period and delay needed changes to their economic policies, but ultimately they would be defeated by market forces, he said.
"There is no level of reserves that you can achieve which will protect you from a fundamental imbalance with regard to the market," Mr. Greenspan said.
He said that falling asset prices, or deflation, could be a "virulent" problem, but said deflation tends to take place after inflation has pushed prices up sharply, as happened to real estate and other assets in Japan.
"The Japanese experience of recent years clearly exhibits both sides of the equation," he said.
Some of the problems in Japan and in the rest of Asia, Mr. Greenspan said, might have been driven by excess liquidity, or too much money chasing investment opportunities.
But his main theme was that the global markets today offer nations with financial or economic problems no place to hide.
"The accelerated opening up in recent years of product and financial markets worldwide offers enormous benefits to all nations over the long run," Mr. Greenspan said in his speech, repeating his oft-stated belief that free markets are the only proven path to prosperity.
"However," he said, "it has also exposed more quickly and harshly the underlying rigidities of economic systems in which governments -- or governments working with large industrial groups -- exercise substantial influence over resource allocation.
"Such systems can produce vigorous growth for a time when the gap between indigenous applied technologies and world standards is large, such as in the Soviet Union in the 1960's and 1970's and Southeast Asia in the 1980's and 1990's. But as the gap narrows, the ability of these systems to handle their increasingly sophisticated economies declines markedly."
The problems sweeping Asia have their roots in troubled banking systems, first in Thailand and later in Indonesia and South Korea. Those three nations have had to call on the I.M.F. to bail out their economies. Japan is also trying to bring long-brewing problems with its banks under control, although there is no indication that Japan's financial woes will require an international bailout.
Leaders in Asia, Mr. Greenspan said, are now recognizing the problems they face and the "unforgiving nature of the new global market forces."
Those forces, however, will be put to good use if they prompt governments in developing nations to strengthen their banking systems, he said.
Mr. Greenspan dismissed as unfeasible the calls from some Asian leaders, most notably Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, to impose strict controls on activities like currency trading.
Mr. Greenspan gave an upbeat assessment of Japan's efforts to confront the huge pool of bad loans afflicting its financial institutions, saying the Japanese Government "finally seems to be appropriately addressing their problems."
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that the I.M.F. and other international institutions could have done a better job of spotting the problems developing in Asia's banking systems over the last few years, but added that it was difficult to get governments to take such politically painful steps as shutting down ailing banks.
"Yes, the potential risks to the banking systems of many Asian countries and the potential contagion effects for their neighbors and other trading partners should have been spotted earlier and addressed," Mr. Greenspan said.
But, he added, "there is significant bias in political systems of all varieties to substitute hope (read, wishful thinking) for possibly difficult pre-emptive policy moves."
In trying to fix the problem, the I.M.F., the World Bank and the governments of the United States and other rich nations should demand that countries in financial trouble take tough steps to buttress their banking systems as well as their economic fundamentals, Mr. Greenspan said. His statement was similar to ones from President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin regarding the terms under which South Korea would get help from the I.M.F. and the United States.
"Assistance without further reform of financial systems and economic policies would be worse than useless since it would foster expectations of being perpetually bailed out," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan did not make specific recommendations about how to improve international surveillance of countries likely to face financial problems, or how to press such nations to make needed policy changes before they face a crisis. But he suggested that failure to do so would lead to ever-larger bills for bailouts.
"Preventive programs should be accelerated sufficiently far in advance of the next crisis to effectively thwart or contain it," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: South Korea Halts Activity At 9 Banks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The Government suspended the operations of nine ailing South Korean financial institutions Tuesday and threatened to shut them down in a move tied to the pending bailout of the nation's economy by the International Monetary Fund.
The relentless uncertainty about the bailout deal and barrage of bad economic news, meanwhile, did further damage to the South Korean stock market today. The market's main index fell nearly 4 percent this morning, as the market seemed headed for its 10th consecutive day of losses. 
 Traders were selling on an announcement that trading in shares in Halla Group, one of South Korea's large industrial conglomerates, had been suspended because the company had defaulted on loans. Seven of South Korea's 40 big conglomerates have tumbled into bankruptcy this year.
Talks between the monetary fund and the Government appeared to be nearing a conclusion and there were widespread expectations that an announcement would be made today. Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the I.M.F., arrived in Seoul today to carry on the talks.
South Korean officials said Mr. Camdessus had come to complete and announce an agreement.
 However, they had previously announced wrongly that an agreement had been reached, possibly using the announcements as a bargaining ploy. It appears that the I.M.F., as well as the United States, has been pushing for the agreement to include tougher steps by Seoul to overhaul and open up its financial system.
The Ministry of Finance and Economy ordered a halt Tuesday to most of the operations of nine merchant banks and said the banks would be closed unless they can devise a plan to right themselves by March 31. Merchant banks tend to specialize in short-term lending.
What to do about insolvent banks has been a major sticking point in the negotiations over the I.M.F. rescue package.
The I.M.F. is expected to provide tens of billions of dollars to South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy and the biggest victim yet in Asia's financial crisis. The money will be used to help South Korea pay foreign debts and overhaul its financial system.
The I.M.F. has been pushing for rapid closings of insolvent banks, saying that is the best way to quickly restore the health of a financial system hobbled by bad debts. Seoul, worried about rising unemployment, labor unrest and the possibility of runs on banks by frightened depositors, has pushed for allowing the ailing institutions to be revamped or merged with healthier ones.
Trading of shares in eight of the merchant banks that are publicly listed was halted Tuesday on the Korean stock market, as stock prices over all plunged again. The stock exchange's composite index fell 4.1 percent, to 376.87, on Tuesday and the value of the currency, the won, also fell sharply against the dollar, reaching another new low.
While there are some fairly healthy merchant banks among the 30 in South Korea, many have huge bad debts and their plight has contributed to the country's troubles.
Henry G. Morris, research director at Coryo Securities in Seoul, said the potential closing of the merchant banks "is being taken very seriously here because, for their scale, they have provided very sizable credits to Korean business and industry." In particular, he said, the merchant banks are important sources of loans for smaller and midsize businesses.
He said the effects of any merchant bank closings on employment would be small because the average merchant bank employs 100 to 300 people. But the Government is more worried about setting a precedent for the liquidation of commercial banks, which are far larger than merchant banks and employ thousands of people.
News reports here were quoting Finance Ministry officials as saying that commercial banks will not have to be closed under the terms of the agreement with the I.M.F.
Seoul has announced that a deal is at hand twice in the last three days. A Cabinet meeting was scheduled Tuesday morning to endorse an agreement, and the Government even issued a statement in the name of President Kim Young Sam urging citizens to bear the pain gallantly.
A short time later the Government retracted the statement.

HEADLINE: U.S. Judge Allows Casino On Ship 3 Miles Offshore

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In another twist to the tangled history of gambling cruises from New York City, a judge in Federal District Court has overruled a Goverment decision that blocked the cruises from operating just three miles off the city's shore.
The decision two months ago by the United States Attorney in Brooklyn to force gambling ships at least 12 miles offshore came at the request of city officials who were concerned about the potential proliferation of offshore gambling. The 12-mile limit led a Brooklyn company, Bay Casino, to suspend its gambling cruises from Sheepshead Bay on Oct. 31. 
 The United States Attorney, Zachary W. Carter, based his decision on a law passed by Congress last year that extended the nation's territorial jurisdiction to 12 miles as part of an anticrime and antiterrorism bill.
After some legal parrying, the Government and Bay Casino decided to seek a ruling on the statute in Federal District Court.
In a ruling dated Monday and released yesterday, Judge Allyne R. Ross of Federal District Court in Brooklyn said that the Government's interpretation of what constituted territorial jurisdiction was too broad. "The court must apply the principle of lenity," the judge wrote, "which leads to resolution of ambiguity in favor of Bay Casino."
"The court cannot conclude that Congress's clearly expressed intent to expand Federal criminal jurisdiction was accompanied by a clear intent to amend also the substantive elements of what constitutes a gambling violation," the judge added.
Andrew Stengel, a spokesman for Bay Casino, said, "We're pleased at the outcome, which confirms what we've thought all along."
When Bay Cruises suspended the cruises on its ship, the Liberty I, it said the 12-mile limit was hurting business by requiring that the ship travel farther into choppier waters. Officials at the company were told that a failure to comply with the 12-mile limit could result in a seizure of the ship and other penalties. At the time, the company said that it planned to resume operations in the spring, whether at 3 or at 12 miles.
Mr. Stengel said that company officials would review the judge's ruling before deciding whether it would speed their plans to resume the cruises.
William J. Muller, executive assistant United States attorney in Mr. Carter's office, said his office had no comment on Judge Ross's ruling, pending further review.
Rudy Washington, Deputy Mayor for community development and business services, said he had not seen the decision but would review it with the city's Corporation Counsel. But he reiterated the city's preference for a 12-mile boundary, saying the added distance would limit gambling cruises to established casino operators who were well financed and could afford larger boats.
Gambling industry analysts have suggested that a three-mile limit could have broad ramifications.
James Murren, a gambling analyst with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, an investment bank in Manhattan, said that Judge Ross's ruling could make "a major difference for casino cruises in New York City."
He added: "The difference between 3 miles and 12 miles is like apples and oranges. The small boat that was independently financed was actually doing quite well at 3 miles, and there are many large companies that are very interested in New York as a cruise market."
Last month, the partnership that helped create the nation's most profitable casino, Foxwoods Resort Casino in Connecticut, announced that it planned to offer daily gambling cruises out of midtown Manhattan for about 1,000 passengers each trip.
For months in 1996, the owners of Bay Casino, which was then called Bay Cruises, told curious residents and politicians that the pier they were busily renovating on the Sheepshead Bay waterfront would be used for a dinner-and-dancing cruise boat that would bring high-class entertainment to a struggling area.
But then last December, the company announced that the cruises -- once on the high seas and out of New York State jurisdiction -- would, in fact, offer casino gambling, which is unregulated in international waters.
But Brooklyn residents complained about the likelihood of increased traffic and parking problems. And Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani worried that casino ships would proliferate, jamming New York's waters. Such an operation, Mr. Giuliani said, would not bring much economic benefit to the city and could be vulnerable to organized crime.
After the Liberty I began operating last December, averaging nearly 200 passengers a trip, city officials said they had received more than two dozen inquiries from other companies that wanted to establish similar cruises.
So the city decided on another tack: asking the United States Attorney's office for an interpretation of maritime law. And in October, the office responded, saying that the boundary for international waters was 12 miles off the coast. In addition, Federal prosecutors said a violation of the requirement could result in as much as two years in prison, fines and seizure of the boat.
Bay Casino complied, ordering its boat to cruise at a distance of 12 miles -- which transformed a 25-minute trip into a much choppier 90-minute one. At first, Bay Casino cut back the number of daily trips from three to two. Later, the company announced that it would suspend the ship's operations until spring, when calmer waters would make the trip much faster.
 Meanwhile, after some legal parrying, the Government and Bay Casino decided to test the statue in Federal District Court.

HEADLINE: Fare Break Is in Works, Official Hints

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A top official of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority indicated last night that the agency was planning to use a surplus in this year's budget to give subway and bus riders a break on fares.
Marc V. Shaw, the agency's executive director, would not provide any details of what sort of fare reduction was in the works. But his comments were the first public indication of how agency officials intended to use the surplus. He said he expected a new fare policy to be approved by the authority's board at its next meeting, on Dec. 18. 
 Since it was disclosed in October that the transit agency was running a large surplus in this year's budget -- the amount stood at $129 million at the end of September -- transit officials have been under intense pressure from politicians, transit advocates and riders to use the money to ease the pain of the 25-cent fare increase in 1995. But until yesterday, top officials of the transportation authority had refused even to acknowledge publicly that a surplus existed, let alone say what they would do with it.
The City Council and the Mayor have called for the authority to offer Metrocard users 12 fares for the price of 10, rather than the 11-for-10 deal the authority already plans to offer in January. The larger discount would effectively roll the $1.50 fare back to $1.25.
Some commuter advocates have called for a monthly transit pass with unlimited bus and subway rides for, say, the price of 40 or 50 tokens. Other suggestions for the surplus have been to increase service or use some of the money to pay off debt, but neither of those options has the political appeal of a fare break.
Mr. Shaw refused last night to discuss specific proposals, saying, "We're still looking at our options." But he said he expected some change in the fare structure to win the approval of the agency's board.
"It's becoming pretty clear that we're going to be doing something at our next board meeting in terms of announcing our fare policy plans for next year," Mr. Shaw said. At the meeting, the board is expected to vote on the 1998 budget for its bus and subway subsidiary, New York City Transit.
Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group that has been calling for a fare cut, called Mr. Shaw's statement "an enormous step forward."
"The Mayor, the speaker, advocacy groups have all been saying, they have the money, let's do something good," Mr. Russianoff said. "But the M.T.A. has been saying we'd like to do something good but we don't know if we have the money. Now we're all saying the same thing."
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who was already planning to spend this morning handing out leaflets on the subway urging riders to lobby for rolling the fares back to their 1995 level, was pleased by yesterday's news.
"Reducing fares is the obvious," he said. "Now let's do the really obvious: 12 rides for the price of 10, and the time to do it is now."
The final decision on fares could well involve political as well as fiscal calculations, especially since Gov. George E. Pataki, whose appointees control the authority board, may be challenged by Mr. Vallone in next year's election. Mr. Vallone's staff, which has projected that the surplus could reach $167 million by year's end, has calculated that a 12-for-10 deal would cost the authority about $100 million in lost revenue, which would still be significantly less than the surplus.
The City Council's Transportation Committee, keeping up the pressure on the authority, has scheduled a public hearing on the surplus for tomorrow.
Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, who also sits on the authority board, said yesterday that city officials had been meeting with the authority's officials to try to persuade them to offer 12 rides for the price of 10.
"We've been optimistic," Mr. Washington said. "They have not been digging in their heels on this, and there have been plenty of other issues that they have been digging in their heels on."
The transit system's balance sheet was $129 million healthier than expected during the first nine months of this year for three basic reasons.
*Ridership is up -- bus revenue and subway revenue are each running $19 million ahead of projections through September.
*Expenses are down -- fringe benefits, rentals and other expenses are running about $47 million less than expected.
*Tax revenue is up -- the city's economy is booming, and the transportation authority gets part of sales, petroleum and mortgage taxes.
But authority officials had expressed doubt, at least publicly, that the financial picture would stay rosy, and said repeatedly that trends were not strong enough to be the basis of planning.

HEADLINE: In Dark Times, Russia's Economic Chief Looks on Bright Side

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Looking confident and self-possessed, Anatoly B. Chubais, the chief overseer of Russia's economic changes, said today that he had a plan to shore up the country's battered economy and get international loans, currently stalled, back on track.
The Russian stock market has plunged in the last few weeks, a ripple effect of financial turmoil in Asia. Foreign investors, who have lost confidence in emerging markets, have pulled more than $5 billion in securities from Russia in the last month. 
 But Mr. Chubais, Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister, whose own stock was badly damaged last month by a scandal over a questionable book deal, was also plotting his redemption. In his first interview with Western reporters since the scandal broke, he tried to make it clear that he was still in charge of Russia's fragile finances and a power to be reckoned with.
He said little about the details of the book contract from a publishing house, which is owned by one of the banks that has recently benefited from government sales of state property.
Instead, Mr. Chubais, who calls the scandal a smear campaign, said he was tripped up by bankers and businessmen who are disgruntled by his efforts to curb the favoritism and insider deals that have veined earlier privatization efforts.
But he acknowledged that the scandal -- which resulted in the removal of some of his closest aides and could still lead to his own dismissal once the current economic crisis is past -- has weighed him down.
"I am now told, 'You must pay wage arrears by Jan. 1 -- yes, there is a little financial crisis, so you must overcome it, and besides, we will tie your hands behind your back and we will tie your legs, too.' "
He added: "So it affects me badly. But what can I do?"
Mr. Chubais said that he had worked out a program with the help of experts from the International Monetary Fund and that it would almost certainly persuade the I.M.F to approve the next $780 million installment of its $10 billion loan to Russia soon.
The I.M.F. postponed giving out the money early last month because Russia had failed to raise its targeted tax revenues.
Last week, Russia sent two top officials to Washington to try to obtain more aid to see the country through the current crisis. The meetings were inconclusive, and United States officials pointedly referred Mr. Chubais back to the I.M.F.
But it was not at all clear how much the plan, which Mr. Chubais heralded today as "tough and radical," differs from steps Russia has previously promised to take.
I.M.F. officials arrived in Moscow this week and will work with their Russian counterparts on hammering out ways for Russia to cut its spending more rigorously and to raise revenues. The team is due to leave on Dec. 12.
Most likely, Mr. Chubais is hoping that a new show of determination -- and the country's dire straits -- will persuade the I.M.F. to relent and release the loan by January.
"Traditionally, in times of crises, international financial organizations come forth and help out," he said.
Mr. Chubais said that the Russian Government would continue to defend the ruble, which has lost value since the financial crisis began. But he noted that it would stop intervening to protect interest rates on the treasury bond market.
This would make life easier for the Central Bank, which has been straining to keep the ruble stable, but might create some turmoil in the short run.
"There may be some high and even hysterical splashes," Mr. Chubais said. "But it is clear that in the next few days it will stop somewhere on its new level, which we will start to protect."
Among the unpleasant tasks Mr. Chubais faces in the coming days is a battle with Russia's Communist-led Parliament, which is supposed to begin debate on the 1998 budget on Friday and which has resisted further spending cuts.
The Parliament has been demanding Mr. Chubais's resignation. And, with his reputation tarnished, he will have an uphill battle to bring the Parliament to a budget compromise.
But Mr. Chubais seemed mainly preoccupied by the war he is waging against some of Russia's top bankers and businessmen. He complained that powerful Russian tycoons are unwilling to surrender the kind of crony capitalism he says he is determined to uproot and that they will do anything to stop him.
"What is happening now in reality?" he asked rhetorically. "The members of my team are under round-the-clock surveillance. Telephone conversations are being tapped. My close relatives are being followed, too. My wife's friends are offered any kind of bribes for any kind of compromising material on Chubais. My son is also being constantly followed."
"But so far they haven't started to shoot," he said. "But we will see."

HEADLINE: THE ATTORNEY GENERAL'S DECISION: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Relief for White House

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Perhaps, as she contended, Attorney General Janet Reno did not exonerate anyone today. But politically, she lifted a huge weight off the shoulders of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.
There was no public gloating or popping of champagne corks at the White House after Ms. Reno announced that she would not appoint an independent counsel to look into aspects of the Democrats' fund-raising. Sticking with the measured, detached pose that he has labored to maintain toward the finance scandal, Mr. Clinton released a one-sentence written statement. 
 "The Attorney General made her decision based on a careful review of the law and the facts, and that's as it should be," it read.
But Mr. Gore, who still has elections ahead of him, betrayed a little more excitement, speaking with reporters at an education event in Connecticut. Twice he declared his pleasure at having the subject of fund-raising calls "put behind us." Then he repaired to the First and Last Tavern in Hartford to share a celebratory pizza with Richard W. Riley, the Secretary of Education.
Of course, the campaign finance imbroglio -- the mystery brew of Indonesian businessmen, Chinese connections, Buddhist nuns and teamster stratagems -- is not behind the President and Vice President. But privately, and with good reason, aides to both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have looked forward to Ms. Reno's announcement, which was expected, as the beginning of the end of the Democrats' fund-raising woes.
While "never been indicted" is not an appealing political slogan, both men can now claim that an exhaustive, months-long inquiry -- "thousands of hours of investigation," in Ms. Reno's phrase -- turned up no evidence that they broke the law.
As long as Republicans on Capitol Hill control the most prominent investigations, White House aides believe -- rightly, judging by the experience of the past year -- voters will dismiss the scandal as a strictly political affair. And tonight. the Vice President tried to guide the public to that conclusion.
"Bear in mind that in the days and weeks and months ahead, there will continue to be partisan attacks, politically motivated," he said.
By contrast, an independent counsel, with its appearance of neutrality and green-eyeshades expertise, packs a political wallop that Congressional panels and investigators rarely muster.
Further, as the Clinton Administration has learned to its sadness, such counsels grind inexorably away, year after year, sustaining press interest.
An independent counsel, if appointed, "certainly keeps it alive," said James Carville, who has battled other independent counsels on Mr. Clinton's behalf. "There's the inevitable, 'They're calling this witness,' and, 'They're in this phase.' Even if there's a competent independent counsel, which there hasn't been in a long time, there'd still be leaks."
An independent counsel would almost inevitably gain broad authority to shine bright lights into the crannies of White House policy making, seeking connections to donations. "Having a special counsel opens everything in the White House to scrutiny," said Kenneth M. Duberstein, who was chief of staff in President Ronald Reagan's second term, when an independent counsel was digging into the Iran-contra affair.
At a very basic, personal level, Ms. Reno's decision saved both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees. "You're looking at probably a million-dollar decision for these guys," said Carter A. Eskew, a Democratic political consultant who sometimes advises Mr. Gore.
But neither man is out of the woods. Continuing finance investigations into lower-level officials like Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt could still lead to the appointment of an independent counsel who would surely take an interest in the White House. It is even possible that the Justice Department's investigation may also still directly implicate Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore.
Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican who professes some ambivalence about the power of independent counsels, nevertheless maintained that one was inevitable in this case. "And then when it finally happens people will say, 'What took you so long?' " he said.
Perhaps. But a year's investigation by the Justice Department, an inquiry by a Senate committee and a fevered competition among journalists have yet to produce a disclosure that would prompt the Attorney General to appoint a counsel.
As a result, Mr. Gore's staff has been looking ahead to today as a critical date for the Vice President, and they prepared carefully. Shortly after Ms. Reno's announcement, aides to the Vice President passed out a 73-page briefing book to reporters at the White House defending his position on the fund-raising calls.
Mr. Gore's aides had postponed answering most interview requests until after the Attorney General's announcement. But they have planned a series of high-profile appearances for the Vice President in the coming days, to show him absorbed in the people's business. On Wednesday he is to meet with entertainment executives to discuss how the industry can protect children from tobacco.
The fact that the White House let Mr. Gore take the lead role in reacting to Ms. Reno's announcement suggested that Mr. Clinton is also eager to polish the image of his Vice President, whose integrity was questioned for the first time during this scandal.
In reacting to the Attorney General's announcement, Mr. Gore worked straight from Mr. Clinton's script. Beyond arguing that Republican critics were politically motivated, he declared that he and the President "will continue to focus on the priorities of the American people, as we have been doing." He pointed to the low unemployment rate and the balanced budget deal. And he went on to try to change the subject from campaign finance scandals to tightening campaign finance laws.
"The same people who are making the partisan attacks are the ones who are blocking campaign finance reform," he said.
For the last year, that approach has worked better for Mr. Clinton than for Mr. Gore, whose favorable ratings have slipped. In a CBS News Poll last month, 31 percent of respondents said they viewed the Vice President favorably, while 30 percent said they viewed him unfavorably. In the full glow of the inaugural festivities in January, those two numbers were 41 percent and 12 percent.
Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton has cruised along for a year with close to 60 percent of Americans saying they approve of the job he is doing.
It is that consistent public attitude that has persuaded the White House that Mr. Clinton, in the absence of an independent counsel, can withstand the political fallout from Congressional investigations and the press. It is also why they believe he can go about his fund-raising without fear. Indeed, even on the evening before Ms. Reno's announcement, the President attended two finance dinners at hotels here, raising $750,000 for Democrats.
"There is a direct chain of events between your support of our efforts and the things which happen in this country," Mr. Clinton assured one set of dining donors.

HEADLINE: A Raider Nonpareil;
France, at Least, Sees Few Capitalists Like Him

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In the corporate world of France, with its cozy intertwined shareholdings and classically educated business elite, it took an outsider like Francois Pinault, a school dropout at age 16, to shake things up.
The local version of a corporate raider, Mr. Pinault has made his way as a capitalist without capital, a businessman who aggrandized himself with other people's money, borrowing and buying low and selling high to pay back his debts and still have plenty left over. 
 His knack for finding loopholes in French corporate law has prompted the Government to change the rules for shareholding and takeovers, and his fancy financial footwork has fostered a movement to protect minority shareholder rights. The corporate establishment has blocked his way several times, but his combination of sharp business elbows and deft political influence has made him come out the winner more often than not.
"When you build an empire, you step on toes, so everyone doesn't love you," said Anne Meaux, a close friend whose public relations firm represents Mr. Pinault and many other more traditional captains of French business and industry.
Indeed, Mr. Pinault, 62, has built an empire on both sides of the Atlantic. Those who buy Samsonite luggage, or wear Converse sneakers, or ski at Vail, Colo., or shop the huge Printemps department store here on the fashionable Boulevard Haussmann are all doing business with a holding company, Artemis, that Mr. Pinault controls.
Not satisfied, however, Mr. Pinault (pronounced PEA-no) is now trying to enter the lucrative business of financial services, with thus far unsuccessful bids for large French insurance and financial products companies. In September, for instance, Artemis made a $4.8 billion hostile bid for a venerable conglomerate, Worms & Cie., and the jewel in its crown, the Athena insurance group. Though Mr. Pinault pulled back, he is not one to give up looking for another prize. A successful bid would fulfill a "wish we have to be in financial services and products," said Patricia Barbizet, the managing director of Artemis, "where we feel a lot of restructuring is coming in France and in Europe."
With the European single currency just around the corner, major banks and insurance companies are already engaged in mergers and acquisitions designed to strengthen their positions for the rapid growth expected as the Continent's financial markets merge effectively into one.
For example, the big Allianz insurance group of Germany, No. 2 in Europe after the AXA-Union des Assurances de Paris, is in a fierce bidding war with Assicurazioni Generali of Italy to swallow up Assurances Generale de France.
In such upheaval, there is, of course, no guarantee that Mr. Pinault will get what he wants. His previous efforts to snare a major finance company, Banque Indosuez, and Navigation Mixte, a unit of the Paribas group, failed because of resistance by entrenched shareholders. His bid for Worms was quickly topped by one from the Agnelli clan of Italy together with Assurances Generale de France. Eventually, Mr. Pinault decided the offer was beyond the value of Worms, and withdrew.
It was one of the few times he has not gotten his way. Mr. Pinault started out by quitting school in Brittany to join his father in the family lumber business, which he ultimately inherited and built into a thriving producer of wood and furniture.
In the 1970's, the Government sought to save jobs by offering entrepreneurs like Mr. Pinault chances to acquire failing privately owned companies at fire sale prices, often as little as one franc. Mr. Pinault gradually amassed a fortune by buying up companies this way, then using Government aid to turn them around and sell them at a profit.
By the late 80's, he had graduated to bigger deals using someone else's francs. In 1987, for example, he plunked down $120 million in mostly borrowed money to acquire La Chapelle-d'Arblay, a foundering paper manufacturer based in Normandy, then reaped a profit of $90 million three years later when he sold it. Mr. Pinault is skilled at chopping companies down to their core businesses, lopping off unnecessary jobs and raising productivity by automating.
Along the way, he forged some lasting friendships and business relationships. In the 1970's, he promoted his business in the area around the southern city of Ussel, where a young politician named Jacques Chirac was building a career. Mr. Pinault has remained fast friends with Mr. Chirac, who is now the President of France. At the same time, he formed close ties with Credit Lyonnais, France's largest commercial bank, whose local branch in Brittany served from the start as Mr. Pinault's house bank.
Mr. Pinault has kept his roots in Brittany, where he and his wife, Maryvonne -- he has three children and she has one, all by their first spouses -- keep a sumptuous country home whose grounds are dotted with contemporary sculptures. They also have an apartment in Paris.
Mr. Pinault, who is uncomfortable with the press and declined to be interviewed for this article, has long been involved in distribution, to sell his companies' wood products and furnishings. His jump into the big league came in 1992, when he acquired Au Printemps, the department store group, in a transaction that exemplifies his aggressive style. After selling a hardware chain, Conforama, for $775 million to Printemps, Mr. Pinault used the proceeds to acquire 66 percent of Printemps. Two years later, he took control of France's largest mail-order house, La Redoute, and FNAC, a book and record store chain.
Alain Minc, a leading financial adviser, described the strategy as "a classical one: to go progressively from production to distribution."
"He never made an unsuccessful move," said Mr. Minc, one of an impressive list of advisers Mr. Pinault brought on board over the years to help him with his expansion.
As France moved out of recession of the early 1990's, and as the battered real estate market recovered, his acquisitions proved a gold mine. By selling unwanted units, he got the cash to repay the debt that had financed the buying spree. The latest to go was Prisunic, a down-market mix of five-and-dime stores and food markets that was sold this year. Last year, profits of the Pinault-Printemps Redoute group rose 36 percent, to $355 million, as sales increased 3.6 percent, to $13.8 billion.
For all that, Mr. Pinault's razzle-dazzle had made him the bete noire of French finance. In 1994, the Association for the Defense of Minority Shareholders took him to court over the way he sought to merge his Printemps chain with La Redoute, by offering Redoute stockholders shares in Printemps. It contended that Mr. Pinault stood to acquire roughly $1 billion in capital for heavily indebted Printemps, while the value of the junior investors' shares would be diluted. Two years earlier, the association had cried foul over the way Mr. Pinault acquired Printemps in the first place, by bidding for only 66 percent of its shares. Though the minority holders lost both court battles, they like to think they won the war: French laws were tightened to require investors to bid for all of a takeover target's stock.
Colette Neuville, founder and president of the association, acknowledges with irony that Mr. Pinault, by sniffing out loopholes, has fostered changes in legislation. "I always say," she said, "that the minority shareholders should raise a statue to Pinault." She concedes that Mr. Pinault has not acted outside the law, and his supporters accuse the junior shareholders of shortsightedness. "Five years ago, they complained," Mr. Minc said. "Now they're applauding."
Analysts, in any event, love Mr. Pinault's magic. With the French economy reviving, his stores will benefit from several years of heavy investment in computerization and improved logistics, said Michelle Wolff, an analyst at UBS Securities in Paris, whose recommendation for the group is a buy. "All the main subsidiaries are improving their margins," she said.
Even so, the minority shareholders group is again pursuing a trail that leads to Mr. Pinault. Last year, a furniture company called Dapta-Mallinjoud declared bankruptcy, leaving bearers of $43 million worth of bonds it issued three years earlier with worthless paper. The French authorities found that Dapta's problems began in 1992, when it paid $14 million to acquire three furniture companies -- from Mr. Pinault, through Printemps.
This time, the association is suing not Mr. Pinault, but KPMG, the French unit of the international accounting firm, which audited the numbers used in the bond prospectus. The largest of the three companies acquired from Mr. Pinault had a $19 million gap on its balance sheet and after the purchase was found in a Government report and a court ruling to have regularly overstated the value of its inventories. The suit contends that when Dapta issued its bonds, the discrepancy was already known to management, and that KPMG failed in its oversight duties by not preventing figures based on the false inventory amounts from being used in the prospectus.
Dapta says it was a victim in all this, and KPMG denies wrongdoing. Eventually, the Printemps group compensated Dapta for the $19 million gap. Commenting on the case recently in French newspapers, Serge Weinberg, chief executive of the group, admitted to a "failing in internal control" but attributed it to a "very decentralized structure."
The case is bogged down in a provincial court, and Ms. Neuville accuses Mr. Pinault of bringing his political power to bear. "Pinault is a friend of the President," she said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Pinault's investment interest is turning increasingly abroad. Since 1990, the overseas share of Artemis's revenues has grown to about 40 percent, from virtually nothing, largely as a result of acquisitions in the United States.
In 1991, Credit Lyonnais was a partner with the Apollo investment fund of Leon Black, the aggressive former deal maker of Drexel Burnham Lambert, in acquiring at firesale prices, for almost $3 billion, the junk bond portfolio of the failed Executive Life Insurance Company of California. But when Credit Lyonnais learned that United States law does not permit banks to own operating companies acquired in a foreclosure, it sought a buyer.
Enter Mr. Pinault. After borrowing money from Credit Lyonnais, Mr. Pinault took a long shot, paying $1.9 billion for a package of the bonds that was subsequently exchanged for equity, including large chunks of almost two dozen United States companies, from Converse and Florsheim shoes to Samsonite and the ski resort at Vail. When stock prices took off, Mr. Pinault hit the jackpot. According to a recent Goldman, Sachs report, his American investments have yielded an average annual return since 1991 of 40 percent.
The cooperation with Credit Lyonnais has not been all roses. In 1992, the bank took a 25 percent stake in Artemis, and Mr. Pinault is locked in a legal battle over the value of those shares with the Government agency liquidating some of the troubled bank's assets. But he thrives on challenges, and he remains undeterred.
"He's never someone who stops," said Ms. Barbizet of Artemis. "He likes to build things, to create things. He's always moving on."

HEADLINE: CANADIANS EXPORT A TYPE OF REACTOR THEY CLOSED DOWN

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 2

 BODY:
On the blustery shore of Lake Ontario, in Canada's most heavily populated region, four aging nuclear reactors bedeviled by leaks, failures and operators who sometimes drank beer or smoked marijuana on the job are being shut down because they cannot be safely run by one of the largest utility companies in North America.
At the same time, workers are busy excavating a huge site in China, about 60 miles south of Shanghai, where two Canadian reactors similar to the troubled ones in Canada are being built under Canadian supervision. 
 The four reactors on Lake Ontario, along with three more farther north on the edge of Lake Huron, are being mothballed because their operator -- Ontario Hydro -- acknowledged last summer that it does not have the money or the proper management to run them safely.
The basic design of the Canadian reactors is unique. Although they are simpler than American-type reactors to build, experts now agree that they are far more complex to keep running safely. Maintaining the units has put enormous demands on Canadian operators with solid technical backgrounds and access to the latest equipment and designs.
However, for the last 40 years, the same type of Canadian-designed and built reactors has been sold to countries around the world, including Romania, India and Argentina, that have far less money or technical expertise than Canada and already are struggling to keep the reactors safe. And because the reactors are unlike any others, the number of qualified operators and knowledgeable inspectors is limited.
The closing of 7 of Ontario Hydro's 19 operating reactors has underscored the difficulties that Canada itself has had in keeping the reactors running safely. It has also raised questions about Canada's policy of aggressively exporting them to countries with limited experience in regulating -- and in some cases simply operating -- nuclear reactors.
Since the dawn of the nuclear age, Canada has determinedly tried to use the power of the atom to demonstrate Canadian technological know-how and economic independence. Even the name of the reactor -- Candu, for Canadian Deuterium Uranium -- was meant to suggest Canadian resourcefulness.
Since 1952, according to one estimate, Canada's nuclear industry has received more than $10 billion in Government subsidies. It sold 11 reactors overseas, including the 2 to China.
But Canada has repeatedly been scolded by its own citizens and other nations for selling reactors to authoritarian governments in Argentina, Pakistan and Romania. In 1974, India exploded a nuclear device it admitted had been made with plutonium from a reactor purchased from Canada.
Yet the Canadians continue to circle the globe trying to peddle the same reactors that have proved so difficult to manage in their own backyard. One of three bids opened by the Turkish Government in October came from Canada. And Canadian officials continue trying to sell more to Hungary, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand, not to mention repeat sales to China, South Korea and Romania.
"All this has to do with a very deeply rooted historic question of technological prestige that has its roots in the nuclear weapons programs of the Second World War," said David H. Martin, research director for Nuclear Awareness Project, an environmental group in Ottawa. "Our nuclear research effort was a way to try to rearrange the world's picture of Canada."
The Government defends the program, saying that each export sale creates thousands of jobs at home. But critics charge that the Government's obsession with the reactor blinded it to the project's serious shortcomings.
Canada's nuclear program began in the early days of World War II. Supplies of heavy water -- in which hydrogen atoms have been replaced by deuterium for use in nuclear experiments -- were brought from Norway to Paris and then, when the Nazis occupied France, to England and later to Montreal.
Canada played a minor part in the Allied effort to build the first atomic bomb. But, intent on demonstrating its economic independence, the country set out to exploit its head start with heavy water.
A crown corporation, Atomic Energy of Canada, Ltd., was formed in 1952 to market the Canadian design. One of the strongest selling points was the Candu reactor's unique ability to be refueled while operating. This helped the reactors achieve industry-leading performance in their early years.
The reactor's reliance on heavy water also made it a formidable producer of plutonium, which could be used to make nuclear weapons. And the plutonium can be extracted without shutting down the unit, and thus in comparative secrecy.
The first exports were to India, which assured Canada that the reactors would be used only for peaceful purposes. But in 1974, India exploded its first nuclear device. Although Canada was not alone in selling nuclear technology, it received stinging rebukes from Western leaders for being naive about atomic power.
"Canada sinned in that area but the excuse always was that we sin because everybody else sins," said Robert Bothwell, a University of Toronto historian who wrote a history of Canada's nuclear efforts.
Offering favorable loans and sometimes questionable fees, Canada sold reactors to Argentina's military government, Pakistan and several of South Korea's rulers. Romania's dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, ordered five, but built only one.
The $3 billion deal with China last year ended a long period without sales, but there was little rejoicing in Canada. Environmental groups criticized the deal while human rights activists opposed doing any business with China.
But then Ontario Hydro's reports last summer about conditions at its reactors in Canada raised questions about the ability of other countries to maintain the complex units.
Officials with the International Atomic Energy Agency, a division of the United Nations headquartered in Vienna, said they had not received reports of serious safety problems at any of the Candu sites. They have scheduled a thorough inspection of Argentina's reactors for the coming months.
But most of the countries that have bought Candu reactors do not have independent nuclear regulators. Local reports suggest there have been mishaps with alarming regularity. The reactor in Argentina is regularly shut down to repair leaking pipes, and heavy water leaks at the reactor in South Korea have occurred so often that the operator, Korea Electric Power Corporation, has ordered plant workers to wear masks packed with ice to block fumes.
"What you see in Canada is something that could happen not only in countries that run into financial difficulties but even in countries that don't encounter such difficulties," said Zigmung Domaratzki, deputy director general for nuclear safety at International Atomic Energy Agency and former director general of reactor regulation at Canada's Atomic Energy Control Board. "It certainly raises questions."
An engineer with Ontario Hydro who spoke on condition of anonymity said running the utility's 20 Candu reactors turned out to far more complex than expected. In the 1980's, the four oldest reactors at the Pickering station on Lake Ontario had to be repaired at huge expense. There was a long list of spills, leaks, and non-functioning valves.
Attitudes slid as well. A job at Ontario Hydro came to be known by workers as "hide and seek for a thousand dollars a week," because they spent so much time goofing off. Operators who were diligent about maintenance and repairs became reluctant to report technical problems.
"The shift supervisor made me feel like I was doing something wrong," said an engineer who once tried to report a minor infraction. "He told me, 'That's another nail in our coffin.' "
In 1984, 6 Candu reactors were among the top 25 performers in the world, according to Nucleonics Weekly, a trade publication. In the latest performance survey last February, only 2 made the top 50 list.
That decline was noticed by the Atomic Energy Control Board, Canada's regulatory body. Citing a long list of problems, the board last year took the unusual step of renewing Hydro's nuclear license for only six months instead of two years.
Ontario Hydro executives heeded the warning. They ordered an extensive internal evaluation headed by an American nuclear expert, G. Carl Andognini.
The report, issued in August, included a terrifying list of mishaps and examples of sloppy management. The utility's nuclear plants were portrayed as dispirited places where rusting pipes were simply painted over and control room supervisors idled away their time playing computer games. Cigarette butts, empty beer bottles and marijuana were found in secure radiation areas.
"I don't think anybody understood the extent to which our management had sunk," Ontario Hydro's chairman, William Farlinger, said after the results were disclosed. He called the utility's nuclear unit, "some sort of special nuclear cult."
The board almost immediately approved a recovery plan to shut down 7 plants and spend around $8 billion improving the remaining 12. Mr. Farlinger insisted that the plants were safe. The problem was not with the reactors, he said, but the people who ran them.
But a section of the 15-volume study gives a different view.
"While no single observation or finding represents by itself a serious safety concern, the number and variety of the findings, when diagnosed from both a cumulative and an extent of condition perspective, may indicate some reduction of Ontario Hydro Nuclear's barriers that constitute the defense-in-depth approach to safe operation," the report said.
"What they're saying is that it may not be safe," said David Lochbaum, a nuclear safety engineer with the Union of Concerned Scientists. "With as many problems as they reported, I don't think you can say definitively that it is safe."
The seven reactors will be "laid up" indefinitely -- that is, they can be restarted someday, although that seems doubtful. But hedging in this way allows the utility to delay the brutal cost of decommissioning the plant, which is a good thing in Ontario Hydro's case.
The company has been adding fees to consumers' bills to cover the decommissioning. But the $2 billion clean-up fund is empty now because the company used the money to reduce its more than $30 billion debt.
 The article also referred incorrectly to the nuclear reactor used by India to produce material for an atomic explosion in 1974. The Indian reactor was a Canadian-made heavy water research reactor called Cirus, not the later Candu model.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 18, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 3 described safety concerns about Canadian-made nuclear power plants sold abroad. It included an estimate that Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., the manufacturer of a power plant type known as Candu, had received $10 billion in Canadian Government subsidies since 1952. The article should have pointed out that the estimate was made by an antinuclear group and that the company says it has received less than $4 billion.

HEADLINE: Long Island Economy Is Thriving, Economists Say

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 3

 BODY:
The Long Island economy is booming, with shoppers spending, builders building and businesses hiring, according to year-end reports by local economists.
"At long last, the Island's economy is now back to where it was in the heydays of the mid-1980's, with one major plus," Dr. Irwin L. Kellner, the former chief economist for Chase Manhattan's Regional Bank, told a group of business executives today at Hofstra University in Hempstead. "It's not a one-trick pony, dependent on only one industry, defense." 
 He said there has been an increase in tourism and financial services and growing diversity in areas like technology, biotechnology, telecommunications and filmmaking.
"I think we're in great shape here and safely out of the woods," said Dr. Kellner, who holds the August B. Weller Distinguished Chair of Economics at Hofstra.
Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group, was even more optimistic.
"Long Island's economic recovery has finally caught fire," Dr. Kamer said in her year-end regional review.
She said that Nassau and Suffolk Counties had 1,123,000 nonfarm jobs in September, up 22,500 from September 1996. The service industry alone added 9,800 jobs, she said.
And while an estimated 37,000 people have entered the labor force since May, there has been no increase in the unemployment rate because many of them were able to find jobs, she said in her report.
In his speech, Dr. Kellner noted Nassau County's 3.5 percent unemployment rate and Suffolk County's 4 percent rate. "A growing number of manufacturing jobs offered opportunities to many people who perhaps don't have a higher education but who have physical skills," he said.
"On the other hand, there are some continuing shortages of people for jobs such as programmers and computer operators, machinists and even accountants," he said.
Consumer spending, meanwhile, has led to a 5.5 percent increase over last year in sales tax revenues in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties, easing the pressure to increase property taxes, Dr. Kellner said.
"And when you consider that prices are up 2 percent, if that much, you're talking about real goods being moved off the shelves and out of warehouses to the tune of 3 to 4 percent over a year ago," he said.
Builders constructed more than 5,500 new residential units this year and could be expected to do the same next year, he said, even though there is little available space.
"There has been a sharp increase in the number of senior citizen assisted-living units being built here," he said. "We're on the cutting edge in this area, adding to the economy not only in terms of building, but in wages and other spinoff effects."
Because the area has an aging population, he said, "this is something that I think will provide at least a modest push to the Long Island economy."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN SOUTH KOREA: THE U.S. ROLE;
Washington to Directly Contribute $5 Billion, at the Low End of Expectations

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it would make as much as $5 billion available for the international bailout of South Korea, hoping to stabilize a country where the United States has considerable economic and security interests.
The direct financing would back up $35 billion being provided through three international institutions to which the United States is the largest contributor: the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. 
 The $5 billion commitment -- at the low end of what reports from South Korea had suggested Washington would contribute -- compares with $10 billion being offered for the South Korean package by Japan, and with the $3 billion in backup funds offered by the United States last month to Indonesia, whose economy is far smaller than South Korea's.
The offer reflected a strategy adopted two weeks ago by the United States and many big Asian nations of calling on the I.M.F. and other international organizations to take the lead in dealing with financially troubled nations, but encouraging other governments with a stake in the region to offer supplemental aid when needed.
"We have a vital national economic and security interest in helping Korea restore market stability as soon as possible," Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said.
The American aid will be made available through a special fund under the Treasury Department's control, and does not require any Congressional authorization. Administration officials said they kept Congressional leaders informed about the situation, and said there were no signs the plan would run into serious opposition from Republican leaders.
But some Democrats and Republicans expressed misgivings, and said that when Congress reconvened next month they would raise questions about the Administration's request for even more funds for the I.M.F.
"It's very bad policy," said Representative Ron Paul, a Texas Republican, who has long argued that international bailouts put taxpayer money at risk and threaten the American economy by weakening the dollar and stimulating inflation, all to insulate banks and other investors from losses. "With the exception of some bankers from Houston, I never hear from anyone who wants to sacrifice taxpayer dollars to go over there to bail someone out," Mr. Paul said today.
Democratic critics want to tie international bailouts and other financial aid to human rights issues and improved conditions for workers.
Administration officials defended both the I.M.F. package with South Korea and the American backup fund as effective ways to impose sweeping changes on the South Korean financial and economic systems. And they said that the last such American financing package -- a key element in the bailout of Mexico three years ago -- was fully repaid, with interest, helping close off the crisis there.
Officials said the United States agreed to provide additional financing only after determining that the I.M.F. package was tough enough on the Koreans to restore market confidence in their economy while reassuring American taxpayers that the Treasury Department was not throwing good money after bad.
A senior Treasury official said today that American aid would be released to South Korea only to fill any gaps in that country's financing needs between the release of I.M.F. installments. The American money would be provided for 60-day periods, with the possibility of extensions if needed. And it would be released only if Seoul continues to meet all the requirements of the I.M.F. program and if the Treasury Department thinks it will be repaid.
The money would come from the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a $40 billion pool administered by the Treasury Department and used at the discretion of the President. It was set up in the 1930'ss to give the Government ammunition to defend the dollar's value. It has been used increasingly, though, in maintaining the stability of global markets by helping beleaguered nations restore confidence in their currencies.
There have been periodic attempts by Congress to restrict the stabilization fund. Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, is currently pushing for legislation that would require that any disbursement of more than $250 million receive Congressional approval.
Mr. Faircloth said he would demand that the Administration accept such a restriction in return for Congressional approval of Mr. Clinton's request for $3.5 billion to bolster the I.M.F.'s finances. The Administration's request for that money was blocked last month by anti-abortion Republicans, who demanded restrictions on American support for international family planning programs in return for new I.M.F. support.
"I believe Robert Rubin needs to stop using the Exchange Stabilization Fund as a personal piggy bank for international bailouts," Mr. Faircloth said.
But Administration officials said that the problems in South Korea could impress on members of Congress the need to strengthen the I.M.F. The Administration won support on that today from four senior Republicans on the House Banking Committee, including the chairman, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa.
They sent a letter to Republican leaders urging them to support the additional funds for the I.M.F. and also for the United Nations, saying that the ability to halt global financial crises was in America's interest.
"With the financial future of Asia uncertain and the possibility of a full bailout of South Korea looming, a depleted I.M.F. may not be able to respond to a currency crisis that could have grave consequences in the United States," said Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, the author of the letter.

HEADLINE: U.N. Troops to Leave Haiti As Feeble as They Found It

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 3

 BODY:
When 20,000 American troops landed here in September 1994 to restore the elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power after three years of military dictatorship, they were greeted rapturously. To the average Haitian, the arrival of soldiers and a phalanx of donors promising aid seemed to signal the dawn of a new era of political stability and economic growth.
But now the United Nations mandate that made the intervention possible has been allowed to expire, a casualty of international exasperation with a lack of progress here. And when the 1,400 Canadian and Pakistani peacekeepers who are the last remnants of that military force begin withdrawing from Haiti on Thursday, they will be leaving behind a country nearly as poor, prostrate and paralyzed as when they stepped in to help. 
 For six months, ever since Prime Minister Rosny Smarth resigned, bitterly declaring that "in this country, power is a disease," Haiti has been without a functioning government.
One attempt to name his successor quickly fell victim to the dispute between factions of the Lavalas coalition that originally supported Mr. Aristide, and a second is now stalled in Parliament with no date set to begin discussing the nomination, much less vote on it.
Because of the political impasse, no budget can be passed, the decay of road, telephone, electricity and water systems is accelerating and more than $1 billion in foreign assistance remains unspent.
As a result, more than half the working population is estimated to be without jobs, the cost of living is rising precipitously and frustration with President Rene Preval and his caretaker Cabinet is growing among the populace and international aid donors.
"There isn't a functioning state right now, and the country cannot wait for one to appear or be built up," Enrique ter Horst, the departing director of the United Nations mission, warned in an interview here today. Haiti also runs the risk, he added, that the international community might "become despondent when the patient clearly has not left the intensive-care ward."
Many Haitians fear that without a foreign military and diplomatic presence to referee internal disputes, the situation can only grow worse.
One manifestation of the crisis particularly alarming to the United States was the interception just off Miami on Nov. 20 of a rickety fishing boat with 417 Haitians on board. Thousands of such "boat people" tried to flee to Florida in 1993 and 1994, at the height of the military repression here, but the group returned by the Coast Guard last month was the largest in two years.
Elected with a resounding majority in December 1990, Mr. Aristide, a populist former priest and spellbinding orator, took office in February 1991, but was overthrown in a coup seven months later. He spent the next three years in exile, as the United States sought to negotiate his return amid mounting violence. But Washington's patience eventually ran out, and President Clinton, in what was hailed as one of the major foreign policy triumphs of his first term, elected to use force to restore him to office.
With the Clinton Administration's prestige still very much at stake here, American policy makers have generally expressed optimism in their public statements about the direction of events, pointing to slow but steady progress in what they call "nation building."
But in a new essay titled "Haiti: Will Things Fall Apart?," Donald E. Schulz, an analyst of Haitian affairs at the United States Army War College, strikes a cautionary tone. "National unity has dissipated" in recent months and the country is "slowly drifting toward chaos," he says.
Foreign officials here, however, continue to maintain there is no cause for panic. "The international community is not abandoning Haiti," Brig. Gen. Robin Gagnon, the Canadian commander of the United Nations troops, said in an interview here just hours before his departure. "There is no more role for the military to play, but we will continue to provide resources."
The backbone of that diminished presence is a 300 member multinational police force that will continue to work with the two-year-old Haitian National Police, widely criticized for incompetence and corruption. But that mandate is scheduled to expire in a year, when Haiti must again hold congressional and mayoral elections, and their ability to shape events here now is clearly more limited than in the past.
Furthermore, nearly half that police presence is to consist of a primarily Argentine "self-defense unit" whose main function, as one foreign official here delicately put it, is to "extricate" the rest of the United Nations force should Haiti once again descend into violence. The team was created, diplomats here said, at the insistence of the same countries that claim the Haitian National Police is now capable of maintaining public order here.
For its part, the United States will continue to maintain a 500-member military "support group" for the foreseeable future. Ostensibly, the unit is here to build roads, bridges and the like, but as one diplomat here put it, its presence is also Washington's way of "sending a signal to any potential troublemaker that 'we are interested and hands off.' "
With the United Nations already having one foot out the door, the political squabbling took an even nastier turn last month with the arrest by the Haitian National Police of Leon Jeune, who served as head of the interim police force after Mr. Aristide was restored to power in 1994. Mr. Jeune, 61, later had a falling out with Mr. Aristide and in 1995 ran for President against his handpicked candidate, Mr. Preval.
Mr. Jeune's wife has complained that the Haitian police SWAT team that made the arrest beat her husband and would have killed him had a United Nations police adviser not intervened. Though a judge ordered Mr. Jeune's release on Nov. 27, he was still being held today.
The Jeune case indicates "there is a macabre plan being formulated by forces within the Lavalas movement that do not support democracy," said Pierre-Paul Marsan, a member of the Chamber of Deputies.
Robert Manuel, Secretary of State for Public Security, denied that Mr. Jeune had been mistreated and attributed his arrest to involvement in a conspiracy to destabilize the state and overthrow Mr. Preval.
"We are living in a moment when many demons have been set loose," Mr. Manuel said, warning of "plots that have both a national and international dimension" and involve "all sorts of old interests who are against democracy."
United Nations officials were openly skeptical of that scenario. "From our intelligence network, there was no indication whatsoever of a plot being prepared," General Gagnon said. "Either we were blind, or it was nothing, and since we have a good network, I do not believe we were blind."

HEADLINE: In a Stakeout, Police Capture A Rape Suspect

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Bronx detectives called him the Cardboard Man, a rapist who struck at least 10 times in the last two years, always placing a piece of cardboard on the ground before assaulting his victims. The attacks struck fear into several Bronx neighborhoods, but the suspect always eluded capture.
On Tuesday night, however, two police officers from the 46th Precinct were staking out a small park at Mosholu Parkway and Gun Hill Road -- where the rapist had struck three weeks ago -- when they spotted a man who matched the description of the suspect and watched him sit down near a piece of cardboard. 
 "We observed him walking into the park with a bag," Officer Adam Sager, 27, said yesterday. "We saw him sitting in a dark and secluded spot, which was consistent with the areas where he had struck before."
Officer Sager and his partner, Officer Alex Golematis, 33, who have been working on the case for 10 months, took the man into custody for questioning. There, the police said, the man, Andres Martinez, 56, confessed to several rapes and revealed the contents of his bag: his trademark mask, a black curly wig and a knife.
He was charged yesterday with six counts of rape, two counts of attempted rape and five counts of sodomy, as well as robbery, assault and weapons possession, the police said.
Mr. Martinez's victims ranged in age from 12 to 48, the police said, and he struck mostly in the Morris Heights and Mount Eden neighborhoods. On at least two occasions, he committed rapes within a block of his home, at 1419 Jessup Avenue, the police said. Mr. Martinez, a married man with children, is unemployed. He is also wanted for questioning by the Massachusetts authorities, who are investigating a half-dozen crimes in Holyoke, Mass., dating from 1983.
