HEADLINE: Fed Survey Finds Wages Still Contained

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Even as more employers are driven to extraordinary lengths to find qualified people to fill jobs, the bulk of the American work force is still not winning sizable wage increases, a Federal Reserve survey showed today.
As a result, inflationary pressures remain largely in check, a situation buttressed by financial disruption in Asia that is curbing demand for this country's products while spurring imports of cheaper foreign goods. 
 This double-barreled force for containing prices, and its implications for slower growth, was seen by analysts as further reducing the possibility that the inflation-wary Fed would need to raise interest rates.
"Tight labor markets but still no sign of a breakout in inflation," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, of today's report covering developments through Nov. 24. "And, already, there were some reports of slower orders from Asia."
In a survey of conditions prepared by its 12 district banks for a Dec. 16 policy meeting, the Fed found "a continued moderate pace of economic growth" but with activity restrained by labor shortages, rail bottlenecks and weaker export markets.
Other concessions to employees in the tight labor market include bonuses, discounts, flexibility on hours and workplace rules and the conversion of part-time jobs to full time.
The survey also found that business travel and tourism continued to boom along the East Coast, with Boston and New York reporting a shortage of hotel rooms and rising rates, especially in Manhattan. The survey found that commercial landlords had greater leverage to raise rents.
Central Ohio had an especially severe shortage of seasonal workers but the Cleveland Fed also cited a falloff in Asian orders for equipment to manufacture semiconductors.
Banks in various districts reported a surge of mortgage refinancing, with rates of consumer delinquency "little changed, on balance."
In another report, the Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell unexpectedly by 1.7 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 797,000, down from September's revised rate of 811,000. The department originally estimated the September sales rate at 800,000. Though the declines were widespread, it still left home sales at relatively high levels.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Business as Usual, With a Few Distant Clouds"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- The economy remained robust, with retailers citing high demand and gas and oil develop-ment at a decade-high level.
 
Chicago -- Winter's arrival brought an increase in retail sales. Labor markets were tight. Low mortgage rates encouraged construction.
 
Cleveland -- As the economy continued to expand, construction remained active. The labor market tightened further,
 
Boston -- Although sales and revenue remained healthy, retailers and manu-facturers predicted a slowdown,
 
New York -- With the economy rolling at a steady rate, prices, wages and retail activity all increased moderately.
 
Philadelphia -- Manufacturing, retail sales and general economic conditions improved modestly in November.
 
Richmond -- After a September lull, manufacturing, retail sales and prices all reported continued growth. Manufacturing continued to expand at a healthy pace.
 
Atlanta -- Moderate expansion continued in retail, while manufacturing, construction and home sales stood pat.
 
St. Louis -- Growth in sales and employment helped the economy expand at a moderate pace. Tight labor markets persisted.
 
Kansas City -- Moderate growth continued in most economic sectors, although energy activity slowed. The job market remained tight.
 
Dallas -- Economic expansion slowed slightly, starting in late October. Although mostly sanguine, some surveyed had concerns about future demand from Asia.
 
San Francisco -- Economic development accelerated further. Technology companies reported operations at or near capacity, and service providers reported growth at a rapid pace.

HEADLINE: The South Korean Bailout

 BODY:
With South Korea's plummeting currency and rising bankruptcies threatening to spread financial turmoil to Japan, Russia and beyond, Washington wisely added up to $5 billion of its own to yesterday's international bailout of Korea. The $55 billion package, put together by the International Monetary Fund, is large enough to stanch further contagion and presumably comes with strict conditions calculated to keep South Korea out of trouble.
Unfortunately, the details of the deal are secret, and may remain so at the discretion of the Koreans. The secrecy has already bred suspicion that the monetary fund has cracked down needlessly hard. Some initial reports, for instance, suggest that it has forced South Korea to cut its projected growth rate in half, as if slow growth were itself a virtue. More likely, the fund recognized that interest rates have to rise in Korea to stop the widespread flight from its currency. Higher rates, in turn, discourage investment and slow the economy. The fund probably insisted that Korea let these necessary corrections run their course. 
 The monetary fund would be mistaken to push down much harder. Unlike Thailand earlier this year and Mexico in 1995, South Korea is not running large fiscal deficits or trade imbalances. It does not have to rein in reckless policies. South Korea's problem is almost entirely in its private sector, specifically banks that have borrowed abroad to make loans, under political pressure, to government-coddled conglomerates. The system has unraveled as financial turmoil in other parts of Asia has cut purchases of Korea's exports. As the export-dependent and heavily indebted conglomerates stumbled, depositors and foreign lenders became alarmed and withdrew their money. Even good banks have been forced to dump assets in a desperate attempt to pay off frightened depositors and foreign creditors. Korea is suffering a self-fueling crisis of confidence that threatens to bury its banks and their customers.
After prolonged negotiations, the monetary fund got South Korea to agree to close insolvent banks and, like America in the 1980's, use public money to help solvent banks get through this difficult period. The longer-term answer is to free Korean companies to seek loans from abroad and, even better, equity from foreign shareholders. That way financial calculation can replace cronyism.
It is hard to justify the tradition of secrecy in monetary fund bailouts when tens of billions of dollars are involved, all of it raised in one way or another from taxpayers in America and other nations. The potential embarrassment to South Korea of disclosing the terms of this package is easily outweighed by the need to know what the fund has extracted for its investment. If the terms are tough but reasonable, South Korea, with a well-trained work force and robust rates of saving and investment, should soon return to rapid growth.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mr. Gore's Mission in Kyoto

 BODY:
It may require a near-miracle for the 150-plus nations now meeting in Kyoto, Japan, to produce, in six days, a comprehensive treaty on global warming. The issue is complex, the disagreements wide. But anyone who has taken the trouble to cut through the diplomatic posturing knows there is room for compromise. At the very least, the negotiators can produce a broad memorandum of understanding that kicks the process forward and provides a firm basis for detailed negotiations.
Failure to do so would be costly. If the world is shown to be incapable of a collective response to a collective problem, whatever sense of urgency the general public has about climate change could evaporate. Failure would also slow the search for technologies that could reduce the world's dependence on coal and other fossil fuels that contribute to the rise in atmospheric temperatures. 
 Fear of failure is essentially what drove President Clinton to send Al Gore to Kyoto next week. The Vice President's ostensible mission is to prevent the American position from being shouted down by the Europeans, who think it is too weak. Yet there are some countries, oil exporters like Saudi Arabia and coal-dependent nations like Australia, that want no agreement. Mr. Gore's real mission is to lure both sides to a workable middle ground. That will mean adjustments in everyone's position on two highly contentious issues.
Targets and Timetables. Mr. Clinton wants to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels somewhere between 2008 and 2012, and cut them by unspecified amounts thereafter. The Europeans want to cut emissions 15 percent below 1990 levels by 2010, a goal Mr. Clinton regards as incompatible with economic growth. But surely there is room for compromise here, either by picking an arithmetic middle ground, or -- instead of insisting on a one-size-fits-all formula -- by setting different targets for different countries, tailored to their economic and social profiles.
Developing Countries. The developing countries argue that they need more time to grow and cannot be forced to cut their fossil-fuel emissions. The United States Senate, however, has told Mr. Clinton it will not ratify a treaty that does not include developing countries, and nearly everyone agrees that unless these countries sign on at some point, any agreement will be worthless. The answer here could be to require the developing countries to sign the treaty but allow them to negotiate timetables and targets down the road. Another answer could lie in a novel proposal, offered by the Americans, under which rich countries would subsidize cleaner technologies in poorer countries.
Kyoto may yet produce a treaty. But even if it does not, it will not have been a failure if it moves everyone to common ground.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cheap imports may hurt labor, but avoid a world recession.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH the cold war over, President Clinton has often explained, the fundamental challenges to the only remaining superpower have become economic rather than military.
This economics-as-war metaphor falsely implies natural conflict -- that their gain is our loss. And it is prone to be misinterpreted as justifying trade protectionism, that trade surpluses are good, while trade deficits are bad. 
 Yet, in the end, Mr. Clinton may be proved right. With the financial crisis gripping Asia and Europe sitting on the sidelines, America's global leadership is indeed being tested. But the challenge to the White House is to turn conventional economic nationalism on its head. To save the world from a serious recession, Washington will have to accept large and rapidly growing trade deficits for the next few years.
Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines -- and this week, South Korea -- are committed to financial reforms in return for a $100 billion-plus bailout led by the International Monetary Fund. But this money is no gift: it will take the form of loans that must be repaid with interest at market rates.
How will these economies meet their debt payments? And how will they sell the torrent of goods they must produce to rekindle economic growth?
They can't look to demand at home. Governments won't be buying much: the I.M.F. loans require fiscal austerity. Nor will businesses: besieged banks will be under orders to lend only to the most creditworthy. Nor consumers: with corporate downsizing the order of the day, workers will be in no mood to buy new cars and appliances.
China can't help. While the Chinese economy is an important customer for South Korea, Beijing is in no mood to increase imports. Indeed, the real worry is that China will react to slowing demand for its own goods abroad by devaluing the yuan -- and in the process increase the deflationary pressure on other low-wage Asian economies.
And if China can't help, Japan won't. With the Japanese banking system in shambles and the economy already of the verge of recession, imports from the rest of Asia are likely to fall. Fiscal stimulus -- tax cuts or spending increases -- might stem the decline. But Tokyo is committed to cutting, not increasing, its budget deficit. And "if you're a pessimist like me," said Rudi Dornbusch, an economist at M.I.T., "you'd expect them to raise taxes to pay for the bailout of their banks."
Far from being part of the solution, Japan is well on the way to becoming part of the problem. The depreciating yen -- now 60 percent below the 1995 peak against the dollar -- will make Japanese exports less expensive, crowding out sales from high-wage Asian economies including South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore.
What about the European Community? The major European economies are clipping right along, and might be expected to suck in part of the Asian surplus as they grow. But Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, argues that on the eve of adopting a common currency, Europe is unlikely to carry its weight in the Asian rescue.
To qualify for monetary union, he notes, all the Continental economies are hewing to tight budgets. And once monetary union is achieved, the new European central bank will probably keep an extra-tight rein on the common money supply to prove its credibility.
In fact, if economic growth falters, the Europeans will not be averse to their own currency depreciation, which would help exporters and take the pressure off industries that must compete with imports. "Depreciation would square the circle" for a newly formed monetary union lacking other means to stimulate domestic demand, Mr. Eichengreen concludes.
That leaves America, which, in theory, is well positioned to serve as the locomotive of global expansion. The Federal Reserve would undoubtedly welcome a gain in the exchange rate of the dollar and an accompanying $50 billion to $100 billion surge in cheap, high-quality Asian imports that reduced inflationary pressures on the fast-revving domestic economy.
But it wouldn't please organized labor, which senses that the time may have finally arrived to demand higher wages. And it wouldn't please Detroit, which is squeezed between an increasingly restive union and vast overcapacity in the global auto industry.
The big question, then, is whether Washington can temper its inclination to protect labor and business from the fallout from Asia. If it doesn't, Asia's problems could spread to Latin America and Eastern Europe -- and, arguably, the rest of the world. "This deflation thing could be big, if it really gets going," Mr. Dornbusch said.

HEADLINE: Technology Issues Lead Stocks Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
A recovery in technology issues led a late rally in stocks yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average rebounded from a 56-point drop to close higher for the fourth consecutive session. The Dow gained 13.18 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 8,032.01. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.09, or a half of 1 percent, to 976.77, less than 7 points from its Oct. 7 closing high. Western Atlas, which does seismic surveys, was the top gainer, rising 4 1/8, or 6 percent, to 71 1/2. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, filled with computer shares, rose 8.76, or six-tenths of a percent, to 1,615.13. The index recovered from a 15-point loss prompted by 3Com Corporation's warning late Tuesday that profits would be disappointing because of slower sales in Asia.
While 3Com fell 3/8 yesterday, to 34 15/16, other networkers, including Cisco Systems and Bay Networks, turned losses into gains by the end of the day. Cisco rose 13/32, to 86 29/32, and Bay Networks rose 1 3/16, to 28 15/16. National Semiconductor, a 3Com supplier, dropped 1 5/8, to 30 11/16.
Treasury prices were also higher, after comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a Fed report reinforced expectations that interest rates would remain steady.
In speeches Tuesday night and yesterday, Mr. Greenspan focused on Asia's financial turmoil and made little mention of the United States economy. That persuaded investors that the central bank was not poised to increase the cost of borrowing to curb inflation, now running at the slowest pace in 10 years.
"It's not anything that Greenspan said last night -- it's what he didn't say," said Patrick Dimick, a bond analyst at UBS Securities. "There was some relief that his speech was so nonthreatening to the Treasury market."
Further, the Fed reported yesterday in its periodic survey of business conditions, known as the beige book, that Asia's economic woes were starting to slow United States exports.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32, to 101 18/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.01 percent from 6.03 percent.
Among individual stocks yesterday, those of telephone companies surged, including AT&T, up 13/16, to 57 1/8, and regional carriers BellSouth, up 2 7/8, to 56 13/16, Ameritech, up 3, to 80 1/16, and Bell Atlantic, up 13/16, to 89 1/2.
AT&T rose after The Wall Street Journal reported that the telecommunications giant's new chief executive, C. Michael Armstrong, will sell assets and discontinue operations to prepare the company for competition in the long-distance market. The article also said Mr. Armstrong was interested in renewing merger talks with SBC Communications. SBC rose 2 1/2, to 74 15/16.
H. J. Heinz rose 2 5/8, to 55 1/4, after the ketchup and cat food company said Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, chief executive since 1979, would resign. He will be replaced by William Johnson, president and heir apparent, effective April 30.
The BB&T Corporation rose 8 15/16, to 65, a record. The bank, based in Salem, N.C., was scheduled to be added to the Standard & Poor's 500 Index after the close of trading. Money managers who track the index's performance are buying the stock.
The CBS Corporation lost 1 3/4, to 30 1/8, after its rating was cut to "neutral" from "outperform" by a Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company analyst Frank Bodenchak.
While an admirer of CBS, which owns the CBS network and changed its name from Westinghouse Electric on Monday, Mr. Bodenchak said he regarded the stock as too expensive.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Japan Grew 0.8% in Quarter, Suggesting a Flat '97 Economy

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4

 BODY:
In the latest indication Japan is edging toward full recession, the Government said Wednesday that economic growth totaled less than 1 percent for the third quarter and that the economy would have trouble growing more than 1 percent for the year.
The figures released by the Economic Planning Agency were far weaker than expected. They also showed that the Japanese economy, the world's second largest, had begun to feel direct pain in the third quarter from the financial crisis afflicting much of Asia, with plunging currency values and rising debts causing imports from Japan to fall. 
 The Economic Planning Agency said that the gross domestic product, a comprehensive measure of goods and services, increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in the three-month period ending on Sept. 30, compared with the previous three months.
While higher private consumption and capital spending contributed to the slight growth in the quarter, housing and public spending remained weak, underscoring rising public uncertainty over the economy.
The trade surplus fell for the first time in 11 quarters due to weak demand from Southeast Asia.
"The feeling that I have at this moment is that it will be pretty difficult for growth to reach 1 percent or more for the fiscal year," Shimpei Nukaya, Vice Minister of the Economic Planning Agency, said at a news conference. The Government had predicted that the economy would grow by 1.9 percent for 1997.
Many economists had forecast 1.3 percent growth for the quarter and saw Wednesday's figures as a harbinger of a recession in the coming year unless the Government acted quickly to invigorate the economy.
"If the Government does not take new fiscal measures to shore up the economy, there will be serious ramifications," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers here.
The weak third-quarter data followed an alarming second-quarter decline of 11.2 percent on an annual basis, attributed mainly to the effects of a sharp increase in the sales tax that took effect on April 1. That was the largest contraction since the sharp rise in oil prices in 1973-74.
Many economists said they now predicted no growth for the year.
The economic figures represented just the latest blow for Japan, which has been struggling with a frail banking system burdened by bad real estate loans, rising unemployment, an anemic stock market and fear about the fallout from economic crises in much of Asia.
The uncertainty over Japan's economy contributed to another plunge in Tokyo stocks. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 324.78 points, or 1.92 percent, on Wednesday, closing at 16,585.51. In early trading this morning, the Nikkei was down modestly. dropping 84.71 points, or one-half of 1 percent, to 16,500.80.
The Japanese yen eased against the dollar on Wednesday, settling in New York at 128.78, compared with 128.64 late Tuesday. Against the German mark, the dollar fell to 1.7720 from 1.7782 on Tuesday.
Economists have called on Japan to undertake expansion policies like income-and corporate-tax cuts and works projects, but they acknowledge that such steps will be hard under fiscal austerity measures adopted by the Cabinet of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto with a view toward modernizing the securities markets.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Record $55 Billion Bailout Set for South Korea
After days of tense negotiations, South Korea formally agreed to stringent terms for an unprecedented economic rescue that will extend $55 billion in loans to the world's 11th largest economy, hobbled by unpaid debts. Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary, the leader of the bailout, called the plan "a strong economic program that provides for a decisive and welcome response to the country's present financial difficulties."
But the bailout is likely to result in severe cuts in public spending and other austerity moves that could triple the unemployment rate, cause a surge in bankruptcies and create other hardships on South Koreans. Page A1. 

The Clinton Administration will make up to $5 billion available for the bailout but the bulk of the package will be provided through the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and Asian Development Bank. D6.
 
Asia aid packages, already totaling nearly $100 billion, are prompting many economists and investment bankers to argue anew that bailouts, even when they accomplish their goals, set a bad precedent. By making lenders whole, critics say, such rescues merely encourage more careless lending and fresh crises. News Analysis. D6.
 
Few Workers Win Big Wage Gains
The bulk of the American work force is still not winning sizable wage increases, a Federal Reserve survey shows, even as employers are driven to extraordinary lengths to find qualified hires. As a result, inflationary pressures remain largely in check and further reduce the possibility that the Fed will raise interest rates at its Dec. 16 policymaking meeting, economists said. D3.
 
Trucks Gaining on Cars
American families bought more sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups than cars last month, the first time these so-called light trucks have surpassed cars in retail sales since the end of World War II. D4.

Auto makers enjoyed a 3.8 percent gain in sales in November, industry figures show. Strong demand for trucks propelled the sales. Auto makers offered generous rebates and discounted finance rates in November. D4.
 
Stocks Rise on Technology Rally
A recovery in technology stocks led a late rally, propelling the Nasdaq composite index up 8.76 points to 1,615.13. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its fourth straight gain, 13.18 points to 8,032.01. D19.
 
Full Recession Feared in Japan
Japan's economy grew less than expected in the third quarter after a sharp drop in the second quarter, the Japanese Government said in a report that suggested the world's second largest economy may be headed for a full recession. The main weaknesses were sluggish consumer spending and diminished exports due to lowered demand from the troubled economies of Southeast Asia. D9.
 
Canadians to Buy Sears Tower
Trizec Hahn, a rapidly growing Canadian real estate company, is acquiring effective control of the 110-story Sears Tower, North America's tallest skyscraper, for $70 million and assuming a $734 million mortgage. It is also paying $40 million for full ownership of an adjacent 1,100-car garage, a site for potential future development. D2.
 
Union Pacific's Claims Questioned
Union Pacific's assertions that it has unclogged the congestion choking rail shipments across the western United States were met with skepticism from the head of the Surface Transportation Board, Linda Morgan, who cited users' comments. The regulatory agency is expected to decide today whether to extend an order requiring Union Pacific to cooperate with competitors in Texas. D4.
 
Copper Futures at 4-Year Low
Copper prices tumbled as weak demand from Asia and rising output pushed stockpiles close to 20-month highs. Copper for March delivery fell 1.55 cents, to 81.85 cents a pound, the lowest since Jan. 12, 1994. D9.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN SOUTH KOREA: THE BAILOUT;
PACKAGE OF LOANS WORTH $55 BILLION IS SET FOR KOREA

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3

 BODY:
South Korea formally agreed today to terms for the largest international economic rescue ever -- a $55 billion loan package that will revamp the country's financial system, likely creating substantial hardship for the nation's citizens in the process and slowing the pace of one of the world's fastest-growing economies.
Government officials and private analysts predicted that the severe cuts in public spending and other austerity moves would cause unemployment to double or even triple in a land where lifetime employment has long been taken for granted. Bankruptcies, already running at a high rate, are expected to skyrocket. Some economists said it would be two years or more before the economy recovered. 
 "I have come here to beg the forgiveness of the Korean people," Lim Chang Yuel, the Minister of Finance and Economy, said in a nationally televised speech tonight. "Please understand the necessity of the economic pain we must bear and overcome."
 The battered South Korean stock market surged 6 percent by midday Thursday in reaction to the bailout package, signaling investor optimism that it would succeed.
The agreement came about after several days of tense negotiations in which the reluctance of the Korean Government to swallow both its pride and some distasteful economic medicine seemed to draw out the discussions. Under the terms of the deal, the International Monetary Fund, the leader of the bailout, will provide South Korea with $21 billion in credits. The World Bank promised to provide $10 billion and the Asian Development Bank $4 billion.
The United States and several other nations agreed to provide $20 billion more as a "second line of defense" if the initial money from the international organizations proves insufficient. Some $5 billion will come from the United States, $10 billion from Japan and the rest from Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Germany and possibly other nations.
The money will initially be used to help shore up South Korea's nearly depleted foreign currency reserves. That should help stanch the rapid devaluation of the Korean won and allow the nation to pay off foreign debt. Some $66 billion is due within a year, and about $20 billion of that is due by the end of this year.
The money will also be used to help restore the health of the financial system, which has been weakened by haphazard lending to the country's supercorporations, huge industrial conglomerates that were nurtured by the Government as the engine for the country's remarkable growth.
In return for the money, Seoul must cut public spending, open its market more to foreign goods and investors and curb the ability of the conglomerates to expand.
For a nation that grew from an impoverished backwater to the world's 11th-largest economy, it marked the humbling end of the economic miracle and the beginning of a period of what President Kim Young Sam has described as "bone-carving pain." It was only last year that South Korea proudly joined the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the club of advanced nations.
Michel Camdessus (pronounced Cam-da-SOO), the managing director of the I.M.F., who arrived here this morning to complete the deal, called it "a strong economic program that provides for a decisive and welcome response to the country's present financial difficulties."
South Korea is the latest and largest "Asian tiger" to fall victim this year to sharp devaluations of its currency and soaring debts. The amount of money available to Korea is larger than the $17 billion offered to Thailand, the nearly $40 billion promised to Indonesia in recent months and the $48 billion offered to Mexico three years ago. Mr. Camdessus said he hoped the loans to South Korea would help stabilize the region.
The Clinton Administration applauded the plan for one of its key Asian allies. "We have a vital national economic and security interest in helping Korea to restore market stability as soon as possible," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a statement. The United States, the largest shareholder in the I.M.F., played a big role in pushing Seoul to adopt stern reforms.
Under terms of the bailout, the South Korean Government agreed to stop pressuring banks to make loans to troubled or politically connected companies.
South Korea also agreed to take steps to attract more foreign investment, including allowing companies to raise money abroad through debt issues. American officials also said they were hopeful that United States and other foreign banks would acquire South Korean banks.
Among the other elements of the proposal is a requirement that South Korea drop some of its trade barriers and that the Government press for legislation making the central bank independent of Government control.
"The program's policy commitments will bring about very substantial changes in the Korean financial sector, which in turn has the potential to open up the Korean economy," another Treasury official said.
The $5 billion United States contribution will come from the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a pool of money that the President can use at his discretion to maintain stability in currency markets. Use of the fund does not require approval by Congress, where there is some resistance to international bailouts.
The package still needs formal approval by the I.M.F. executive board, which is expected as early as Thursday. Until then, full terms of the agreement were not being released.
Because South Korea will hold elections on Dec. 18 and Mr. Kim is constitutionally barred from running again, Mr. Camdessus took the unusual step of seeking pledges from South Korea's three presidential candidates that they would honor the agreement. The candidates gave their promises, some reluctantly.
The Korean stock market, after plunging early in the day, rallied at the end of trading to close up 0.65 percent, ending nine days of consecutive decline.
The rally was fueled by reports that the I.M.F. agreement would raise the percentage of a Korean company's stock that could be owned by foreigners to 50 percent from 26 percent immediately and to 55 percent next year. That portends an influx of foreign money into the stock market.
With the new austerity program, many economists predict unemployment, now at 2.5 percent, will double or even triple as huge layoffs mark a nation in which lifetime employment is considered a right.
Lee Jeong Ja, head of research for the Seoul branch of HSBC James Capel, a securities firm, said she would not be surprised to see as many as one-fourth of the more than 700 companies listed on Korea's stock exchange go bankrupt. She said the economic downturn would last two years, but other analysts said it would be longer.
"I would say we're not going to see any return to growth over 5 percent for the next few years," said Eugene Ha, head of research at J. Henry Schroder in Seoul. South Korea is expected to grow about 6 percent this year, but the target for next year under the plan is about half that.
In addition to bemoaning the pain, there was also some anger here that the nation had surrendered control of its economy.
"With the complete opening of Korea's financial market, foreign capital will virtually be in control of the profits and management of Korean companies," an announcer on the state-owned Korean Broadcasting System said tonight. He also warned, "U.S. automobiles and Japanese products are expected to pour into Korea."
But any long-term gains for the United States and other nations from market openings in the package will be at least partly offset by South Korea's economic slowdown, which will cut its imports. Many civic groups are starting frugality campaigns, urging consumers to help save the economy by not buying foreign products because they contribute to the nation's trade deficit.
In some cases, the I.M.F. package will give the South Korean Government the cover to make reforms that special interests in the country had prevented thus far.
President Kim, for instance, came into office pledging to pare down the industrial conglomerates but has been unsuccessful.
The huge conglomerates, known as chaebols, have enjoyed ready access to bank loans because they were favored by the Government. With ready credit, they expanded haphazardly into numerous industries and developing markets worldwide. The result was a buildup of huge debts.
Now, many of those diversification attempts are failing, and chaebols are falling like dominoes. Seven of the top 40 have become insolvent this year. The Halla Group today barely avoided becoming the eighth when creditors agreed to postpone a deadline for debt repayment.
The I.M.F. agreement would limit the ability of one unit of a chaebol to guarantee the debts of another subsidiary, according to Korean media reports. This should help slow their expansion.
South Korea had announced several times this week that it had an agreement with the I.M.F., only to retract the statement later.
Officials said that the I.M.F., in part prodded by Washington, added more demands for market-opening measures and structural reforms. A big sticking point was over whether failing banks should be liquidated or allowed to reorganize. Korean officials say liquidation of commercial banks will not be required.

HEADLINE: Crusader and Pragmatist: The Two Chris Smiths

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In the trophy case in Representative Christopher H. Smith's Capitol Hill office sits a photograph of Wei Jingsheng, the Chinese dissident. The coffee table is littered with press releases about flood control programs and health clinics back home. On his desk rests a signed book of Richard Gere photographs from Tibet ("A celebrity who really cares," Mr. Smith says).
There is little here to tell a visitor that this place belongs to one of Congress's most fervent -- critics say obsessive -- opponents of abortion. And that is just how Mr. Smith wants it. 
 "High profile doesn't mean it is all you do," the nine-term Republican from central New Jersey said of his abortion fights. "Nobody should ever be a single-issue politician."
His comments, and his office decor, reflect the difficult political balancing act Mr. Smith struggles to maintain each day. In Washington, he is best known as a relentlessly effective floor leader in the fight to outlaw abortion, a battle that routinely allies him with Congress's most conservative members against most of his New Jersey colleagues, Republican and Democrat alike.
But beyond the Beltway, the Republican Congressman cuts a more complex figure, one not easily explained with conventional labels. To human rights activists, he is a vocal advocate for political freedoms abroad. To union organizers, he has become a surprisingly reliable friend. And to many voters back home, he has been a dependable defender of popular Government programs, from Medicare to Social Security to veterans' benefits.
Still, he is often labeled an ideological conservative. As a result, Mr. Smith is continually struggling to maintain credibility with the Northeastern moderates who are his natural allies on many issues, but who find his no-holds-barred anti-abortion tactics abhorrent.
Those tactics came into sharp relief last month in the final days of the Congressional session. As other members were making preparations to leave town, Mr. Smith led a move to hold up American payments to the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund as a way to force action on anti-abortion legislation. When the Clinton Administration refused to deal, the Republican leadership, at Mr. Smith's urging, blocked the payments, disrupting White House foreign policy plans as crises were developing in Iraq and Asia.
The maneuver infuriated leaders from just about every patch of the global political spectrum, including United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan, Senator Jesse A. Helms and President Clinton, whose spokesman called it "bone-headed." The pressure on Mr. Smith to back down was intense, the lobbying, including from members of his own party, furious. None of it seemed to faze the 44-year-old Congressman.
"It only makes me more determined," he said. "I can't say it's been just another day at the office. But I'm getting used to this sort of thing."
For Mr. Smith, such battles have become a way of life. A devout Catholic who often quotes scripture to explain his political philosophy, he says his religion is the unifying force behind his diverse views, from opposing abortion and the death penalty to supporting human rights in other nations.
As a freshman at Trenton State College, he formed a chapter of New Jersey Right to Life after seeing a news story about a fetus that had survived an abortion. After graduation, he went to work for the group as executive director. At age 27, he won what even he called a fluke election, defeating a powerful incumbent Congressman, Frank Thompson Jr., who had been recently indicted on -- and was later convicted of -- fraud charges in the Abscam scandal.
Ever since, he has been associated almost exclusively in Washington with fighting abortion, which he equates with murder, even genocide. He has been co-chairman of the House Pro-Life Caucus for 15 years.
Last year, no less a conservative than House Speaker Newt Gingrich punished him for backing an anti-abortion candidate against an incumbent Republican, Representative Sue W. Kelly of New York State, an abortion-rights supporter. On the other hand, Representative Henry J. Hyde, the dean of anti-abortion congressmen, calls him "heroic."
"For the most part in Congress, the name of the game is compromise," said Jo Blum, vice president for government relations with the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League in Washington. "But Chris Smith is not one to compromise."
Yet Mr. Smith is also walking proof that the abortion issue is not in itself enough to sustain a congressional career. Friends and critics alike describe him as deeply complex, capable of teaming up with the conservative Westerners on abortion one moment, then working with Northeastern liberals to preserve wetlands or increase the minimum wage the next. Even White House officials say he has been very helpful on immigration and refugee issues.
"There are two Chris Smiths," said Brian M. Hughes, a Democrat who ran against Mr. Smith in 1992. "There is one in Washington where abortion is his primary issue. Then there is the one in New Jersey, who is for economic development, fighting for veterans, fighting for Social Security. You wouldn't think he spent any time on the abortion issue."
"He's never walked away from the issue," Mr. Hughes added, "but he doesn't highlight it the way he does in Washington."
In part, pure political survival dictates Mr. Smith's voting record. His district wraps like a belt across New Jersey's waist, from Democratic Trenton, with its many unionized government workers, through a band of blue-collar towns to the shore, with its large bloc of retiree voters. Not surprisingly, Mr. Smith has repeatedly bucked his party's leadership and opposed efforts to cut programs cherished by the elderly, like Medicare, or to restrict union rights.
"When you take a look at his voting record, from building trades to public sector unions, he's been there for us," said Chuck Loveless, director of legislation for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees union.
But even some allies wonder whether his uncompromising style on abortion can be self-defeating. An official with an international human rights group described Mr. Smith as a "prince" who had used his position as chairman of the House Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights to press for political freedoms in other countries.
But the same official, speaking on condition of anonymity, lamented that Mr. Smith's anti-abortion guerrilla tactics had undermined his standing among moderates and liberals in Congress. On human rights issues, the official said: "Chris is truly a leader and one of the best ones we've got. I'm just concerned that his natural allies in Congress think of him as a one-issue person. And he's not."
Indeed, his position on abortion constantly infuriates moderates in his own party. For example, he refused to campaign for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman this year because of her strong support for abortion rights, prompting Hazel Gluck, a leading Whitman supporter, to call him "an extremist."
But Mr. Smith routinely angers conservatives, as well. Just as he was winning plaudits from conservatives for blocking payments to the United Nations, he was fighting Republican free-trade advocates by opposing so-called "fast track" legislation, which would have expanded the President's powers to negotiate trade agreements. He was one of only six Republicans to vote against reducing Medicare spending in 1995. And an anti-immigration group, the Federation for American Immigration Reform, has attacked him for his efforts to open American borders to more political refugees.
Even Senator Helms, the rock-ribbed anti-abortion conservative from North Carolina, was incensed at Mr. Smith for blocking the United Nations payments, which were linked to legislation Mr. Helms had meticulously negotiated to reorganize the State Department.
Mr. Smith, who was born in Rahway, said his support for labor comes from his father, a teamster turned sporting goods wholesaler who was laid off from a job driving for Borden's Food in Newark when Mr. Smith was 14. "When plant-closing legislation became an issue in Congress, it really brought back some vivid memories," he said.
But he says his activist streak comes from his grandfather, a Montclair lawyer who, for no charge, helped Chinese immigrants move their families out of Communist China. "He opened my eyes," Mr. Smith said. "I learned you can live out the Gospel by tangibly helping people."
He met his wife, Marie, at Trenton State where they were both active in Right to Life. They have four children, ages 10 to 19, and live in the northern Virginia suburbs so that he can spend more time with them -- an issue that has occasionally been raised in campaigns against him. "I love New Jersey, but while I'm on assignment, I'm not going to jeopardize my family life," he said.
The Democrats have repeatedly run abortion rights supporters against Mr. Smith, thinking the issue would work against him among New Jersey's relatively moderate voters, who polls show generally support abortion rights. The strategy has failed miserably: he has won re-election with more than 60 percent of the vote most times. Last year, the Democrats reversed field, choosing an anti-abortion conservative. He, too, lost by a wide margin.
With such stalwart support back home, Mr. Smith says he feels even greater freedom to push his anti-abortion agenda in Washington, a role he likens to the crusade of the 19th century abolitionists. And he says he has no intention of backing down in the standoff over payments to the United Nations, an issue sure to return next year.
"With abortion and the violence inherent in it, there is a meanness," he said, eyes blazing. "It is a national blind spot that will be removed."

HEADLINE: Judge Splits on Issues and Money in G.E. Executive's Divorce Case

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 3

 BODY:
In a high-stakes divorce case closely watched in corporate suites around the country, a Connecticut judge today awarded the wife of a top General Electric executive half of their cash, stocks and other hard assets, plus a part of his stock options and future pension benefits. According to his lawyers, the award is worth about $20 million. In an estate valued by her side at as much as $130 million, that would be far less than the 50 percent she had claimed for contributing to his success. 
 The ruling today, dissolving the marriage of Gary C. Wendt, 55, the chief executive of the GE Capital Corporation, General Electric's most profitable subsidiary, and Lorna J. Wendt, 54, had been awaited by many people as a possible verdict on how much a stay-at-home spouse contributes economically to a marriage. But the judge, Kevin Tierney of the Superior Court in Stamford, did not give his reasoning in outlining the complicated settlement.
In the case, Mrs. Wendt presented herself as someone who had helped put her husband through Harvard Business School, gave up her career as a music teacher to rear two daughters, created an elegant home, gave dinner parties for his clients and co-workers, accompanied him on business trips and provided daily support -- all of which contributed to his success.
The case is also important because it deals with how assets like stock options should be valued in a divorce settlement -- an issue with a growing number of couples as executive pay has soared, fueled by the more common use of stock options and deferred compensation.
Both sides said they were happy, to some extent, with the ruling today. "One point we were trying to make is that these valuable future assets are marital property, subject to division," said Arnold Rutkin, a lawyer for Mrs. Wendt. He said the award was worth more than $20 million -- Mr. Wendt's figure -- but he could not yet tell how much more. He added: "We are not happy with the amount, but we definitely made the point. Some of the boys in the board rooms will be really unhappy when they read this."
In a statement, Mr. Wendt said, "Despite the extensive publicity to the contrary generated by Mrs. Wendt, the principal issue in this case was not the relative contribution of the nonworking spouse versus the working spouse, but rather the division of future earnings after the nonworking spouse has been generously rewarded."
Neither side ruled out an appeal.
Judge Tierney said he would give his reasoning in a 450-page document, a draft of which he waved before Mrs. Wendt, various lawyers and about 30 reporters who had crowded into a small courtroom here. Mr. Wendt, who was delivering a speech in New Jersey, was not among them.
The Wendts, high school sweethearts in tiny Rio, Wis., married soon after they graduated from college in 1965. Mrs. Wendt said that when Mr. Wendt told her he wanted a divorce in 1995, she was shocked that he offered her a settlement worth about $10 million. She felt entitled to half, including his stock options, restricted stock holdings, deferred compensation and pension benefits. Her side valued the estate at $100 million, a number that may now be as high as $130 million as the stock market has rallied.
Mr. Wendt's side argued that assets like the stock options, which have a future value, should not be part of the tally because they would be contingent on his performance after the divorce and on his continued employment at General Electric until his retirement. In the last year, his side said, the estate's total value has grown from around $25 million to perhaps $45 million.
In the settlement, Judge Tierney struck a course that bowed to Mrs. Wendt's reasoning but delivered a result closer to Mr. Wendt's view. In addition to homes in Stamford and Florida worth about $2.8 million, he gave Mrs. Wendt half the cash, stock and bond holdings, worth $7.9 million; alimony of $252,000 a year, and an annual cash payment equal to half the projected dividends from 199,000 shares of restricted stock. Mr. Wendt gets to keep the stock, but the judge also awarded Mrs. Wendt half the value of his qualified pension plan and about 28 percent of his long-term performance award -- neither of which will be available until the future. Mrs. Wendt will also get private club memberships in Connecticut and Florida and a Macy's credit card entitling the holder to a 45 percent lifetime discount.
Mr. Wendt will keep all of his supplemental pension plan, his 401(k) retirement plan, all deferred compensation and various properties.
As in most other states, divorce law in Connecticut calls for equitable, not equal, distribution of a couple's assets, leaving the judge to consider the length of the marriage, the contributions each partner made, fault, need and other circumstances in dividing the pot.
In equitable distribution states, judges have tended to mandate a 50-50 split only if the assets are worth less than $10 million to $15 million. Anything beyond that goes to the breadwinner, usually the husband.
Courts have differed on whether to divide assets that were accumulated during a marriage but with value that will be realized in the future. The New York State Court of Appeals recently reversed a lower court's conclusion that stock options granted during a marriage are entirely marital property, calling for a time-based formula to determine who is entitled to what. The ruling agreed with an influential decision by the Colorado Supreme Court, which held that options granted during a marriage for past service are marital property, while those granted for services after a divorce are not.
Mrs. Wendt recently started the Foundation for Equality in Marriage to advocate that marriage is a partnership of equals. Through it, she hopes to make the case that society should view both monetary and nonmonetary contributions to a marriage with equal weight. In a statement issued before the ruling, Mrs. Wendt said, "My new career will be devoted to raising these topics and convincing the courts to examine the value of the parent's love versus a spouse's paycheck."

U.N. Forces To Leave Haiti
When the 1,400 Canadian and Pakistani peacekeepers who are the last remnants of the United Nations military force in Haiti begin withdrawing this week, they will be leaving behind a country nearly as poor, prostrate and paralyzed as when they stepped in to help. A political impasse means no budget can be passed, and as a result, the decay of infrastructure is accelerating and half the population is jobless. A1

British diplomats met with Chinese officials in Beijing this week, for the first time since Britain returned Hong Kong to China, and raised issues of democracy and human rights. HEADLINE: For Europe, Greenhouse-Gas Issue Is How Much to Cut

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany

 BODY:
High-pressure steam heat has always been the life-force of BASF A.G.'s giant chemical complex here, where one street is named Ammonia and another is named after a catastrophic explosion that killed scores of workers in the 1920's.
The old power plant still burns coal by the bargeload, pumping high-pressure steam to heat reactions for making plastics and fibers and spewing about four million tons of "greenhouse" gases into the atmosphere every year. Until recently, this complex burned so much coal that the company owned its own mines. 
 Yet as American and European negotiators battle in Kyoto, Japan, over a proposed treaty to reduce the output of greenhouse gases implicated in global warming, this complex marks a fairly typical example of how the two sides often seem to be on different planets.
While American industry has warned that mandatory reductions would lead to factory shutdowns and hundreds of thousands of lost jobs, BASF executives say they are not worried.
Regardless of what is decided in Kyoto, BASF executives predict, this complex will emit 25 percent less carbon dioxide in the year 2000 than it did in 1990, well ahead of the ambitious goals advocated by the European Union. "The goals are absolutely achievable," said Max Dietrich Kley, BASF's managing director in charge of financial affairs.
Europe already releases less than half the volume per person of greenhouse gases as the United States. And it is urging a 15 percent cut in the industrialized world's discharges from 1990 levels, compared to the Clinton Administration's call for "stabilizing" emissions at those rates.
Compared to American business groups, European industry has been more receptive to the costly cleanup. Manufacturing groups are pursuing their own ambitious clean-air commitments. The debate here is not about whether to make steep reductions in carbon dioxide output, but how steep those reductions should be.
By any measure, Europe will have a hard time meeting its own ambitious goals. Pollution from cars and trucks is soaring, as traffic volume increases far more rapidly than automobile efficiency. Manufacturing executives warn that even big improvements in efficiency will be diluted by growth in overall production. And European industry has been fighting various proposals for stiff new "carbon" taxes that are tied to the use of fossil fuels. Thus far they have not gone anywhere.
"We are very skeptical about the European goals," said Joachim Hein, head of environmental policy at the German Federation of Industry, which has pledged steep voluntary reductions. "It's easy to put more burdens on industry, but the problem is much more multi-faceted than that. What we are saying is that industry will do its best."
Critics note that Europe has benefited from a few one-time historical events. The reunification of Germany in 1990 led to a huge reduction in emissions, because the former East Germany's bankrupt and filthy factories and power plants were quickly demolished. Between 1990 and 1995, carbon dioxide output in eastern Germany plunged by nearly half, to 172 million tons from 305 million.
Britain got a similar boost when the Government abandoned protections for domestic coal producers, which sparked a rapid shift to cleaner natural gas.
Part of what makes Europe look "greener," moreover, is nuclear power, considered an environmental villain in North America. Nuclear power supplies 75 percent of the electricity in France, 50 percent in Sweden and 30 percent in Germany, compared with 20 percent in the United States.
As Europe's economy picks up, some energy-conservation projections are already falling by the wayside. The Netherlands Federation of Industry, for example, committed itself to improve energy efficiency by 2 percent a year. But Dutch carbon dioxide emissions actually grew slightly last year, largely because of increased economic growth.
"What we have done so far is follow a 'no-regrets' policy," said Wiel Klerken, director of environmental issues at the Dutch trade association. "In other words, these are measures that are good anyway, even if there was not a CO2 problem, because you save money. But when you come to 15 percent reductions, you come into the area of 'regrets policy,' and so we think the current goals are too ambitious."
Nor have European countries entirely figured out how to distribute the burden of making changes. Under the European Union's so-called "bubble" concept, Germany agreed to assume a huge share of the total European burden -- a 25 percent cut in emissions by 2010. The bargain would allow poorer countries like Portugal and Ireland to increase emissions as much as 30 percent.
The problem is that even if each country met its obligations, which is far from assured, emissions of greenhouse gases across Europe would fall by only 10 percent, and national leaders would still need to search for more cuts.
By any measure, the efforts within Europe far outpace anything even contemplated in the United States. The German Federation of Industry, the umbrella association that covers manufacturers of everything from cars to steel to chemicals, recently released audited results showing a 20 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions since 1990.
But those gains are in danger of being undermined by some of the same trends as in the United States: faster growth in manufacturing and an intensified love affair with cars. Officials at the German industrial federation emphasize that the demolition of old East German factories and power plants is complete. And while existing factories will inevitably become more efficient, those advances will also be diluted by continued growth in production.
Pollution from cars and trucks is even more threatening. While cars are generally much smaller than those in the United States, they are getting bigger, heavier and more numerous. The number of privately owned cars in the former East Germany is expected to double between 1990 and 2005, and the number of commercial vehicles to increase six-fold in the same period.
Car and truck traffic is already the second-biggest source of carbon dioxide after power plants in the European Union, and officials predict traffic-related emissions will soar 39 percent by the year 2010 if current policies remain in place.
Yet thus far, European Union proposals for "carbon taxes" on gasoline have gone nowhere, and many experts worry that introducing them would jeopardize national competitiveness if other industrial countries refuse to follow suit.
To some extent, European countries are victims of their own energy thrift. Energy prices here are far higher than those in the United States, and mandatory conservation measures are far more widespread. That makes further choices more difficult and more expensive.
Buildings, for example, are already being constructed according to far stricter energy-efficiency standards than in the United States. The next big round of improvements can only come from renovating old buildings -- an expensive job that governments cannot simply order property owners to carry out.
"Buildings will be a major challenge," said Alfred Voss, head of the Institute for Energy Economics and Rational Energy Use at the University of Stuttgart. Homeowners often have little incentive to invest in more efficient boilers or thermal windows, because the costs are high and the payoff can take years. Commercial landlords are often resistant as well, especially if tenants pick up the costs of heating and electricity.
Europe has nothing to apologize to the rest of the world about, of course. Compared with efforts being made almost anywhere else, European companies are models of environmental enlightenment.
The biggest single element reducing carbon dioxide emissions here in Ludwigshafen, for example, is a one-month-old "co-generation" plant that produces both electricity and high-pressure steam heat. It will burn natural gas, which emits one-half as much carbon-dioxide as a coal-fired power plant, to produce all the steam heat that BASF needs. Excess steam pressure will be used to run electric turbines. BASF can buy whatever electricity it wants, and the rest will be fed into the public electricity grid. Overall, company executives say, the new plant produces heat and electricity at about 88 percent efficiency, more than double that of the old coal plant.
Other co-generation ventures are underway elsewhere. Hoechst A.G., the chemical and pharmaceutical conglomerate, is underwriting an 800-megawatt plant in Frankfurt.
BASF is also systematically slashed its reliance on fossil fuels by re-cycling heat from one process to another. The complex here at Ludwigshafen relies on coal or gas for only 25 percent of the energy it uses, down from 75 percent 20 years ago. And deeper reductions are on the way. The company's newest plant, in Antwerp, relies on fossil fuels for only 5 percent of its total energy use.
BASF is not just trying to be a good world citizen. Its main motivation is to save money -- and in that, it exemplifies Europe's pervasive culture of energy conservation.
German energy prices are among the highest in the world, in part because the Government protected domestic coal producers for decades. European gasoline costs between $3 and $4 a gallon, roughly three times higher than American prices. Yet, the political debate is not whether to lower the huge fuel taxes that are responsible, but whether to raise them.
Electricity and heat costs are often higher, especially in countries like Germany that have been protecting domestic coal producers. For that reason, few protest the stringent energy-efficiency standards for new buildings here in Germany. Also largely for that reason, air conditioning is almost non-existent in homes and is absent from many office buildings. Lights in public hallways are designed to switch off when people leave. And thanks in part to shorter distances within Europe, trains remain a far more important mode of passenger transportation than airplanes, which consume much more energy.
Political support for deep reductions in greenhouse emissions has been strong across Europe. Even Great Britain, which often displays American-style hostility to regulation, has supported tough action on greenhouse gases under both Conservative and Labor governments.
"In Europe, there is a perception that energy is expensive and will continue to be expensive in the future, while Americans have a perception that energy is cheap and will continue to be cheap," said Lee Solsbery, director of energy and environmental issues at the International Energy Agency in Paris.
The key challenge, said Professor Voss of the University of Stuttgart, will be to come up with policies that promote deeper reductions and yet do not jeopardize economic growth. "If you are going to make real progress, you have to treat economic and environmental goals. The danger is that people will not do that, which could mean that you reach neither goal."

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 562 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
U.S. Banks Still Face Risk, But Bailout Eases Pressure

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
South Korea's rescue package orchestrated by the International Monetary Fund removes an enormous weight from some of the largest American banks, which could have suffered heavy losses if borrowers had failed to repay loans.
But it is premature to consider the banks protected from the economic turmoil in Asia, particularly with serious issues unresolved in Japan. 
 "The I.M.F. package plugs one of the holes in the dam, but it doesn't mean the pressure on the dam has completely ebbed," said Gene Frieda, an analyst with the Institute for Development of Economic Analysis in New York, which advises financial institutions. "A bailout is not a bailout if they don't implement the reforms that go along with it."
Mr. Frieda said that the bailout, which now totals $57 billion, might not be enough to repair the financial damage in South Korea and that tens of billions of dollars in more aid might be needed. Nonetheless, the agreement offered a strong vote of confidence in the South Korean economy and touched off a sharp rally in some large bank stocks yesterday.
"I think it's a benefit that the South Koreans are doing this because it contains the financial epidemic," said Raphael Soifer, a bank analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
United States banks have $20.2 billion worth of "cross border" exposure to South Korea, which includes loans, currency transactions and derivatives contracts, according to figures compiled by the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Counsel, a group comprising the largest United States banking regulators. The largest piece of that belongs to the six huge money-center banks, which jointly carry about $14.5 billion in cross-border exposure: the Chase Manhattan Corporation, Citicorp, the BankAmerica Corporation, J. P. Morgan & Company, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the First Chicago NBD Corporation.
Citicorp and BankAmerica, respectively, have $2.3 billion and $3.2 billion in cross-border exposure, but none of the others offered similar detail. Chase Manhattan's exposure is at least as large as BankAmerica's, while First Chicago's is much less, according to people close to the banks.
The six big banks declined to comment or said appropriate executives were unavailable to comment on the I.M.F. agreement.
Mr. Soifer said that even with the bailout package, some of the big banks might be forced to write off bad loans. When Latin American countries suffered a debt crisis in the 1980's, United States banks wrote off as much as 35 percent of their loans after debt was restructured.
But the vast majority of restructured debt in Latin America was issued by local governments, whereas much of the South Korean debt is corporate and therefore may be likelier to be repaid.
Indeed, some analysts think few, if any, American banks will face write-offs in South Korea.
"The fact of the bailout would suggest that all of these credits aren't as bad as they could have been," said David Berry, a bank analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. "I don't think the banks will have to write off anything."
Mr. Berry said that except for Citicorp, the big banks had less than 10 percent of their assets in Asia. He said that Citicorp had 20 percent there but that fears about its exposure were overblown, partly because Asia's crisis is far less severe than the Latin American crisis.

HEADLINE: Rights Group Assails U.S. on Land Mines and Ties With China

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration was accused of arrogance and "active obstruction" today in its policies toward international human rights in the annual report of Human Rights Watch.
In a survey of 65 nations, the United States Government received some particularly strong criticism from the private human rights group on issues ranging from the global attempt to destroy land mines to the interplay of economic and human rights values in relations with China. 
 "Many Western countries seemed more concerned with striking business deals than protecting human rights," Kenneth Roth, executive director of the group, declared in making public the 465-page survey of government repression in the world. "The fundamental principle that human rights apply to all nations without exception -- the universality of human rights -- came under sustained attack in 1997."
He called for an end to "hostage politique" in China relations: "bargaining for the release of single individuals without changing the underlying structure that allows the Chinese Government to detain thousands of others in jail and to make new arrests."
Human Rights Watch said the year was also notable for the emergence of a fresh twist on repression in Central Africa with the slogan of "African solutions to African problems" used as a "thin cover" for abusing citizens.
Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Congo (the former Zaire) were singled out, with European and North American governments accused of being eager to build ties with a new generation of African leaders who allegedly fail to rein in their security forces' resort to repression.
In addition, the group described the United Nations Commission on Human Rights as "increasingly crippled by its own indifference to the human rights record of its membership." This is a "charade," Mr. Roth said, that has left the United Nations "enfeebled" in defending human rights as an issue that this year cost the lives of 15 rights monitors, all but one of them perishing in either Colombia or Rwanda.
The criticism of the Clinton Administration was focused on its refusal to sign the treaty banning land mines and its reservations toward plans for an International Criminal Court and the proposed world ban on "child soldiers" below the age of 18.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, described as "obviously ridiculous" the charge that the Government "actively obstructed" any move to strengthen the International Criminal Court in its proposed role of deterring despots. He also said there was "no question" the United States was a world leader in fighting the land mine problem, despite some reservations about the new treaty.
"I think that if you look around the world and you ask the people of the world which nation they look to as the beacon for human rights, democracy and freedom, there's no question the answer will be the United States," Mr. Rubin said.
But Mr. Roth contended there was "a troubling arrogance" in Washington toward international human rights law, with the Government wary of treaty provisions that might touch on domestic rights abuses.
On China, he said Beijing was the greatest beneficiary of "selective commitment" to human rights by world powers eying the huge China market.

HEADLINE: Spouses as Shareholders

 BODY:
Lorna Wendt did not get 50 percent of the assets in her marriage to Gary Wendt, chief executive of GE Capital Corporation, which she argued was as much economic enterprise as marital relationship. But she did not do badly either. A Connecticut judge awarded Mrs. Wendt a settlement worth $20 million or more from a family fortune that her experts say is worth at least $100 million. The case raises the question of what a marital partnership means.
The Wendts represent a new corporate elite that now enjoys a level of personal wealth unimaginable in decades past, much of it in stock options, pensions and other forms of deferred compensation. Some of the complexity of the Wendt case revolves around dividing these non-cash assets. But that issue is not novel, and courts routinely place values on future pension benefits and even professional degrees for property division purposes. 
 The crux of the case was about how to apportion success. Mrs. Wendt maintained that her 31-year performance as corporate wife -- raising two children, maintaining a gracious home, entertaining Mr. Wendt's business associates -- contributed to a joint economic operation that entitled her to a 50-50 split of the assets.
Some legal experts say that Mrs. Wendt would have gotten half the assets if the family fortune were, say, $5 million. That is because divorce settlements are often intended to provide non-working spouses with sufficient financial resources to live in their accustomed manner.
The size of the Wendt estate makes that worry unimportant. Though less than half the estate, $20 million is a grand sum. But as a matter of principle, should she be entitled to half the marital property? In the 11 community-property states, such as California, the answer is yes. But the law in Connecticut, like New York, calls for "equitable distribution" of assets, a standard that allows a judge to weigh individual needs, the length of the marriage and contributions made during the marriage.
Artists and professional athletes, for example, can argue that their earning power is based on unique talents that have nothing to do with their marriages. Some wage earners might even argue that stay-at-home spouses too shy to socialize were actually a drag on their financial well-being. Mr. Wendt simply argued that Mrs. Wendt was not responsible for his business success. Yet her presence must have affected his life and business performance to some degree. The judge's award recognizes that contribution.

HEADLINE: Productivity Strong, Although Revised

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Worker productivity during the third quarter grew more slowly than previously estimated but still increased at the best rate in five years, the Labor Department said today.
Productivity -- a measure of the time, effort and cost of providing goods and services -- rose at an annual rate of 4.1 percent. That was down from the estimate on Nov. 13 of 4.5 percent but was the highest rate since the 1992 fourth quarter. 
 In the second quarter, productivity rose at a 2.4 percent pace.
Today's report showed that unit labor costs fell two-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, compared with the initial estimate of three-tenths of 1 percent. Hourly wages, adjusted for inflation, rose 1.9 percent, down from the initial estimate of 2.1 percent. Hours worked fell one-tenth of 1 percent, unchanged from the initial estimate.
Separately, the Labor Department said that the number of first-time claims filed for state unemployment benefits fell by 3,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 303,000. The drop was the second consecutive weekly decline.
The four-week average, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, fell to 314,000 last week from 317,250 the previous week.
