HEADLINE: Memo From Moscow;
When Yeltsin Talks, Nobody Listens (Aides Hope)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 4

 BODY:
First, he named Japan as one of the world's nuclear superpowers. The Japanese have no nukes. Then he stunned his aides at a meeting in Stockholm by announcing -- without a word to any of them -- that Russia would disarm unilaterally. There are no such plans.
Then, as his senior generals gasped, President Boris N. Yeltsin told an astonished crowd this week that he would cut Russian troop strength in the Baltic region by 40 percent. That was a few hours after he confused Norway with Sweden when talking about a major oil deal that Russia is desperate to conclude. 
 His press secretary and defense chief spent the rest of the day issuing urgent denials of almost everything Mr. Yeltsin had said.
"We don't take what he says all that seriously," a senior American diplomatic official conceded today, after the latest round of public gaffes. "We have come to learn that lots of times he just says what's on his mind at the moment. And his mind changes rather quickly."
It is normal for people under pressure to make mistakes. But with Mr. Yeltsin there is a growing feeling here that perhaps it has become a little too normal.
And Mr. Yeltsin is not any old leader: he runs one of the biggest nuclear powers on earth. And he runs it like a semi-democratic czar. With no legislature that can really challenge him, he rules essentially by decree.
There is no apparent successor to the President, who is 66. Whatever movement Russia has made toward democracy and a free market -- and that progress is debated always -- Mr. Yeltsin remains enigmatic, inconsistent, contradictory and overwhelmingly powerful.
"He is like a little boy," said Dmitri V. Trenin, a military specialist based here for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
"He always wants to stun the world, attract the most attention. He will say anything to get attention. And when he speaks like this, peopledo listen."
The Swedes certainly did, although perhaps not the way a publicist would want. The day Mr. Yeltsin got to Stockholm, the leading Swedish newspaper, Aftonbladet, felt compelled to announce the arrival of the Russian delegation with the headline "Moscow Circus Arrives in Provinces." And not without reason.
After all, this is a President who just this year told a captivated world at a NATO summit meeting that he would remove nuclear warheads from Russian missiles. No, he didn't mean that.
In Ukraine this year, Mr. Yeltsin made a big gesture of removing sales taxes between the Slavic states whose people are friendly but whose Governments are often at odds. Mr. Yeltsin's Finance Ministry -- already under severe international pressure to collect more taxes and become more fiscally responsible -- went absolutely nuts over that one.
"Something seems to happen to him when he goes overseas," said Pavel Voshchanov, one of Mr. Yeltsin's more critical former press secretaries. "He loses control there. It has always been the case. When he is here he is shown just as Mao was with his own people. Doors open, he comes out, says something that is rehearsed and then he leaves. A Czar need do no more. But in other countries they have other rules. It can't be good for Russia to see him this way."
Actually, most people here don't seem to blame Mr. Yeltsin for his gaffes. Perhaps that is because there is so much else to blame him for. A year ago he was so sick -- many thought near death -- that his recovery had been seen with great relief in Russia and in the West. For a while.
But today, the country is buffeted by a growing financial crisis. His Western-oriented reform leader, Anatoly B. Chubais, has been tainted as corrupt and partisan. Foreign investors are pulling their money out of the market -- mostly in response to fears about emerging markets in Asia that have nothing to do with Russia -- but it has still crippled the treasury. An economy that seemed on the verge of a rebound once again seems as if it might plummet.
"How long do we need it?" Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, Mr. Yeltsin's former national security adviser and now an archenemy, asked today. "How long do we need such a man sending us toward our doom before he finally resigns?"
It is a question that few others have asked. It is not that Mr. Yeltsin is so popular -- he is deeply unpopular according to every poll taken in the last year. Yet, few alternatives to the President have emerged during his six years in power -- in part, of course, because he has done all he could to defeat opposition voices.
Mr. Yeltsin does not appear to be ill, and his aides say he has greatly cut back on drinking since his heart bypass operation a year ago.
Much of what he said this week, in fact, means nothing. A 40 percent reduction in the army is significant. But earlier this year he called for such a cut, campaigned for it on radio, and insisted that it begin at once.
"Don't go trying to figure him out," said Vera Kuznetsova, a political reporter for Izvestia who covers Mr. Yeltsin and has written about him for years. "Nobody ever has. Even his daughter had no idea what he was talking about in Sweden."
Mr. Yeltsin's daughter Tatanya Dyachenko is one of his chief aides.
Early in Mr. Yeltsin's second term, his press secretary, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, expounded grandly on plans for the President to travel to many parts of the world he had never seen. South America was mentioned; more trips to the United States and Canada were considered. Africa and the Middle East were, too.
Mr. Yastrzhembsky was mute this week about Mr. Yeltsin's future travel plans. Looking like a man who just wanted to get his President home while he still had his feet out of his mouth, Mr. Yastrzhembsky could only shake his head and laugh.
"The President has opened a new window for journalists on the diplomatic negotiating process," he said. "Now I have to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The pomp of a state visit called for Boris Yeltsin to ride by carriage to Stockholm's Royal Palace on Tuesday. But the Russian leader's gaffes prompted a Swedish newspaper to liken his visit to one by the Moscow Circus. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Another Year, Another Bundle;
Billions in Bonuses Are Expected to Fall on Wall Street

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
As the year draws to a close, Christmas and Hanukkah do not seem to be foremost in the thoughts of people on Wall Street. They are jousting over money, their own money.
For December is the time when most firms and big money managers bestow the bonuses that make up the bulk of their senior executives' compensation -- often 90 percent or more. 
 And this bonus season promises to be a rich one. With sharply rising stock markets and hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of takeovers, 1997 has been one of the most prosperous years ever on Wall Street, even compared with the two fat years that preceded it.
At Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm's 190 partners will make a minimum of about $4 million each, with star performers and top managers snagging as much as $25 million, according to recruiting specialists who often work with the firm's executives. On Goldman's next layer, some 215 managing directors will take home an average of $1.5 million apiece, while the rest of the payroll, more than 10,000 other employees, must content themselves with comparative pennies for their bonuses, anywhere from a few thousand dollars to perhaps $100,000 or so. Goldman would not comment on compensation but confirmed the number of employees and managing directors.
Over all, bonuses for Wall Street's top bankers and traders are expected to rise an average of 20 percent to 30 percent, senior bankers and recruitment consultants say. Top executives with skills in high demand -- like equity analysts, merger bankers, high-yield-bond specialists, managers of new stock offerings and technology gurus -- may do even better.
P. Clarke Murphy of Russell Reynolds Associates, executive recruiters, said bonus increases for bankers who manage "products like high-yield bonds will be in excess of 50 percent." Their average bonus may jump to perhaps $1.5 million from $1 million a year ago -- a rise, in Wall Street slang, to "a bar and a half" from "a bar."
The common wisdom on Wall Street is that more than 1,000 people in the business will get bonuses of more than $1 million this year.
On Wall Street's upper tier, base pay is almost an afterthought -- perhaps $200,000 a year; the real money is in bonuses. And the firms expected to pay out the biggest ones are those that are particularly successful in areas now in vogue. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette; Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover are all well known, as is Goldman, for their equity analysis, merger advice, stock offerings and junk-bond businesses.
In the days before Christmas, Donaldson -- whose profits for the first three quarters exceeded its profits for all of 1996 -- is expected to inform its executives of bonus increases of 25 percent or more, bankers and recruiters say. Joe L. Roby, the president and chief operating officer, made a total of $33.2 million last year, although Donaldson officers are quick to point out that some of this represented the receipt of restricted stock accumulated in earlier years.
Of course, some professionals in the securities industry will get small bonuses, or none at all. These are the unlucky executives in sectors that have fared poorly in recent months -- emerging markets, say, or Asian equities. Executives at Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., a Hong Kong investment bank, for example, expect little or no bonus after the debacle in Asian markets that prompted the bank to dismiss 275 of its workers in late November, just days after Zurich Group, the big Swiss insurer, stepped in to buy 24.1 percent of the firm for about $200 million.
At the other end of the bonus spectrum, successful managers at hedge funds -- those little-regulated pools of investment capital like Tiger Management and the Quantum Fund and other investments managed by George Soros -- will outdo even their successful Wall Street colleagues. These funds, named for the hedging techniques they use to maximize returns, do not have all the considerable operating expenses of a huge Wall Street firm, where a year's bill for computer hardware and software alone can run to hundreds of millions of dollars.
"The big hedge funds will dwarf the main Wall Street firms," said Alan M. Johnson, a recruitment and pay consultant, who added that Julian H. Robertson Jr., the proprietor of Tiger, "must be making $300 million or $400 million this year." (A Robertson spokesman declined to comment.)
The Government certainly expects a bonanza. Using tax prepayments and other data, the office of the New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, predicts that the city's securities industry will increase bonus payments by 15 percent over last year, to a total of about $10.8 billion. Past predictions from the comptroller's office have been conservative; last year, it forecast a 30 percent increase, while bonuses actually ballooned by more than 50 percent over 1995.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. McCall welcomed the prospective income for the local economy, but cautioned that New York could not count on such bounty, which could disappear as soon as Wall Street had a bad year.
The next few weeks will tell how much that income will be this year. In December, most of the country's biggest securities firms tell their executives what their 1997 bonuses will be. Bonus checks do not generally go out, though, until late in the month, or even in January. Merrill Lynch tells its executives in the last week of January.
Mergers like the recently completed union of Salomon and Smith Barney make the bonus round trickier than usual. Wall Street bosses have to reconcile the different cultures and payment practices of different firms, always aware that competitors and headhunters hover nearby, eager to try to tempt away the talented with better offers.
That strategy apparently worked for Lehman, which just hired Diane B. Glossman and Michael Plodwick, both well-regarded Salomon bank analysts, despite the high bonuses that Salomon's bosses had promised. Lehman guaranteed the newcomers multiyear pay packages, bankers say, and matched their expected 1997 bonuses.
Not everyone on Wall Street benefits from all this largess. Generally, it is only senior executives, the top caste in Wall Street's hierarchy, who get the outsize checks. At some firms, junior employees get annual bonus payments out of a pool, but the amount is rarely more than 15 percent or 20 percent of their salary.
The vast sums that the bosses pocket certainly help to stoke the markets for sleek cars, fancy homes and other goodies that always tempt the rich. "The joke is you can't buy much of a house in Greenwich for $3 million," said Mr. Johnson, the recruitment consultant. "I guess by the end of this year it will be $4.5 million." Mr. Johnson's firm, Johnson Associates Inc., gives compensation advice to financial powerhouses like Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman, Sachs and J. P. Morgan.
Now, though, Wall Streeters are generally much less ostentatious with their windfalls than they were in the 1980's. These days they tend to stash their bonuses with money managers, reminding themselves that these good years may not last much longer -- or perhaps that they may not be able to stand the pace too many more years.
Of course, more money means more quarreling, seasoned Wall Streeters warn.
"Relatively few people are made very happy, even if their bonuses are very large," said Roy C. Smith, a former partner at Goldman, Sachs who now teaches at New York University's Stern School of Business. Describing bonus time as "one of the least pleasant parts of the business," Mr. Smith said it takes up "about two months of management time, and is probably more comparable to dealing with free agents in athletics."
It is hard to feel sorry for Wall Street's bonus babies. Moreover, the increasing proportions of Wall Street firms' net revenues that go to pay -- some 50 to 60 percent -- "makes it extremely difficult to produce acceptable returns on capital in this business," Mr. Smith said.
It has been known to baffle those outside Wall Street. Some of the nation's most successful executives, like Warren E. Buffett, the renowned Omaha investor, and John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the General Electric Company, have left Wall Street shaking their heads at the way top executives insist on monumental bonuses. Mr. Buffett sold his controlling stake in Salomon this year after several unsuccessful attempts to rein in pay, and Mr. Welch sold most of the assets of G.E.'s Kidder, Peabody subsidiary to Paine Webber in 1994.
"The amounts now have grown so staggering that some firms may just get forced out of the business," Mr. Johnson said. He expects that foreign firms, following the lead of Barclays and NatWest of Britain, which are selling chunks of their investment banking businesses, will continue to leave Wall Street as compensation keeps soaring.
Wall Street has also taken to awarding executives, as part of their bonuses, huge amounts of stock options and restricted stock -- often representing more than half their total pay. On the surface, this is an effort to align the interests of management more closely with those of shareholders. The trouble is, critics contend, so much profit is paid out that there is precious little left for the outside stockholder. "Many of these formulas will not lead to long-term profitability," Mr. Johnson said.
One early hint of the richness of this year's bonus round came from the Bear Stearns Companies, which gives out its bonuses after the end of its fiscal year in June. This summer, it paid $87 million to its top five officers, with the chief executive, James E. Cayne, getting $23.2 million, more than half of it in restricted stock. Alan C. Greenberg, the chairman, got $20.7 million, including $14 million in cash.
In truth, the bonus game has a lot of theater to it. Executives tend to lobby their bosses furiously in the weeks before they are told the magic numbers.
"There's a certain animal character to this," said Mr. Smith, who used to run Goldman's investment banking business in Europe. "You have to growl and roar and be fierce."
The perceived need to pay ever-larger bonuses to superstars means there is greater pressure on less-stellar executives. Over the last decade, some firms have become more aggressive at this. Goldman, for example, has made partners "go limited" and has even forced a few out of the partnership. Goldman spokesmen, who refuse to discuss specific cases, tend to explain such moves as changes in partners' personal priorities.
In the last couple of years, Ernest S. Liu and Carl G. Palmstierna, among others, stepped down from Goldman partnerships yet remained at the firm, Goldman colleagues said. They added that Mr. Liu wanted a less pressured life. An assistant at Mr. Palmstierna's old office at Goldman said he had left the company but could not say where he could be reached.
"This has been going on a while," one senior Goldman alumnus said. "In part it's a natural pruning of the bush."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Market Brings a Lift to a Town-House Development in Queens

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A town-house community in an affluent section of Queens that struggled to get started during the recession has received a lift from New York City's strengthening housing market.
Six years ago, there were no buyers for the first units in the community, Oak Park at Douglaston, and the recession dried up the financing to complete the project. 
 Now, all 121 of the one-, two- and three-bedroom homes in the project's first phase have been built and sold, and the developer has started work on 92 units in the project's second phase. Sales prices have increased four times since 1995: they range from $215,000 to $415,000 for the 1,137- to 2,281-square-foot units, said John P. McInerney, vice president at the DeMatteis Organizations, the company based in Uniondale, N.Y., that is developing the project on Douglaston Parkway, just south of 244th Street.
Real estate experts say that the project's changing fortunes demonstrate how the housing markets around New York City have improved in a sort of rolling wave that started in Manhattan and then spread to other boroughs.
"It is definitely good news," Rita E. Scheiner, president of the Oak Park condominium board, said. "All homeowners are happy to see that the value of their property is increasing."
The improvement in the housing market began with the rental market, said Jeffrey E. Levine, a past president of the Queens County Builders and Contractors Association. Rents increased, he said, and that, in turn, set the stage for new rental construction. But higher rents also provided people with an incentive to buy, said Mr. Levine, who also heads his own development company in Douglaston.
Now sales prices are also rising. Through September, the average sales price for existing single-family detached homes in Douglaston was $347,200, up from $283,400 in the same period last year. In all of Queens, the average sales price of one-family homes, including town houses, was $173,881 as of the third quarter, up from $164,860 from the same time last year, according to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island.
Getting Oak Park to this point, however, was a long, bumpy journey. The project took shape on land that was part of a 27 1/2-acre tract formerly occupied by Cathedral College of the Immaculate Conception, a four-year liberal arts school that trained men for the priesthood. The school closed in 1988 because of declining enrollment and the owner, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, sold the 14 1/2 undeveloped acres of the campus for $10 million to the DeMatteis Organizations the same year.
The money from the sale enabled the diocese to renovate the college's main building, a 250,000-square-foot center for academics, administration and student housing, into a diocesan center, said the Rev. Michael J. Hardiman, the center's director. The center includes office space for the diocese, a home for retired priests and a dormitory for students studying for the priesthood. Those students attend St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, for their academic training and then go on to the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception in Huntington, N.Y.
DeMatteis, judging the site's setting well suited for housing, spent two years gaining local approvals for its town-house project.
The development is close to the Douglaston Golf Course, Alley Pond Park and Little Neck Bay. The Cross Island and Grand Central Parkways and the Long Island Expressway also are nearby.
But by the middle of 1991, when the first 40 units were complete, the recession had driven most buyers away, leaving the units to languish on the market unsold. At the same time, Crossland Savings Bank, which held a construction loan on the project, failed and was taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The following year, the DeMatteis Organizations bought the mortgage on the Oak Park site, as well as on two undeveloped parcels elsewhere on Long Island, for $20 million. To stimulate sales, Mr. McInerney said, his company reduced the asking prices of the town houses by up to 20 percent, to $194,000 for the smallest unit, and $310,000 for the largest. It also offered other incentives, like one year of free maintenance, and sold all 40 units by 1993.
In 1995, as the housing market stirred back to life, he said, his company secured financing from Grand Pacific Finance Corporation in Flushing. It built the remaining 81 units in the first phase and started construction on the 92 in the second phase last April. Contracts have been signed on 56 units since May.
The design of the project has remained relatively unchanged. But its scale was reduced by 10 units in the second phase to its current size to make room for a second recreational area, including an outdoor pool, a children's play area and a clubhouse.
The new houses, like the existing ones, are to be traditional in design and built in clusters, with 8 to 16 units each. Three models, from single-story to three-story units, are being offered and most will have a one- or two-car garage. The monthly maintenance fee ranges from $195 to $391, and there is a New York City tax abatement on property taxes for the first 11 years: with the abatement, for example, taxes on a one-bedroom unit are $408 a year; without the abatement it would be $1,620 a year.
Mr. McInerney said buyers will start moving into the first 10 homes of the second phase in June, with all 92 units expected to be ready for occupancy by the spring of 1999.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Encouraged by the housing market, the developers of Oak Park at Douglaston have begun a second phase in the town-house community. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In West Bank, 'Time' for Settlements Is Clearly Not 'Out'

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: OFRA, West Bank, Dec. 4

 BODY:
If there is any serious talk of a "timeout" in settlement construction, it sure hasn't reached Ofra. On one hillside, 27 houses stand in various stages of completion, while bulldozers shift boulders on another hill to make room for 24 more.
Outside their settlement, Ofra residents have moved mobile homes onto another hilltop. Despite a national strike that paralyzed all such work elsewhere in Israel, private electricians were busy stringing wire to the outpost. 
 Similar activity can be seen in many other settlements, where construction that was frozen under the former Labor Government has resumed under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's right-wing coalition.
According to Peace Now, a left-wing Israeli organization that closely monitors settlement activity, 4,714 housing units are now under construction in 61 of the 140 West Bank settlements. The organization also said the Government had put out tenders for the construction of 26 housing units in a small Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip, marking the first construction there since the last Likud Government in 1992.
"Time out?" declared Yona Hoffman, the head of the 1,860-member Jewish settlement five miles northeast of Ramallah, as talk turned to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's suggestion that Israel take a pause in settlement construction to break the deadlock in peace negotiations with the Palestinians. "It would be a disaster! Let her freeze construction in her own United States. I sure hope if she demands this, that Bibi will give a good answer."
"Bibi" -- Mr. Netanyahu -- is to meet Ms. Albright on Friday in Paris, where she is likely to press him for progress on the requirements Washington has laid out for resuming the peace talks. They include a "significant and credible" further withdrawal in the West Bank and a timeout in settlement expansion.
On Sunday, the Israeli Cabinet voted to approve a withdrawal in principle, but declared that it would set the time and scope only after Mr. Netanyahu presented a plan for the final agreement in the West Bank.
On the settlements, Mr. Netanyahu has insisted that the construction is only "natural growth," and that no new settlements are being built. The exception is the new Jewish housing project at Har Homa, in southeastern Jerusalem, which is not regarded as a "settlement" by the Government since it does not regard East Jerusalem as occupied territory.
In fact, preparatory work on Har Homa has been completed, and the Government has yet to put out tenders for construction. Some right-wing politicians have asserted that Mr. Netanyahu is deliberately delaying the next stage in a gesture to Ms. Albright, but the Prime Minister has made no such claim.
It is generally accepted among Israelis of both left and right that Mr. Netanyahu is constrained from building settlements by the outcry this would provoke in the West -- not to mention the fury and possibly the violence of the Palestinians, to whom the heavily guarded enclaves of red-roofed houses scattered throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip stand as a permanent reminder of Jewish designs on lands they consider theirs.
But Peace Now recently asserted that the settlers had found a new way to claim territory in the West Bank, by building five new industrial zones deep inside the territory. On the bypass road around Ramallah, near Ofra, bulldozers were working on the first of the zones, and Mossi Raz, the head of the settlement watch team at Peace Now, said that four others already had formal approval, and that one was pending.
Pinchas Wallerstein, head of Yesha, the main settlers' association, said that the zones were projects approved already under Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's Labor Government, and that they would provide work also for Palestinians.
But Mr. Raz argued that the industrial zones were a means of occupying strategic territory without the full Government approval required for a new settlement. "We see the industrial areas as a way to bypass settlement construction," he said.
Khalil Tufakji, head of the geographic department at Orient House, the Palestinian headquarters in East Jerusalem, said, "They build to make facts on the ground."
According to Mr. Tufakji, several settlements, Ofra among them, have quietly planted mobile homes on nearby hilltops to stake out areas that will remain under Israeli jurisdiction in any future deal. The hill seized by the Ofra residents, he said, would move the settlement's boundaries closer to a military listening post, and thus give the settlement added insurance against being isolated or even handed over to Palestinian control.
For the settlers, this "battle of the hills" is an integral part of what they perceive as a sacred struggle against "the Arabs" for the biblical Land of Israel.
"What's the meaning of a 'slow down' in settlement construction -- to clear this land of Jews?" Mr. Wallerstein demanded. "No one talks of freezing construction in Arab villages. They grow, they build up neighborhoods."
On the political front, the settlement debate is mired in endless disputes over legality and history. The settlers insist that most of their current construction was approved under the last Labor Government, and does not violate the Oslo agreements.
That may be so, retort Israelis to the left, but the difference is in strategy and motive. The Labor Government allowed expansion of settlements in three blocks Mr. Rabin regarded as strategic for Israeli security -- one east of Tel Aviv, another around Jerusalem and the third in the Gush Etzion bloc south of Jerusalem. But he froze construction in what he called "political settlements," those whose main evident purpose was to secure West Bank territory.
Mr. Rabin also stripped almost all settlements of special economic status as development areas, which gave settlers various economic benefits including subsidies for housing and education. On Sept. 2, the Government restored most settlements to the status of an "area of national priority."
Another argument against permitting housing construction in the settlements is that there are already enough vacant houses and apartments in the West Bank to absorb natural growth. A United States report last year created a stir with the claim that a quarter of the housing was vacant.
According to Peace Now, the real figure is closer to 12 percent. According to the organization's figures, there are 3,183 vacant housing units in the West Bank, even while 4,714 new ones are being built.
"In 1996, the natural growth was 4,700 births, but the number of settlers increased by 13,000, or about 9.4 percent," Mr. Raz said. "So about two-thirds of the growth was 'unnatural.' We know that 12 percent of the flats are empty. So if they were only worried about natural growth, they could stop building for four years."
Mr. Wallerstein rejected such arguments, noting first that the growth rate was the same under the past Government, and second that the vacancies were not necessarily in settlements where there was a demand for housing, but usually in isolated settlements.
"It's like saying there are vacancies in Utah if you want to live in Manhattan," he said, noting that houses in Ofra, for instance, sold immediately at prices up to $120,000.
But even as he watched the bulldozers and the workers erecting dozens of new houses, Mr. Hoffman, the head of the Ofra settlers, insisted that he was not satisfied with Mr. Netanyahu.
"We expected a Prime Minister openly for settlements, who would build thousands of new units here after four years in which we couldn't build," he said, expressing the universal nostalgia among settlers for the days before 1992 when Ariel Sharon was Housing Minister and lavished vast Government spending on building up the settlements.
The main problem was the American pressure, he insisted. "I hope Netanyahu is strong enough to take the pressure," he said, "but I'm not sure he is."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Executives Upbeat About New Jersey

BYLINE: BY ALAN FEUER 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In a survey released yesterday, small-business owners in New Jersey said they were optimistic about the state economy, with more than half of them saying they expected sales and profits to rise next year.
The results of the survey, conducted for the 39th year in a row by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, a trade group, were compiled from 1,160 responses to questionnaires mailed to more than 15,000 member companies. 
 Seventy-seven percent of the business owners said the state economy is expanding, up from 58 percent last year. Only 9 percent said the state was in a recession, down from 26 percent last year, said Joseph E. Gonzalez, the association's president.
More than a third of the respondents expected that the economy would improve in the first six months of 1998, and about 40 percent said prospects in their own industries should improve. Roughly a third predicted that employment would rise.
The survey also showed concern about the state's increasing labor shortage. "Our member companies reported having the greatest difficulty since 1989 in filling professional, technical, managerial and other high-skilled jobs," Mr. Gonzalez said.
 ALAN FEUER

HEADLINE: Atlantic City and State Battling on Crowded Schools

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3

 BODY:
When H. Benjamin Williams became the Superintendent of Schools here last spring, he expected to contend with crumbling buildings, jam-packed classrooms and some of the lowest-achieving students in New Jersey.
But Mr. Williams said he never imagined that his most formidable problem would be the New Jersey Department of Education. For most of his short tenure, the Superintendent has been battling the State Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, over his plan to put a middle school in a vacant high school building. 
 The state, which over eight years has seized control of schools in Newark, Jersey City and Paterson, has taken preliminary steps toward a takeover of the Atlantic City district, based on its financial problems and low test scores. So Mr. Williams, a former assistant superintendent in Paterson, already faced heavy monitoring, which he said frustrated him.
In an interview this week, Mr. Williams said that the fierce conflict raised important questions not only about state intervention in local affairs, but about the differing interests of the downtrodden residents of Atlantic City and the politicians who want to lure casinos to town. Mr. Williams, who is black, even suggested that the battle was fueled by racism, since Mr. Klagholz and others who have denounced his plan are white.
Mr. Klagholz has denied the allegations of racism, saying that he wants only to make sure that the students are safe and that the financially strapped district does not waste money.
At issue is Mr. Williams's decision to move 1,800 children in fifth through eighth grades to the Albany Avenue School, which has stood empty since a new high school opened three years ago. State education officials initially fought the plan, saying it would be too disruptive and expensive, but then relented just before school began.
But after the school was plagued by violence this fall, Mr. Klagholz again stepped in and ordered Mr. Williams to return the 500 youngest students to their neighborhood elementary schools. In an even more unusual move, the Superintendent refused.
In a hearing scheduled for Friday morning, a Superior Court judge will decide whether to enforce Mr. Klagholz's order to remove fifth-grade students from the Albany Avenue School. Mr. Williams says that if the judge sides with the state, he will appeal to the New Jersey Supreme Court and, if necessary, the United States Supreme Court.
"This district has been subject to a degree of political intrusion that I've never experienced in all my years of public education," said Mr. Williams, who came to Atlantic City last March from Paterson. "What we are seeing played out is a game of power and process."
A spokesman for Mr. Klagholz said that Mr. Williams was the only one playing a game, noting that 150 students at the Albany Avenue School had been suspended and 40 arrested since September.
"We are extremely upset that the Superintendent continues to play Russian roulette with the safety of the Albany Avenue students," the spokesman, Peter Peretzman, said. "His behavior is unconscionable and clearly in this case, he is not abiding by the law."
Mr. Peretzman and other state officials said they never considered the school, a brick behemoth built in 1920, appropriate for young students because of its size and multiple entrances. State officials proposed trailers as a short-term solution to overcrowding since the city is hoping to build six new elementary schools in the next decade. When Mr. Williams refused to use trailers, they gave in to make sure children could start school on time.
But the state did not give in completely, refusing to approve Atlantic City's school construction plans until Mr. Williams closes down the Albany Avenue School. Mr. Klagholz also sent an auditor to monitor the district's spending. That further incensed Mr. Williams, who was already angry that Mr. Klagholz had cut $1.3 million from his 1997-98 budget.
The showdown began in earnest in October, when Mr. Klagholz discovered that Albany Avenue students were being suspended and even arrested almost daily for fighting. The school adopted a strict disciplinary policy and increased security around Halloween. But on the day that state inspectors visited the building to see whether the violence had ebbed, one eight grader slashed another with a box cutter.
Two days later, on Nov. 19, Mr. Klagholz ordered Mr. Williams to send the 500 fifth-graders back to elementary schools by Dec. 1. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman -- who typically is even more loath to interfere in local school districts than Mr. Klagholz -- has publicly urged the Superintendent to follow the order.
Mr. Williams, who has the support of the school board and the leader of the local teachers' union, has repeatedly said that there is more to the drama than meets the eye. He and the school board president, Marven Hill, say that Mayor James F. Whelan and state officials want to get students out of the old high school building so they can sell it to Mirage Resorts, which is building a $750 million casino complex here.
Mayor Whelan said that he did offer the Albany Avenue School to Mirage, which thought it would be an ideal place to train 1,900 Atlantic City residents for jobs at its hotels and casinos. But Richard Bronson, director of Mirage's Atlantic City operations, said the company had no interest in the building as long as it was needed as a school.
"I'll find another facility, it's no big deal," he said. "Atlantic City is not at a loss for having vacant buildings."
But the fact that Mayor Whelan offered the building to casino executives when the city had overcrowded schools suggests that he and other local politicians are more interested in promoting economic development than in improving education, Mr. Williams said. His accusations have touched an especially delicate nerve in some neighborhoods here, where the mostly black residents have long accused the city and the state of putting the casinos' needs ahead of theirs.
"There's thought out there that people don't want housing and schools to be built in Atlantic City, that it should be a resort and not a place for families," Mr. Hill said. "The casinos and the common people can live side by side, but the politicians are making problems."
Adding to the tensions are the community's fears about a possible takeover of the school district. Mr. Williams has said that Mr. Klagholz was fighting his middle school plan to speed up the takeover process, which he and Mr. Hill said they would resist. Many residents of Newark, Paterson and Jersey City have resented state intervention, saying that the state does not understand their schools' needs and rarely seeks their input.
Mr. Williams said in an interview that after spending five years in Paterson's state-operated schools, he believed that takeovers did not work. Mr. Hill said many school officials, parents and teachers resented what they felt was the the arrogance of state officials who thought they knew how to solve Atlantic City's problems. "It's not the monitoring we mind, it's the attitude," Mr. Hill said bitterly. "They're making problems for the children of the Atlantic City, just like they did in Newark and the other places. We feel we are on the right track."
Mr. Peretzman, the Commissioner's spokesman, said that while the school district has proved "unwilling and unable" to improve, there are no plans for a takeover.
Mr. Williams said that dozens of parents and teachers had rallied around him. But a cluster of students waiting for the bus outside the Albany Avenue School today said that fifth-graders did not belong at the school because it was too big and dangerous. They said that fights still broke out daily, that strangers walked in off the street and that older students sneaked to the cavernous basement, where they smoked marijuana and had sex.
"If you bump into someone, they take it the wrong way and get violent," said Marques Johnson, 13, a wide-eyed eighth grader who said his younger sister attended fifth grade at the school. "My grandmother kept my little sister out all week. She didn't want her baby getting hurt."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Koreans Not Rushing to Shake the Hand Holding the Bailout Check

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Even though the United States has pledged $5 billion as part of the International Monetary Fund plan to help South Korea rebuild its economy, many Koreans are not exactly grateful.
Instead, many see the United States as the puppeteer behind the I.M.F., using the international organization to impose conditions that will open South Korean markets and benefit American companies. They see Japan, which is pledging $10 billion, as doing the same thing. 
 "It is very disconcerting that the United States and Japan demanded unbearable market-opening measures as conditions of financial support," Dong-A Ilbo, a daily newspaper, said in an editorial today. "It is not wise for our friendly relations to use such a crisis situation for selfish benefit."
An article in Joongang Ilbo, another major newspaper, was published with the headline "Korean Businesses Revolt Against U.S. Conspiracy to Strip Korean Companies of Power." It said the bailout agreement was designed to disband the big Korean conglomerates, which compete with American and Japanese companies in electronics, automobiles and other industries.
Despite such resentment, the stock market here welcomed the agreement, rising 7 percent and shrugging off, at least for a day, concerns that the rescue will result in slower growth and more corporate failures. The Korean won, which has been in free fall lately, also gained strength against the dollar.
 The stock market continued its rally on Friday, rising an additional 7.56 percent by the midday recess.
The flare-up of anti-Americanism is a potential irritant in the sometimes testy relations between Washington and Seoul. And it is the first challenge for Stephen Bosworth, the new United States Ambassador to South Korea, who arrived here Sunday night, a week earlier than planned, just as Seoul's negotiations with the I.M.F. were entering the final chaotic stages.
A South Korean Government official said, however, that while public sentiment might turn anti-American, relations between the two Governments would not be affected.
Some of the finger-pointing at the United States and Japan is merely an attempt to find a scapegoat for a humbling experience, some analysts say. The bailout is seen here by many as a loss of economic sovereignty -- an emotional issue for Koreans, who have spent much of their history trying to avoid being dominated by bigger powers like Japan and China and who are still smarting from having their country divided after World War II.
Many South Koreans despise the Japanese, their former colonizers, and have an ambivalent attitude toward the United States, which helps protect South Korea from North Korea but sometimes sets the agenda on South Korean foreign policy. And Korea is not alone. Many countries see the I.M.F. as a tool of the United States to spread its free-market philosophy.
The terms of the bailout have still not been made public, and even its overall dimensions are not entirely certain. The South Korean Government said that the deal arranged by the I.M.F. now totaled $57 billion, up from $55 billion, because Italy had agreed to participate and three other countries had increased their pledges.
However, the agreement, which was officially approved by the I.M.F. executive board today, has been widely reported to contain terms that seem to some Koreans to have little to do with rescuing a debt-laden financial system. A ban on the imports of Japanese cars and other products -- which Korea justifies because it has a huge trade deficit with Japan -- is to be lifted, Korean officials said. There is also reportedly a measure to streamline imports of all cars, though an American diplomat here said that he was not aware of any such measure.
In 1996, only 10,000 of the 1.6 million vehicles sold in South Korea were imports, according to the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, a percentage that makes Japan look wide open by comparison.
But a senior United States diplomat said Washington "did not ever put its bilateral trade agenda on the table," though it contributed to the plan as the I.M.F.'s largest shareholder. "We were not bashful about making our view known in specific instances, but this is not a U.S.-designed program," he said.
Parts of the agreement will benefit American and Japanese companies, even if they are primarily designed to help the Korean economy. Stemming the steep slide of the won, for example, would make Korean exports less competitive. Allowing foreign companies to buy Korean financial institutions will inject more capital into the ailing financial system, but it will also help foreign companies expand here. Rumors are already circulating that Citicorp is interested in acquiring a local bank.
Breaking up the close cooperation by the Government, the banks and the industrial conglomerates is necessary because that system led to the investment in unprofitable ventures that contributed to the debt problem. But stemming investment will also help Korea's competitors.
Some United States companies do not support the bailout. Micron Technology Inc., a semiconductor company, argues that American tax dollars should not support Korean chip makers that flood the world with chips, lowering prices and profits.
Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, said he had similar concerns.
"We're not against the bailout," he said. But he added, "We know the bailout must include real obligations to change the way the Koreans are doing business."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton Interview: Taxes, Budget, Rights Nominee

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton conducted today by reporters from The New York Times from a transcript supplied by the White House:
Q. Earlier this week you had a discussion with Chairman Archer, about taxes I presume. Are we going to be hearing something from you about some sort of change, reform, reduction in the tax code, and for what purpose? 
A. He asked me if I would meet with him. I met with him about a year ago, and we talked about his ideas about the tax code. And he wanted to bring a gentleman in who was an expert in, you know, basically his idea that we ought to have some sort of national sales tax. And I said I would be glad to talk to him, and I had a fascinating hour's conversation with him.
I have drawn no conclusion yet about what I would be for, but let me say, my objectives on taxes are -- and my questions about all tax reform is: Is it fair to average American taxpayers? Is it realistic that you can implement the proposal, whatever it is? Will it be good for the economy as a whole? Will it support our continuing growth of our economy? And will it be simpler? Can we do that?
Now, since we've been here, we've done a lot of work to make it easier for people to interact with the tax code. More than half the taxpayers now fill out that simplest little form. Millions of people can file electronically who couldn't before. We've done what we could to really improve the system as it is, based on progressive income taxation.
So at the end of the year, every year, we do this. We're open to new ideas, and I wanted to listen, but I didn't draw any conclusion from it and I haven't reached a decision yet about what, if anything else, I might recommend in this area. . . .
Q. But can we expect to see some form of tax reform or tax relief in the next budget in the State of the Union?
A. No, I wouldn't say -- I don't think I should give you any false expectations there. I can't say yes, I can't say no. I wouldn't rule out the fact that I might find something that I think would work, but I don't have an idea on the griddle as you are doing this interview.
But one thing, let me say, I have a different view about this than some people do. We do not have a surplus now. We do not have a surplus now. We have a deficit now. It's a tiny one, and it's less than 10 percent of what it was when I took office, but the people who say we have a surplus, I think it's very important that we understand what they're saying. They're saying that the deficit has gone down more rapidly than it was predicted to go down when we signed --- when I signed the balanced-budget bill and when it passed back last summer.
Therefore, some people think that we should go back to the curve that we predicted last summer and spend all the money between where we are now and where we were then. I think that is a questionable course. I hope that we can continue to grow at 3 percent a year -- and private sector growth has been over 3.5 percent a year since I've been President. I hope we can continue to do that. But I think that it is not prudent for us to go spending a lot of money that we haven't really realized yet. So I think we have to be very careful -- this so-called spending the surplus -- it is not a surplus that is being spent, it is the difference between the projected deficit line today and the one that existed last summer.
And if we hold tight and save all of that money or most of that money, and show some discipline here, we might get a balanced budget a lot quicker than they thought, and then we can decide what to do. But I think we need to be somewhat careful before we just go spend all this money that hasn't materialized.
Q. Have you had any success in converting anyone in the Senate on Bill Lann Lee?
A. No, but I think it's a real mistake. I think they made a real mistake on that. And I still don't even know -- you know, I've had a pretty good working relationship and a very candid relationship with both Senator Lott and Senator Hatch, and I must say, I'm just -- I'm really disappointed. I just don't -- I just think it was a mistake, and I don't even think it makes political sense for them.
This guy, his life story, his life's work, he made it unambiguously clear that he was going to enforce the law as it is written and interpreted by the Supreme Court; that he would recuse if the specific California issue came up. I mean, this is a -- they just didn't make much of a case for being against this guy. It looked to me like whoever was in this kind of conservative bloc there just decided he was going to take the fall. And I think it's a terrible mistake. I think he's a very able, good man.
Q. Are you going to recess-appoint him?
A.I'm not prepared to make a statement on that one way or the other yet.

HEADLINE: With the Federal Deficit Falling, The President Weighs a Tax Cut

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was weighing a tax cut as part of next year's budget proposal but warned against the temptation of spending a budget surplus that does not yet exist.
Mr. Clinton set guidelines for fairness and economic soundness that any tax cut would have to meet to win his support. His staff members suggested that Republican proposals for a national sales tax or flat income tax fell short of the President's standards. 
 Mr. Clinton has been meeting with Republican leaders as well as his own staff to explore proposals ranging from a comprehensive overhaul of the American tax system to targeted tax incentives designed to advance his policy goals, including programs for workers and communities damaged by foreign trade.
The President said he would consider proposing a tax-cutting measure next year if he were persuaded that it was fair to average taxpayers, good for the economy and would lead to a simpler Federal tax code. But he said he had not decided on whether to propose a tax cut or what one might look like.
The President reviewed the past year and looked ahead to the remainder of his term in a 30-minute interview in his office this afternoon with The New York Times. Mr. Clinton glanced occasionally at a page of handwritten talking points. Excerpts, Page A28.
The President also gave a strong signal that he was prepared to flout Senate Republican objections and use his Constitutional power to appoint Bill Lann Lee as the Justice Department's top civil rights officer while the Senate is in recess.
The President said he was "really disappointed" by the Senate's refusal last month to confirm Mr. Lee, a California civil rights lawyer of Asian descent.
"I think they made a terrible mistake," Mr. Clinton said. "I don't even think it makes political sense for them." He repeated his determination to see Mr. Lee placed in the Justice Department post by any means necessary.
A senior White House aide said Mr. Lee was willing to accept a so-called recess appointment that would give him the job for the next year while the White House continued to lobby for his confirmation. The aide said Mr. Clinton was ready to make the appointment as early as next week if he could not win a commitment from Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, to bring Mr. Lee's nomination up for a yes-or-no vote when the Senate returned in January.
The Senate left town last month without acting on Mr. Lee's nomination after Republicans declared his views on affirmative-action programs to be unacceptable. Senior Republican leaders in the Senate have warned that a recess appointment would profoundly damage relations between Congress and the White House and make it virtually impossible for Mr. Lee to carry out his duties.
Mr. Clinton also spoke publicly for the first time about the dissent by Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to the decision this week by Attorney General Janet Reno not to seek an independent counsel to investigate fund-raising telephone calls by the President and Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Freeh's objections to curtailing the fund-raising investigation would not undercut the Attorney General's credibility. "She did what she had to do based on her reading of the law," Mr. Clinton said. "And everybody knows that she is an independent-minded person."
The President said he hoped that removing the threat of a years-long independent counsel investigation would move Congress to act on campaign finance legislation.
Mr. Clinton spoke at some length about the possibility of a tax cut as part of his budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning next September. He said he met for more than an hour this week with Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, to discuss what form an Administration tax plan might take.
Mr. Archer made his case for replacing the current complex, progressive income tax code with a national sales tax that would eliminate virtually all of the Internal Revenue Service's tax-collection duties. Mr. Clinton was noncommittal about Mr. Archer's proposal, saying, "I have drawn no conclusion yet about what I'd be for."
The President said he did not want to raise "false expectations" about a sweeping revision of the nation's tax-collection system. But it appeared clear that neither Mr. Archer's sales tax proposal, nor other Republicans' calls for a single-rate flat tax would satisfy Mr. Clinton's criteria for changing the current tax system.
Mr. Clinton said any tax plan must answer four questions: "Is it fair to average American taxpayers? Is it realistic that you can implement the proposal, whatever it is? Will it be good for the economy as a whole; will it support our continuing growth of the economy? And will it be simpler?"
White House officials have said a national sales tax and a flat tax would satisfy the fourth condition but fall far short on the others.
The result is more likely to be a modest tinkering with the tax code to finance some of the President's pet projects and those -- like aid for trade-affected communities -- that can win him votes for other priorities, like renewal of "fast track" trade-negotiating authority.
But, Mr. Clinton said, "we should be open to ideas and listen to arguments."
Republicans plan to use tax revision as a centerpiece of their political agenda next year, hoping to appeal to taxpayers with proposals that go much further than anything the Administration is willing to accept.
An aide to Mr. Archer said the Congressman was encouraged by his meeting with the President, calling it an exercise in bridge-building between two politicians who remained far apart on their approaches to taxation. He said Mr. Archer still believed that radical change of the United States tax code must await the election of a Republican President.
Mr. Clinton also sought to dampen speculation about a substantial Administration tax-relief plan by noting that the Federal budget is not yet in balance, despite a sharp drop in the deficit in the last year.
The Federal budget deficit for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $22.6 billion, the lowest figure in a quarter-century. If the economy remains strong, many analysts say, the budget could show a surplus in the next several years.
Many members of Congress are agitating for large tax cuts or new spending programs because they believe the Federal budget problem has been solved. Some Administration officials are arguing that Mr. Clinton should propose new spending on programs that have long been his priorities: health care, worker training, education, child care and the environment.
But Mr. Clinton said such plans represented a "questionable course" because the projected surplus had not yet materialized.
"I think that it is not very prudent for us to go spending a lot of money that we haven't realized yet," the President said. "If we hold tight and save all of that money or most of that money, and show some discipline here, we might get a balanced budget a lot quicker than they thought, and then we can decide what to do."

HEADLINE: Gore Refuses to Concede Fund-Raising Mistakes

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
In his first extensive interview about the fund-raising storm that has enveloped him for nearly a year, a defiant Vice President Al Gore today refused to concede that he had made any mistakes in how he raised money or how he handled the political accusations against him.
Casting the furor in partisan terms, Mr. Gore asserted that "the Republican Party is bound and determined to prevent change" in campaign financing. 
 And he said it was unfair for people to dwell on the months of scorching publicity about his appearance at a Buddhist temple, fund-raising solicitations from the White House and his legalistic defense of himself at a news conference in March.
"A snapshot does not have as much accuracy as a moving picture," Mr. Gore said. "Perspective is very important in politics. At the beginning of January in 1997, we had a high deficit, higher unemployment, less people with health insurance."
Many of the closest advisers to Mr. Gore have said he regrets some aspects of how he reacted to the campaign finance accusations. The advisers, inside and outside the White House, also described the accusations as the most severe political crisis of Mr. Gore's career -- one that had upset his carefully planned efforts toward the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.
But Mr. Gore said he was not distracted by the drumbeat against him. Asked repeatedly whether he had made mistakes -- in raising money or in reacting politically -- he did not answer. The closest he came to acknowledging that it had been a difficult year was when Mr. Gore referred to "adversity."
"This has been a great learning experience, really and truly," he said in the interview with The New York Times, in his White House office. "I think that you learn more from adversity than you do from the success. I think growth comes more easily and naturally when you learn how to move past the difficult moments. I think this past year really has been a great year for the country."
For months, Mr. Gore declined requests for interviews. His aides said he was waiting for the Dec. 2 deadline for Attorney General Janet Reno to announce whether she would seek an independent counsel to investigate telephone calls by President Clinton and Mr. Gore. Ms. Reno declined to appoint a counsel, but she said the Justice Department's inquiry into campaign finance practices in the 1996 campaign was not over.
In the interview, Mr. Gore was clearly seeking to move beyond the accusations about his conduct. Asked about the controversy over Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who had made clear his disagreement with Ms. Reno's decision, Mr. Gore said:
"I haven't heard such comments. The only comments I heard were perfectly proper, and I've had a productive, appropriate working relationship with him. But this was Attorney General Reno's decision."
Mr. Gore did not say he had regrets about the March news conference, for which he has been lampooned for repeatedly defending his phone calls from the White House by saying there was "no controlling legal authority" on whether they were permissible. Today, he said of the event: "There were misunderstandings that came out. But the full and independent review confirms the essential elements of what I said."
Mr. Gore also defended some of his closest advisers who have been accused of using their connections to him to lobby the Government in exchange for lucrative fees. Asked about Peter S. Knight, one of Mr. Gore's closest friends who has come under scrutiny for his lobbying, the Vice President said:
"Peter is one of the most honorable, honest men I have ever known in my life. The partisan attack against him has hit way wide of their intended mark. He's a great friend."
Among other things, Republicans accuse Mr. Knight of using his 20-year friendship with the Vice President to help a Massachusetts company win Government contracts and a visit from Mr. Gore.
Mr. Gore said he did not feel responsible for friends who had been pulled into the inquiries.
"Everybody who gets involved in national politics," he said, "understands that the partisanship is higher now than a few years ago."
The Vice President struggled for an answer when asked several times whether he had learned any lessons from this year, or whether he would do anything differently in how he raised money. He asserted that the attacks on his integrity had not exacted any personal toll on him.
"Putting things in perspective involves understanding part of the attacks are part of the American political system," he said. "It's always better to see them in perspective and not as a personal matter. That's an important lesson to learn. It was reinforced periodically this year."
Throughout the interview, Mr. Gore adhered to generalities, declining even to describe what he disliked about the existing system of raising money for campaigns. Asked about what some lawmakers consider an unseemly process, Mr. Gore said, "The American people are right to demand change, and we agree that sweeping campaign finance reform is needed." He then said the Republicans were "content with the current system."
Determined not to be engaged on the subject, Mr. Gore responded to some questions by referring to the news conference he held eight months ago -- saying his perspective had not changed.
Asked whether he would be more cautious in raising money, he said it was "premature to speculate" about his political ambitions.
He was far more interested in talking about matters like global warming and the humming economy.
Charles Burson, counsel to Mr. Gore, said in an interview that the Vice President was bracing for more accusations from Republicans.
"They're going to keep attacking him," Mr. Burson said. "They're going to keep dredging up the Buddhist temple. You just got to deal with it because it's going to keep coming. I don't see it letting up."
But Ralph Reed, the Republican strategist, offered a bright outlook for Mr. Gore today.
"My bet is Al Gore will be the nominee," Mr. Reed told reporters. "I think relatively handily."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Europeans Move to Banish All Tobacco Ads by 2006
Europe's health ministers agreed to prohibit all forms of tobacco advertising during the next nine years, going far beyond restrictions now in force in the United States. 
 The agreement, coming atop an existing ban on broadcast ads, would banish the Marlboro man and all other cigarette brand symbols from billboards, print media, clothing and eventually would even outlaw cigarette company sponsorship of sports or cultural events. The accord is a big defeat for tobacco companies, notably Philip Morris, the largest cigarette seller in Europe. Page A1.
 
Subpoenas were issued by a Congressman to force four cigarette makers to divulge hundreds of internal documents that an official has said may show an industry conspiracy to hide the health dangers of tobacco. A26.
 
Union Pacific Order Is Extended
Federal regulators extended an emergency order that Union Pacific open some track to competitors to help ease traffic congestion on its railroad system, the nation's largest. Union Pacific had argued the backlog could be eliminated, but shippers told regulators that problems still remained. D4.
 
Shoppers Still Want Bargains
November sales results from major retailers show American consumers remain mostly interested in things offered cheaply, upholding a sentiment that has prevailed during the holiday selling season for the past few years. For the most part, merchants that specialize in discount goods fared better than competitors last month. D6.
 
Third-quarter worker productivity grew at a 4.1 percent annual rate, slower than the 4.5 percent previously estimated but still the best gain in five years. D3.
 
KPMG Accused of Violation
The S.E.C. staff accused KPMG Peat Marwick of violating Federal securities laws because it audited a company managed by a KPMG consultant. D12.
 
Wells Fargo Shares Surge
Shares of Wells Fargo & Company soared after its chief executive said he would be willing to entertain a takeover bid if the price was right. Analysts said the bank might sell for as much as $40 billion, and speculated on possible buyers, including Norwest, U.S. Bancorp and Nationsbank. D2.
 
Mass Layoffs at Singer
Hurt by Southeast Asia's weakened economies, the Singer Company said it would close some factories and dismiss nearly 6,000 workers, or 28 percent of the sewing machine company's labor force. D4.
 
Fallout From Sunbeam Deal
Three months after he approved an endorsement agreement with the Sunbeam Corporation, the chief executive of the American Medical Association resigned. The official, Dr. P. John Seward, said the endorsement contract, which drew sharp criticism, "was a serious mistake." A24.
 
Intel to Offer HDTV on PC's
Intel has new software that enables personal computers to receive digital, high-definition television signals -- providing a possible end to a format war the computer industry has fought against the broadcasting and consumer electronics industries. D8.
 
German Growth Slows
Germany's economic growth slowed slightly in the third quarter but still benefited from rising exports, bolstered by the mark's 13 percent decline against the dollar this year. D2.

A Defiant Winnie Mandela Denies Murder Charges

Though the United States has suggested a "timeout" in building settlements in the West Bank, the construction continues at a brisk pace. President K. R. Narayanan ended weeks of political squabbling by setting new elections for February, three years early. The move ended 18 months of fragile coalition government. Mr. Narayanan called the election after concluding that Prime Minister I. K. Gujral's coalition, which resigned last week, could not be reconstituted with a parliamentary majority. A11
 
Push for Nazi Compensation
At the close of a conference on Nazi gold, the United States tried to increase pressure to have compensation paid within the next two years to hundreds of thousands of Holocaust survivors. An American official said that Swiss banks in New York defending themselves against class-action suits from Holocaust survivors and their heirs face pressure to reach a settlement soon. A9
 
French Court Frees American
A trans-Atlantic legal storm erupted when a French court refused to extradite Ira Einhorn to the United States to carry out a life sentence for bludgeoning his girlfriend to death in Philadelphia in 1977. Mr. Einhorn, who was tried in absentia in 1993, was set free by a French court, which said it made its decision because he would not be guaranteed a retrial in the United States. In France, a defendant tried in absentia has the automatic right to a retrial once arrested. A7
 
U.S. Chided Over Bosnian Plan
After meeting in London with Secretary of Defense William S. Clinton Weighs Tax Cut, But Insists on 'Fairness'
President Clinton, in an interview with The New York Times, said he is weighing a tax cut as part of next year's budget proposal, but warned against the temptation of spending a budget surplus that does not yet exist. He set a series of tests that any tax cut would have to meet to win his support -- tests for fairness and economic soundness that his staff suggested key Republican proposals for a national sales tax or 'flat' income tax do not meet. A1

Folic Acid Recommended
Adding even a small amount of folic acid to women's diets in their childbearing years should reduce brain and spinal cord birth defects sharply, a study suggests. The Food and Drug Administration has ordered that folic acid be added to all food grains by the start of the year. Many breads, cereals and pastas are already being sold with the nutrient added. A16
 
Abortions Climb Again
While the number of women having abortions has declined steadily since 1990, several reports show that, for reasons as yet unknown, the numbers began rising again last year in many parts of the country, according to figures made public by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. A14
 
A New View on Mars' Past
The Pathfinder robot uncovered evidence that Mars was once warm, moist and more like Earth than its forbidding surface might suggest, scientists say in newly published papers. All of this is "a shot in the arm for the possibility of finding evidence of life" on the Red Planet, said one researcher. A20

New York's highest court upheld Gov. George E. Pataki's right to remove the Bronx District Attorney from a murder case because of the prosecutor's opposition to the death penalty. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NINE WEST SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Nine West Group Inc. said late yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings would be 35 to 40 cents a share, well below analysts' forecasts. Nine West, which is based in Stamford, Conn., makes and sells women's shoes and accessories. It was expected to earn 56 cents a share in the quarter ending Jan. 31, according to analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Earnings of Nine West have been reduced by its mistiming of fashion footwear trends, weak demand for products, shipping problems and weakness in the Asian economy, where it operates stores. The company also said third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent to $34.6 million, or 95 cents a share, for the quarter ended Nov. 1, from $35.3 million, or 96 cents, in the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Gas Taxes Curb Pollution

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Nov. 30 front-page article on pollution and light trucks faults the auto industry for making inefficient, high-emission products, but Detroit is only providing what customers want. Even the paragons of efficiency, the Japanese auto producers, have been rushing to introduce light trucks to maintain their position in the United States market.
Customers can buy large numbers of trucks because the cost of gasoline in the United States is a negligible part of operating the vehicle. In Europe and Japan, where gasoline costs $3 to $5 a gallon, light trucks are not popular, fuel efficiency is higher and emission levels are lower. 
 If the Government and the press are serious about fuel efficiency and emissions, they should be proposing a substantial gas tax which, by the way, has been proposed in the past by the United States auto industry itself.
 
CLYDE V. PRESTOWITZ JR .
Washington, Dec. 2, 1997
 
Pres., Economic Strategy Institute

TYPE: Letter
