SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 29; Column 2; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3179 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
A City Built on Four Wheels and a Full Tank

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
I remember Detroit during its days of glory in the late 1940's, when the assembly lines were churning out the cars the country had gone without all during the war. It was a proud, self-confident city.
My father took me there to watch the Tigers' great lefthander, Hal Newhouser. We would stay at the Statler or the Book-Cadillac, a pair of swell big-city hotels, shop for my mother at Hudson's, one of the nation's premier department stores, and eat dinner at Lester Gruber's London Chop House, a clublike restaurant that served better food and wine than any club I know of. 
 All gone now, except Hudson's, and it's in the suburbs, along with its customers. The rivers of asphalt that Detroit laid down to handle the cars it built -- the expressways named for industry titans like Edsel Ford and Walter P. Reuther -- turned out to be exit ramps for the bulk of the city's white population. Detroit was left with a rotting core surrounded by prosperous suburbs, a kind of Los Angeles with snow.
The Hideaway Report, a newsletter for moneyed tourists, reported last year that its readers considered Detroit the world's least appealing destination.
Pity. Cultural riches abound, survivors of those distant days before the 1967 riots and the 1973 oil shock. The Detroit Institute of Arts is the nation's fifth-largest art museum and one of its most comprehensive. An excellent, innovative Museum of African-American History opened just last spring.
The Detroit Symphony Orchestra has one of the most venturesome conductors of the day, Naeme Jarve, and the Detroit Opera, housed in a splendid hall, brings singers of the caliber of Maria Ewing and Ruth Ann Swenson here. The Cranbrook Art School, which produced atavars of modern American design like Eero Saarinen, Charles and Ray Eames, Harry Bertoia and Florence Knoll, is close by.
Detroit was founded by the French as a fur-trading post. It sits on the narrow Detroit River, which along with Lake St. Clair and the St. Clair River links Lake Erie to Lake Huron. The name means "strait" in French, and French names also survive in the city's street grid -- Gratiot, Livernois, Beaubien.
 
Bouncing Back Again
Now Detroit is on its fourth or fifth comeback attempt. General Motors is moving its headquarters into the Renaissance Center, a relic of failed earlier comebacks. The football Lions are headed back downtown from exurban Pontiac, to play in a new stadium near a new ballpark for the Tigers. For the first time in decades, property values are rising, and licenses have been granted for three casinos meant to make Detroit the Atlantic City of the Midwest.
"This time it will work," said Max M. Fisher, who has helped to finance Republican campaigns in city, state and nation for 40 years. "Times are good, the auto plants are humming and we have a Mayor who gets people together."
Well, maybe. Nobody doubts the political skills of Mayor Dennis Archer, who has just won another term. There is plenty of loose change out in the suburbs; a restaurant called Tribute, in Farmington Hills, which is open only for dinner, and only Tuesdays through Saturdays, sells $70,000 worth of wine a week.
But the clean-up job is enormous. Drive out Cass Avenue on the west flank of downtown; once you leave the marble-clad Ameritech headquarters with its vivid Alexander Calder stabile, you pass block after block of empty, weed-infested lots and boarded-up buildings, bleak as Bucharest. And as David Adamany, outgoing president of Wayne State University, said the other day, "The level of public conflict in Detroit is destructively high, between the city and the suburbs, along racial lines, management versus labor, public officials versus public workers."
 
Automobilia
Cars define Detroit. So begin with a trip to the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, which celebrates not only cars, but also the culture they spawned. A 1931 Bugatti Royale is on display, and a gangster's 1929 Packard speedster, and they will soon be joined by Old 16, the Locomobile that in 1908 became the first American car to win a major race; a gas station, diner and motel room stand nearby.
Improbably, the museum also houses fine collections of American glass, silver and clocks. The adjacent Greenfield Village groups historical buildings Ford brought here, including the laboratory of Thomas A. Edison and the Wright Brothers' cycle shop. The place is done up at Christmas with a lavish hand.
The Automotive Hall of Fame, just down the road, honors industry leaders. It is worth visiting just to see the orange and sunflower-yellow 1931 Cord roadster with white sidewalls, which has never been matched for rakish glamour.
Almost at the start, Henry Ford paid a revolutionary $5 a day, and workers came from around the world to earn his wages. They came from the South, too, and many were black; one family brought with them a young son named Joe Louis Barrow, who dropped his last name and won worldwide acclaim as heavyweight champion. His status as a local hero is confirmed in the name of the Joe Louis Arena and in the many-times-life-size statue of his right forearm and fist downtown.
In the 1960's, a producer named Berry Gordy Jr. created the phenomenally popular Motown sound with the help of performers like the Supremes, the Temptations and Smokey Robinson. He started his record company in a house he called Hitsville, U.S.A., near the General Motors headquarters. It is now the Motown Historical Museum.
 
From Slavery to Outer Space
Detroit is nearly 80 percent black, so it is an ideal site for the 120,000-square-foot Museum of African-American History, which tells its often appalling story soberly and effectively. Powerful exhibits designed by Ralph Applebaum, who created the displays at the Holocaust Museum in Washington, range from slave manacles to a space suit worn by the first black female astronaut. Recordings of New Orleans jazz and bop, films of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Barbara Jordan at the peak of their oratorical form, and historical photographs round out the collection.
A false dichotomy has been set up by some critics between the Institute of Arts and the Museum of African-American History, which are only two blocks apart. One is pictured as white and elitist, the other as black and populist. But in fact they are up to completely different things. One takes an encyclopedic approach to the fine and decorative arts (not excepting works by such leading black artists as Romare Bearden), while the other includes art as one element in its story.
On the Sunday when I was there, the crowd at the Institute of Arts was predominantly black, while the visitors at the African-American museum were mostly white and Asian. Go figure.
Despite cutbacks in Government financing that permit it to open only 27 hours a week, despite the loss of a talented director to the Frick Collection in Manhattan, the institute looks surprisingly spiffy. Its collections are dotted with masterpieces too numerous to mention, but I was struck, in meandering through its rooms, by the richness of the colors in many of its best works: an icily white Meissen crane by Kaendler, three glowing predella panels by Sassetta, Bruegel's exuberant "Wedding Dance," a self-portrait in blue and gold by van Gogh, a view of the Mexican volcano Cotopaxi erupting through a fiery sky by Frederic Edwin Church, a pulsating scene in the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem by Reginald Marsh, and one of Emil Nolde's many "Sunflowers."
Diego Rivera, the great Mexican muralist, supplied the museum's centerpiece, a series of frescoes on the walls of a central courtyard. Those on the two long walls show a Model-T assembly line and engine-block plant. They are unabashed hymns to the dignity of working men of all races, many of whom are shown wearing fedoras as they toil.
 
Notable Architecture
Plenty of out-of-town architectural stars worked here, from H. H. Richardson to Cass Gilbert to Frank Lloyd Wright. But the architect-in-chief of Detroit's Golden Age was Albert Kahn, a German-born immigrant (no relation of Louis I. Kahn, the Philadelphia architect of a later day, who came from Estonia). He built mansions for industrialists in Grosse Pointe (including a Cotswold-style spread for Edsel Ford at 1100 Lake Shore Road, which is open to visitors), libraries for the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and the immense River Rouge plant for Henry Ford.
His Fisher Building, in the midtown district known as the New Center, is an Art Deco masterpiece. An arched hallway three stories high cuts through it, punctuated by eight massive cylindrical chandeliers. (An Art Deco gem by other hands is the Guardian Building at 500 Griswold Street, decorated with patterns of gaily colored, locally made Pewabic tiles.)
Kahn also built a house called Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills, north of the city, for George G. Booth, owner of The Detroit News, who converted his estate into an educational complex including boarding schools for boys and girls and an art school. Eliel Saarinen, a Finnish architect who had placed second in the international competition in 1922 for the Tribune Tower in Chicago, designed the campus and headed the art school.
The peristyle at the art school, a severe, unornamented sandstone gate with a fountain by the Swedish modernist Carl Milles, now houses a small museum that mounts temporary shows as well as a permanent exhibition of works by Saarinen, his son, Eero, and other eminent students. It is a dictionary of American taste, circa 1965, with Eero's pedestal chairs and the Eames's bent plywood ones.
During the warmer months, the house Eliel built for himself and his family on the Cranbrook grounds in a refined Deco style is open to the public.
A drive of only about 20 minutes brings you to the G.M. Technical Center, one of Eero's masterworks along with the CBS Building in Manhattan and Dulles International Airport near Washington. It is one of the projects studied by every would-be architect in the United States.
Like the automobile itself, the long, low buildings are constructed primarily of glass, steel and aluminum, but the end walls are made of glazed bricks in vivid colors -- royal blue, yellow, red. They are grouped (at Twelve Mile and Mound Roads in Warren) around a lake in which fountains play out a computerized "ballet" devised by Calder. A three-legged stainless-steel water tower stands like an exclamation mark above this remarkable ensemble.
 
Attractions And Events
 
Here is information about places mentioned in the article about Detroit and other sites:
 
Where to Stay
 
RIVER PLACE, in a redeveloped area just east of downtown known as Rivertown, is much the pleasantest place to stay anywhere near the center, at least until General Motors has shaken up the grim, silolike Westin, whose truly abysmal service makes it the weakest link in that chain. River Place, built in 1902, has 108 large, modern, individually decorated rooms, half with views of the water, plus an indoor pool and two tennis courts. 1000 River Place, (800) 890-9505. Daily weekend room rates, $99 to $149.
THE RITZ-CARLTON, is the top luxury hotel in the Detroit area with all the usual Ritz amenities: chandeliers, antiques and acres of marble. Rooms are a bit small, but prices are gentler than at most of the group's properties. The food is good and the service near-perfect. Fairlane Plaza, 300 Town Center Drive, Dearborn, (800) 241-3333. Weekend room rates, $155 to $180 a night.
THE DEARBORN INN is a Georgian-style alternative on the west side, next to Greenfield Village and close to Ford headquarters. Built by Henry Ford in 1931 in mellow red brick, it was tastefully restored a few years ago by Marriott. A solicitous staff helps make it a good choice for families. 20301 Oakwood Boulevard, Dearborn, (313) 271-2700. Weekend room rates, $79 to $89 a night.
THE TOWNSEND HOTEL is my own favorite, a snug little gem with a wood-burning fireplace in the lobby and charmingly decorated rooms and suites. Tucked into the shopping district of Birmingham, a smart suburb north of town, it is not far from the Cranbrook Art School. At full tilt, it sometimes seems just the slightest bit understaffed. 100 Townsend Street, Birmingham, (800) 548-4172. Weekend room rates, $169 to $240 a night.
 
Where to Eat
 
TRIBUTE may be the best restaurant between New York and Chicago; it is certainly the finest in Detroit. In the far northwest suburbs, right at a freeway exit, it is the creation of an inventive chef, Takashi Yagihashi, and an ebullient, pony-tailed maitre d'hotel, Mickey Bakst. One night recently, the menu ranged from risotto with white truffles to bracingly fresh sashimi to perfectly judged New Zealand venison. The room sparkles with colored glass and the glass-walled wine cellar sparkles with the best of France, the Napa, Oregon, Italy and Australia. 31425 West Twelve Mile Road, Farmington Hills, (248) 848-9393.
FORTE. Wackily shaped mirrors and yards of velvet give Keith Famie's new brasserie a distinctive personality, as does the noisy, well-heeled crowd. The chef is a magpie, drawing inspiration from a multitude of sources. He imports rice from Valencia for his paellas, bakes his pizzas in a proper Neapolitan oven and pairs his lamb chops with a Gorgonzola and potato pie. My pick: real osso bucco with saffron risotto and porcini mushrooms enriched and enlivened with balsamic vinegar. If there are a lot of you, ask for the appetizer assortment served in an antique silver bain-marie. (201 South Woodward Avenue, Birmingham, (248) 594-7300.
FIVE LAKES GRILL. Brian Polcyn used to run the Pike Street Grill in Pontiac, but the commute wore him down. So he retreated to the village of Milford, northwest of town, where he and his family have lived for years, and started the Five Lakes Grill. The decor is spare, the furniture plain, the service Midwest-sweet and the cooking deft (sauteed Great Lakes pickerel, smoke-roasted pork loin, Amish chicken breast stuffed with pecans and spinach). (424 North Main Street, Milford, (248) 684-7455.
THE RATTLESNAKE CLUB. Detroit's best-known chef, Jimmy Schmidt, has stretched himself thin since he started opening casual joints in the suburbs. On its good nights, the Rattlesnake Club, his original restaurant, serves excellent New American food, including skillfully handled freshwater fish like perch and whitefish. The wines are well selected. But bad nights -- kitchen misfiring, waiters disorganized -- come dishearteningly often, especially since there are so few other first-rate options close to downtown. 300 Stroh River Place, (313) 567-4400.
MON JIN LAU is much loved by local chefs for its inventive pan-Asian fare, like chili-pepper squid and Mongolian rack of lamb. Situated in Troy, land of K-Mart and used-car lots, it is an excellent choice on Sunday night, when many area restaurants are closed. 1515 East Maple Road, Troy, (248) 689-2332.
ZINGERMAN'S, the deli of my dreams, is unmatched outside New York. You can choose whitefish salad on onion rye, pastrami sandwiched between potato pancakes, silky chopped liver, corned beef (the real thing! in the Midwest!) or brisket with schmalz. To go: home-baked breads, mustards, oils, jams and the best selection of English farmhouse cheeses this side of Cheddar. 422 Detroit Street, Ann Arbor, (313) 663-3354.

Round-trip airfare from New York City to Detroit can vary widely, depending on the time reservations are made, the days of travel and the airport of departure. Northwest Airlines offers round-trip fares of $158 from Newark and $178 from Kennedy with no advance purchase. All fares are subject to availability. R. W. APPLE Jr.

HEADLINE: Heroin and Red Herrings

BYLINE: By Michael Massing; Michael Massing writes frequently about the drug problem in America.

 BODY:
The recent deaths of 10 young people in Plano, Tex., who had overdosed on heroin seems further evidence that more members of the middle class are using the drug.
A booming Dallas suburb with a median household income of more than $50,000, Plano is the last place where one would expect to find an heroin epidemic, least of all among people as young as these victims, one of whom was only 14. 
 The news about Plano is only the latest of many alarming accounts of heroin's growing hold on affluent Americans. We have read newspaper articles and seen television news programs about strung-out stockbrokers and models, movie stars and rock musicians.
There is no doubt that the drug's use has increased in areas like Hollywood, the East Village and Wall Street. Supplies of heroin are up, in a form pure enough to snort rather than inject. This has heightened the narcotic's allure for some Americans, especially those too young to remember the heroin epidemic of the late 1960's. Yet the amount of attention these well-heeled junkies have received is out of all proportion to their actual number.
None of the leading drug surveys bear out the claims of a new wave of middle-class heroin use. The 1996 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse found that just 0.2 percent of the more than 18,000 people polled had used the drug in the preceding year. A mere 0.1 percent had used it in the past month.
And according to the University of Michigan's annual survey of high school students, just 1 percent of all the country's 12th graders questioned in 1996 said they had used the drug in the past year. It's true that in the last few years that number has gone up, but this is hardly the stuff of a national crisis.
The uproar over middle-class heroin use overlooks those with the real heroin problem, addicts in the inner city. This population of hard-core users, numbering about three million, constitute our nation's true drug problem.
Longtime users who have burned out on cocaine and crack have been turning to heroin and its more mellow high. Many add it to crack and smoke it in a pipe; others mix heroin and cocaine together and inject it in a potent cocktail called a speedball.
Since many of these users are homeless, unemployed and emotionally disturbed, they tend not to show up in national surveys. Unfortunately, policy makers are oblivious to them as well. Current drug policy has become almost completely irrelevant to what is going on in the street. The Clinton Administration's latest initiative, unveiled with great fanfare earlier this year, is a $195 million television advertising campaign aimed at keeping young people off drugs. While such a campaign probably won't hurt, it will do little to help chronic, longtime users, most of whom are adults.
That money would be much better spent on new treatment slots at rehabilitation centers, many of which have long waiting lists. Addicts don't vote, however, and so politicians have little incentive to help them.
And, while we broadcast public service announcements on television, heroin, crack and cocaine will continue to afflict those in the inner city. The effects can be seen in the many children who are abused by drug users, addicts who get H.I.V. from dirty needles and the street people who overdose. These are the real-life victims of heroin -- even if they don't make the nightly news.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 3; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1348 words

HEADLINE: A New Journal: A Digest That Feeds on Digests

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Caught the article about Heidegger's craving in Diacritic's special fall issue about addiction? How about that piece on Dutch Domestic Realism in the spring issue of Representations? Or Critical Inquiry's page-turner on the trauma of Dada montage?
Welcome to the world of scholarly and ideas journals, where a typical cover line could be "Blankness as a Signifier" and a healthy circulation is around 2,000 (F.Y.I., Better Homes and Gardens' circulation is 7.6 million). 
 Little known outside the contemplative campuses of academia, many of these journals explore topics that can intimidate even the most formidable of intellects: structuralism, post-structuralism, post-modernism, post-colonialism. Despite their seeming obscurity, such journals have played an important role in the development of scholarly movements that have influenced what generations of students are taught and in fierce intellectual debates that have reverberated through American society, for example, the culture wars and feminist legal theory.
"Work that looks like it's being done in an ivory tower actually can have very far reaching consequences for the way that cultures grapple with their own meanings," Stephen Greenblatt, a co-editor of Representations who teaches English at Harvard University, said in an interview. "Intellectuals often tell themselves that it basically doesn't matter. But in fact, it's a lie."
The field is jam-packed, with publications ranging from such new titles as Doubletake to established periodicals like Partisan Review. In addition to political journals, literary journals, scientific journals, there are journals that deal with fine arts, race, law; journals that grew out of a particular ideology or theoretical school and others that are affiliated with universities or associations.
Now the sociologist Daniel Bell has taken the next step: creating a journal for the journals. On Monday he plans to publish the first issue of the Newsletter of the Committee on Intellectual Correspondence, a twice-yearly, 32-page publication that uses summaries and excerpts from articles drawn from publications in Europe and Japan as well as the United States.
While academic journals typically speak to their own rarefied constituencies (be it the International Journal of Osteoarchaeology or the Journal of Hispanic/Latino Theology), Mr. Bell is hoping disparate journals will now speak more directly to one another across cultural boundaries.
"If you asked American writers who they read in Germany or France or Italy -- other than one or two names -- they'd draw a blank," said Mr. Bell, a professor of social science at Harvard University and author of the provocative books "The End of Ideology" and "The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism."
"There is a great degree of specialization in academic life," he continued. "People are involved in their own fields. "
The newsletter is sponsored by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in Cambridge, Mass., where Mr. Bell is a scholar in residence, the Suntory Foundation in Osaka, Japan, and the Institute of Advanced Studies in Berlin.
Some 60 publications, ranging from better-known magazines like The Nation to more obscure scholarly periodicals like the Tocqueville Review, have agreed to participate.
In the 17th century, the growth of an increasingly educated public hungry for reading material gave rise to idea journals, according to Alan Charles Kors, a history professor at the University of Pennsylvania who specializes in 17th- and 18th-century European intellectual life.
With the explosion in book publishing, Mr. Kors explained, people turned to journals to keep up with current intellectual thought. "The feeling was, you can't read it all but you've got to be able to talk about it," he said. "Learned journals, by their reviews, let you talk as if you had read a book. They also let you know what was worth reading."
In the United States, many academic journals grew out of scholarly associations like the American Economics Association, Mr. Bell said. Although several current publications cut across academic disciplines, they are often identified with specific scholarly movements. Founded 26 years ago and published by the Johns Hopkins University Press, for example, Diacritics became the home of deconstruction (the theory that no text can have a fixed, coherent meaning; for more, look it up) and was one of the first to publish articles about and by the French philosopher Jacques Derrida.
The journal Representations, published by the University of California Press, has become known for promoting the New Historicism, a cultural approach to history that examines influences on everything from books, paintings and battles to kitchen tools. Mr. Greenblatt said he started the magazine in 1983 to make contact with a broader circle of people and ideas.
"I found that some of the most interesting conversations I was having were with people outside my own field," Mr. Greenblatt said. "I began to realize that the group of people I talked to constituted a kind of intellectual community, though not a community that had taken shape as such."
A recent article in Representations looked at the relationship between Western mountain climbers and Sherpas in the Himalayas through two different scholarly lenses. Sherry B. Ortner, a professor of anthropology, first applied the perspective of Orientalism, which explores how European cultures dominate non-Western societies, to mountaineers who risked the lives of Sherpas because they defined them "as not caring about life." Then she used a cultural approach to explain that Sherpas care deeply about death but handle their grief in ways that are unfamiliar to outsiders.
In one of his own articles, Mr. Greenblatt examined the idea that in Shakespeare's plays, fantasy has the power to kill: people are not only murdered, they can be wished dead. In "Henry IV, Part II," for example, Prince Hal thinks his father has died of natural causes and takes his crown, only to then have King Henry awaken. "I never thought to hear you speak again," Prince Hal says. The King replies, "Thy wish was father, Harry, to that thought."
The journal Critical Inquiry, started in 1974, prides itself on avoiding ideological labels. "We refuse to be identified with a school or a movement or a particular methodology or discipline," said the journal's editor, W. J. T. Mitchell, a professor of English and art history at the University of Chicago.
Recently the journal's editors had such a heated debate over an essay submitted for consideration called "Who Killed Feminist Criticism?" that they decided to publish it. The article suggested that attacks on feminist criticism for being too white and too Western undermined the movement. "One of our measures of whether something is worth publishing is if it produces a real argument among ourselves," Mr. Mitchell said.
While these journals may create a stir among those who read them, rarely do the editors hear about it. Richard Klein, a co-editor of Diacritics, said he could not recall ever receiving a letter from a reader. "It's very rare that one gets very much feedback," he said.
This has spurred academic journals to make more of an effort to expand their audiences. The journal Transitions, for example, published by Duke University Press, does not include footnotes. Started by the Ugandan intellectual Rajat Neogy in 1961 and revived in 1991 by the Harvard professors Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Kwame Anthony Appiah, Transition publishes the work of journalists and essayists as well as academics. "Transition has tried to get beyond theory," said Michael Colin Vazquez, the journal's executive editor, "to write for a more popular audience." The cover of the 1996 winter issue featured a photo of Miss Italy in a bathing suit with her crown and scepter.
It is precisely to create a wider, more inviting intellectual community that Mr. Bell started his new consortium of journals. "We wish," Mr. Bell said in the newsletter's introduction, "to retake the common terrain."

HEADLINE: Barney's May Get New Bidder, DFS, as Business Strengthens

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The DFS Group, the world's largest chain of duty-free shops, is preparing to make a bid for Barney's Inc., the New York luxury retailer now in bankruptcy, executives involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
An offer, should one materialize, would come on the heels of strong sales and better cost controls at Barney's and would recast the entire bankrupcty bidding process, which has so far been dominated by Dickson Concepts Inc. of Hong Kong. In August, that company offered to buy Barney's for $205 million and a 49 percent equity stake. 
 The creditors committee is not entirely pleased with that bid -- it has argued that the company is worth more, and is also having trouble carving up the spoils with the Isetan Company of Japan, a former partner of Barney's with which it is embroiled in litigation.
It is not hard to figure DFS's desire for Barney's.
LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods company, acquired 58.75 percent of DFS for $2.47 billion in 1996 and now holds 61.25 percent. DFS's latest store concept, Galleria, has several possible synergies with Barney's.
The Galleria stores, large specialty retail shops in major cities in the Far East as well as in San Francisco, carry many of the same tony suppliers as Barney's, including Giorgio Armani, Chanel, Hermes and Gucci. In the last few years, the company has invested $300 million in those stores and views them as its largest growth vehicle.
Further, LVMH owns several fashion companies, including Christian Dior, Givenchy, Celine and Louis Vuitton, and would welcome another outlet that it controls to sell them through. LVMH also recently acquired Sephora, a French chain of perfume stores, and plans to expand that chain rapidly, offering further possible economies of scale with suppliers.
Perhaps just as important, Isetan, the former Barney's partner and the largest creditor in the bankruptcy, carries many of the LVMH products in its own retail stores in Asia. It appears that a friendly relationship between the two, which is crucial to having the deal done, already exists.
And DFS is run by Myron E. Ullman 3d, which may provide a key to DFS's intensified interest in Barney's, which it first looked at well over a year ago. Mr. Ullman has a long relationship with Thomas C. Shull, who was named president and chief operating officer of Barney's in September. Mr. Ullman was chief executive of Macy's before it was acquired by Federated Department Stores; Mr. Shull was the retail chain's senior vice president for corporate planning. The two were White House Fellows from 1981 to 1982. Both worked at Sanger Harris, a former Federated unit, before it was sold to the May Department Store Company.
Mr. Shull is credited among people involved with the bankruptcy for the recent turn of fortunes for Barney's: Sales in stores open at least one year during the first quarter ended Nov. 1 were $91.4 million, an 11.5 percent increase from the corresponding period last year, and the company is expected to turn a strong profit before taxes this quarter.
If there is an offer from DFS, it will certainly put Dickson Poon, the chairman of Dickson Concepts, in the position of deciding whether he thinks the company is worth getting into a bidding war over. At this point, if he is outbid and chooses to walk away, he will have to be reimbursed $1.5 million in a breakup fee and exit unscathed.
Creditors have estimated that earnings before interest and taxes at Barney's this year could be as high as $17 million, compared with a loss of about $2 million on the same basis last year. DFS would have to pay about 19 times those pretax earnings to beat out Mr. Poon -- a valuation that may be too steep.
Still, while DFS may be quite hungry for the company, Bernard Arnault, the fiercely competitive chief executive of LVMH, must give any bid the final blessing, and he is not fond of overpaying for anything.

HEADLINE: A Good Fit Is Starting to Pinch;
Nine West Tries to Fend Off Investigations and Debt

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Jerome Fisher and Vincent Camuto founded their shoe company in 1977 on a simple but brilliant idea: spot the hottest designs on the fashion runways and quickly make the shoes affordable for the middle-class masses by manufacturing them in Brazil.
The strategy seems to have paid off handsomely for the two men and their company, which was named for its first location, at 9 West 57th Street in Manhattan. The company, now known as Nine West Group, says that one of every five pairs of shoes that American women buy comes from Nine West. In shopping malls across the nation, women with $50 to $80 to spend on a pair of shoes can hardly miss one of the company's 13 brands, from the classy Enzo Angiolini to the comfortable Easy Spirit. 
 But now there are signs of trouble -- everything from investigations by two Government agencies to mounting debts and slower sales. The company's stock, recently a darling among Wall Street's retail stocks, has fallen 45 percent in price from this year's high of $52.75. It closed yesterday at $29 a share, up 50 cents. Much of the drop came after management said in May that the Securities and Exchange Commission had been inquiring for at least six months about possible accounting irregularities concerning its wholesale revenues. Company officials first disclosed the inquiry in a paragraph deep inside a routine public filing. Stunned shareholders wondered why the company had not been more up front about the investigation.
Just when stockholders were beginning to believe management's repeated assurances that the S.E.C. would find little amiss, the shoe company announced last month that the agency was widening its investigation to look at the company's imports from Brazil. The company also reported that customs officials were making a separate inquiry into the Brazilian imports.
Even before the investigations hit, there were problems. Company officials had publicly boasted of double-digit gains in sales. Most of that growth, however, comes from acquisitions and new stores. Take those figures out of the picture, and sales at stores that have been open for several months are falling. For the third quarter, those same-store sales were down 3 percent from a year ago.
The Oppenheimer Total Return Fund decided to sell its 5 percent stake in Nine West about six months ago, after the company's storerooms were left filled with boxes of open-toe shoes that had languished during the snowy spring, said Bruce Bartlett, who manages the fund.
"It looks like an inexpensive stock," Mr. Bartlett said, noting that shares now sell for about 11 times this year's earnings. "But we question the direction of the earnings."
The company, nearly debt free in 1994, borrowed deeply in 1995 when it paid $600 million for the footwear divisions of the U.S. Shoe Corporation. Now it must warn investors in S.E.C. filings that interest expense is eating into its cash and that the high debt could upset its expansion plans.
If anything, the company should be sitting pretty, with 60 percent of its goods coming from Brazil, whose currency has weakened against the dollar. Instead, management warned yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings would be 40 percent lower than expected.
The two founders declined to be interviewed for this article. But in a statement to shareholders, Mr. Fisher, the chairman, blamed fashion faux pas in part for the disappointing year. He said the company was also facing "shipping challenges" in its accessories division.
"We have taken action by critically evaluating every aspect of our business," Mr. Fisher's statement added. For one thing, the company vowed this week to lower the price of certain shoes by as much as 5 to 8 percent.
Despite selling most of the company to the public in 1993, Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto -- who describe themselves as experts in shoes, rather than finance -- are still very much in charge, judging from comments by people inside and outside the company.
Some experts on corporate practice question whether some things would be different if outside shareholders had more sway. Specifically, they find fault with the company's small board, with a chief financial officer who comes straight out of the company's accounting firm and with the company's leasing office space from its two founders.
Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto, the chief executive officer, occupy two seats on the company's five-member board. John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University, said that public companies similar to the billion-dollar Nine West often had boards of 12 directors or more, with 80 percent of the members coming from outside.
The other three directors are C. Gerald Goldsmith, an investment consultant from Palm Beach, Fla.; Henry W. Pascarella, a lawyer in Greenwich, Conn., and Salvatore M. Salibello, a partner at the small accounting firm of Salibello & Broder in New York.
The board, which ordinarily meets only four times a year, has been kind to top management. Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto each received $1.8 million in salary and bonus last year. The two have also found another way to make money from Nine West: by sharing a 15.5 percent stake in a partnership that owns the company's headquarters in Stamford, Conn. The company is relocating to White Plains but must continue to pay rent -- now more than $2 million a year -- on the Stamford building until 2002, unless it can find someone to sublet it.
At least two family members also work for the company. Mr. Fisher's son, Marc, earned $982,808 last year as president of a division that sells shoes under other companies' names. The chairman's daughter, Jodi, also works at the company, fielding calls from reporters.
Mr. Galvin, the chief financial officer, is a former partner in Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, which has long audited the company's books. He was hired after he advised Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto on the U.S. Shoe acquisition.
It is legal for companies to hire former auditors. But Mr. Galvin's prior employment at Deloitte raises ticklish questions about the independence of the accounting firm before and after he was hired, and about whether a pending job offer could have influenced Deloitte's reading of the Nine West books. Even now, his intimate knowledge of Deloitte's auditing procedures and his relationship with various professionals could make it harder for the firm to conduct its audit.
A Deloitte spokeswoman said the firm would not comment on a client matter.
Mr. Coffee, the law professor, said, "All of this company's watchdogs look a bit tame." He added that the small corporate board and the founders' ownership in the real estate partnership, which would likely be unacceptable at other public companies, seemed to be characteristic of "a somewhat dysfunctional company that has not yet made the leap from a private company to truly public company."
But Mr. Galvin said the company believed that the board was large enough to give its public shareholders a strong voice. He said outside consultants with expertise in corporate compensation had determined that Marc Fisher's salary was appropriate. And he said that while he had worked on the audit of the company while he was at Deloitte, he was not the partner in charge of the audit. He said the entire board -- not just Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto -- had approved his hiring.
In an interview, Mr. Pascarella, the board member from Greenwich, said he was comfortable with the company's management and its response to the investigations. In addition to holding a special board meeting with management this fall, he said the three outside directors had met privately with their own counsel and with representatives of Deloitte to discuss the S.E.C. inquiry. He also said he was confident with management's assurances that the problems were not material.
That said, the scrutiny is proving painful for a company that was always at its best taking on the industry. Now, it has grown so much that it is the industry.
"The founders were very great entrepreneurs," said Faye I. Landes, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. "But this is now a very big and complicated company." She is not recommending the stock to clients.
The company became more complex with the U.S. Shoe purchase, which doubled the number of its retail stores. Some U.S. Shoe brands were losing money, but Nine West management thought it could turn them around by manufacturing overseas. This year, it closed three Midwest shoe factories that had been operated by U.S. Shoe, so that it could buy even more shoes from Brazil. The company laid off more than 1,000 workers in Kentucky and Indiana, including 300 in Vanceburg, Ky., where the unemployment rate was already more than 10 percent.
Now, S.E.C. investigators are looking at the way Nine West recorded wholesale revenues at some of the former U.S. Shoe divisions, in the seven months from the acquisition through the fiscal year ending Feb. 1, 1996, according to Nine West news releases. The company says it records revenues when the shoes are shipped to wholesale customers, who resell the shoes through noncompany outlets like department stores.
The S.E.C., as is its policy, will not confirm an inquiry or comment on whether one has begun. While it is not clear what the S.E.C. may suspect, some other companies have run into problems with the agency when they overstated sales by shipping products that they knew would be quickly returned or by parking goods marked "sold" in warehouses.
Given management's assurances that the problems were confined to certain brands and involved a limited period, investors were rolling with the punches until the company disclosed on Nov. 6 that the S.E.C. had widened its investigation to look at the way the company was importing shoes from Brazil. "Many people felt misled," said one analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Management said this was very narrow and confined, but it's not."
The company said in its Nov. 6 salvo that it had received an S.E.C. subpoena on Oct. 29 for documents relating to shoes bought from Brazil since 1994, including information on the prices and customs duties paid for those shoes.
Mr. Galvin said he continued to believe that any findings by the investigators would not hurt Nine West financially. He also said that he thought the accounting policies were appropriate and that the company had made no changes to policies or practices since the S.E.C. began asking questions last fall. But such assurances ring hollow to some analysts, who say revisions by the company have forced them to lower their earnings estimates time and again.
"It is still unclear why they are having such a hard time making these estimates," said Ms. Landes of Smith Barney. "It is hard for me not to think that they are sitting in meetings with lawyers much of the time."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photo: "Under Scrutiny"

Nine West Group's stock was trading at more than $50 a share and its products were selling briskly. But recently things have gone downhill, amid mounting debts, slower sales and disclosures of two Government investigations.

HEADLINE: Split Over Poorer Countries' Role Puts Cloud on Global-Warming Talks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Elements of a possible agreement on cutting industrialized countries' emissions of heat-trapping waste gases have begun to emerge from intensive negotiations here, and today it was widely believed that the countries could reach agreement on this central issue next week.
But there was little apparent movement on a second key issue, that of the immediate role to be played by developing countries in controlling the gases, and that issue continued to threaten the overall prospects for the success of the talks. It also raised the possibility that while some sort of agreement might be achieved, the United States might find it unacceptable and refuse to sign what would be called the Kyoto Protocol. 
 As the 10-day session on what to do about global warming reached its halfway mark, attention turned to the expected arrival on Monday of Vice President Al Gore and high-level ministers from more than 150 countries, marking the start of the talks' decisive final three days.
Awaiting them will probably be the rough ingredients of an agreement on targets, timetables and structures for cutting rich nations' emissions of carbon dioxide and other atmospheric gases that scientists say are warming the atmosphere. "I think the elements are there," said Raul Estrada-Oyuela of Argentina, the chairman of the talks.
Pieces of an agreement "are beginning to take shape," said Melinda Kimble, a senior State Department official who has led the United States delegation in the early phase of the Kyoto discussions. "We need to tweak them a little more to get them to fit together."
One emerging element is called differentiation, an arrangement whereby countries would adopt different levels of emissions reductions, tailored to their particular national circumstances. Differentiation presents a way around an impasse over a uniform, flat-rate reduction target for everyone. The United States said for the first time on Monday that it would consider the differentiation approach.
Initially, the Americans proposed a one-size-fits-all target of cutting average emissions levels in the period 2008 through 2012 back to 1990 levels. The Europeans proposed a flat-rate reduction of 15 percent below 1990 levels by 2010. Both sets of targets and timetables would be legally binding, and both remain formally on the table at least for now.
A number of countries, including the United States, argue that the range of differentiation should be kept narrow. One way to achieve this would be simply to set a target range for reductions -- say, between 5 and 10 percent, or zero to 5 percent, below 1990 levels. Another way would be to adopt stringent objective criteria, based on countries' varying economic profiles.
A key holdout on differentiation has been the European Union. Many other delegations find this stance unfair, since the European group proposes a form of differentiation for itself. Under what is called the European "bubble" proposal, Europe as a whole would be bound to a firm target. But some countries would be allowed to fall short of the target -- in one case, by 40 percent -- while others make up by exceeding it.
The Europeans have been under intense pressure from the Japanese and the Americans to justify the bubble concept. Europe, in fact, has appeared on the defensive over the issue this week, and some insiders say the pressure on the bubble is a tactic to help extract concessions from the Europeans on other issues, including differentiation for all countries and emissions trading, a mechanism heavily favored by the United States.
In emissions trading, a country or industrial company would be able to meet its emissions reduction target by cutting emissions itself or by buying reductions from another country or company that achieved excess cuts, or both.
Proponents of this approach argue that it provides an incentive for companies and countries that find it relatively easy to cut emissions to go further than required and then profit by selling the excess to companies that find it harder or more costly to reduce emissions on their own. The proponents say this approach achieves reductions most efficiently and cheaply.
The Americans say that market-based, cost-saving mechanisms like trading are essential to any long-term system for emissions reduction, and that at this early stage of a decades-long process such structural matters are as important as the reduction targets themselves.
Meanwhile, the developing countries are continuing to insist that they will take on no further obligations -- beyond a general one requiring them to adopt measures to control greenhouse gases -- until the rich nations act. But unless they do, some key United States senators say, the Senate is unlikely to ratify any agreement emerging from Kyoto.
The senators, in fact, have become more than shadow players in the talks. Several are observers here and have had discussions with a number of delegates. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said here yesterday that he believed the Senate would approve an agreement "if it feels like all countries are reasonably and responsibly sharing in the solution."
No one expects the developing countries to take on the same commitments as the rich nations, and a number of possible options for strengthening developing countries' participation are being considered. One would be a legally binding commitment to limit the growth of developing-country emissions -- though not reduce them outright -- after about 2010.
A proposal to begin talks next year leading to such commitments for all but the poorest countries by 2014 was offered formally tonight by New Zealand with American backing, and it ignited fierce opposition. The chairman of the developing country caucus, Dr. Mark Mwandosya of Tanzania, said his group would simply refuse to take part in the preparatory talks.
Another option would be to allow developing countries to take on legally binding commitments voluntarily, as their economies grew and matured.
A third option would be what is called "joint implementation." In this arrangement, highly favored by the United States, a business or government in a rich country finances or provides the technology for a specific emissions reduction project in a developing country -- a more efficient, emissions-saving power plant, for instance. The donor country or company would share credit for any emission reductions.
More than two dozen experimental pilot projects are now under way.
A fourth option, proposed by Brazil and favored by the developing countries as a group, would require rich countries that fail to meet targets to pay into a fund that would finance the adoption of greenhouse-friendly energy technologies by developing countries.
Voluntary solutions might not be acceptable to the Senate, Senator Baucus said. Senator Chuck Hagel, a conservative Nebraska Republican who heads a key committee, emphatically agreed and said that new developing-country commitments must begin at the same time as those of the rich nations.
Some environmentalists here are urging the United States delegation to ignore the Senate and go for the best agreement possible. Ratification does not have to come immediately, they say, and in the meantime the United States can proceed with its own domestic emissions reduction program, as President Clinton has said it would do if no satisfactory agreement is reached here. Then, at some future date, the United States might ratify the treaty.
Other interested parties, like Kevin Fay, who heads a moderate business group called the International Climate Change Partnership, say it would be better to put off discussions beyond Kyoto if it looks like no agreement acceptable to the Senate is possible. To do otherwise, he said, risks poisoning efforts to get Congress to approve funds for the domestic emissions-reduction programs.
Not everyone is gloomy about the developing-country issue. Mr. Estrada had this to say: "The only thing the developing countries are waiting for is for the developed countries to make commitments. The moment we have that, everything else will fall into place."

HEADLINE: Markets Feel Minor Impact From Job Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets broke with convention yesterday, as they both shrugged off unexpectedly strong November employment data.
Buoyed by vibrant growth and an inflow of money from foreign investors, the stock market ran its recent rally to six sessions and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks surged to its first new high since the market plunge seven weeks ago. Bond prices, which fell sharply after the Labor Department announced nonfarm payroll jobs jumped 404,000 last month, managed to rebound by the end of the day to erase most losses. 
 For much of this year, good economic news has pushed bond prices lower, as traders and investors worried about rising inflation and an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve. Stock prices usually followed suit, though a robust economy should be good for corporate earnings.
But the financial turmoil in Asia seemed to have changed the equation.
The optimistic interpretations of the strong jobs report that let the stock market rally and the bond market rebound seem based on a newly optimistic view of Asia. A month ago, Asian financial shocks were causing stocks to plunge and many investors to seek a haven in the bond market.
Now, many investors appear to think the bailouts by the International Monetary Fund are containing the problems and that the drag on the American economy from any slowdown in Asia will actually be a benefit, especially because it could keep the Fed from raising rates.
"The late rally in bonds is related to people who feel that the employment data is old news," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "It may be the best number on employment we are going to see for a long time because Asia will slow down growth."
Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, said stock investors were looking through the strong jobs data and seeing the economy slowing in 1998. "And the odds of the Fed tightening, even with these jobs numbers, is not very high," he said. The Fed's policy-making committee meets on Dec. 16.
Stephen D. Slifer, the chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers, added, "Investors seem to be convinced that we can have more of the same: moderate growth, low inflation and the Fed not tightening."
In this equation, the biggest question remains moderate growth. The economy grew at a 3.9 percent pace in the 12 months ending in September, well above the Fed's goal of 2 to 2.5 percent. If the Asian drag does not slow the pace enough by February, when the Fed meets again on interest rates, the central bank may decide to raise them.
The S.& P. 500 rose 10.69 points, or 1.1 percent, to 983.79, just eclipsing the previous high of 983.12 on Oct. 7. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 98.97 points, or 1.2 percent, to 8,149.13, just 110 points from its high of 8,259.31 reached on Aug. 6.
Mr. Pradilla argued that a strong lift for the stock market was coming from oversees investors and from Americans who had invested abroad. "People will not be buying India, Malaysia and Thailand for some time," he said.
The price of the 30-year bond plunged 1 16/32 after the release of the employment report but rebounded to end down just 1 6/32 at 100 20/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, surged to 6.16 percent before falling back to 6.08 percent, up from 6.05 percent. On Thursday, the yield had dipped below 6 percent for the first time since January 1996.

HEADLINE: Report Finds Persistent Health Ills Among Young Blacks

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
A group of black academics and community leaders said yesterday that despite the citywide economic progress in recent years, the social and economic conditions among the city's blacks, especially black children and teen-agers, still lag behind those of other groups.
The Urban Issues Group, a New York policy research institute focusing on issues concerning black people in the city, said that its compilation of Federal, state and city data showed that black infants still have the highest rate of mortality in the city, at 13 deaths per 1,000 live births, a rate nearly twice of that of the white infants. 
 "Black children are still faced with tremendous problems in this city compared to the children of other ethnic groups," said Dr. June Jackson Christmas, the executive director of the Urban Issues Group and a former New York City Mental Health Commissioner. "We believe that we've got to challenge New Yorkers of all backgrounds to do something active to help the welfare of black children."
Black infants, she said, are more than twice as likely to be born with low birth weight than the white infants, a condition she said could lead to developmental problems and affect the children's future. Health experts have linked infant mortality to late or inadequate prenatal care, and Dr. Christmas said that pregnant black teen-agers in New York often receive inadequate care.
Dr. Christmas also said that black youths are more likely to drop out of high school and to die from violent crimes and AIDS-related illnesses than members of other ethnic groups in the city. Black teen-agers, she said, also continue to have a higher rate of unemployment compared with their white counterparts. Those with jobs generally earned less than the white youths.
Participants said that recent budget cuts in social services have made it more difficult for them to continue providing services to the needy families in their neighborhoods. Willie Wren, the president and chief executive officer of the Miracle Makers, a family and children services center in Bedford-Stuyvesant, said his agency has already laid off 30 workers and will lay off 7 more by next February, when the city's Department of Health will stop financing a meal program for AIDS patients.
Fred Winters, a spokesman for the Department of Health, said the patients will be fed by other nonprofit agencies. He said his agency has not cut financing to black neighborhoods in the last two years.
The report showed that of the 78 children 12 and younger who were suffering from AIDS in 1995, 48 were black, and of the 77 AIDS-related deaths in 1993 among children of up to 14 years old, 42 were black. In 1993, when 39 whites between 15 and 24 died as a result of homicide, 368 blacks did.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

DATELINE: Saturday, December 6, 1997

 BODY:

The dollar jumped, surpassing 130 yen for the first time since May 1992 to settle at 130.20 yen, up from 129.39 yen on Thursday. D11.
 
Kodak Loses Trade Ruling
The World Trade Organization sided with Fuji Photo Film of Japan in a dispute with Eastman Kodak. The ruling vindicated Japan, which had been accused of unfairly protecting its photographic film market, and was a defeat for the Clinton Administration, which had sought to use international trade rules to open up the Japanese economy. The decision was also a big loss for Kodak, which has been locked in a struggle with Fuji. A1.
 
The campaign against a proposal to relax the standard for products labeled "Made in U.S.A." was unexpectedly fierce. What started out as an effort to recognize the reality of American commerce in the global market turned into a referendum on product quality, truth in labeling, the power of unions and good old-fashioned patriotism. California Bank Sale Studied

The United States economy last month created 404,000 jobs -- double what had been forecast -- as the unemployment rate edged down to 4.6 percent, another 24-year low, the Labor Department said in a surprisingly strong report.

HEADLINE: JOB GROWTH IN U.S. POSTS HUGE JUMP; WAGES ALSO CLIMB

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The American economy showed surprising strength last month by creating 404,000 new jobs, as the unemployment rate edged down to another 24-year low and wages surged, the Government reported today.
Yet the jump in jobs and wages comes with little sign of inflation. And the recent economic troubles in Asia will probably mean lower-cost imports into the United States, putting further downward pressure on consumer prices. 
 So, at least for the moment, the traditional worry that more jobs and higher wages will surely bring inflation and higher interest rates is being set aside.
For once, what was good for workers was also seen as good for Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 98.97 points, to 8,149.13. Bond prices plunged early in the day but recovered somewhat. The yield on the 30-year Treasury ended the day up three-hundredths of a percentage point at 6.08 percent.
Looking at the jobs report, economists and analysts saw evidence of optimism for household incomes, corporate profits and even holiday retail sales.
"We're in the best of all possible worlds," exulted President Clinton's chief economic adviser, Janet L. Yellen. "This was just stunning job growth."
The addition of more than 400,000 jobs was twice what had been forecast by most economists. The jobless rate declined by one-tenth of a percentage point from October, to 4.6 percent in November, the lowest since October 1973 -- before the Arab oil embargo. Without signs of inflation reviving, economists say, there seems to be scant threat to the current economic expansion, which is now almost seven years old.
Hourly earnings did climb a hefty 7 cents, which analysts said would encourage holiday shopping, but this was not thought likely to overly concern the Federal Reserve, which meets Dec. 16 for the year's final deliberations on monetary policy.
Over the latest 12 months, earnings rose 4.1 percent. Using the most recent monthly measure of consumer prices, the real gain in wages -- that is, adjusted for inflation -- is running at 2 percent, the highest in two decades, according to David Wyss, director of research at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, a research firm.
Analysts generally agree that the economy has been growing too fast over the last year to keep inflation at bay for long. But they say the turmoil in Asia will serve as a brake on the American economy, with the Asian nations tightening their belts and buying fewer goods from America, perhaps knocking half a percentage point from growth in total output.
So, the troubles in Asia, economists say, may slow the American economy enough that the Federal Reserve will not have to cool off the economy with higher interest rates.
At the same time, most economists agree with the Administration's contention that the economy is plenty strong enough to cope with the expected falloff in demand for American goods from Asia.
"We're well positioned to absorb repercussions from the Asian situation," Ms. Yellen said in an interview.
From around the country, employers and workers attested to the booming labor market, reflected in the third-biggest monthly increase in payrolls this decade.
John Stollenwerk, president of the Allen-Edmonds Shoe Corporation in Wisconsin, said he snapped up seamstresses and other workers when a company in Milwaukee closed down. "We sought these stitchers the way the crusaders sought the Holy Grail," he said.
One of the employees, Maria Gonzalez, said simply, "They hired me quick."
Today's report showed that Hispanic workers have benefited particularly from the labor shortage, which is most pronounced in the Midwest. The unemployment rate for Hispanic workers tumbled to 6.9 percent in November from 8 percent in October and is now at its lowest since this rate was first calculated in the early 1970's.
Another record was set as the proportion of the working-age population with jobs -- the so-called employment-population ratio -- rose three-tenths of a point, to 64 percent.
In contrast to some months when big swings in payrolls are attributed to things like strikes or storms, the November figures did not reflect any special circumstances, Labor Department officials said.
"A booming November employment report," was how James McCormick, an economist at J. P. Morgan, described the situation to clients. "The message is that the economy is still strong, the labor market is getting increasingly tight and wages are accelerating."
By region, the shift was greatest in the West, where the jobless rate fell four-tenths of a point, to 5 percent. Elsewhere, unemployment was only slightly lower or unchanged -- with the Northeast at 5.1 percent in November, the Midwest at 4.2 percent and the South at 4.5 percent.
Not only did payrolls swell by 404,000 last month, the growth for September and October was also revised up a combined 34,000, to bring the three-month average to a staggering 330,000. The gains were heaviest in services and retail trade, but factories added 44,000 jobs, the third big increase in four months, and construction jobs jumped 29,000, despite unusually cold weather.
Retailers, facing a shrinking labor pool, were nonetheless able to recruit workers for the holiday season. Department stores put 31,000 more people on payrolls. Restaurants and bars hired 30,000 more people, the first big increase since July.
Despite the stock market's slide in late October, the finance industry added 15,000 workers last month.
Some 671,000 more people had jobs last month than in October, enough, when combined with a 453,000 expansion of the labor force, to trim the nation's unemployment rate one-tenth of a point. This matched the 4.6 percent last posted in October 1973; the rate has not been lower since a 4.4 percent reading in March 1970.
"The tailwinds behind the U.S. economy are strong," concluded Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. But, he said, "powerful headwinds" loom, especially the Asian crisis, which he expects will hold growth in the American economy in the first half of 1998 to a 2 percent rate, barely half that of the latest 12 months.

HEADLINE: Dollar Hits 5 1/2-Year High Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar jumped yesterday after a surprisingly strong United States employment report, hitting a five-and-a-half-year high against the yen and overcoming warnings that Japan might act to curb further weakness in its currency.
The rise put the dollar in New York above 130 yen for the first time since May 1992. 
 Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka of Japan briefly interrupted the rally in Asian trading, saying in a Tokyo news conference that Japan was prepared to deal with excessive yen weakness in a "timely and appropriate way."
Unconfirmed reports that Japan quietly used money from its foreign exchange reserves to make dollars available to Japanese banks also briefly checked the advance. Some troubled Japanese banks are having difficulty borrowing dollars cheaply in international money markets.
But more investors flocked to the dollar after the Labor Department said payrolls surged 404,000 in November -- nearly twice the expected rise. The dollar also got support from a rally in United States stocks.
 "The dollar has been doing very well and stocks are up," said Doug Lee, an assistant vice president at Sakura Bank Ltd.
In New York trading, the dollar settled at 130.20 yen, up from 129.39 yen on Thursday. The dollar also rose to 1.7830 marks from 1.7715 marks. The pound fell to $1.6573 from $1.6669.

HEADLINE: Partisanship Imperils Advisory Panel on Medicare

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Medicare is such a hot political potato that politicians here realized long ago that using normal legislative procedures, they would never be able to agree on measures to make the program financially secure for baby boomers when they retire.
So they took a traditional Washington escape route. They voted last summer to create a commission to tell them what hard choices to make. 
 But there are strong signals that this approach will not work either, from the partisanship that infects most things here to the natural unwillingess to take political risks. The commission, even though President Clinton filled it out by naming his appointees today, has a task ahead that is all but insurmountable.
The problem is that beginning in the second decade of the next century, there will be many more retirees and many fewer workers paying taxes to support the retirees' health insurance under Medicare. Any long-term solution is bound to have unpleasant aspects: higher taxes on the working-age population, more out-of-pocket costs to retirees, fewer Government-paid medical services for the elderly, restrictions on who is eligible for the program, or some combination of those steps.
"We have an obligation to strengthen it for the next century, to insure that it is as strong for our children as it has been for our parents," the President said today.
In that vein, provision was made in the Balanced Budget Act that Congress adopted and Mr. Clinton signed last summer for an advisory commission, the members to be appointed by the President and Congressional leaders by Dec. 1, to study the program and recommend changes.
The notion was that if a commission of experts could lay out for the public the dire situation facing Medicare when the baby boomers begin to retire, that would provide the cover politicians would need to make difficult choices and cast tough votes.
Now, prospects have dimmed that the commission will be able to set aside partisan differences and resolve how to change the health insurance program for the elderly and the disabled.
First, Mr. Clinton and the Republican leaders in Congress found themselves unable to agree on who should become chairman of the commission. The President initially decided to miss the Dec. 1 deadline for picking members and wait to name the four members of the 17-member panel he is allotted until he could announce a chairman. But with the chairmanship still unresolved, he went ahead and named his appointees anyway.
Commission chairmen are generally the ones responsible for whether an advisory panel succeeds or fails. They choose the staff and set the tone for the panel's work.
Then Speaker Newt Gingrich's office said on Monday that he had required his four appointees to pledge in advance that they would not accept a tax increase as a solution to Medicare's fiscal problems.
Most authorities on health policy assume that taxpayers, beneficiaries and health-care providers will all have to contribute eventually to making the Medicare system sound. The Speaker's stricture severely limits the options available to the commission members.
That was the point made by Horace B. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, who was approached by Mr. Gingrich about becoming a commission member and declined because he could not take the no-tax pledge.
In an interview later, Mr. Deets said: "The commission should look for all possible solutions. It's too early to take anything off the table. I hope the commission will approach its work with an explorer's mentality, not a crusader's mentality."
Mr. Clinton had a similar response. A tax increase may not be needed, he told reporters on Tuesday, but he added, "I hate to see the commissioners themselves have their hands tied at the outset."
Mr. Gingrich's strong stand against increased taxes had the additional effect of anointing the commission with a distinctly partisan oil.
Republicans have made it clear that they intend to make their opposition to taxes in all forms the cornerstone of their Congressional campaigns next year. The implication of the Speaker's position is that Democrats will be forced to defend themselves at every turn if they do not explicitly reject higher taxes to bolster the Medicare system.
Of course, this is not the first time that politicians have used Medicare for political advantage. For more than 30 years, Democrats have reminded voters in election after election that most Republicans voted in 1965 against the establishment of Medicare.
A repeated theme in the President's re-election campaign last year was his accusation that Republicans were out to gut the program.
But the history of Federal advisory commissions on politically sensitive topics is that the only ones that succeed are the ones that set partisanship aside.
That was the case with the National Commission on Social Security Reform, a panel headed by Alan Greenspan, then a Wall Street economist and now chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. With support from Democrats and Republicans, the Greenspan commission voted in 1983 to recommend a package of Social Security benefit cuts and tax increases. Congress enacted the recommendations almost intact.
By contrast, the National Economic Commission, which was supposed to find ways to lower the Federal deficit at the beginning of the Bush Administration, split along party lines and was never able to agree on a set of recommendations.
Rank partisanship is not the only reason to doubt that the Medicare commission will resolve the problem of how to pay for the program after the baby boomers retire.
No one doubts that a serious problem exists. Even if the rise in medical costs could somehow be restrained, the demographics demand change. There are now almost four workers paying taxes for each retiree on Medicare. By 2015, the ratio will fall to about 3 to 1, and by 2050, there will be only two workers per retiree.
But the crisis in Medicare is years away, and politicians almost never make difficult choices unless their backs are against the wall.
In the case of Medicare, Congress adjusted the program this year to stave off insolvency until at least 2007 (the estimate of the Congressional Budget Office) and perhaps 2010 (the estimate of the Clinton Administration's health care actuaries) or even 2015 (the latest Office of Management and Budget estimate). That was plainly responsible in the short term, but by making a long-term solution more difficult, it was perhaps irresponsible in the long run.
The crunch is "at least four election cycles" away, said Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, an authority on health care financing.
"For a Congress in which over half of the members were not on Capitol Hill four elections ago, that is a political lifetime," Mr. Reischauer added. "The Medicare problem will become someone else's problem."

HEADLINE: 16 Evicted as City Closes Building It Calls a Firetrap

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
The Brooklyn building was a hunting ground for rats, not to mention dangerous -- the stairs were rotting, the wiring exposed, the fire escape a ladder to nowhere. But for 15 adults and one child it was still home, something they now lack after being abruptly evicted by the city this week.
The residents of 477 Park Avenue, a single-room-occupancy building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, were evacuated by the Fire Department on Wednesday and Thursday after inspectors determined that the building had been illegally converted and was a firetrap. 
 "They did the right thing by closing it," said Nestor Collazo, 42, an unemployed handyman who lived in a tiny room on the ground floor. "But we ended up on the street."
Along with many of the other tenants, Mr. Collazo returned yesterday to collect some of his possessions. He grabbed his best clothes and an iron, bidding farewell to a room so small he had to stack two night stands on top of a dresser and a television still on top of that.
The upheaval began Wednesday night, when the Fire Department responded to a call of a kitchen fire. Richard Cruz, 32, another tenant, said small fires were an almost monthly occurrence, but that this time several high-ranking fire officials came to inspect the building.
Fire officials determined on Wednesday that the building had been illegally converted into 11 units, with several tenants sharing kitchens and bathrooms, said Chief Brian Dixon, a department spokesman. Mr. Collazo, who shared a toilet with another tenant, said he used a hose in the unlit basement to shower.
On Wednesday, five tenants were evacuated, Mr. Dixon said, and the Department of Buildings was called in. The next day, fire officials re-evaluated the building, determined that in the case of a fire, tenants could be trapped in the back courtyard, and decided to remove the rest of the tenants. Most of those evicted are now staying with friends or relatives; the Red Cross provided rooms at a motel in Queens for five adults and one child.
Ted Birkhahn, a spokesman for the Department of Buildings, said that while complaints about illegal conversions were common, the city rarely evicts tenants; rather, it usually gives landlords the opportunity to bring buildings into compliance.
Some housing experts and advocates for the poor have accused the city of turning a blind eye to overcrowded and unsafe dwellings, because they absorb many low-income residents who might otherwise be homeless.
At 477 Park Avenue, Mr. Birkhahn said, the lack of a secondary exit in case of a fire posed an "imminent danger" to tenants. "It was a real firetrap," he said, adding that the Buildings Department had received only one complaint about the building, in 1994, related to an exterior scaffolding.
Mr. Birkhahn said the landlord, Shulem Goldenberg, will have to appear before the city's Environmental Control Board, which will assess a fine for any building code violations. He said the landlord must bring the building into compliance with the law before tenants can return.
Those unable or unwilling to return will be placed by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development in shelters or new housing.
In the basement of the building, a tangled mass of electrical wiring lay a few feet from a storeroom stuffed with mattresses. There were other hazards: tenants said they would disinfect kitchen tables before eating because rats had crawled over them; a piece of ceiling had collapsed in one bathroom, cracked windows had been repaired with tape.
The building, along with one at 466 Park Avenue, was bought by Mr. Goldenberg, of Brooklyn, from Victor and Marcus Melendez in 1996, according to property records. Mr. Goldenberg also purchased a dilapidated multifamily residence around the corner on Bedford Avenue, records show.
Reached by phone, Mr. Goldenberg said he was in a rush and refused to answer questions. But Victor Melendez, who owns the bodega, Iris Grocery, across the street, said that when he owned the building, "the Fire Department used to come, the inspectors used to come, they never said anything."
Residents at 477 Park said they paid anywhere from $160 to $400 a month for apartments in a range of sizes.
Mr. Cruz, who lived in an illegal extension at the building's rear, said he was eating dinner on Thursday night when he was handed a pink eviction notice. "It was like, boom, they said get out, just like that," he said. "Our Christmas gift was getting thrown out."
Several tenants pinned their notices to a Christmas tree inside the building before leaving.
