HEADLINE: Kodak Is Loser In Trade Ruling On Fuji Dispute

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization stunned the United States and the Eastman Kodak Company yesterday by vindicating Japan in a protracted dispute over whether the Japanese unfairly protect their photographic film market.
The ruling by a tribunal of the organization sided completely with Japan and a Kodak rival, the Fuji Photo Film Company, and marked an embarrassing failure for the Clinton Administration, which had portrayed the dispute as a challenge to what it contended was a basic problem with the Japanese economic system. The tribunal's ruling also confronted the Administration with the politically ticklish problem of whether to punish Japan with sanctions anyway to help Kodak do business there. 
 For supporters of Kodak, doing nothing could send a message of United States weakness just as more American companies complain about an inability to penetrate the domestic market of the world's second-biggest economy. But any unilateral punishment would not only risk aggravating already-frayed United States-Japanese trade relations but would also smack of hypocrisy, since Washington had agreed to abide by the panel's findings. Indeed, the Americans pushed hard for the creation of such an arbitration process when 118 nations created the trade organization four years ago. Until yesterday the United States had won all seven rulings in trade grievances it had brought before the trade group.
The findings, delivered by a tribunal of officials from Brazil, Switzerland and New Zealand, are preliminary and subject to review. But it was considered unlikely such a complete rejection of the American arguments would be changed. All 21 points in the United States filing were dismissed.
The panel's report is confidential and sent only to the parties directly involved, but officials from Fuji, Kodak and the United States Government described its contents.
"The panel's findings simply do not address market realities," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. "Even within Japan, it is common knowledge that Japan's market is overregulated, its distribution system is closed and exclusionary business practices are prevalent."
The United States had contended that the structure of large sectors of the Japanese economy violated rules negotiated in 1993 by members of the trade organization.
In its filing, the United States had argued that years of regulations and Government guidance had produced such close ties between film manufacturers and distributors in Japan that foreigners had little chance of success. In Fuji's case, the Americans argued, the company enjoyed exclusive relationships with Japanese film distributors serving more than half the domestic market, largely because the Government had let such relationships flourish.
But the tribunal decided that the Japanese Government's actions, some of which took place 30 years ago, did not amount to restrictions on international trade.
The decision was also a setback for Kodak, the Rochester-based photography giant that has been struggling with losses in other businesses and has been locked in a struggle with Fuji for dominance of the world's film markets. George M. C. Fisher, the company's chairman and chief executive, called the panel's findings "totally unacceptable."
Kodak contended that it had been stymied for years in efforts to expand its 10 percent share of the huge Japanese film market, while Fuji has been capturing a rising share of the United States film market.
But most analysts said yesterday's decision would not wound Kodak. "Kodak is finally getting its consumer marketing act together at home, and that will have a far greater impact on its performance than any W.T.O. decision," said Ulysses Yannas, a securities analyst with Mercer, Bokert, Buckman & Reid.
Most analysts also noted that Japanese consumers were very loyal to Fuji, just as American consumers had shown a distinct preference for their own home brand, Kodak. "Maybe the Japanese market is somewhat restricted, but Japanese consumers just aren't clamoring to buy Kodak film," said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Kodak had argued that Japanese restrictions gave Fuji a protected profit sanctuary in Japan, and thus an ample source of cash to subsidize its expansion elsewhere. But most analysts discounted that argument, noting that effectively, if not by Government decree, Kodak had the same type of profit opportunities here. Indeed, despite Fuji's inroads in the United States, Kodak still commands 70 percent of its home film market -- the same percentage Fuji commands in Japan.
But perhaps most important to Wall Street, few analysts accept that Kodak's well-publicized financial woes have much to do with its inability to penetrate the Japanese market.
"No W.T.O. action can change the realities that Kodak's core businesses are under siege while its digital endeavors have failed to establish a beachhead," said John P. Gavin of American Express Financial Advisors.
The international tribunal's decision is politically awkward for the Clinton Administration partly because it comes at a time of domestic discontent with free trade policies. President Clinton failed to persuade Congress a month ago to adopt legislation renewing the Administration's ability to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could adopt or defeat but not amend.
At the same time, the soaring value of the American dollar is producing a widening trade deficit and posing a serious competitive threat to big industries like auto manufacturing.
Both Ms. Barshefsky and Michael McCurry, the White House press secretary, pointed out in separate public statements about the trade panel's findings that American options included invoking Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act, which allows the President to impose sanctions on countries that restrict American exports.
But for all the tough words, there was little enthusiasm in Washington for a move to impose sanctions.
A senior Administration official pointed out that before becoming final, the text of the panel's ruling must go through a two-month review in Geneva, the trade organization's headquarters.
While the review process is largely a formality, it does give the Administration time to determine what to do next, and possibly seek a settlement with Japan.
If no settlement is reached, the Administration could still appeal the tribunal's decision to the World Trade Organization's appellate division, as Japan and the European Community have already done when they have lost cases to the United States.
The main political pressure on the Clinton Administration during the photographic film dispute has come from Kodak and from New York's Congressional delegation. But Kodak and New York's Senators, while bitterly critical of the tribunal's decision, stopped short yesterday of asking the Administration to impose sanctions on Japan.
Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, and Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, issued a joint statement contending that the Japanese market remained closed to Kodak, but called for the Administration to file an appeal with the trade organization. Japan's Government did not comment on the trade panel's findings because it had not seen them. But Minoru Ohnishi, Fuji's chairman and chief executive, praised the findings, saying the panel had "proved its mettle by ruling on the facts."

HEADLINE: As Older Cuban Exiles Die, Young Pragmatists Emerge

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 5

 BODY:
At least once a week as he has done for the past 36 years, Andres Nazario-Sargen, head of the Cuban exile organization Alpha 66, goes to a paramilitary training camp where members dress in camouflage and train with semiautomatic weapons for the day Cuba erupts into armed insurrection against Fidel Castro.
"Gradual change is only in the minds of people who are used to democracy, but that concept is not in Fidel like it wasn't in Hitler," said Mr. Nazario-Sargen, 78, who fought alongside Mr. Castro in the Cuban revolution but now denounces him as "a Hitler-style totalitarian." 
 Mr. Nazario-Sargen represents the unyielding anti-Castro sentiments of the generation of Cuban exiles who lived in pre-revolutionary Cuba as adults and are still fighting to oust Mr. Castro nearly 40 years after he came to power, these days mostly through political pressure rather than violence.
But the death last week of one of this generation's youngest and most prominent members, Jorge Mas Canosa, was a reminder that many of the older Cuban exiles are dying without achieving their political goal, and that younger generations may seek a way to change the government in Cuba through a more pragmatic path than their elders.
This Saturday, Miami's exile organizations plan a march here to reaffirm "our intransigent opposition to Castro's dictatorship," after Mr. Mas's death and on the eve of a cruise trip to Cuba by American Roman Catholics, including Cuban exiles, to see Pope John Paul II when he visits the island, for the first time, in January. But the passage of time is giving that opposition a softer edge. Indeed, while political pressures among the Cubans in the United States work toward the unified hard-line stance symbolized by Mr. Mas, polls have shown a steady generational shift toward a less confrontational position.
A benchmark poll by Florida International University taken every two years found last June that a strong majority still favored the American embargo on trade with Cuba, believed that the American law penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba was a good tool to bring about change and supported military action, either by the United States Government or exile groups.
But the poll also found that an increasing number of Cuban-Americans favor negotiations with the Cuban Government: 48 percent, compared with 36 percent in a similar poll in 1991.
The moderate views are mostly found among younger Cuban-Americans and those who arrived in the United States since 1980 and still have family ties to the island. Seventy-seven percent of those ages 18 to 29 favor establishing a dialogue with Cuba, compared with 36 percent among those 65 and older. Among Cubans who arrived in this decade, the poll found that 74 percent favored a dialogue, compared with 38 percent among those who left the island in the 1960's.
Some younger Cuban-Americans are willing to voice sentiments that would have seemed heretical just a few years ago.
Frances Morales, a 31-year-old language teacher born here of Cuban parents, for example, supports negotiations with the Cuban Government to steer Cuba toward democracy. Ms. Morales is sharply critical of what she sees as the counterproductive, confrontational attitude of many of her elders.
"It's ridiculous," she said. "How many years has it been? If something doesn't work, you have to do something about it. You got to be intelligent."
Ms. Morales, who visited Cuba for the first time three years ago to take medicines to relatives, said the experience made it clear to her that more creative approaches to dealing with Cuba were needed.
The passage of time has also tried the patience of many older Cubans, partly because many are pessimistic about change any time soon. The poll in June found that only 36 percent of Cuban-Americans in Miami-Dade County said they thought that major political change would take place in Cuba within five years, compared with 77 percent in the same poll six years earlier; 17 percent said they thought positive change might never come.
"His excuse all along has been to blame the United States" for Cuba's problems, said Dan Molina, 50, referring to President Castro.
Three years ago, Mr. Molina, a distributor of television sports programs, joined Cuban Change, an organization that seeks normal relations between Cuba and the United States.
"Without an embargo, he has no excuse," Mr. Molina said. "What is he going to tell people? He'd have to adapt or fall apart."
Despite such moderate views, the political agenda that prevails in exile circles is still that of those whose property in Cuba was confiscated and who were forced into exile, of the veterans of the failed Bay of Pigs invasion and other paramilitary missions, of the politically imprisoned and the most damaged. It is their pain that silences others who may object to the lack of open political debate about Cuba here or even the playing of music from Cuba on the radio.
In no small measure, some experts on Cuban-American affairs say, Mr. Mas's Cuban American National Foundation solidified this position since its founding in 1981 by gaining unusual political influence here and in Washington.
"That was part of the brilliance of Mas Canosa; they established the moral definition of what it is to be a good Cuban-American," said Guillermo J. Grenier, one of the principal researchers of the Florida International University poll and himself a 45-year-old Cuban-American who left the island as a child. "That's to be anti-Castro, not to be tolerant of views that are supportive in any way of the Castro regime, and to be vigilant and become a watchdog to protect what it meant to be Cuban."
For the older generations, those in their late 50's and older, the death of Mr. Mas at 58 was a particularly harsh blow. Nonetheless, many in the exile leadership say they feel strengthened rather than demoralized.
"Everybody is very saddened" by Mr. Mas's death, said Luis Botifol, 89, a retired banker who helped create the Cuban American National Foundation, which Mr. Mas headed. "But I haven't found anyone destroyed or disillusioned."
Nobody seems to be reassessing strategy. Exiles like Mr. Nazario-Sargen dismiss any negotiation with Mr. Castro as futile because, they say, they know the man, and some insist they are closer to victory. Faulting the Soviet Union's economic support of Cuba and the United States' policy against military intervention for the longevity of Mr. Castro's rule, exiles lately take solace in the fresh signs of internal restlessness in Cuba, in the resurgence of the Roman Catholic faith in the island, and, of course, in the inevitability of Mr. Castro's own death.
Organizers of this weekend's "Patriotic Reaffirmation March" say the event, planned before Mr. Mas died, is also meant to counter any efforts in Congress or elsewhere to use his death to re-examine current policy.
In fact, there are powerful younger keepers of the conservative flame, including Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, both Republican Cuban-Americans from Florida.
Mr. Diaz-Balart, 43, said any change in American policy, like lifting the trade sanctions, depended on Cuba's willingness to meet three conditions: legalizing all political activity, releasing political prisoners and holding free elections.
"What are the other alternatives?" he said. "The clearest voice against dialogue is Castro's. He's made it very clear that he will not democratize and that he'll die in power."
But while few expect a radical change in American policy toward Cuba for now, even some staunch anti-Castro Cuban-Americans say a subtle erosion of the hard line is likely as conservatives like Mr. Mas die, leading to more debate and a more tolerant political environment here. The same generational shifts, some say, will lead to more political openness and improvement in human rights in Cuba.
"As you get away from 1959, you tend to be more moderate and rational, less passionate and traumatized," said Miguel Gonzalez-Pando, 56, the director of the Cuban Living History Project at Florida International University who served two years in Cuban prisons for his participation in the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, two years after Mr. Castro seized power.
Mr. Gonzalez-Pando said he now advocated respect for all alternatives to deal with Cuba because "nobody has a crystal ball."
In Miami, older exile leaders like Mr. Nazario-Sargen say they realize that democracy in Cuba may not occur in their lifetime. Mr. Nazario-Sargen dreams of building a political party in a new Cuba, and he at first laughed, saying, "I'm going to be in Cuba many years."
But then he said that even if that was not to be, "I'm satisfied because I have done everything I could for my country."
"I have successors," he said. "We're all one generation. The generation of freedom."

HEADLINE: How a Fierce Backlash Saved The 'Made in U.S.A.' Label

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
New Balance Athletic Shoe Inc. wanted to sell more sneakers to Americans who coveted the "Made in U.S.A." label. Trouble was, many of the shoes New Balance made at its factories in this country used outer soles from China.
So when the Federal Trade Commission accused the company in 1994 of violating the rarely enforced, half-century-old standard, New Balance mobilized the Congressional delegations of Maine and Massachusetts, where the company employs 1,300 workers, and waged a campaign for more flexible standards on products originating in the United States. 
 After an extensive two-year review, the commission looked kindly on the request, and last May it proposed relaxed standards. It seemed as if New Balance and other big companies that import a lot of components or goods had won a ringing victory for the increasingly global marketplace.
"It was time to update the standard," said Donna Ruane, a spokeswoman for New Balance, based in Brighton, Mass.
Not yet it isn't.
In a stunning retreat, the commission announced on Monday that it was abandoning its proposal after an avalanche of criticism from organized labor, state officials, consumer groups, more than 250 members of Congress and a large chunk of the nation's small businesses.
The ferocity of the response -- part grass roots, part high technology -- shocked the commission. Populist radio talk-show hosts like Oliver L. North pilloried the idea and urged their listeners to call the commission in protest. Tens of thousands of angry people flooded Capitol Hill offices with postcards.
And a coalition coordinating the opposition posted a web site on the Internet (http://www.usamade.org) to keep its members informed.
"I was pretty surprised," said Jodie Z. Bernstein, director of the commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, which wrote the proposed guidelines. "There were days when I said to my staff, 'Where are all the people who wanted this to happen?' "
What started out as an effort to recognize the reality of American commerce in the global bazaar had unexpectedly turned into an often-times emotional referendum on product quality, truth in labeling, the power of unions and old-fashioned patriotism.
"The F.T.C. tried to do the best they could, but they got creamed on this one," said Maury Lane, a spokesman for Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the Commerce Committee and a leading opponent of proposed guidelines. "They totally misjudged public sentiment."
At the heart of the matter is what Americans expected from a product labeled "Made in U.S.A." The debate shifted along with the political tides during weeks of lobbying this summer and fall.
But in the end, the public comments to the commission overwhelmingly insisted that the label mean just what it says.
"When I see that label, it's like seeing a flag -- it's patriotism, it's job security," said Charles E. Mercer, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s union label and service trades department. "It means everything America stands for."
Indeed, the decision was an important triumph for organized labor, which argued that loosening the standard requiring products to be "all or virtually all" made in the United States would encourage American companies to build even more factories abroad, ultimately eroding wages and living standards in the United States.
People on both sides of the debate said the issue tapped the same vein of economic anxiety and uneasiness that fueled the successful effort last month to derail President Clinton's request for "fast-track" authority to negotiate international treaties.
Up until last May, however, there were few signs of the firestorm to come.
By then. some 150 companies from a wide array of industries had weighed in, as did 26 members of Congress. They were evenly divided over whether to modify the World War II-era "Made in U.S.A." standards, which was often interpreted to mean 98 percent of a good's value.
After holding workshops, conducting public opinion surveys and consulting numerous experts, the commission concluded that most Americans valued the "Made in U.S.A." label. But it also recognized that in today's marketplace, few products are made with all-American parts and labor.
So the commission suggested changing the 50-year-old standard of "all or virtually all" to "substantially all." Goods with as little as 75 percent of their manufacturing costs, but still assembled in the United States, would be entitled to bear the "Made in U.S.A." label. The new standards would not apply to automobiles, textile, woolen or fur industries, which are regulated by individual laws.
"I thought we came up with something very reasonable," said Ms. Bernstein, the consumer protection bureau's director.
When the commission unveiled the proposed guidelines in 16 pages of regulations on May 5, the response from Capitol Hill was less than deafening.
The commission delivered copies of the guidelines and a press statement to all 535 members of Congress, and invited them to a special briefing a week later.
A total of 7 Senate staff members and 10 House aides showed up.
But opposition was building momentum. On May 15, Representatives John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and Bob Franks, Republican of New Jersey, along with 13 other House members introduced a nonbinding resolution opposing the proposed guidelines.
"The bottom line is this: the agency charged with upholding truth in advertising is attempting to pull a fast one on America's consumers," Mr. Franks said at the time. "The label that represents pride in American workmanship could soon become a Government-sanctioned tool of commercial hucksters."
A group of consumer advocates, labor unions, agriculture associations and small businesses soon formed the Made in USA Coalition, an umbrella organization run by three lobbyists from WinCapitol Inc., a public affairs firm in Washington.
The coalition updated the web site, bought advertisementsin two Capitol Hill newspapers, organized a high-volume fax campaign and coordinated the efforts of the alliance.
Among the most vocal opponents of the guidelines were small family-owned hand-tool and tile-making companies, many of whom faced stiff competition from foreign companies or American companies that imported foreign parts.
"American tools have always been recognized around the world as having superior design, engineering and overall quality," said Harry McCarty, president of Baltimore Tool Works Inc., which makes chisels, wrecking bars and other tools.
"I was offended by the deceptive description that a product could be labeled 'Made in U.S.A.,' but have components from somewhere else, Mr. McCarthy added."
Darlene Adkins, vice president of the National Consumers League, a 10,000-member advocacy group, said, "The 'Made in U.S.A.' label is even more valuable than it was 50 years ago because we are living in an increasingly global marketplace, and consumers want to support American jobs and manufacturing."
By late summer, senior commission lawyers and aides feared that they were being swept up in an increasingly emotional issue. More than 150 Republicans and Democrats had signed the House resolution.
On Sept. 11, the Senate opened a second front in the lobbying war when Mr. Hollings and Senator Spencer Abraham, a Michigan Republican who is a member of the Commerce Committee, introduced a nonbinding resolution supporting the existing standards. The guidelines' fate was sealed when Senator Trent Lott of Missippi, the majority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, joined the Senate resolution.
"If a product says 'Made in the U.S.A.,' it should really mean it, and that brought together people from diverse political and economic perspectives," Mr. Abraham, who sparred with the commission earlier this year over a hospital merger in Michigan, said in an interview today.
Conspicuous by its absence was any well-organized campaign by companies that supported the proposed changes, including shoe wear and bicycle companies, to counteract the opponents.
Just as big business bore some of the blame for failing to rally round Mr. Clinton's "fast-track" authority, this time around corporations that stood to benefit from the commission's proposals were silent.
"Where industry failed is that companies tried to do everything through trade associations and didn't step forward themselves," said Jason B. Clawson, a lobbyist in Washington for many companies that favored the changes.
But most of the biggest trade associations, including the National Association of Manufacturers and the United States Chamber of Commerce, took no position on the proposed changes, because their members were badly divided on the issue.
Nor did the White House weigh in one way or the other. "I never got a single call or comment from anyone in the Administration," said Robert Pitofsky, the commission chairman.
In the end, the opponents just outlobbied the supporters of the guidelines. "It's a complicated issue and we tried," said Ms. Bernstein, a 30-year veteran of Washington's regulatory wars. "But we just didn't communicate the proposal well enough."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
2 Queens Men Arrested In Massage Parlor Holdup

DATELINE: LYNDHURST

 BODY:
Tipped off by an employee of a methadone clinic who had seen a television news report about a series of robberies at New Jersey massage parlors, police detectives in Manhattan arrested two men yesterday and charged them in one of the holdups, the authorities said.
Daniel T. Solla, 33, and George Rivera, 25, both of Queens, were charged with robbing a Lyndhurst massage parlor on Sept. 29, said William H. Schmidt, the Bergen County Prosecutor. He said they are suspects in another holdup in Lyndhurst and three others in Passaic and Lodi. 
 Mr. Solla, who is unemployed, was arrested by detectives from the 13th Precinct at a Manhattan methadone clinic after an employee recognized him from a Dec. 1 report on Fox 5 News, said Officer Kathleen Kelly, a spokeswoman for the New York City Police Department. Mr. Rivera, who works for a construction company in Watchung, was later arrested at home, Officer Kelly said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 3303 words

HEADLINE: Editors' Choice

 BODY:
On the 1997 list of best books of the year, chosen by the editors of the Book Review, are five novels, one volume of stories (more or less), two biographies, one history, one volume of science and one true account of a tragic adventure. Of the fiction writers -- four men and two women -- only one, an Englishwoman who began writing novels 20 years ago, when she was 60, has never appeared on this list before. Of the nonfiction authors -- two women and three men -- only one has appeared on the best books list before. In a year that was not notable for translation of new work, eight of the 11 authors are Americans and three are British.
Three of the novels on the list are concerned with American history, and three of the nonfiction volumes are about people who, whatever else they did, were writers (one novel is also about a writer). What is more striking is that no nonfiction work here is longer than either of the two biggest novels. In recent years one has come to expect biographies to outweigh any other genre, but this year's biographies were both written by British authors, who respect relative brevity more than we do -- even when, as this year, both biographers used a kind of enveloping method, fusing the lives of their subjects with the history of their periods to give a deeper perspective. Those two big novels, the longest books on the list, both by men, count 827 and 773 pages; the two shortest volumes (226 and 236 pages) are also fiction, both by women. 
 For the first time in at least 15 years the boss commanded that the discussions the editors conduct before they vote be presided over by civility. They were, so there is nothing to be said about them. Perhaps civility inspired generosity, for this year's group of the chosen, longer than last year's, was selected from 11 works of fiction and 13 of nonfiction nominated by individual editors throughout the year -- the shortest roster of nominees in a decade.
Certain types of books, like letters and diaries, are not eligible, even though this year's letters included those between Gertrude Stein and Thornton Wilder, between Evelyn Waugh and Nancy Mitford, and a selection by Marianne Moore, and among the diaries was that of Alec Guinness.
The best books are taken from among those reviewed here since last year's Holiday Books issue, and the summaries given below are generally based on those reviews. And the best books are not included among the Notable Books of the Year, the listings of which begin on page 58.
 
AMERICAN PASTORAL
By Philip Roth.
Houghton Mifflin Company.
This novel is a lament for the death of the dream of assimilation that was precious to the children of Jewish immigrants of Philip Roth's generation. Nathan Zuckerman returns to New Jersey for a high school reunion and meets again his boyhood hero, Swede Levov, the admirable athlete who dutifully took over the family business, married a beauty queen and grew rich. But after Swede dies, Zuckerman undertakes an imaginative investigation into this success story and finds disaster. Swede's only daughter at 16 had joined the Weathermen, planted bombs in public buildings, lived destitute in hiding for years, became a radical devotee of an Oriental religion and finally returned to New Jersey, where Swede has a shocking meeting with her shortly before his death. What this beautifully elaborated tale dwells on is the deaths she caused, the damage she spread through her family, and on an insistent question: how is it possible that these good parents could raise this dislocated person? A hint of an answer is heard in an apparently innocent little contest, when the girl was very young, between Swede's father and his wife's Roman Catholic mother for the soul of their granddaughter. The themes the old people sound reverberate in virtually every conversation among other characters here, exchanges that have nothing to do with religion but ask just as pointedly how much we can share without losing our souls. Thus the tone of this allegory -- a remarkable mixture of rage and elegy.
 
AMERICAN SCRIPTURE
Making the Declaration of Independence.
By Pauline Maier.
Alfred A. Knopf.
Most historians have treated the Declaration of Independence as a central document of the Age of Enlightenment, a product of the natural rights philosophy of John Locke and other British theorists. And most people see Thomas Jefferson as its author, a claim Jefferson made the year he died. Now, with good-humored feistiness and some mockery of official pieties, Pauline Maier presents the Declaration as the embodiment of the American mind and colonial experience rather than as the work of Jefferson or the progeny of any philosophy. The big deal in 1776, she argues persuasively, was the popular decision to get out of the British Empire; independence was a necessity, not a philosophical choice. With striking originality, she sets the famous document in the context of 90 local declarations of independence issued beforehand by colonies, cities, towns and grand juries; the people had declared independence before the Continental Congress did. She shows Jefferson cobbling together his draft from his own preamble to the Virginia Constitution and George Mason's early version of Virginia's Declaration of Rights (which said all men are created equal). And she reproduces the editing done in two days by the Congress, so we can watch the delegates shortening and improving Jefferson's draft. The July 4 document, virtually ignored for a generation after it appeared, became the great American scripture only after it was enlisted as a weapon in partisan political battles of the early 19th century.
 
THE BLUE FLOWER
By Penelope Fitzgerald.
Mariner Books/Houghton Mifflin Company.
Penelope Fitzgerald's early novels were comedies of contemporary British eccentricities so sharp that she got a reputation as an almost disreputably enjoyable author. As she moved on to stories about other countries and other eras, her habitual insight and authority carried over naturally into these more historically complicated settings. Her new novel makes the greatest leap of all; it is her most recondite and challenging book, and as authentic a piece of imagination as one can find about a writer -- in this case the great German Romantic Novalis (1772-1801). Here he is a philosophy student in the 1790's, his mind exploding with ideas and his heart falling captive to a spirited teen-age girl. There is no better introduction than this novel to the intellectual exaltation of the Romantic era, its political ferment, its uncertain morals, its innocence and refusal of limits. It is also a wholly convincing evocation of that notoriously difficult matter, genius; its presence in Novalis and his siblings fairly crackles in these quiet pages. The book also reaches far beyond its story, becoming an interrogation of life, experience, human horizons and love (its reminders of what it feels like to be in love the first time are luminous). As always, Fitzgerald's economy is next to miraculous, and the language is an enchantment: without a hint of mimicry, she uses virtually undetectable shifts in emphasis and phrasing to conjure up the tone of the German of 18th-century Saxony; it rings true.
 
HUXLEY
From Devil's Disciple to Evolution's High Priest.
By Adrian Desmond.
Addison-Wesley.
This racy biography of Thomas Henry Huxley (1825-95) is a portrait of the modern age being born. Huxley was a superb scientist and Adrian Desmond writes about science as lucidly as anyone can, but Huxley was also the great apostle of Darwinism, and Desmond vividly sketches his ferocious assaults on the structures of Victorian society -- religion, class, education -- as he molded Darwin's scientific revolution into a social engine to overthrow the old order. The man and the historical transformation are one in this intensely dramatic, amusing account. It does not try to make either the man or his age too coherent; Huxley was a bizarre, intricate character, and there was a sense of chaos -- the reader can feel it -- as the established regime crumbled and Huxley's version of evolution became the ideology of the new industrial order. He was the most contentious man alive; he was also prodigiously energetic and cunning. To see the rise of science, and the middle class, amid such political tumult is to gain a new insight into history. He created the idea of "the scientist" as the idol of the new age. He coined the word "agnostic" and proudly applied it to himself. Gifted publicist and social engineer that he was, he sold the world on the ideals of skepticism, experimental openness, objectivity and undogmatic clarity. The idea of being lofty, above politics and wholly objective may have been absurd in Huxley's case, but it was seductive enough to change the entire outlook of later generations.
 
INTO THIN AIR
A Personal Account of the Mount Everest Disaster.
By Jon Krakauer.
Villard Books.
Until May 1996, 630 people had climbed Mount Everest and 144 had died on it. That spring at least 30 expeditions of tourists made the climb. On May 10 a rogue storm blew up, and eight people in three separate expeditions approaching or leaving the summit died. Jon Krakauer, a 42-year-old writer, was with one team, assigned by Outside magazine to report on the commercialization of Everest. Although 12 people died altogether in 1996, he says, a record, 84 made it to the top, so it was a safer-than-average year. Krakauer explains the economic incentives for experienced climbers to lead groups of amateurs up the mountain, the even greater incentive for Nepal to license the trips and the total lack of incentive to limit the numbers risking their lives. When things go wrong in the death zone, the last 2,000 feet, and eventually they do, even the world's best guides cannot save the tourists, or themselves. But his book does more than report on lethal tourism. He wrote it to "purge Everest from my life." It didn't. It may put Everest ineradicably into your mind. This deftly constructed tale lets you sense the excruciating torture of climbing five miles high, the exhilarating and terrifying disorientation of oxygen starvation, the capricious moods of wind and snow, the strange seductiveness of death at odd moments. His re-creation of the storm that killed his companions swirls around the reader like the gale itself and gives this appalling struggle with death a horrifying intimacy.
 
MASON & DIXON
By Thomas Pynchon.
Henry Holt & Company.
Thomas Pynchon's finest novel is a book of heart, fire and genius. Its structure is classic comedy: the astronomer Charles Mason, as straight man, and the surveyor Jeremiah Dixon, to whom the madcap is just a reflex, bumble along in the mid-18th century drawing the line that separated Pennsylvania from Maryland and West Virginia, the North from the South. The narrator says history needs tending by fabulists, counterfeiters and cranks, and Pynchon gleefully joins the company. The story of this map-making becomes an investigation into the order of the universe, aiming to convince us that reason is inadequate to penetrate the world's mysteries. The book's abundant humor balances on the thin edge of anachronism; history, myth, anecdote and hyperbole are perfect equals. The style is bumptiously Fieldingesque, but subversively pumped up with allusions not only to yesterday and today but to Pynchon's other novels and many 20th-century masters of fiction; the allusiveness and self-awareness are a good part of the fun. The robust characters -- merchants, prostitutes, barmen, Indians, caffeine addicts, a talking dog, cabalists, sailors, poets, clerics, along with historical icons like Washington, Franklin, the Penns and Baltimores -- wrestle with a reader's understanding. As for Mason and Dixon: they are Pynchon's deepest creations; we know them from youth to death and, for all their confusion, surliness, resentment and loneliness, they inspire sympathy, perhaps even affection.
 
THE PUTTERMESSER PAPERS
By Cynthia Ozick.
Alfred A. Knopf.
Fiction, schmiction -- Cynthia Ozick is a literary centaur, half-scholar, half-artist, who loves a fantasy landscape with infinite allegorical possibilities, and she cheerfully leaves it to the reader to fill in the blanks when she feels like popping out of her story into commentary. What holds these five pieces together is simply Ruth Puttermesser (the word means butter knife, and the book ends with a funny, poignant poem about love and butter knives), a New York Jew whose mental life is richer than all the financial markets and political offices she floats through and who has to wait for heaven to realize her best dreams and worst apprehensions. Along the way she creates a female golem who makes Puttermesser Mayor of New York but who also grows gigantic and has to be unmade when her sexual appetites exhaust the Mayor's entire administration. Next Puttermesser and a new lover take on the roles of George Eliot and her lover, George Henry Lewes -- a caper that allows Puttermesser to deliver some brilliant literary insights, including a few into the work of Ozick. After an interlude with Puttermesser's Russian cousin -- a breathtaking sendup of Upper West Side intellectuals and their critics -- Puttermesser is in Paradise, married, with a son, and grown woefully wise about heaven. These papers can hardly be said to have a beginning or end, but when they stop, one is surprised to feel so deeply possessed by the painfully comic spirit of Puttermesser.
 
TOWARD THE END OF TIME
By John Updike.
Alfred A. Knopf.
From Word 1 John Updike undermines readers' -- and critics' -- logical assumptions in this novel, for the text is the journal of a 66-year-old man, Ben Turnbull, who at the end of his own time seems freed of time. His journal reveals not only the world but the wanderings of his wits. So what if a woman turns into a deer his wife had wanted him to kill? So what if he jumps from a United States in the next century, disintegrating after a war with China, to ancient Egypt, or to virtual reality? So what if characters appear and disappear like phantoms in a dream? Our sense of logic rises from time, and here time is drizzling into a black hole. Turnbull's journal is like "Walden" gone haywire; Ben is brilliantly observant of nature, but if Thoreau's gaze is innocent, Ben's is a gritty-eyed squint. And unlike Thoreau, Ben has women: a wife (the unvoiced struggle as each watches for the other to croak first is an entrancing game); a middle-class slut, or a deer, who inspires lust, guilt and longing for lost youth as they rollick through contortions of very Updikean sex; and a barely nubile gang moll who brings back to Ben his prepubertal self. No matter; soon enough time melts Ben's potency to ooze, and he is as ruthless in describing decay as he was in depicting his sexual romps and obsessions. Indeed, if Ben's ruthlessness is evenhanded, so is his alarming intelligence; it falls on every scene, person, object and thought in the book, giving it an eerie ambiance.
 
UNDERWORLD
By Don DeLillo.
Scribner.
Don DeLillo has always been a harshly original writer, rich in dangerous alienation, with great gifts of eye, ear, nose, palate and fingertip. But his reputation was cult-borne. With "Underworld" he fills the sky. In this novel he diagnoses the debilitation of the cold war, by probing into how people rearranged their lives around the moral void of an absurdity, mutually assured destruction. From its opening, at one of baseball's greatest games, to its inspired epilogue in a Central Asian institution filled with radiation-misshapen humans, it surges with magisterial confidence through half a century. But its true locations -- test sites -- are not on maps, and its characters live, psychologically, downwind from them. Here bland, hopeful American life glows with the sick light of betrayal, innocence abused; everyone's better feelings take a beating, and ambient moral fear pinches everyone -- not only his invented characters but a host of cultural heroes who appear, from J. Edgar Hoover to Lenny Bruce. The protagonist is an entrepreneur of waste; the novel bursts with witty and dramatic conjurings of garbage, voidance, slag. The dialogue is a rockingly comic attack on our mental excreta: the distortions and sound bites of the television age. DeLillo was absent from his fiction before, an unbodied intelligence, but here is an undertow of personal pain he has never touched. This is his most demanding novel and yet his most transparent, giving the reader the privileged intimacy that comes from seeing a writer whole.
 
VIRGINIA WOOLF
By Hermione Lee.
Alfred A. Knopf.
Virginia Woolf said a biographer had to be like the miner's canary, "testing the atmosphere, detecting falsity, unreality and the presence of obsolete conventions." She might have been writing about Hermione Lee. This exceptionally well-researched, beautifully written and graceful life rescues Woolf from her iconic standing and restores her to human dimensions. Among the obsolete conventions Lee avoids are the politicized agendas of the academy and jargon-ridden psychoanalytic speculations. Without special pleading -- Woolf's faults are in full view -- she maintains a real modesty in the face of the irreducible nature of the writer, but she is capable of shrewd psychological conjecture about Woolf's intellectual and imaginative growth. She vividly re-creates the world Woolf was born into in 1882, a maze of formalities and reticences, and then leads us through changes that, slow in coming but shocking in effect, made all that seem light-years away by the time Woolf was 50. She convinces us that Woolf, contrary to previous assumptions, reveled in a deep intimacy with her husband, Leonard. Finally, she makes a persuasive case for the underlying sanity of this woman as she battled her own madness and shows the brilliant literary uses she made of her instability; as Woolf said, her madness kept her sane. In the end, without being told so by Lee, the reader is pretty sure to conclude that Woolf was personally heroic in life and that, against all odds, she had become a great writer.
 
THE WHOLE SHEBANG
A State-of-the-Universe(s) Report.
By Timothy Ferris.
Simon & Schuster.
The whimsical title refers to what cosmologists do. They are trying to account not for the physics or chemistry or any one aspect of the universe, but for the composition, history, appearance and operation of the whole thing. As Timothy Ferris -- an admirably knowledgeable journalist and a great guide for ordinary readers -- says, this is a big order. So is his book. The sweep is vast: in eight chapters he canvasses the theory of the Big Bang, the dynamism of the universe, the shape of space, the origins of the chemical elements, the debate over the dark matter that makes up most of the universe, the mystery of the clumping together of stars and galaxies, the search for a Darwinian explanation of the history of the universe and the hope of finding one unified theory to explain everything. Then he gets to the really big stuff: the inflation of the universe and what that implies, where it all came from, how quantum mechanics works and why it suggests there may be many universes, and how humanity, the source of all these theories, fits into a scientific explanation of the whole shebang. Ferris's theorists are not just thinking machines; some are as strange and unyielding as the universe they study. He has a gift for making readers understand not only what the scientists know but how they know it. Finally, as in no previous book of his, Ferris sticks his neck out here, showcasing at least one theory that cannot be tested for years.

HEADLINE: Chicken Kiev

BYLINE: By Ken Kalfus; Ken Kalfus is an American writer living in Moscow. His collection of short stories, "Thirst," will be published this spring.

 BODY:

THE BLUE LANTERN
 And Other Stories.
 By Victor Pelevin.
 Translated by Andrew Bromfield.
 179 pp. New York:
 New Directions. $22.95. 
 Does the world exist? Could its reality be something entirely different from what our experience has led us to believe? Do I really want to eat that chicken?
There is nothing particularly Russian about these questions, except perhaps the last one. Doubt about physical reality has become integral to a worldwide contemporary culture that has built very nearly concrete alternate realities out of electronic impulses. If anything, it verges on cliche. The way Viktor Pelevin makes his existential inquiry fresh and relevant is by bringing to it his Russian, post-Soviet experience of the world.
Soviet society was disconnected from reality in a particular way, by ideology and propaganda. When these props were removed, Russians found themselves adrift in another universe, one in which new laws of physics (or at least economics) held sway, history had been rewritten once again and the old verities were radioactive trash. These days, an overlay of Western advertising and imagery has descended upon the land, especially in boomtown Moscow, creating yet another weird simulacrum. For a writer keen on the disjunction between the actual and the virtual, current Russian circumstance is a bonanza.
Born in Moscow in 1962, Pelevin is best known in the West for his short satirical novel, "Omon Ra," which is based on the conceit that the Soviet Union's spectacular success in using robotic spacecraft early in the space age was a fraud. The sputniks and luniks were in fact operated by pilots hidden away inside the vessels, doomed never to return. As Omon, Pelevin's kamikaze cosmonaut, soars into the higher reaches of space and the Soviet space program, he discovers new frauds and new spheres of official reality.
In "The Blue Lantern and Other Stories," Pelevin continues to gnaw at our confidence in conventional reality, like a dog worrying a bone. Nearly every story in this collection contains an ongoing dialogue about the nature of reality -- between two Moscow prostitutes, between two cocaine-snorting soldiers in revolutionary Petrograd and, in a story called "Hermit and Six-Toes," between two truth seekers who, in the end, turn out to be chickens plotting their escape from the Lunacharsky Broiler Combine.
American readers will note a strong resemblance between Pelevin and Philip K. Dick, who often placed his characters in situations in which they were unsure whether they were awake or dreaming, alive or android. Russians are more likely to read Pelevin alongside Andrei Platonov. In Platonov's novel "The Foundation Pit," completed in 1930, workers debate the nature of the universe as they dig the foundation for some vast Soviet building. Like Platonov, Pelevin understands that beyond the narrative screen of language is another reality that we can't quite get at.
Pelevin, however, is a whole lot funnier than Platonov, who suffered obscurity and repression under Stalin. But then Pelevin lives in much more amusing times -- darkly amusing as they may be. In "Mid-Game," the prostitute Lyusa, working the Moscow hotels in the most impoverished years of perestroika, translates the inscription on an American five-dollar bill, "legal tender," as "legitimate affection." In "News From Nepal," a "rationalization engineer" in a trolley garage is having a bad day at work, made all the worse when she discovers that she and her colleagues are dead:
"Shushpanov was trying to plug the bullet-hole in his temple with the top of a pen, Karyaev was trying to straighten the bones of his smashed skull, Shuvalov was combing his forelock over a blue mark left by lightning, and even Kostya, obviously recalling something from a brochure on drowning, was giving himself artificial respiration."
And it is the chickens who treat us to a lengthy philosophical discussion about the oblong white spheres from which they emerge and which, paradoxically, also emerge from them -- as well as the 70 worlds, the Wall of the World, the Decisive Stage, Shop Number One and love. Prophets to the other chickens, Hermit and Six-Toes exhort what is literally their flock to exercise and fast, in order to put off being slaughtered and frozen. "Those of you who from this day forth until the very Day of Judgment shall fast, shall be born again. Oh, Lord! And now arise and sin no more!"
Anyone who has ever contemplated a Russian factory chicken, in all its scrawny, blue-skinned glory, can imagine the number of them who found religion in vain.
From the evidence of Andrew Bromfield's translation, Pelevin does not appear to be as great a stylist as Platonov. (Neither was Dick.) But Bromfield, who also translated "Omon Ra," successfully captures Pelevin's irony and black humor and has found a fluid, contemporaneous English that suits the stories' post-Soviet outlook. Bromfield exists, I'm sure of it. As for Pelevin, his stories' sheer loopiness suggests that he is simply a figment of the reader's imagination.

HEADLINE: Lonesome Dude

BYLINE: By Andy Solomon; Andy Solomon is a professor of English at the University of Tampa.

 BODY:

COMANCHE MOON
 By Larry McMurtry.
 752 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $28.50. 
 In the years since Larry McMurtry's first novel, "Horseman, Pass By," was made into the movie "Hud," he has created a body of work almost as large and cinematically picturesque as the Texas landscape that is his favorite setting. And he doesn't look to be quitting any time soon: his latest book (which is being billed as the final volume in his enormously popular "Lonesome Dove" series) is a colorful adventure that fills the gap between the green days of Gus McCrae and Woodrow Call, seen as young Texas Rangers in the novel "Dead Man's Walk," and their sunset years, depicted in the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Lonesome Dove."
"Comanche Moon" finds the affable McCrae and taciturn Call at the height of their powers -- and they need to be. Led by Capt. Inish Scull, a Harvard scholar who "saw no reason to be teaching military history when he could go out in the field and make it," the rangers are still facing the formidable opponent they first encountered in "Dead Man's Walk," a fierce Comanche named Buffalo Hump.
The decade from the late 1850's to the late 1860's, when the novel takes place, is a period of relentless white settlement interrupted by the four-year hiatus of the Civil War, and as it proceeds Buffalo Hump sees his future all too clearly. The buffaloes are vanishing as quickly as the whites are multiplying, and noble warriors are reluctantly moving to the reservations. But Buffalo Hump believes that a great Comanche war chief does not go gently. Rather, "since the white men were there in his land, his country, he meant to live off their animals." He has little patience with chiefs who talk of treaties or hotheaded warriors who fight without respecting the old ways, including his own son, Blue Duck, whom he expels from the tribe. As a final hurrah, Buffalo Hump mounts a sweeping campaign of slaughter from Austin to the Gulf of Mexico, the Great Raid of 1856.
Blue Duck survives to become the murdering renegade of "Lonesome Dove," but in "Comanche Moon" his lust for atrocity is anticipated by the bandit Ahumado, the Black Vaquero, who lurks south of the Rio Grande and alternates his mode of torturing captives: skinning them alive or tossing them into a pit of rattlers and scorpions or setting them atop sharpened tree trunks and watching them slowly descend. But for McCrae and Call, these physical dangers are easier to cope with than the dangers posed by their ungovernable emotions -- notably their love for two very different women.
McCrae proposed to Clara Forsythe on the day he met her, "but she had hesitated then" and years later she is still hesitating: "Though Gus moved her in ways no other man ever had or, she feared, ever would, something in her still refused." Clara simply can't imagine happiness with a man suffering from such wanderlust, so she slips away and marries a dull but safe Nebraskan. Unlike McCrae, Call seems incapable of passion for anything -- except maybe his rifle. The lovely prostitute Maggie Tilton worships him and even bears him a son, but despite the affection he holds for her, Call finds it impossible to acknowledge her devotion.
In "Comanche Moon," McMurtry has created a sprawling, picaresque novel that, like the history of the West itself, leaves more than a few loose ends. Some characters' fates we can only surmise. Others await resolution in "Lonesome Dove." As usual, though, the characters are the novel's strength. McMurtry's rangers are heroic because of their vulnerabilities, not despite them. Except for Scull, who declaims Xenophon in Greek, and McCrae, who'd been a college man until it wore off, these are mostly men of few words. McMurtry's women are more effusive; they love abundantly, but they are also pragmatists. His Comanches are respected, not romanticized. When Buffalo Hump rides off to die, he is grateful for "the knowledge that in the years of his youth and manhood he had drawn the lifeblood of so many enemies."
McMurtry's novels often have titles that hint of a wistful twilight: "The Evening Star," "The Last Picture Show," "Leaving Cheyenne." Here the wistfulness lies in a West he is savoring even as it is disappearing. Like the Comanches, McCrae and Call know that their time is nearly gone. After all, pacifying the frontier is a job whose ultimate goal is to render them unemployed. In the heroic time of "Comanche Moon," these men set out to tame the West; just a few years later, in the 1880's of "Lonesome Dove," they will finally be tamed themselves.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2429 words

HEADLINE: HOTEL CHECK-IN;
What's in a Brand?

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE; BETSY WADE writes the Practical Traveler column.

 BODY:
A COMPANY in Parsippany, N.J., called HFS Incorporated has its signs on 5,550 hotels in the United States. But you don't see "HFS" over the door. The signs bear more familiar names: Howard Johnson, Ramada, Days Inn, Super 8, Travelodge, Knights Inn, Villager Lodge and Wingate Inn. And in these and other properties around the world, HFS owns not a single registration desk, not one HoJo ice bucket, not even an imprinted ballpoint pen. HFS was formerly known as Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc., and it is the largest lodging franchiser in the world.
Biggest, and growing. One of its brands, Super 8, opens a new motel every 2.5 days. Like all the other components of HFS, it does not own, manage or operate any hotels bearing its name. 
 "The consumer often does not know that the company whose name is on the door does not own the real estate," says Chuck Ross, a vice president of Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which tracks changes for the travel industry.
Hotels, like fast food, are advertised, and chosen, based on those names, which are intended to telegraph certain information: the level of comfort and service, price range, convenience, security. The big names may offer frequent-guest programs tied in with airlines. And while staying at a name-brand hotel can assure travelers of some standards, the control a chain has over individual properties can be quite minimal.
In Silver Spring, Md., Choice Hotels International franchises of seven brand names used by 2,843 hotels in the United States. Since October, when Choice was spun off by Sunburst Hospitality, the real-estate company that owns 75 properties, Choice has done nothing but license the names Sleep Inn, Comfort Inn and Comfort Suites, Quality Inn and Quality Suites, Clarion Inn, Clarion Hotel and Clarion Resort, Econo Lodge, Rodeway Inn and Mainstay Suites.
Among other major franchising companies are Hilton, Holiday Hospitality, Hampton Inn and Embassy Suites (both Promus companies), ITT Sheraton, about to become part of Starwood Lodging Trust, and Radisson Hospitality. Best Western, one of the oldest brand names in the United States, with a board elected from among its members, is an association of independently owned hotels.
To confuse the issue further, some of these big franchising companies manage some of the hotels that bear their names. Still other famous names -- Hyatt, Ritz-Carlton and Four Seasons among them -- are primarily management companies. Inter-Continental does some of both. A few companies, often small ones like Chalet Susse International, own the places with their names.
The franchise evolution dumbfounds Anthony G. Marshall, dean of the School of Hospitality Management of Florida International University in Miami. "Forget Ramada Inn!" he cried. "There is no Ramada Inn company. There is no such thing anymore. Let the buyer beware: Do not put your full faith and confidence in a sign."
At more and more hotels these days, one company owns the name and nothing else, a second company or real estate investment group owns land and buildings and still another operates the hotel -- and none of these, to use Mr. Marshall's example, is the Ramada Inn company. The Ramada Inn name is in the sole custody of an HFS division, Ramada Franchise Systems Inc.
John Russell, the chairman and chief executive officer of HFS Hospitality, which comprises the giant company's eight hotel brands, said: "By the year 2000, about 50 cents of every dollar will come through a franchise company. That is a huge increase from the 15 cents that franchises represented six or seven years ago."
Samuel F. Pryor 3d, a partner at the Manhattan law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, said that about two years ago he was on the road half the business days of the year. His schedule is easier now, he said, but in any event his hotels are virtually always familiar names, although he notes that lawyers on their clients' business pick places that the clients consider appropriate. "They stay in first-class hotels," Mr. Pryor said, "we stay in first-class hotels." His firm, like many, has a travel department, and it also has rules that favor established names.
Frequent guest programs also tend to channel business travelers into established brand names. Mark Benerofe, vice president for programming for Sony, is on the road so much that he asked for reservations for the Westin Copley Place in Boston for all Tuesdays in the next three months. He said Boston was so overbooked he was wait-listed for five nights. His company authorizes use of both Westins and Ritz-Carltons, but as a Gold member of the Westin's Premier frequent-guest program, he has a vision of a reward trip to the Far East, "if I ever get the time."
His current complaint about Westin, a management company, is that it has not yet put his personal preferences -- for a nonsmoking room, for instance -- into the computer system the front desk uses at an individual hotel. He took one complaint to Westin headquarters in Seattle, but found no great response.
As for consistency, a main attraction for many travelers, Mr. Marshall says it is possible for franchisers like HFS, Choice or any other to set good safety and cleanliness standards as a condition of permitting use of the name and providing reservation services. "But the level of franchiser control that is spelled out in the contract," he said, "is usually as low as possible, and just enough so the sign can be pulled off the property if the owners fail or default."
From the traveler's standpoint, safety considerations should come first. Almost all franchisers require smoke detectors in bedrooms, even in towns where local fire codes do not. In new buildings, most franchisers require that the detectors be wired into the building power supply so they are not disabled by dead or missing batteries. Hotels higher than three stories that want to meet Government standards for its employees have sprinkers in the bedrooms, too. Where new hotels are being built, sprinklers are usually part of the required construction.
The other area in which franchisers often make a security requirement is electronic keys, and most franchisers are moving in this direction in their higher- or medium-priced properties. These safety essentials may never appear in an independent lodging place if no local code requires them.
When a brand name is new, and the franchiser requires the franchisee to build a new property to get the name, the franchiser may set the design of the building, lobby, rooms and even the showers. This is the case with Sleep Inns.
The franchise situation can become a problem for the consumer when it's necessary to get hold of someone who can fix a problem or authorize a refund. The question that often arises in a theft, for instance, is whether a franchiser will make amends for failed security. Mr. Marshall says that the franchiser usually leaves the owner or operator to cope with the complaint under local innkeeper-liability laws. Such laws are in place to protect the property owner, the theory being that no one would open an inn if he or she had to compensate guests for every theft on the premises. These laws are usually posted on the back of the hotel door.
The experience of a reader from Stowe, Vt., Frank Calderon, shows how far a franchiser may back away from the problems of the hotel itself. On a business trip in April, Mr. Calderon was waiting for his room at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in Madrid, when a suitcase containing his heart medicine was stolen from the lobby. Frustrated in his attempts to deal with the hotel, in June he sent to Thomas R. Oliver, the chairman and chief executive officer of what is now Holiday Hospitality, a copy of his complaint. The response he got, from Wendy Olson, an assistant in the guest relations department in Salt Lake City, said:
"The hotel in question is a franchised property. Holiday Inn Worldwide does not own, operate, manage or control the day-to-day operations of franchised Holiday Inn hotels, such as this one. Pursuant to the terms of the license agreement, the owner is responsible for all claims relating to the operation of the hotel . . .
"We are concerned with the operation of properties carrying our name. Your comments will be taken into consideration in Holiday Inn Worldwide's evaluation of guest satisfaction at this hotel. However, due to the nature of your disagreement with his property, it falls beyond our sphere of jurisdiction to render action."
Mr. Calderon's dispute with the hotel continues, with the core of the issue whether the hotel had taken control of the suitcase at the time the bag was stolen or whether it was still in the owner's custody.
What franchisers do provide, typically, are buying services for furniture and equipment that meet their specifications; brand-name advertising and promotion programs such as movie tie-ins; central telephone reservations systems; wholesale purchasing of towels and similar items, and staff training. Last year Super 8 created a training program for its owners and managers called the University of the Pineapple, a reference to an old hospitality symbol.
The promise of consistency is what makes the franchising system work. How does a franchiser keep the name bright and worth the price when it cannot, or does not want to, get in there and vacuum the rug or replace the plumbing? A clause in its contract allows withdrawal of the brand name. When complaints mount, or company inspectors find things not plumped up and shiny, or royalties are not paid on time, the franchiser puts the property into technical default. Then comes a "curing period," when the owner or manager is given time to come up to standards. If that does not happen, the sign comes down and the franchiser stops taking reservations for the property.
If a customer calls and asks for a reservation for a particular Quality Inn in Someplace, Iowa, and the contract there has been canceled, "we just tell them there is no Quality Inn in Someplace," said Betsy Bromberg O'Rourke, senior vice president for marketing services at Choice Hotels International. The reverse can happen when a traveler calls a local number, expecting to hear "Quality Inn, how may I direct your call?" and gets the news when a voice says, "Moderne Manor, how may I . . . ?"
The physical sign belongs not to the franchiser, but to the owner or operator, so when a property is "terminated," in the franchise companies' language, and the operator refuses to take the sign off, the franchiser may have to go to court. This usually takes 90 days, Ms. O'Rourke said. If the sign stays on in this period, she said, Choice headquarters makes good on any guarantees that the brand name advertises. Most other companies interviewed said the same.
SMITH TRAVEL RESEARCH says that 5 to 10 percent of the properties in a particular brand are culled each year for not meeting standards. Ms. O'Rourke said 5 percent was the overall figure for Choice brands, but Econo Lodge was closer to 7 percent. Mr. Russell at HFS put his overall figure at 7 percent last year: out of 5,400 hotels, 378 hotels (representing 32,000 rooms) were terminated.
The principal reasons for terminations were failure to send the money in and failure to meet the standards; Mr. Russell said most were a combination of the two.
Hampton Inns, another big franchiser, got considerable publicity when it began its 100 percent satisfaction guarantee in 1989, but other franchise companies say that almost all properties must make full refunds for real dissatisfaction. Many even have an official policy. This means that all travelers have in effect been appointed inspectors for the franchisers. The number of refunds that must be given at a particular place are collated and tracked and the total becomes part of the property's record. Not incidentally, this data base enables a franchiser to keep track of fraud -- customers who complain regularly as a way of staying free.
Wherever a satisfaction guarantee is offered, and a guest cannot get it from the front desk, a letter should be sent to the franchise company at the address given on the opinion card in the room. The companies probably talk a better game than they deliver, but there is no reason to give up after one pass if the problem was serious.
The company now called Holiday Hospitality began life in 1952 as Holiday Inns, then as now a franchise company. It is owned by Bass, a British company. The new Holiday Hospitality chief, Mr. Oliver, in office nine months, said the company was mandating an expensive overhaul of all its 2,350 properties because many looked old. "Everything tends to run down," Mr. Oliver said. "We need to maintain health and fitness."
He estimated that the 5 percent termination rate at Holiday properties would rise because some owners would not want to spend the money to renovate. As many travelers realize, hotels that lose one brand name may find a new one lower on the price-amenities scale. In the hotel trade, this is called a soft landing, and many clusters of brand names maintain an inexpensive group for this purpose.
As for taking the sign down, few events can match the Ritz-Carlton dust-up earlier this year. Ritz-Carlton is not a franchiser but a hotel-management company of which 49 percent is owned by Marriott International. That's only the beginning of the list of the cast of characters. Just after midnight of Aug. 1, four hotels, in New York, Washington, Houston and Aspen, Colo., out of the 24 in the group, lost their names. Ritz-Carlton, which had been managing them, had been in a dispute with an investment firm owned by Sheik Abdul Aziz bin Ibrahim al-Ibrahim, a Saudi. The investment firm controls the holding companies that own the four hotels. The holding companies in 1995 accused Ritz-Carlton of mismanagement, and Ritz-Carlton has said that the holding companies owe $4 million in fees. When the contract expired, Ritz-Carlton lowered its flag.
Two weeks later, ITT Sheraton, a Boston company that franchises 213 of the 439 hotels with its name, got one-year contracts to manage the nameless luxury properties. Sheraton placed the hotels in its high-priced Luxury Collection, where they were listed, in late November, as "ITT Sheraton Luxury Collection Hotel-Aspen-Washington-New York City-Houston." Stacked above such syllable-sparse names as St. Regis and Carlton, they do stick out, as Lisa Dickason of Sheraton said. But that won't last. "We hired a naming company," she said.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Despite Rise in Rates, Hotels Are Filling Fast

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
TRAVELERS who keep up with lodging trends know that New York hotels have essentially been full most of this year and last, but they are sometimes surprised to learn that hotel rooms are scarce in many other cities. "The occupancy rate is so high in Boston that many Boston-bound travelers are staying in Providence and driving the 45 minutes to conduct their business," said Brenda D. Farrell, a spokeswoman for Johnson & Wales University, which runs a hotel school in Providence, R.I.
Much the same is true in most regions of the country, where the combination of business and leisure travelers, with a huge assist from international visitors, is filling hotels not just in traditional tourist cities but in nearby cities and states as well. Moreover, most categories of hotels are benefiting from the growing tendency of business travelers to stay over on weekends -- either to obtain air fares that are often two-thirds less with a Saturday-night stay, or because they have their families join them on weekends. 
 Yet while budget and economy hotels benefited from the nationwide demand for rooms, the clear-cut winners this year are luxury hotels, whose 75.7 percent occupancy rate led every other category by a wide margin. Upscale hotels, one step below luxury, which also have restaurants, room service and an array of amenities, were the runner-up with 69.4 percent occupancy. "This is the total reverse of a decade ago, when the budget and economy hotels had the highest occupancies," said Chuck Ross, a vice president of Smith Travel Research.
Because of such demand, the average room rate in the United States rose 6 percent to $74.96 through September of this year, the latest month for which figures are available, compared with the same period last year. Among the cities with the biggest hikes were New York (the highest at 12.9 percent), San Francisco, Orlando, Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia.
Nationwide occupancy during the first nine months of 1997 actually decreased .9 percent from the same period last year, to 66.5, according to Smith Travel Research. But without the rate increases and a 3 percent growth in the number of rooms, occupancy so far this year conceivably would have surpassed last year's record nine-month occupancy of 66.9 percent.
However, as many travelers have discovered, while hotel owners pray for a full house, demand for rooms has emboldened many of them to raise rates even if it means lower occupancies -- a far cry from the early 1990's, when a sputtering economy forced many hotels to lower rates so far that owners could barely service their debt, much less earn a profit.
In some cities, lackluster performance resulted from the addition of smaller, limited-service hotels with more rooms to fill. That appears to be the case in Dallas, where occupancy dropped 3.7 percent as the construction of predominantly budget and economy hotels led to an 8 percent increase in available rooms. In Atlanta, new limited-service hotels built in anticipation of the 1996 Olympic Summer Games yielded a 10.3 percent increase in available rooms, which now appears to have contributed to the city's occupancy rate tumbling 6.1 percent. Room rates have fallen 7.7 percent to $76.99.
Atlanta has also had trouble cashing in on the worldwide exposure from the Olympics (when room rates averaging more than $115 a night also led to lower than expected occupancy). By contrast, although hotel occupancy in New Orleans dipped .3 percent through the first nine months of this year, in the face of a 2.3 percent gain in available rooms, room rates grew 8.2 percent, to a hefty $104. As P.K.F. Consulting noted in September, the ability of hotels in New Orleans to charge premium prices during the Super Bowl -- which took place last January -- has lasted throughout the year.
Washington's hotel market remains an anomaly, largely because its results include hotels in nearby Virginia and Maryland -- convenient locations to which many travelers turn for lower room rates. Over all, however, the region racked up a 72.3 occupancy rate this year, a gain of 3.1 percent over 1996, and room rates rose 5.8 percent to $99.64. The Clinton inauguration last January helped, but a bigger factor was that the number of new rooms grew only a minuscule .8 percent during the nine months.
For all Smith Travel's diligence, however, its data have a notable (although deliberate) omission -- Las Vegas, the biggest hotel market of all, with more than 100,000 rooms. It is not included, Smith Travel said, "because of the unique nature of the attractions of that city and the reliance on gaming." But Kevin Bagger, senior research analyst at the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, said the city's occupancy rate through August of this year was 88.2 percent -- down 3.6 percent from the same period last year. Not to worry. During that 12 months, room supply grew about 10 percent to 103,916, but when 26 new gates open next summer at McCarran International Airport, said Mr. Bagger, "it should help fill most of those rooms also."
