SECTION: Section 6; Page 48; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1053 words

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
Our Pious Press

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
My text this sunday is the "Unsecular Media," a good book by Mark Silk that inspires thought if not yet faith. It sets you thinking about the saintly role that religion has acquired in our allegedly irreligious media. And it leaves you hopeful that Silk's critique may yet embolden journalists to explore religious faith and institutions with greater sophistication, the way they cover theory and practice in politics, science and economics.
Silk, a historian of religion and an occasional journalist, heads the Center for the Study of Religion in Public Life at Trinity College. His 1995 treatise was cast as a defense of the media against the charge that they are run by "secular humanists" hostile to all faiths. But his main message was that journalists mostly see religion as it sees itself. He found us so intimidated by the subject that we dare to discuss religion only in the vocabulary of mainstream religious values. 
 As Silk recounts, some of the first newspapers in the American Colonies were indeed iconoclastic about the clerical establishment -- as well as their governments. And in the mid-19th century, James Gordon Bennett's New York Herald set the standard for mass-circulation dailies by freely covering clerical sin, exposing conflict over church properties and intruding into previously closed ecclesiastical policy debates. And the very appearance a century ago of successful Sunday papers like this one became a symbol of journalism's sacrilege. In the words of one New York minister, the Sunday paper "not only employs a large number of persons for its sale upon God's holy day but it furnishes secular reading to divert the mind from the holy themes especially appropriate to the Sabbath."
After a marked decline early in this century, reporting on religion once again increased, but it returned in notably timid, sentimental and pious forms. Even when the news concerned clerical hypocrisy or other churchly wrongdoing, the press accepted the mainstream churches' definitions of themselves, hewing to story lines that are rooted in religious doctrine.
All too often, what passes for religious coverage is a ritual celebration of papal tours or holiday ceremonies. Only a few of the conventional Saturday "church" pages venture deeply into the realm of beliefs and dogma. Mostly, Silk found, religion writing holds to a predictable pattern of safe topics: the good works that churches do; their tolerance of other mainstream religions; the hypocrisy of religionists who betray their professed beliefs; the false prophets in unconventional cults like Heaven's Gate; the validation of once-alien faiths like Islam, and the recurrent cycles of religious decline and revival.
The media, in short, love to dwell on the feel-good stuff about religions and to pounce on the pious phonies who steal from the collection basket, cavort with prostitutes or pretend to be Jesus. But only rarely do we follow the trails of doctrine by which different religions inspire political action in society. We cover the formal legal scrapes about the "separation" of church and state but shy from the moral and ideological influences of the clergy and lay religious leaders.
Taking their lead from the established religions, the media are often too quick to demonize the "cults" of unconventional sects and movements. They forget that all too recently even Mormons were thought to be following a false prophet and Roman Catholics were openly scorned for betraying American interests to the Pope's. Faiths like the Unification Church or Branch Davidians are rarely examined for the essence of their appeal to their followers; instead they are rapidly denounced for "brainwashing" their faithful. Yet the reports of miracles and supernatural visions in the more established ministries cause even the most skeptical reporters and editors to wax poetic and suspend their disbelief.
Now that television has awakened to the entertainment value of angels and other Heavenly servants, the same sentimental cliches appear in prime-time dramas. Even the best of these, ABC's "Nothing Sacred," dwells mainly on the healing powers of handsome priests who rush among urban emergencies. A recent episode championed the gift of tongues against the villainous atheism of a skeptical psychiatrist.
You would think that such a program's worshipful respect for religious experience could not possibly provoke significant objection. But American society has grown so unaccustomed to honest examination of religion that a lay league of protesting Catholics was able to frighten a slew of commercial sponsors away from "Nothing Sacred." They took offense at the program's suggestion that priests sometimes experience sexual temptation and that some Catholics tolerate abortion. Even if the program survives, it will not grow braver.
The paradox of such sensitivities is that they drive religion out of our public debates. The media's prescriptions for a healthy society come almost exclusively from contending physicians, politicians and advertising agencies. Their recipes for the good life come more from cooks than clerics.
Is it too much to expect serious newspapers and television magazines to broaden their approach to religious issues and institutions? Besides exploring the ethics of law, medicine and business, why not debate the multiple sources of our ethics? Why not track the teachings and, yes, the lobbying of our many religions on such issues as assisted suicide and euthanasia, marriage and divorce, social welfare, immigration, feminism and environmentalism? What do religions have to teach us about our quests to prolong life and to locate extraterrestrial life, about how to ration medical care and welfare?
There is obviously a certain news value in the commonplace accounts of the number of Americans who regularly attend a church or religious school and the delicious diversity of those institutions. But those reports should be only the beginning of media efforts to discern how and where we Americans acquire our moral teachings, our shifting sense of what is right and wrong in human transactions. Different religions are, by definition, different views of the world, and they are often usefully divisive as well as cohesive. It is merely pious coverage that is truly irreverent.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 100; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: Faith Is a Hands-On Proposition;
Deputizing the Flock

BYLINE: By Laurie Goodstein; Laurie Goodstein is a religion correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
It is a Wednesday night at Canaan Missionary Baptist Church in Louisville, Ky., and every room in the sprawling building is alive with activity. Sitting in the pews, 520 people are studying Matthew 28. In the recreation hall, 57 children in the youth choir are rehearsing. Downstairs, a class for new members is led in prayer by a seasoned church member who joined all of nine months before.
And down the hall, toddlers are singing to the tune of "Frere Jacques": "I am special, I am special. Look at me." 
 The church's pastor is not here tonight. The Rev. Walter Malone Jr., an intense man with a speaking style as deliberate as a hike up Mount McKinley, is on his way to Israel for a 10-day tour for African-American clergy. Malone is the reason many say they were drawn to this church, but his absence doesn't stop them from coming. They come to worship, they come to socialize and they come because there is work to be done.
Canaan Baptist makes ministers of its members. The church expects its men and women -- mostly African-American, from all over the city -- to pitch in and build up both the church and its community, in the struggling west end of Louisville. There is a mission to match every talent: a sports ministry, a youth ministry, a men's ministry, a food pantry and, as of 1992, a nonprofit Community Development Corporation. And everyone is asked to be a "prayer partner," expected to pair up with another member of the congregation and look after that person's spiritual, physical and emotional health.
"The key is," says Eugene McCormick, the church's administrative assistant, "once they come in, you've got to get them involved. You don't do that, you lose them." McCormick, a layman himself, helps teach the Wednesday-night Bible study in the pastor's absence. "The Bible says we are a kingdom of priests. We can all be ministers."
It used to be that virtually the only way laypeople could serve in their church was to volunteer as ushers, Sunday school teachers or deacons, positions usually reserved for men and women of especially upright reputation. For most people, church was something that happened on Sundays.
Talk to ministers and congregations across the country now, and you will find that churches that ask little of their flocks are withering on the vine. The churches that demand a lot -- in time, in tithes, in commitment -- are the ones attracting a growing, and younger, membership. This may sound surprising in an era when people complain about working longer hours and having less free time, but it makes sense. On average, Americans move more than 10 times in their lives, and many find themselves shopping for a new church -- and applying the same smart-consumer mentality they use to choose a new car or a college: what features does this product offer me? They want to know, is there a day-care center? A singles ministry? A senior outreach program? Do I feel comfortable there? Even the oldest and largest churches can't hire a staff big enough to minister to so many different needs, so they turn to their members to magnify the reach of the church.
Leaving the Canaan Baptist new-members' meeting on a recent evening, Niesha Stubbins said that she and her fiance had joined the church after hearing Malone preach that life is like a basketball game. "He was saying, 'You've got to get in the game -- you can't sit it out,' " said Stubbins, an 18-year-old nurse's aide. "That made sense to me."
Ministers like Malone who preach a gospel of individual empowerment and community self-reliance are in step with their times. "While we are on the way to heaven, we have to have some bacon and eggs on the journey," Malone says. "God wants us to experience life at its best. Every person needs to have the opportunity to experience what it means to be truly human. We have to help build people's lives individually so people can live with a sense of vision in their lives, a sense of purpose."
Malone, 42, sees himself as a "spiritual heir" to the teachings of Martin Luther King Jr. A lean 6 feet 4 inches, he wears a goatee and a baseball cap that says "JC" -- as in Jesus Christ. He founded Canaan Baptist 14 years ago with 97 members. Now it has 2,429.
Not long ago, four members sat in the nearly bare offices of the church's Community Development Corporation and described how Canaan Baptist had drawn them in. They liked the rollicking choir and the unpretentious warmth of a place where strangers greeted one another with full hugs. But what really won their allegiance, they said, was the church's appeal to reach out to the people Jesus called "the least of these."
Having grown up of modest means in Olive Branch, Miss., Shirley Gettis recalled that "my mother took everybody in. Everyone poor, drunk, down on their luck. I never really used that experience till I came to Canaan. We get out and feed the hungry and take them clothes and visit the sick."
And Canaan Baptist's Community Development Corporation moves beyond the realm of charity to the poor. It relies on volunteers, mostly from the church, to teach courses in job preparation, entrepreneurship, home ownership and computer skills. It has built three houses for low-income, first-time home buyers and is building four more. It has begun teaching classes for neighborhood children in dance and drama.
Sherri Franklin left her job as a graphic designer to join the development corporation three months ago "to do something more meaningful," she says. Franklin remembers that the first time she called Canaan Baptist for directions about five years ago, Malone himself answered the phone; after that morning's services, he sought her out and told her that the church needed her. "No other pastor had ever taken the time to tell me why I should join their church," Franklin says.
Malone expects not merely time from his flock but also money. Members are asked to donate 10 percent of their income, and they are also expected to give $12 a week toward a Dare to Dream fund to expand the church's activities, and $7 a week for the development corporation. Last year, church members raised $86,053 for the corporation and $20,000 more for educational scholarships, divided among 10 students from the congregation. For many Canaan Baptist members, such obligations are difficult to meet. The congregation is a home to students and truck drivers as well as professionals, and many people hold more than one job. There are homemakers, grandparents raising grandchildren and the unemployed. There are, as Malone says, the working poor "and the just po'."
"He has high expectations," says Saundra Calvin, one of Canaan's founding members and now the executive director of the development corporation. "Every time he asked, I know I didn't have the money, but I gave and got back double."
On a cold fall evening before Malone left for Israel, I rode with him as he steered his Mercedes slowly around the perimeter of his newest and most ambitious project: the 22-acre compound across town that his church just bought from Southeast Christian Church to hold its expanding congregation.
"All this is our property," Malone said. Except for the tall cross on the roof, the new church that Canaan Baptist will be moving into late next year has the look of a modern shopping mall, with more than 50 classrooms, a fellowship hall and a 2,500-seat sanctuary clustered like an island in a sea of blacktop.
Yet it isn't clear what the future may hold for Canaan Baptist. For all Malone's emphasis on sharing leadership, most congregation members I spoke to said they were stunned when he announced one Sunday last year that their church had bought the Southeast Christian property -- in a white, middle-class part of town. Some members were skeptical about the financial risk. Others were chagrined that the church seemed to be abandoning the hard-bitten west side with which it was so identified.
Malone responded to the concerns by pledging to keep the development corporation running in the west-end location. And the initial surprise has given way to an instinct to pull together. In the church's lobby, a red fund-raising "thermometer" shows nearly $600,000 raised toward the cost of the move; and Wednesday night's Bible study closed, as usual, with a parade of lay leaders stepping to the pulpit to plead for volunteers for the basketball and cheerleading ministry and ticket buyers for the development corporation's annual banquet.
Saundra Calvin told the churchgoers that she knew the $35 price was steep. "But God has blessed all of us in some way, and the Lord truly, truly, truly has His hands on Canaan," she said. "The Bible says, from those to whom much is given, much is required."

HEADLINE: Young Artists Finding Island Fuels Creative Juices

BYLINE: By PHYLLIS BRAFF 

 BODY:
WE used to think that all ambitious and talented young artists trying to launch their careers set up studios in the cosmopolitan city center, yet an increasing number seem to be deciding that Long Island has advantages that outweigh the city's promise. Their reasoning often involves space, nature, light, life style, serenity, economics and, not infrequently, the Island's special geography.
A variety of thoughts about their Long Island studio locations emerges from conversations with more than a dozen artists, all in their 20's and 30's, who have been receiving recognition for significant work. Those who chose the East End became increasingly conscious of the historically important artists who established studios in the area. Every one couples his ideas about locale with a firm determination to make his mark, and most feel that the region's characteristics provide the needed psychological and physical setting. 
 Referring to the shore, for example, Michael Rosch, a 37-year-old Bridgehampton artist, explained, "I like being on the coast, for that edge helps me know where I am and gives me a sense of relationship to the globe." Born in Yonkers, Mr. Rosch first came to know the area as a Southampton College student.
It is the openness of the landscape that is important to Hilary Helfant, 34, of Bridgehampton, who feels her evocative abstract surface configurations derive from nature. Ms. Helfant grew up in Great Neck and first visited the East End on family excursions as a child. Since completing graduate work at Hunter College, she has shown in galleries in New York, Long Island and Europe.
Sally Egbert, 38, of East Hampton also acknowledges the role landscape has in her abstract canvases and speaks enthusiastically about the linear structures she discovers in bare tree limbs.
Ms. Egbert, whose recent canvases are on view in "New Possibilities," which runs through Friday at the Staller Center on the State University campus in Stony Brook, has also shown nationally and internationally and has received major grants, including one from the New York State Council on the Arts. She moved east from the Brooklyn studio she had following college upstate. A native of Bay Shore, she said she always knew she loved water and the flat terrain.
Serenity is a reason many cite for their choice of Long Island studios. "Time is more abstract and I can get more out of a day," observed Ms. Egbert.
Deborah Fisher, 27, of Stony Brook, whose imaginative mixed-media objects and sculptures can be wonderfully contemplative, feels the pace on Long Island suits her creative temperament. After completing studies at the Maryland Institute, College of Art, she returned to set-up a studio-residence in Stony Brook, where she grew up. Currently the recipient of a New York Foundation for the Arts grant, Ms. Fisher has been exhibiting her sometimes metaphysical, sometimes metaphorical pieces throughout the country.
Hilarie Fuchs, 32, who makes somewhat ritualistic, shrinelike sculptures, is conscious of the way the trees and greenery provide a calming balance to her physical involvement in welding and grinding. She chose a Northport studio and a return to Floral Park, where she was born, after trying to work in loft space in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.
Those who had New York studios before choosing Long Island were uncomfortable with the quality of life and its effect on their work. Ms. Egbert speaks of hearing gunshots. Kathleen Kucka, 35, a Port Jefferson resident who attended Cooper Union and grew up in New York, where she frequently exhibits, observed, "I had no idea what it would be like to hear the sound of Canada geese outside my window instead of backed-up traffic." Many others mention the economic pressures they experienced trying to meet the living costs while also devoting their time to art.
After 10 years in Manhattan, Chicago-born Tom Wasik, 39, moved to Sag Harbor, where the available light, space and seemingly fluid time are more conducive to furthering the Asian spiritual qualities, theoretical issues and language-based ideas that appear in his recent paintings. Examples from this series have been included in five East End exhibitions this year. Other pieces have been shown across the country and in Europe during the past decade.
"The city is restrictive and claustrophobic, in spite of its museums and its vitality," Mr. Wasik noted.
Certainly the great yearning to control distractions contributed to decisions to relocate. "I wanted to see what would happen with the work under more isolated circumstances," commented Florida-born, New England-raised Peter Buchman, 37, who, after 13 years in New York, now creates his sizable collages in East Hampton. These are pieces laced with ironic, frequently well-researched observations of American society. Mr. Buchman had a one-man exhibition at the Delaware Art Museum last year.
For those who were raised on Long Island, relocation to the New York art world would seem to be a significant career consideration. James Fischetti, 31, who has spent his entire life in Islip, thought he was ready for the city after a decade of exhibition success but reconsidered, believing that in Suffolk he could better concentrate on his experiments in photography and his large, ambitious and bold painting projects that result from examinations of the world's religions.
Currently he is absorbed in studying African cultures. He also feels that on Long Island he will have a chance to develop workshops, expand his ideas about education through art, and perhaps make a difference.
While no one came to Long Island for exhibition opportunities, the artists inevitably form opinions about the region's art spaces. "Long Island galleries gave me a nice leg up," observed Gregory Corn, who has special praise for the staff at the Islip Art Museum for their openness to his thoughts for a creative, innovative installation. As he discussed his forthcoming exhibition in SoHo, Mr. Corn remarked about the pleasure of having easy access to New York while still staying with the bay and open spaces he has long favored.
Mr. Buchman feels that artists can use the Island's gallery structure for their career goals and Mr. Rosch agrees that "the area's galleries do a good job."
Mr. Wasik has found the Long Island galleries are more accessible. "With less competition for their time, it is easier to meet and discuss the work in a relaxed way," he said.
It seems to be the conceptual, and perhaps younger artists who feel that the right opportunities for solo exhibitions will most likely come from New York. Matthew Satz, 26, who was born in Brooklyn, went to school in Massachusetts and now paints in East Hampton. He thinks it is more probable that he will find connections in the metropolitan area for his sharp, satirical explorations of touchy aspects of contemporary American society. Nevertheless, in recent months he has had one solo show on Long Island and has been invited to participate in a number of group exhibitions.
A talented conceptual photographer working in Port Jefferson, Jennifer Shea, 26, whose local recognitions include the award of excellence at the Firehouse Gallery's juried exhibition, also plans to eventually try New York as a venue for her psychologically penetrating, satirical interpretations of female roles and her thematic series of images that create connections between physical obsessions, sexuality and sensuality. Born in New York, Ms. Shea grew up in Detroit but moved to Long Island as a C. W. Post student.
Concerns as to whether distance hurts relationships with the New York art world are logical, yet this has not become a problem for most of those surveyed. Ms. Egbert, Ms. Fuchs and Ms. Helfant were all in SoHo shows recently, and Ms. Kucka had made strong gallery connections in New York before relocating.
Following his move to East Hampton from his native New York City a decade ago, Robert Harms, 35, showed his vigorous, nature-inspired abstractions extensively on Long Island, but is now represented by a SoHo gallery.
Mr. Harms's experiences here over the years reinforce observations others readily offer about friendships, sense of community and support systems. Some speak of discovering mentors. "People are easier to access because there exists a certain tranquillity here," noted Mr. Satz.

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
In Boom Times, Restaurants Offer Luxury

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
THE stock market is booming and so is the Long Island restaurant scene. The improved business climate has encouraged local restaurateurs to take a plunge back into palatial luxury dining spots that have a French rather than Italian spin and stress elegance and excellence rather than economy. The first of them, the magnificent chateau-like Louis XVI on the Great South Bay in Patchogue, opened recently to raves from critics and diners alike. Now comes Enoteca.
It is an upscale contemporary French-American restaurant, scheduled to open the week of Dec. 15 at 146 Birch Hill Road in Locust Valley (671-9486). This 95-seat luxury spot, where Sapore di Medittereno had been, boasts a fast-rising, French-trained 27-year-old executive chef, two wine lists offering 400 selections and a menu with an eclectic array of dishes that display worldwide influences and French techniques. 
 The new restaurant also has a glassed-in wine cellar that is thermally cooled by a waterfall, Reidel glassware, Limoges china, Oneida sterling silverware, an impressive wine wall and a large round table with a huge floral arrangement.
Albert Melera, the Buenos Aires-born kitchen commander, received his training at the Cordon Bleu School in Paris, was a sous chef at Restaurant Raphael in Manhattan and Giorgio's Mediterranean Grill in Hollywood, Fla., and saw service at Restaurant Bouley in the city, as well as at Le Grand Vefour, a Michelin two-star restaurant in Paris.
His French-American menu features Spanish, light Asian, Middle Eastern and North African-influenced dishes, including Thai-spiced rare yellow fin tuna ($26), paella marinera ($24) and cardomon-anise seared muscovy duck breast ($28). Appetizers are priced from $9 to $12, pastas $16 to $18 and made-on-the-premises desserts $6 to $8.
Fabio Machado and Piero Casalicchio of the Pomodoro restaurant group and Patrick Bruno, a restaurateur who has been associated with them in the past, are the owners of the new enterprise, and Roland Stefan is the interior decorator.
Asian restaurants are also upgrading. The Bombay Cafe, described as a "fancy Indian restaurant" by its owner, Sewa Arora, has been open for about three weeks at 1610 Old Country Road in Westbury (222-1689). Mr. Arora once owned the modestly priced Jhoola Indian restaurants throughout the Island.Entrees range from $8.50 for vegetarian dishes to $23 for shrimp tandoori.
Among the specials from the tandoor oven are whole trout and cornish hen. The focal point of the 70-seat spot, which Mr. Arora says is "opulent," is a 30 by 7 foot ceramic tile mural that was painted by a leading Indian artist. The chefs at the Bombay Cafe came to the Island from India and Bangladesh.
 
Potpourri
The second edition of Great Restaurants of Long Island, a glossy magazine that features pictures, menus and write-ups of most of Long Island's leading restaurants, is available at local bookstores and supermarkets. The 180-page book, published by Morris Sendor, an art director and graphic designer, contains descriptions of 130 restaurants, 8 vineyards and a brewery. It sells for $3, and is available at bookstores, supermarkets and from advertisers who are participating in the magazine.
Ken Lammer, who for the last few years was the chef and owner of the well-received Ken's Place in Sea Cliff, is opening a restaurant called K.P.N.Y. (Ken's Place New York) in Manhattan.
Mr. Lammer, who closed his local spot in August, and his partner, Peter Speranza, plan to open at 557 Hudson Street on Dec. 15.
Mr. Lammer will introduce his New York City balanced health cuisine menu to Island diners at a $50 buffet dinner, music and dance event at the Light Works in Glen Cove on Friday. The four-hour event, with entertainment, will begin at 7 P.M. Reservations can be made by calling 671-3978.
The Catfish Cafe, 172 Merrick Road, Lynbrook (599-0627), is offering a traditional Louisiana crawfish boil every Friday night. It consists of cornbread, whole crawfish, mussels, potatoes, corn and andouille sausage steamed in a spicy broth, for $15.95.
Cornucopia, at 360 Glen Cove Avenue in Glen Head (759-4100), has a $12.95 twilight menu that is served from Tuesday to Friday from 4:30 to 7 P.M. The three-course meal includes main courses like Salisbury steak with mashed potatoes and mushroom gravy and oven-roasted salmon in a lemon white wine sauce.
The new menu at Cafe Samovar, the Russian-American restaurant at 2455 Long Beach Road, Oceanside (764-7676), features a number of low-fat choices along with its traditional Russian specialties.
Among them are stuffed grape leaves with garlic yogurt sauce ($5.25), a tomato and onion swirl topped with a balsamic vinegar and olive oil ($4.25), shrimp Black Sea, or grilled and marinated jumbo shrimp, with grilled vegetables ($14.95) and trout Odessa, broiled in olive oil, served with garlic and dill sauce ($13.95).
Gisela's, at 32 Railroad Avenue in Glen Head (656-0374), has introduced a $14.95 sunset dinner served Sunday through Friday from 6:30 to 10 P.M. It includes a choice of red or white house wine, salad or soup, entree, dessert and beverage. Among the seven main courses are chicken Della Casa, grilled salmon Napolitano and roasted duck in an orange sauce.
During its holiday special sale, the Lenz Winery on Route 25, Main Road, in Peconic is featuring wines that consistently compared favorably with the best from France and California in blind tastings.
Among the offerings are Lenz 1995 cabernet sauvignon estate bottled ($24.99) that beat a 1993 Chateau Latour at $217 a bottle. It was also rated only four points behind the 1993 Opus One ($90). A Lenz 1994 estate bottled merlot ($29.99) topped a 1992 Chateau Petrus by one point. A Petrus 1993 beat a Lenz 1994 by eight-tenths of a point. Petrus costs $300 a bottle.
The independently held tastings occurred last summer, in San Francisco, at Postrio Restaurant in Union Square, the summer of 1996 at the Tribeca Grill in Manhattan and earlier this year at Ross's Northfork Restaurant in Greenport.
The Single Gourmet (674-6186) is holding three events in December: An Indian buffet featuring an 18-course buffet dinner at Jewel of India in Syosset on Wednesday, a Japanese dinner featuring a combination of traditional sushi dishes and more modern tempura and teriyaki dishes at Hokkaido Japanese Restaurant in Albertson on Dec. 16 and its annual holiday dinner dance party featuring a five-course continental wine dinner with live music for dancing and gifts to celebrate the season at Chateau Briand in Carle Place on Dec. 29.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Infrastructure Aid Stirs Interest in Industrial Parks

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THREE years ago a developer for Nestle Foods who was seeking a site for a distribution center looked at a 54-acre industrially zoned tract in Killingly, off Interstate 395.
"We made it through the second cut in the site-selection process, but then it never progressed," said R. Thomas Homan, the Town Manager. "So we knew the site was attractive. It just wasn't getting the interest it should because the infrastructure wasn't there." 
 Now, under a joint state and local government program known as Smart Parks, $8 million in road and utility improvements are under way at five public and private industrial parks totaling almost 500 acres in Killingly and the neighboring Town of Putnam and new interest has been generated.
"As soon as people recognized that we were running utilities in there, voila, in comes Staples," said John E. Burke, the Town Council chairman. "That's not a coincidence. Obviously, they were waiting for the utilities."
Staples, the office-supply company, has completed construction of a $21 million, 326,000-square-foot regional distribution center on the site Nestle passed over. It will be opened early next year.
Putnam's economic development director, Elizabeth T. Murphy, said that her town was also starting to see some results from the state-local initiative, which requires localities to put up 15 percent of the funds needed for improvements.
"Three companies just moved in, and another expanded, all within the last year or so and I think Smart Parks was a major reason for most of them," Ms. Murphy said. "Another advantage is the price -- about $28,500 an acre for industrially zoned land. It's not only very affordable, but Interstate 395 makes it accessible to areas that are much more expensive. You can do business here as easily as in some areas that would cost you a lot more."
State Senator Donald E. Williams Jr., Democrat of Thompson, one of the sponsors of the Smart Parks program, said the regional collaboration on the parks helped win state financing for the initiative. He said the program could help turn around an area that has never recovered from the collapse of manufacturing in the 60's and 70's.
Smart Parks began in 1996, initially with a $2.5 million grant from the state's Department of Economic and Community Development for utility-line improvements to the Northeast Alliance, an economic development organization whose members are 10 towns in northeastern Connecticut.
"Northeastern Connecticut has traditionally lagged behind the rest of the state economically," said Senator Williams. "We've been putting the building blocks in place to change that. Now, as we see the state and New England moving slowly forward in terms of their economy, hopefully northeastern Connecticut is poised to take advantage of that."
The latest statistics at the state's Department of Labor put unemployment in northeastern Connecticut at 7.2 percent, almost two points higher than the 5.3 percent state average. The average manufacturing wage in the area is $478.55 a week, the lowest in the state, and about 26 percent less than in Hartford, an hour west.
The poor economy of the region is one of the reasons the General Assembly approved in 1994 the state's first multitown enterprise zone stretching along the I-395 corridor and taking in eight towns -- Griswold, Lisbon, Putnam, Killingly, Plainfield, Sprague, Sterling and Thompson. (A second one, including Ansonia, Derby, Seymour, Naugatuck and Beacon Falls, was approved in 1995 along the Route 8 corridor.)
All the industrial parks affected by the Smart Parks initiative will qualify for the special benefits of an enterprise zone, including a five-year, 80 percent abatement of property taxes, a 10-year, 25 percent state corporate tax credit and job-training grants.
The Smart Parks project has focused on Tracy Road in Killingly, which turns into Park Road in Putnam. The road gives access to three public and two private industrial parks.
Sewer and water lines, electrical upgrades and some telephone cable improvements have already been completed. A new water tower was constructed and the water lines from both towns were connected -- although they operate separate systems -- to provide the maximum water pressure.
THE original state plan for Tracy Road improvements called for the infrastructure changes to be limited to the part of the road in Killingly. Killingly argued that the work should continue into the Putnam parks to improve access for both.
"What's unique about this project is that it started as a regional project," Senator Williams said. "This was not a situation where one town took the lead and another town joined in late. Oftentimes you see competition or even hostility between towns when it comes to economic development. This was, right from the start, a cooperative venture by the two towns' officials."
"Towns like Thompson, Putnam, Killingly and Plainfield all share a common heritage as former textile mill towns," he continued. "They're all located along the Interstate 395 corridor and the Providence & Worcester rail line. They share many interests, so I think it's natural that the towns link up the way they have."
Local officials said there was a recognition that fighting over what town would attract the next company was not a good strategy.
"We're more likely to attract the attention of corporate decision-makers if we can put out an entire inventory of industrial sites," said Ms. Murphy, the Putnam official.
"With Smart Parks, people are starting to see that it's to everyone's advantage to cooperate," said Elsie Bisset, the economic development coordinator in Killingly. "People are going to live in our town and work in Putnam, or live in Putnam and work here. Obviously, if you have a business in one town it's going to benefit all the towns."
Ms. Bisset said the parks had been particularly attractive to distribution centers. Besides Staples, there are two major sites in the privately owned Killingly Oaks industrial park, developed in 1989 -- the 450,000-square-foot Brooks Pharmacy distribution center and United Natural Foods, which has an addition under construction that will bring its total to 250,000 square feet.
The first phase of the town-owned Killingly Industrial Park has already attracted 13 companies employing more than 2,000 employees, including a bottling plant, a plastics manufacturer, a mattress factory and a cosmetics concern. That park, which has been under development since 1981, has only one six-acre site left.
But an expansion is planned on 110 acres adjacent to the park. The town has received a $109,000 planning grant from the state to do a survey and evaluation, and U.S. Generating, a private power generating company, has already taken an option on 38 acres to build a 500- to 810-megawatt natural gas-fired power plant, she said.
"Under the current law they would have to sell power wholesale," said Ms. Bisset, explaining how the plant could help the park. "But if electric utilities are deregulated as expected they would go into the retail business, and could sell directly to the companies in the industrial park. It could mean lower rates, which would make the park very attractive to a lot of high-technology companies."
"Warehouse distribution is good because it pays high taxes," she continued, "but it doesn't create a lot of high-paying jobs. And that's why we want to get some more high-technology companies into the parks. As a region, we're targeting photonics, plastics, and agri-tech firms and we'd like to see more back-office operations in the industrial parks to give us a mix."
It's a strategy that has also been adopted by Putnam, said Ms. Murphy.
"We're subdividing some of the land left in our industrial park into two-acre parcels so smaller companies with good growth potential can find a place to start doing business," Ms. Murphy said. "If you have three of these companies and even one of them takes off, it can really make a difference in the local economy. And if the two next to it go out of business, the one that does make it can expand."

HEADLINE: New Effort To Combat Student Use Of Alcohol

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE rallying cry among young drinkers used to be a rousing "Party Hearty!" Increasingly, it is now a sobering "Party Hardly," especially after the alcohol-related death of a Port Chester college student earlier this year, the suspension of high school athletes in Harrison and Peekskill this fall and recent drinking fatalities at college campuses nationwide.
"There has to be a better way," said a worried Shannon Fogarty, president of the Greek Council at Iona College, which represents 14 sororities and fraternities on the New Rochelle campus. "We've got to change things." 
 In Westchester and the rest of the country, college and high school students -- along with their teachers, guidance counselors and deans -- are taking a fresh look at an old problem. The recent spate of alcohol-related incidents and fresh data on student alcohol use is presenting an increasingly ugly picture.
Last spring, the body of 20-year-old Patrick McNeill was found in New York Harbor. A lawsuit filed by his parents in State Supreme Court in White Plains contends that the Dapper Dog bar in Manhattan illegally served alcohol to the Fordham University student until he could no longer stand and that his drunken condition was the reason he fell into the harbor and drowned.
In Harrison, 13 football players and a tennis player at the high school were suspended this fall after some admitted drinking at a Yonkers bar, Dicey Reilly's. Besides being under age, the students violated school policy prohibiting varsity athletes from drinking or using drugs.
Also this fall, the Peekskill Red Devils were forced to forfeit their high school homecoming game against Somers when seven players were suspended. The players were among a group of students discovered drinking in a park before morning classes.
In another recent incident, Police Chief Russell J. Beckley of Mount Pleasant said a 19-year-old female student at Pace University passed out in a dorm, apparently after spending a Saturday night drinking illegally at a Sleepy Hollow bar. The under-age drinker was taken to a hospital where she was treated for alcohol poisoning and later released.
There have been other cases: inOneonta, N.Y., a 22-year-old student at Hartwick College became drunk last May at a fraternity party, fell into a nearby river and died; in Boston this fall, an 18-year-old freshman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology drank heavily at a fraternity party, lost consciousness and died, and was found to have a blood alcohol level of .41, more than five times the legal driving limit; at Louisiana State University this fall, a 20-year-old fraternity pledge died and a dozen members fell ill from drinking at an off-campus party.
Those are examples in a string of similar incidents in recent years, stretching from North Carolina to California. About 4,000 Americans die every year from alcohol poisoning, many of them college students, said Sally Linowski-Damon, a University of Massachusetts health educator.
The following sets of statistics also indicate the breadth of the problem: A recent study by the Harvard School of Public Health found that 44 percent of all American college students who were surveyed engaged in binge drinking -- taking five drinks in succession for men, four for women; Studies of alcohol use among teen-agers in high school show that 70.6 percent used alcohol in 1995-96 and in grades 6 through 8, 44.5 percent, reported Andrew Bearman, a spokesman for the National Parents Resource Institute for Drug Education of Atlanta.
"Alcohol is the king drug," said Dr. Patricia Singleton, a Mount Kisco psychologist who specializes in chemical and alcohol addictions. "It dwarfs the problems of cocaine and heroin." Alcohol problems often begin in early adolescence when all youngsters come under harsh group pressures and some develop anxiety and depression, she said.
While there are some indications that drug use may be leveling off among high school students, the use of liquor and cigarettes appears to be increasing. The State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services said that 8 of 10 secondary school students have tried alcohol, and nearly half of those are regular drinkers.
In Harrison, Ronald D. Valenti, Superintendent of Schools, said it was "a daily battle, very much an uphill battle" to control alcohol abuse among students.
He said the recent suspension of the athletes sent "a message not just for one game, but for life, that their behavior has consequences. Winning or losing a game or the section was secondary to that lesson."
Stacey Benjamin, a counselor with Student Assistance Services at Harrison High School, said that drinking among teen-agers cuts across all socio-economic lines, while the more expensive drugs like cocaine and heroin tend to be used more by wealthier youths.
Compounding the alcohol abuse problem is the fact that at both college and high school levels, under-age drinkers find many bars willing to serve them.
At Manhattanville College in Purchase, Mary Corrarino, the vice president of student affairs and development, said that two White Plains bars, Iguanawana and Flamingos, formerly the Top Shelf Pub, hired students to inundate the campus with fliers advertising the bars and appealing to both legal-age drinkers and those who are under age.
Mark Rosato, owner of Flamingos, said that the bar did not sell alcohol to under-age drinkers and that it no longer tries to attract the college crowd. Kerri Mackin, a bartender at Inguanawana, said that a guard checks identification at the door. On Wednesday nights, however, the bar encourages college students who are at least 21 to come in, he said.
A flier from a Port Chester bar, 7 Willow Street, advertises free beer until midnight and "$1 kamikaze shots all night."
Libby McCaffrey, student government president at Manhattanville, said that for under-age drinkers who want to go to bars, "it's easy to get a false I.D."
Even more of a problem, she said, is the fact that many bartenders are college students themselves and are willing to overlook the drinking age.
In the Patrick McNeill case, the bar served the student even though a bartender who was a suite mate at Fordham knew or should have known that he was under age, said Aldo V. Vitagliano, a lawyer for the McNeills.
"The parents would like to send a message that these establishments that solicit under-age drinkers and let them drink must be held accountable," the lawyer said.
In the case of the Pace University student, the police said she had apparently been drinking at South Paws North, a bar in Sleepy Hollow known by authorities to cater to the college crowd and serve under-age patrons.
Police Detective Frank Corona of Sleepy Hollow said the department had many problems with under-age drinking at the bar, where fighting also broke out routinely. He said the police department had referred the problem to the Westchester District Attorney's office and was cooperating in efforts to crack down on the bar's management.
On Oct. 30, District Attorney Jeanine Pirro reported that an undercover operation had resulted in 44 arrests for selling alcohol to people younger than 21. It was the result of a countywide sting conducted in August and September by the District Attorney's Office and the police departments of New Rochelle, Pelham, Ardsley, Sleepy Hollow, Port Chester, North Castle, Harrison, Mount Kisco and Greenburgh.
Under-age youths acting in an undercover capacity were able to buy alcohol without proof of age in 44 of 100 establishments in the county. In each instance, the sales were witnessed by an investigator from the District Attorney's office, and most were videotaped. In some cases, youths presented driver's licenses marked younger than 21 to store clerks who nevertheless completed the sale.
Selling alcohol to a minor is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to $1,000 and/or a sentence of up to a year in jail. The New York State Liquor Authority can impose penalties, including fines and suspensions and revocations of sales licenses.
Meanwhile, efforts to alter the "Party Hearty" attitude are growing, Mr. Fogarty at Iona College said.
Knowing that binge drinkers are 11 times more likely to fall behind in school, 10 times more likely to drive after drinking and 7 times more likely to have unprotected sex, according to the State Office of Alcoholism, colleges are toughening their approach to the problem.
Iona has become "basically a dry campus," with alcohol served at some events only by special permission, Paul LaMantia, director of student development, said. The college has also developed a relationship with the nearby Beechmont Tavern, which serves nonalcoholic drinks free to designated drivers and is said to stand by a policy of refusing to serve alcoholic beverages to anyone younger than 21.
At Manhattanville, Ms. Corrarino said the college was considering earlier class times to discourage late-night partying. It will also set aside part of a dormitory next year for students who are recovering alcoholics.
Pace University has set up an alcohol education and rehabilitation program for students with St. Vincent's Hospital-Westchester in Harrison.
"We're looking at ways to change the drinking culture," said Geoffrey J. Harter, dean of students at the Pace campus in Pleasantville. "We want students to believe that they don't have to drink to be cool, that they don't have to get loaded to have fun."
 
Changes in Behavior Can Signal Trouble
HOW do you know if a high school or college student is abusing alcohol? While it is not always easy to spot the problem, there are some behavior changes that could signal trouble, said Dr. Mary Pressman, director of the County Medical Center's day-treatment program for adolescents with substance abuse and emotional problems.
Be alert to irrational outbursts, hypersensitivity, irritability or mood swings, school absenteeism, poor grades and other changes, Dr. Pressman said, adding that adolescents at risk of substance abuse tend to spend their leisure time with older teen-agers and young adults who can provide access to alcohol or drugs.
Other possible indicators of a substance abuse problem: isolation from friends and family, ignoring curfews and sneaking out at night, lying or blaming others for irresponsible actions and theft from family members or stores.
Also watch for selling possessions for money, increased secretiveness about personal problems or activities, erratic eating or sleeping habits, dropping out of sports or other activities, an increased incidence of fighting with peers, decreased attention to personal hygiene and obvious signs of hangover or drug use, including reddened eyes, headaches and blackouts.
Dr. John Wallace, a psychologist and the director of alcohol and substance abuse services at St. Vincent's Hospital-Westchester in Harrison warned that in addition to causing health problems among young adults the heavy use of alcohol can also lead to unprotected sex and sexually transmitted diseases.
Problems of date rape also increase with intoxication, mainly because both parties run the risk of "misreading each other's cues," Dr. Wallace said.
The State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services reported earlier this year that binge drinkers are 7 to 10 times more likely than others to have unprotected sex, to get into trouble with the campus police, to damage property, to be injured and to fall behind in school. About 90 percent of campus rapes and 95 percent of campus violence were committed when alcohol was consumed by the offender or the victim, the office said.
Experts are also seeing a link between heavy drinking and compulsive gambling. "Kids become emboldened when intoxicated and place major bets," Dr. Wallace said, "and then they have no means to pay."
Alcohol was cited in the drownings last spring of Patrick McNeill from Fordham University in the Bronx and a student at Hartwick College in Oneonta. Those who are intoxicated are also more likely to choke on food, and if they vomit after passing out and lying on their backs, they can drown.
Alcohol intoxication can also encourages use of drugs like marijuana and cocaine, Dr. Wallace said. While alcohol is a depressant, cocaine acts in the opposite way -- as a stimulant that can cause closed arteries, chest pains and heart attack.
"Also, cocaine users think they can drink more," he warned. "And with pills and tranquilizers flying around at some parties, the synergy of alcohol and drugs can shut down the respiratory centers in the brain. It's a dangerous combination."
The State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services reports that in the state, 15 percent of students in grades 7 through 12 are heavy users of both alcohol and other drugs. Among juniors and seniors, more than 1 in 5 are heavy users of both.
Among college students in the state, 86 percent drink alcoholic beverages, the office said. Marijuana is used by nearly half of the college students in New York. The next most popular substances are hallucinogens like LSD, amphetamines like diet pills and cocaine.
How much alcohol is lethal? It depends on the drinker's body weight and other factors, but just a pint of spirits, when rapidly ingested, can raise the blood alcohol content to 0.35 and above, which is considered lethal range. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: In Middle Age and Suddenly Single

BYLINE: By NANCY RUBIN 

 BODY:
SOME of them married soon after high school or college. Others continued to date for another decade before saying, "I do." Still others ended an early first marriage only to wed again with equally unhappy results. But whatever their particular story, the number of Westchester residents who became divorced in their middle years has been on the rise in the last decade.
Figures from the United States Bureau of the Census indicate that the number of Americans who divorced between the age of 40 and 54 in 1995 represents nearly 14 percent of the population, up from 11 percent a decade ago. While specific figures are not available on the marital status of Westchester residents, a 1995 study by the State Department of Health revealed that 600 cases, or 25 percent of all divorces filed in Westchester County that year, involved couples who had been married 15 to 30 years. 
 Local officials, matrimonial lawyers and behavioral experts attribute much of the midlife divorce phenomenon to the dramatic social and economic changes of the last three decades.
"Women who stayed in marriages before don't feel as compelled to stay now, and much of that has to do with economics," said Camille Murphy, director of the Westchester County Office for Women and President of the National Association of Commissions for Women.
"Today women are better off economically because they are better educated, and thus more marketable for jobs," Ms. Murphy said. "As a result, they just won't tolerate a bad marital situation the way they did years ago."
Other experts attribute the rising midlife divorce rate to expanded expectations. "It's my impression that that upswing in midlife divorce in Westchester has a lot to do with the increased stress in people's lives, and those stresses are enormous," said Mary Kelly, a partner in the White Plains matrimonial law firm of Kelly & Knaplund, which often litigates divorce for couples in their 40's and 50's.
"One source of stress can be the fact that both adults in the family are working and trying to raise children," she said. "Another is the idea we have today that personal happiness is important and not be be deferred. All it takes is for one partner to raise his hand and say, 'This isn't right for me,' to end the marriage."
A matrimonial lawyer, John Bavero of the White Plains firm Berman Bavero Frucco & Gouz, said: "There's also some truth to the idea of the midlife crisis. People who are 45 or 50 have a sense of their lives passing and start focusing on what might make them happy in a new way. If the kids are leaving or have already left for college that's one more tie between the couple that is gone. All these forces come together and often that begins the process that dissolves the marriage."
Despite the perception that there are more divorced people in midlife living in the county today than ever before, many newly single residents contend they are an invisible population.
"It's a completely different experience to be single here in the county." said Leonora Macris of Irvington, who was married 32 years before being divorced. "After all those years, suddenly you're not a pair. In a way it would be easier to be widowed because you'd get more compassion." But Robin Goldstein, a mother of two, said: "It's not that people aren't sympathetic. But often they don't know what to say, so they say nothing. Being single is like being part of an underground population here. When I was married, all my friends were couples. I didn't know anyone who was single or divorced."
Added to the sense of invisibility is economic duress, particularly for divorced women, many of whom remain in the suburbs to provide a safe environment and good schools for their children.
"We see that poverty among many of the women who call our office," said Ms. Murphy of the county's Office for Women. "Often it looks good on the surface. But behind it, behind the house she's still living in, there's poverty. A lot of divorced women are house poor but remain here for the sake of the kids."
National studies indicate that men suffer less economic distress than women after divorce but their finances tend to improve. A study in June 1996 published in the "American Sociological Review" found that a woman's standard of living fell 27 percent after divorce while a man's rose by 10 percent. Nevertheless, suddenly single Westchester men have their own brand of problems.
"Part of the difficulty for men is the displacement that occurs with divorce," Mr. Bavero, the matrimonial lawyer, observed. "Usually they have to find a new residence and create a new household. Secondly, they often have less contact with their young children. Thirdly, they have to deal with the economic obligations they still have to former spouses and children."
Despite those hurdles, many midlife men and women often start dating again, even though the process may be difficult. "When I go to dances, it makes me feel like I'm back in junior high because the men stand on one side and the women on another," a 45-year-old government worker who had been married for two decades said.
Many women find the dating situation is particularly difficult, especially if they are mothers with children still at home.
"Who has time to date?" said Susan Portlock of Chappaqua, a mother of four. "My whole life is still raising kids. The only difference is that I don't have a husband around anymore. And even when men ask me out, I don't really have either the time or energy for a relationship."
Some single women, however, complain that there are no available men. "It's hard to meet professional men here in Westchester because a lot of divorced men move to the city," said a middle-age teacher who attended a program for single people in Elmsford.
Statistically, that may be true. Census Bureau data from 1990 indicates that there were 14,600 divorced men living in Westchester in 1995 compared with 26,003 women. Many psychological and behavioral experts say that many divorced men tend to remain isolated because they do not know how to make appropriate social connections, a skill that was usually left to their wives when they were married.
"The problem is that many men don't know how to network the way women do," said Judith Gilbert Kautto, co-director of the Marital Project for the Center for Family Learning in Rye Brook. "Women pick up the phone; they have friends. But men tend to keep to themselves."
Such was the case for Paul Dengler, a manufacturer's representative from Yonkers. "When you're married, you get into a pattern in which you come home after work and relax and become a couch potato," he said. "Once you're single it becomes important to get out and meet people. But in the beginning it's difficult.
Some men, like Sam Heslowitz, 58, of Yonkers, who had been married 22 years, say that they no longer have the social skills needed to date. "In the beginning you don't know how to behave, how to interact, what to say, how to react," he said. Mr. Heslowitz said he attended a barbecue where he was talking to a single woman who suddenly excused herself to get mustard for her hot dog. "That was the last I saw of her," he said. "Now I can deal with that -- the little hurts that come with dating again. But in the beginning I didn't know how."
Even men who have been single for many years often say that living in the suburbs can be lonely. "At my club it's still difficult because nearly everyone else is married," Peter Price, 46, of Harrison, said. "That makes it more difficult to go to parties and dances unless I invite a date."
Repeatedly, suddenly single middle-age people observe that because Westchester was the traditional bastion of married couples, there are few places to meet other middle-age people. "It's tougher here than in Manhattan or even on Long Island," said Tony Geidel, 45, of White Plains, who is president of the Westchester-based Catholic Singles organization, which he helped found in the 1980's. "There are fewer singles groups in Westchester, fewer places for singles to go at night and a lot of apprehension about who the singles are going to meet if they do go out as individuals." As a result, many single women are cautious about where to meet men.
In response, some singles groups have sprung up in the county for people older than 40. Most of them offer suggestions on how to meet other single people. Among them was Meet Me at the Movies, a monthly Sunday afternoon program that invites singles to attend a film, followed by dinner at a restaurant and a discussion about what they saw. The group, founded several years ago by Carol Sacks of Chappaqua after her divorce, is meant, she said, "as a way to enable single midlifers to meet each other and have a chance to get to know each other by talking about a common experience."
Today Ms. Sacks's mailing list has grown to more than 1,200 from 120. Another group is Westchester Singles, which serves about 3,000 single midlifers a year, many of whom travel from Rockland and Putnam Counties as well as Westchester. On Saturday nights the group sponsors events like dances and discussion groups and demonstrations of yoga and tai chi at the Unitarian Fellowship building in Mount Kisco.
Still other groups, like those started by Marion Smith, an entrepreneur who is host of Singles Tennis parties on Saturday nights at the Rye Racquet Club, find sports are another natural way for singles to socialize. "Playing tennis is an easy way to meet others," said Ms. Smith, who began by being the host of tennis parties in Westchester and the Bronx 20 years ago. "It's a good way to get some exercise, hone your tennis skills and make new friends."
Ms. Smith, who also offers a Sunday night dance and buffet for singles at the Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown, has more than 17,000 Westchester singles on her mailing list. Unlike many of her single clients, Ms. Smith maintains that it is now easier for singles to socialize in Westchester than it was in the past.
One suburban enthusiast is Isabella Deutsch, a divorced businesswoman who lives in Briarcliff Manor and was married for 22 years. "I live part time in New York City, and it's not necessarily easier to meet people there than in suburbia," she said. "In Manhattan your neighbors in your apartment building are polite, but often that's about it. Here when I get home, it's a time for relaxation, for enjoying the outdoors. I can't think of a more beautiful or cultural place to live."
Ms. Deutsch, like many singles who have chosen to live in Westchester, has also discovered that happiness has less to do with location than attitude.
"Being single is a great opportunity to become introduced to all kinds of new interests and develop skills you didn't have time for before," she said. "It's a time to enjoy your life and take a few risks as well. People who are basically positive remain so wherever they live."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Less Density Helps Sell West Orange on 2 Projects

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE future of two of the last large parcels in West Orange, put on hold by the real estate recession of the early 90's, now appears to be set.
Construction is under way on a 100-unit town-house community on a 34-acre site along Eagle Rock Avenue. And by the end of next spring work is expected to start on a mixed-used project comprising 150 town houses, a 100,000-square-foot office building and a 500-seat amphitheater on 50 acres a quarter of a mile away off Interstate 280. 
 A new owner, a partnership of BNE Associates of Livingston and Roseland Property Company of Roseland, is developing both projects, which will replace those conceived in the mid-80's building boom but either never completed or not begun. The current projects also will be built at a substantially lower density than had been proposed forthe earlier ones.
The larger site had been targeted for a 900,000-square-foot office complex and the smaller one was to accommodate two mid-rise residential condominiums with a total of 281 units, as well as 48 town houses. They were to accompany the existing 178-unit, eight-story condominium on the site.
The revision in plans is good news for West Orange, a nearly fully developed township of about 40,000 residents in suburban Essex County.
"The earlier proposals were too dense and would have caused needless congestion," said John F. McKeon, president of the Township Council. "Though we would have preferred to leave the land undeveloped these new proposals are reasonable from an esthetic perspective." They also are sources of revenue, he added.
The revised plan for the two sites demonstrates the changes over the last decade in market conditions, consumer preferences and community views of high-density development. But it also underscores the intricate juggling act towns perform as they search for ways to expand their tax bases and preserve their residents' quality of life.
Getting the projects to this point involved, among other things, the rezoning of the larger site from commercial to its current use and amending the approvals for the town-house development.
Larry Pantirer, a principal of BNE, said he and his partners persisted because "you just don't find that many large sites in the northern part of the state that would allow multifamily housing, and when they come around if you don't take them someone else will."
The projects are advancing at a time when town houses are finding renewed interest from professional couples and empty-nesters who want the maintenance-free life-style such housing offers, residential brokers say. Those are the buyers Mr. Pantirer said he and his partners want to attract.
As of the third quarter the average sale price for existing one-family homes, including town house units, was $192,400, up from $191,600 the same time in 1996, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison. "The demand for well located town houses that are appropriately priced outstrips the supply," said David J. Schoner, vice president of the metropolitan region at the New Homes Division of Coldwell Banker, a brokerage based in Short Hills.
BUT the lack of supply of suitably zoned land will temper the pace of construction of such projects, which, at least for the near term, should help those projects now under way or about to begin. Mr. Schoner added, however, that location was a key ingredient for success. The developer of the two West Orange projects feel location is on their side.
"Almost all of the sales of town houses in West Orange have been to empty-nesters, said Marshall B. Tycher, a Roseland principal. "It is a very good market and there is no longer that much available so we feel very comfortable."
The 50-acre site of the mixed-use project edging a busy interstate includes the township-owned five-acre Crystal Lake and thick trees extending to the Watchung Mountains. For the first half of the century the property was a recreation area, offering boating, fishing and swimming. At one time it also had an amusement park, restaurant and picnic grounds, but over the years they were left to deteriorate.
In the late 80's a joint venture of Trammell Crow of Dallas, one of the nation's largest commercial developers, and Kajima, a development company in Tokyo, planned to turn the site into a 900,000-square-foot office complex. But before they could find a tenant, the recession hit. Trammell Crow lost interest and pulled out and Kajima ultimately put the project on hold.
Last year BNE and Roseland, considering the site better suited for housing, contracted to buy it contingent upon getting it rezoned for 208 town houses and six single-family homes. But the township rejected that proposal. The two sides compromised on the current project and last June the township rezoned the site to accommodate it.
The developer also has agreed to restore the weed-choked lake and set up a $200,000 reserve fund the township can tap to maintain it. They also agreed to make $250,000 in road and traffic improvements, including relocating the main entrance to the site, now at the intersection of Prospect Avenue and the I-280 exit and entry ramps, to a point north of the crossroads. In addition, they will pay a fee on each unit, totaling about $60,000, to West Orange for use in making capital improvements to its schools and build the amphitheater, which they will donate to the township for public use.
"This development is the best use of the site," said Mr. McKeon, the Township Council president. "It gives us the most favorable return on our need for new ratables and does not outweigh what we have to pay out in terms of new municipal services." He estimated that the project, when fully built, would generate about $600,000 in new annual tax revenue.
Of the compromise, Mr. Tycher said: "We are satisfied with our return and with the risk of blending the town houses with this amount of office space."
The project still must receive final site plan approval from the Township Planning Board. As soon as that is obtained, Mr. Tycher said, the site will be cleared and construction is expected to start by spring on all three components of the project.
The project has been designed by the Martin Organization of Philadelphia. As now envisioned, the amphitheater, which will back up onto the lake, and the three-story, 100,000-square-foot office building will sit on either side of the main entrance to the site. The town-house community will front the lake. About 65 percent of the site will remain as open space.
THE traditional style two- and three-bedroom homes will be built in clusters, with an average of six units each, around interior courtyards. The units, each with a 2-car garage, will range in size from 1,900 to 2,300 square feet and in price from $275,000 to $325,000. Monthly maintenance charges have not yet been set. The entire project, estimated to cost $50 million, will take about three years to build.
Meanwhile, work continues at the nearby 100-unit town-house community, called the Villas at Crown View. Its 34-acre site off Eagle Rock Avenue was part of the Orange Quarry that for most of this century was mined for bluestone used for highway construction in the area. It closed in 1983.
Last year the partners bought the site, framed by a ridge climbing to 140 feet, from the Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan, a subsidiary of HSBC Holdings. The bank had taken over the property, including the existing building, known as Crown View Manor, when the former developer went bankrupt several years ago.
In the intervening years the bank sold the 178 apartments in that building, which sits on eight acres. Mr. Tycher said he and his partners scaled back the project initially to 180 town houses for several reasons. Among them were that they felt town houses would be easier to sell in today's market, that the township and existing residents would be more supportive of a smaller project and that the bank had adjusted the purchase price of the land to reflect the lower density.
Nonetheless, the partners spent about a year and a half negotiating with the township and the Crown View Manor condominium board and agreed to modify the project to its current scale before an agreement was struck. The township approved the project last spring. The town houses, laid out in three-unit clusters, will have 2,050 to 2,450 square feet of living space, two or three bedrooms and a two-car garage. Prices range from $300,000 to $375,000. In the six weeks since sales started 16 of the projected 100 units have been sold.
Mr. Pantirer said that once this project was half completed the partners would begin marketing the remainder, keeping the pace of absorption steady. If the economy remains strong, he said, "we feel the market will stay with us."
