HEADLINE: Middle-Aged, Single, Looking for a Life

BYLINE: By NANCY RUBIN 

 BODY:
SOME men and women married soon after high school or college. Others continued to date for another decade before saying "I do." Still others ended an early first marriage only to wed again with equally unhappy results. Whatever their story, the number of Connecticut residents divorced in their middle years has become increasingly visible in the last decade.
Figures from the Federal Bureau of the Census indicate that the number of Americans who divorced between the ages of 40 and 54 in 1995 represented nearly 14 percent of the population, up from 11 percent a decade earlier. While the overall divorce rate in Connecticut has declined slightly since 1992, officials, lawyers and behaviorists attribute much of the rise in mid-life divorce to the social and economic changes of the last three decades. "People are marrying later and having children later and therefore it's not surprising that they're getting divorced later," said Leslie Brett, executive director of the Connecticut Permanent Commission on the Status of Women. 
 While balancing child-rearing and work comes into play as before, the issues around divorce are changing. In the past, disgruntled middle-aged husbands often left their wives for younger women. But today more women are also striking out. "A major contributor to that dissatisfaction," observed Eliot Nerenberg, a West Hartford lawyer and chairman of the family life division of the Connecticut Bar Association, "is the sense in midlife that time is running out." He continued: "In the middle years, many people are beginning to realize their mortality. If they're unhappy, they begin wondering 'Do I want to spend the next 20, 30 or 40 years with this person? I'm middle-aged and I'm still attractive. Maybe I can find somebody better'."
Another factor is the changing view of divorce itself. "There's no stigma to getting divorced today as there used to be," said Dr. Helen Fisher, an anthropologist at Rutgers University and the author of "Anatomy of Love: The Natural History of Monogamy, Adultery and Divorce" (Fawcett, 1994). "At the beginning of the century women who were widowed or divorced went to live with their children or parents. But today those who are single in mid-life often look for a new mate."
Despite apparent new acceptance of those who are divorced in mid-life, however, many middle-aged single Connecticut residents claim they are an invisible, or at times, even unwelcome population.
"When you've been married for 20 years the losses you suffer are great," said Marc Berenzweig, a doctor who lives in Greenwich. "You lose your community, your friends, your communal identity, and sometimes even your children. It's very lonely. A newly divorced man is a pariah. No one wants to invite him to a dinner party."
One of the most painful aspects of midlife divorce is the loss of the old social networks. "Some of your friends drop away because they're married and you're not. You don't have that much in common anymore," said Kathy Kurzatkowski of Fairfield.
Some people noted that the isolation they felt after divorce was far worse in Connecticut's exurban communities than in its cities. "I used to live in Weston," recalled Fran Kloss, "and because it was very family-oriented there was nothing there for singles. After my divorce, some friends continued to include me. But unless you connected with a new man very quickly, you become a fifth wheel," she said. Eventually, Ms. Kloss got a teaching job in Milford and moved to Westport -- a community, she said, where "there were many singles and more opportunities to meet them."
Added to invisibility is economic duress -- particularly for divorced women, many of whom remain in suburban or exurban areas to provide safe environments and good schools for their children. "It's absolutely more difficult for women who get divorced economically," said Ms. Brett of the Status of Women commission. "Study after study shows that the standard of living drops for a woman after divorce and the standard rises for men."
Many divorced women "are left with a house that's difficult to afford. As a result there are hidden pockets of poverty everywhere, including Fairfield County," Ms. Brett explained.
A 1989 study jointly published by the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund, the Permanent Commission on the Status of Women and the Women's Research Institute of Hartford College for Women found that the mean per capita income of Connecticut women following divorce dropped 16 percent while that of divorced men increased by 23 percent. National studies support the finding.
A June 1996 study published in the American Sociological Review indicated that a woman's post-divorce standard of living decreased by 27 percent while that of a divorced man rose by 10 percent.
Several sociological factors contribute to the disparity. To begin with, Ms. Brett said, there is still a 25 percent wage gap between the earnings of men and women. Simultaneously, the vast majority of divorced women retain custody of their children and shoulder a disproportionate share of the child-care expenses.
"At the same time, today's courts try to divide the assets in half in divorce settlements. If you do the math, women and kids come up with fewer resources," said Ms. Brett.
Moreover, many middle-aged and older women today took time out from their jobs to care for children as well as for elderly members of their families. Those lost years in the work force place women at a disadvantage. "While they get child support and alimony for a period of time after divorce, their economic life style changes dramatically," said Mr. Nerenberg, the matrimonial lawyer. "If they've been a homemaker and raised children and go back into the job market when their divorce maintenance ends, they find they can never make up that difference in income."
One of those women is Lynn Barrow, a Newtown mother of three, who has three part-time jobs. "I'm trying to get back into the work force and obtain one good position," she explained. "Now that my teen-agers are more settled from the divorce, I'm trying to get my own career in order."
Some people point out that income discrepancies between middle-aged men and women are only part of the problem both partners face in the post-divorce years.
"Just because the man has a higher standard of living doesn't necessarily mean he's living happily ever after," said Sarah Oldham, a partner in the Westport law firm of Rutkin and Oldham. "Many men feel cut off from the social activities they once enjoyed when they were married, activities that were arranged by their wives. Often, they don't have a ready framework for replacing those networks. They don't know how to get invited to dinner parties or how to host them. And that's especially true in places like Fairfield County, which is very focused on couples and family life."
Others maintain that dating is difficult for middle-aged women. "Middle-aged men have a lot more opportunity to meet women because they can date women from a wide range of ages -- from 30 to 50 if they wish," said Mr. Nerenberg. "But a 45-year-old woman has a limited dating pool, and often goes out with men who are considerably older. That, in turn, leaves her with fewer choices."
Moreover, divorced men tend to remarry more quickly. Many Connecticut men who work in Manhattan return to live in the city, further shrinking available numbers. According to figures from the 1990 Bureau of the Census, there are 105,130 divorced men living in Connecticut compared to 149,093 divorced women.
In several Connecticut communities singles' groups have been created through local churches, community centers and individual enterpreneurs. Westport Singles, established 21 years ago in that community's Unitarian Church, was designed as a meeting place for those who were unattached and reluctant to visit, say, singles bars.
Don Smith, president of the group, said it's "a place to have fun, to talk to people in a friendly way, to mix in a comfortable and casual atmosphere, and where it's possible to meet someone romantically."
The group, which sponsors weekly activities ranging from discussion groups, dances and hikes to gourmet and theater clubs and weekend camping trips, has 800 members on its mailing list. It is still housed in the Unitarian Church but has become a separate entity that offers programs throughout Fairfield County.
Some members, like Helen Baker, a mother of two and a marketing director from Fairfield, said that Westport Singles was a catalyst that enabled her to create a new social life.
"It's a place to make friends and develop relationships and work through the transition from being married to being single again," Ms. Baker said. "Without an organization like this, being divorced here in Connecticut could be very isolating."
Other members, like Dan Castiglia, believe that it is no more challenging to be a single in suburbia than in Manhattan. In fact, it may even be easier.
"It seems to me that it's even more difficult to be single in the city because there most people go to singles bars," he said. "But if you live in Fairfield County you can come here and meet people more casually because there's a natural camaraderie, and one that isn't necessarily geared to romance."
Nevertheless, even as divorced middle-aged people have become more common, Westport Singles' membership has dwindled from its peak in the 1980's of 4,500 to its current membership of just 800, now often divided between a 21 to 35 age category and those who are over 35.
One reason for the shrinkage may be the lessening of that sense of being different.
"Today, it's much easier to be single. Our population here may not be as large as it used to be," said Mr. Smith, "but the overall environment is much friendlier to singles. And it's because we were originally so successful, we've inspired other singles' groups today."
A group specifically designed for single middle-aged men and women is Greenwich-based Capers, a for-profit club created by Jim Godbout in 1990. At the time, Mr. Godbout, a marketing and advertising executive from Ridgefield who had joined several private Fairfield County singles groups after his own divorce, targeted a large population of single adults just entering their middle years.
"To me that was the big market, the big picture," he said. "As a marketing director, demographics was my business. I knew that the yuppies were becoming middle-aged and getting divorced. And not only were they a huge entity with expendable income, they needed ways to meet each other."
To attract that professional population, Mr. Godbout was host to singles' dances in elegant restaurants and yacht clubs. The first, held in October 1990 at the Roger Sherman Inn in New Canaan, attracted 150 people from a 50-person mailing list. Since then, Capers' mailing list has grown to 3,500 names, its parties number 26 a year -- and 175 marriages have resulted.
"What Capers does is require that you dress up," said Sean Sullivan, a partner in the Stamford-based advertising firm of Sullivan & Mulvaney. Two years ago Mr. Sullivan, a father of four who had been divorced for 18 years, met Rita Gilcrest, at a Capers party.
"It was just a matter of timing," he said. "She was just getting ready to leave and I was just arriving. We literally bumped into each other." Within a year they were married.
Some groups that have become regular meeting places for newly single people, however, have evolved by chance. One was the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, which first began holding monthly parties for single people, in 1994.
"The idea at the time was to try to boost membership in the 25-35 age group that didn't seem to be utilizing the museum," said York Baker, special events coordinator for the museum. Although the first party held in February 1994 was canceled because of snow, 100 people made reservations for the second one. To Ms. Baker's surprise, 150 showed up, and in April, 300 attended.
"Gradually, we realized that we were attracting an older crowd, those in their 40's and 50's. I had no awareness that there was such a large and active singles' mid-life population out there," said Ms. Baker.
Ultimately, many divorced middle-agers maintain that singlehood should be celebrated as a life style of its own, rather than perceived as a waiting period between mates. "We don't get an identity from another person, we get it from ourselves," said Marian Bauer, a mother of three and school guidance counselor from Stamford. "It's fun to be single. You meet all kinds of people and have all kinds of experiences. Being single is a time to expand yourself and your own horizons."

HEADLINE: State or Towns: Who's Better at Caring for the Poor?

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE quiet, orderly office of the Department of Social Services in Norwich bears no resemblance to the chaos in the lives of the people who pass through the door seeking help.
Norwich, a flourishing city of textile mills at the turn of the century, joined the rest of New England in losing its manufacturing base in the post-World War II period. The city was hit hard again in the late 1980's, when the state's military industries began laying off workers and its unemployment rate remains consistently higher than elsewhere in the state. 
 Thus the need for a wide-ranging plan from the Social Services Department and its director, Beverly Goulet. The department does a great deal more than issue welfare checks, she says. Its social workers provide the first line of defense against hunger, cold and homelessness. A network of services has been set up to supply emergency food, housing, medical care, clothing, money for transportation, job training and substance abuse and psychiatric evaluations. For the past five years, the department has also run a nine-town regional employment program.
But Norwich's safety net may fall apart, Ms. Goulet said, because the State Department of Social Services is scheduled to take control of all general assistance programs by July of next year. The state will handle only mandated benefits at its 14 regional offices. The cities and towns are expected to continue providing services like home visits and crisis management.
General assistance, also known as city welfare, provides aid to single, unemployed adults who do not qualify for other state or for Federal programs. Under state law, the 14 cities in which state welfare offices are situated had the right this year to petition to retain control of their welfare programs. Norwich was the only city in the group to do so and is awaiting the state's decision. The remaining cities have already turned their programs over to the state.
State Representative Robert Keeley, a Democrat of Bridgeport, said his city was eager to shed responsibility for general assistance. The state took over Bridgeport's program in April. "Bridgeport wanted out for one reason: money," said Mr. Keeley, who is House chairman of the legislature's Human Services Committee. "The city has saved a couple of million dollars already," he said. "There wasn't a lot of concern over how well the program would be administered at the state level."
The Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments supports giving towns control of their general assistance programs. But a law would have to be passed to allow municipalities other than the 14 cities to do so. Two attempts to introduce a bill changing the present law failed, said Claudette Beaulieu, director of public and government relations for the State Social Services Department.
William Tallman, the City Manager of Norwich, wrote that the issue of who should administer general assistance should not be about control but about who is best able to provide direct services to the poorest and most medically needy people in the state. In a letter to Joyce Thomas, Commissioner of the State Social Services Department, Mr. Tallman said, "It should not be about fixing something that is not broken."
But state lawmakers believed the local general assistance programs were not working, Ms. Beaulieu said. "They felt they had 169 different programs out there in as many cities and towns. They had concerns about fraud and felt it would be more effective to consolidate cash and medical services under one roof and under one set of rules."
Discussions about general assistance among lawmakers and state officials reflect the changing approach to welfare in general, said State Senator Mary Ann Handley, a Democrat whose district includes Bolton, Glastonbury, Hebron and Manchester. Ms. Handley is Senate chairwoman of the Human Services Committee. "The general assistance program as it is now is essentially a program in which the relationship between the client and the social worker has diminished considerably," she said. "All of that was seen as a good way to reduce the welfare load. By making it less personal, some people would walk away from the system."
Mr. Tallman said the social worker providing the benefits should be intimately aware of all aspects of a case in order to address the barriers that prevent a person from holding a job. Social workers in Norwich have experience that cannot be replaced easily by workers trained only to decide whether or not a person is eligible for benefits, he said.
As Kathleen Kuvalanka, a social worker for the Norwich social services department, explained, "Many of us grew up here. We went to school with some of the people we're trying to help. They're more than just a name. The state will be removed from the consequences. Nobody will have any investment in what happens and any accountability."
In rural Lebanon, one problem is that residents on general assistance do not have transportation to a state welfare office, said Joyce R. Okonuk, Lebanon's First Selectman, in a letter to Ms. Thomas. "We can serve our clients better on a local level," Ms. Okonuk wrote, "as we are familiar with their circumstances and able to monitor their needs on a one-to-one basis."
The First Selectman of Stonington, Donald R. Maranell, agreed with Ms. Okonuk's point of view. "We believe the state cannot manage the town's welfare program with the same efficiency, empathy and common sense," he said in a letter to Ms. Goulet. "Just because the state takes away the administration does not mean the problem goes to the state. Each municipality will still need some level of service to deal with people who fall into the cracks of the system."
In Norwich, a 57-year-old former banker, unable to find a job because of his age and health problems, went to Ms. Goulet's office for help. The man, who asked that his name not be used, has diabetes, high blood pressure and deteriorating vision. He is unable to stand or walk for long periods because he has no feeling in his feet, and sores that form on his feet take a long time to heal.
He tried starting his own business, but, pressured by the recession, was forced to file for bankruptcy. Divorced after 22 years of marriage, the man has no children or relatives living nearby. At first, he said, he was too embarrassed to ask for help and so depressed that he thought about committing suicide. He contacted a priest, who referred him to the Norwich social services department.
"I stopped trying to do everything on my own. I had to face the fact that I was disabled," the man said.
A part-time job and a city welfare check of up to $300 a month helped the man get by for a year. During that time, the application he submitted for Social Security disability pay was denied twice on the grounds that he was employable.
The application was finally approved, and he is receiving disability pay of $1,000 a month. But nearly half that amount goes toward rent. His prescriptions and medical supplies cost $420 a month, and he doesn't know how he will pay for treatment for his vision. He is not eligible for Medicare and cannot afford private medical insurance.
For the past couple of years, the man has survived with help from his friends. He is struggling to start a home-based business, but has no savings to fall back on.
"The government doesn't address people who have been substantial taxpayers and all of a sudden can no longer sustain themselves because of economic cutbacks or physical disabilities," the man said. "In the local office, they at least met with me and talked with me. The state offices couldn't give me the personal attention I needed."
People receiving city welfare do not fit a single profile. They are a diverse group with varied work histories, skills and education. They include young adults in abusive homes, older people with chronic illnesses, people who are released from hospitals or treatment centers without jobs and former workers whose unemployment benefits have run out, said a report by the Connecticut Alliance for Basic Human Needs, an advocacy organization.
The state's response to Norwich's petition will be based on whether or not the city's general assistance program is cost-effective, Ms. Beaulieu said.
Mr. Tallman said the cost to taxpayers would be greater if cases are not managed properly. An agency unable to deliver services like cash assistance and medical benefits has more difficulty getting clients involved in activities that help them become self-sufficient.
State Representative Peter Nystrom, a Republican of Norwich, says it is unfair for the state to make a decision based on cost-effectiveness: "How can they say that? They're not paying for anything any more. They've shifted the whole cost to Norwich. The city has carried its share of social responsibility. They have no right to dismantle that."
Mr. Nystrom says he plans to introduce a bill in the next legislative session allowing local control of general assistance. He added there is bipartisan support for the measure. "I have no faith in the state being able to do what local people have done," he said. "The state has no intention of even trying."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Job training has become more important as the welfare system has changed. Above, welfare recipients in a food service program at Three Rivers Community-Technical College in Norwich serving a graduation buffet. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: Market's Strong -- but for How Long?

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THE real-estate market tends to run behind the curves of the national economy, economists say, like a whip's curl. And so, with the nation's recovery well into its sixth year, the residential sector of the market snapped out of its doldrums only three years ago, with the New York metropolitan region on the trailing end of the curve.
For two years, the Manhattan co-op and condominium market has been bubbling -- fueled by big Wall Street bonuses, the burgeoning computer-based information industry and the chicken-or-eggish, self-fulfilling potential of bidding wars and price hikes -- all concentrated in a pressure cooker caused, in part, by limited housing production. 
 As economists and real-estate specialists predicted, the Manhattan market has since boiled over a bit, so that real estate activity in the city's other boroughs and its suburbs -- driven also by low and stable interest rates, low inflation and increasing employment -- has been simmering for at least the last year.
"The momentum is strong," said James Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, "so we're not going to fall off a cliff, unless there's a major external shock."
With the nation's economic variables apparently propitious and certain elements specific to the region (particularly New York's position in the global information revolution) strengthening, economists have begun to debate how sustainable the current rise in the region's residential market may be. But, at least for the near future, they say -- and none would be more definitive than that -- the signs seem positive.
Where there was only a hole in the ground 18 months ago, a 42-story co-op tower now looms over the western shore of Queens. Coupled with ongoing affordable housing projects, mortgage-assistance programs have helped revitalize whole blocks of otherwise blighted neighborhoods in the boroughs outside of Manhattan, so that even a few stretches of the South Bronx now seem like suburban tracts. And, after working their way out from under the burden left by, at best, unreliable sponsors during the dog days of the late 80's and early 90's, some co-ops in Queens and Brooklyn have refinanced their underlying mortgages and begun to sell apartments -- at increasing prices.
"We are selling co-ops in Forest Hills," said Ed Gitlin, a broker with Benjamin Realty, "and the average price of a one-bedroom that was $35,000 a year ago, right now it's ranging from $50,000 and up."
"In some buildings that have become more financially stable, prices have risen 30 percent just in the past year," Mr. Gitlin said.
"Is it rational? No."
Sales have also been relatively brisk and prices have inched upward through much of the suburban ring, although there remain stalled spots, particularly in and around some of the region's small, still-struggling cities, among them Paterson, N.J., and Hartford, Conn.
Home building is booming in certain areas, particularly if they are close to Manhattan or other major commercial areas. In Westchester County, for example, building permits are up 54 percent over 1996, while in Connecticut they are up 24 percent.
And less quantifiable, yet reflective of the mood of the market, there has even been a sprinkling of reports of packed open houses and bidding wars in the suburbs.
Plunging into the vicissitudes of that percolating market, Robert and Carolyn Matzelle of Ridgefield, Conn. -- he an accountant, she a teacher -- both bought and sold homes, in just three weeks.
"We're in the process of closing on a house in Newtown, southeast of Danbury," Mr. Matzelle said -- a four-bedroom colonial on 2.4 acres that, eventually, went for $326,000.
"We thought we had a confirmed sale at $317,000," Mr. Matzelle said. "We had a binder." But, apparently, a binder means "nothing," he said, "not unless you have a signed contract."
Two other couples made bids after the binder was signed. "We had to come back with our best offer, $326-even," Mr. Matzelle said, to win the war.
To "cinch the deal" on the sale of their four-bedroom, raised ranch on one acre in Ridgefield, the Matzelles agreed to hold an open house. "We had 20 people coming through; what a scene!" Mr. Matzelle said.
The winning bid: $322,500.
"So, we're actually getting a house that's larger than what we're currently in, newer than what we're currently in, more property than what we're currently on, for the same money," Mr. Matzelle said.
For all of Fairfield County, which includes the communities where the Matzelles bought and sold, the median sales price stood at $207,000 at the end of the third quarter of this year, according to data compiled by the Commercial Record, a business weekly -- a 13.7 percent increase over the $182,000 median price a year earlier.
And the number of sales for the county -- which includes more modest communities like Monroe and Shelton, as well as wealthy areas like Greenwich and Darien -- stood at 13,219 during the first nine months of this year, up 8.5 percent over the 12,189 sales during the corresponding period last year.
"Our problem here is that inventory is very low," said Randi Hutton, a broker with Weichert Realtors in Westport and Weston, Conn. "So we've had five situations just in the last week involving multiple bids."
"It's a good problem," Ms. Hutton conceded.
In Nassau, Suffolk and Queens, according to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, which includes all three counties, the median price for a single-family home increased from $157,500 in January to $167,000 at the end of September, a jump of 6.03 percent. And sales volume in the three counties during the first three quarters of this year has kept pace with last year.
The pattern was similar west of the Hudson, where the New Jersey Association of Realtors divides the state into three sections. In northern New Jersey, the median sales price stood at $205,000 at the end of the third quarter, up 2 percent from $201,000 at the start of the year, according to the association. A year earlier, the median price was $188,100. At the same time, sales volume in northern New Jersey was well ahead of last year. In 1996, 58,400 homes were sold, an average of 14,600 in each quarter. In the first three quarters of this year, 46,750 homes have been sold, an average of 15,883 in each quarter.
"There's two main ingredients fueling the real estate economy," said Michael Ford, president of the New Jersey realtors group. "The first one, obviously, is the very attractive interest rate, and the second is the first-time buyer."
MORTGAGE rates in the region, said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage research company, "are hovering at the lowest point in 19 months -- 7.36 percent for a 30-year, fixed." And they have been "extremely stable this year," ranging from 8.3 percent in April for a 30-year, fixed rate, to the current low.
"We are just a half percentage point above the 28-year low that we reached back in October 1993 -- 6.83 percent," Mr. Gumbinger said, pointing out that in October 1981 the 30-year, fixed rate stood at a celestial 18.31 percent.
Among the first-time buyers that Mr. Ford spoke of were Dina and Mario Sosa who -- along with their daughters, Nicole, 4, and Jenna, 2, as well as Grandma Hilda and Grandpa Manuel Sosa -- were deep in the throes of packing last week.
"It feels good, except there's so much to be done," said Mrs. Sosa, a pharmacy supervisor in Woodbridge, N.J. Mr. Sosa is an auto mechanic.
The Sosas moved from Brooklyn a decade ago and were renting a house in Rahway. "You know what it is?" Mrs. Sosa said. "You put so much into a house and it's not yours, so you finally want something that's yours."
The new house, a four-bedroom split level that is only a few blocks away in Rahway, cost $180,000. The entire purchase process lasted a month.
"I thought it was going to be a lot harder," Mrs. Sosa said. "You hear the horror stories: the people change their mind, the mortgage doesn't go through. But we were the first to look and he took our offer."
A problem has arisen, with the children. "They want to paint their room red, so I'm arguing with them to make it a nice pink," Mrs. Sosa said. "And they want to know if the dog is coming. 'Yes, we're taking Taz.' "
In the current heated market, upscale Manhattan has been particularly torrid. By way of illustration, statistics compiled by the Charles H. Greenthal Residential Sales Corporation indicate that the median price for a two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan stood at $521,000 in September, up 20.1 percent from $433,616 in September 1996. "People are not leaving New York," said Joyce West, executive vice president of Greenthal, "they're buying up. And so many areas have been reborn: I remember in the 70's I couldn't get people to go up above 86th Street."
Newcomers, too, are fueling the Manhattan market.
"What the mud of the Nile is for Egypt each year, the flow of the best and the brightest from the best or, at least, the most expensive schools is to New York," said George Sternlieb, the retired founder of the urban policy institute at Rutgers. "Suddenly, with glamour, we're pulling from all over."
A barometer of the pull to Manhattan for young newcomers was offered by a 34 percent increase in studio apartment sales -- from 462 in the first 11 months of 1996 to 619 in the corresponding period this year -- reported by the Corcoran Group.
"The studio segment is the first to go down and the last to go up," said Barbara Corcoran, the company's founder. "So, I read a lot into that number: that this market is fully recovered. The rich always do well, but studio owners usually don't. And these days the underdog is moving at a very fast pace."
John Graham, 34, an investment banker from Virginia, bought a studio in Manhattan during the spring. "Technically, it's not a studio," Mr. Graham insisted. "The bedroom has a door that closes it off. But it's very small, like living on a sailboat."
Perhaps the best description for an apartment situated above the elevator shaft and below the water tower of a 20-story building on West End Avenue would be: penthouse studio.
"I finally found a place that's perfection, on top of the world," Mr. Graham said. "However many millions of people there are in New York, I have no neighbors. I have windows all the way around. I've got a fireplace, hardwood floors, and it has a deck outside, too."
The price for high-rise, studio-scale perfection: "In the low-$300's."
In the estimation of Mr. Ford, the New Jersey realtors association president, the current upward trend "started back in '96, and this whole year has seen a good, sustained market, from Cape May to Fort Lee."
"This market," Mr. Ford added, with a broker's ingrained optimism, "I would love to say it looks like it's never going to end."
Fat chance, most economists say. But not all.
"We had a dreadful crash shortly after '87," Dr. Sternlieb pointed out, "and while other parts of the country recovered, the Northeast in general, but New York City in particular, was the caboose on the national recovery train.
"Now, the definition of a real estate developer is essentially a speculator without a memory, because, generally speaking, the problem of the real estate field is that by the time you have secured your financing, assembled your land and are digging a hole in the ground, the economy is beginning to peak and crumble. You're always behind the curve."
YET, there is no arguing with the fact that the nation's economic recovery is 6 1/2 years old -- two years short of the longest this century, from 1961 to 1969 -- while the average postwar expansion has lasted only four years. "So there is substantial national economic momentum," Dr. Hughes at Rutgers said.
The region's recovery is about 5 1/2 years long. "Not as long as the nation but, nonetheless, a very long expansion," Dr. Hughes said. And, over the last three years, the real estate market has joined the parade.
Sales of existing single-family homes across the country hit an all-time high of 4.08 million last year, according to the National Association of Realtors, and if the pace continues this year, a new record will be set.
According to "U.S. Housing Market Conditions," a report published by the Department of Housing and Urban Development last month, the median price of existing single-family homes throughout the nation in the third quarter of this year was $126,500, 5 percent above the third quarter of 1996.
And helping to spur the metropolitan area's real estate recovery is, of course, job growth. John Weiting, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said 1997 "is shaping up as a fairly strong year for employment in the region." The tristate area added 134,000 jobs in the year ended in October, Commissioner Weiting said, topping gains of 114,000 in the prior 12 months, and only 43,000 in the year that ended in October 1995.
Job growth, low inflation, low and stable mortgage rates, all combined with New York's status as a center for the global information revolution and a mecca for immigrants, bode well for the future of the region's real estate market, economists say.
"One caveat," said Arthur Margon, director of the New York University Real Estate Institute: "The scenario is based on all those factors continuing or, at least, avoiding a serious contraction. And the only sign of trouble is that outside the United States you have these sort of air pockets in Asia."
In the glow of extended expansion, some observers have, in recent months, touted a "new economic paradigm," premised on the contention that integration of the world's markets because of computer technology has increased exports and productivity to such a degree that prices, wages, inflation and interest rates will all remain moderate for the foreseeable future. And, yet, at the same time, increased productivity has generated job growth.
All ultimately good for the real estate market.
JOHN TUCCILLO, consulting economist with the National Association of Realtors, does not quite hold to the theory. "All that doesn't mean we are not going to have recessions or that the business cycle is dead," Dr. Tuccillo said, "but it does mean that the economy is generally biased toward growth."
One other factor contributes to Dr. Tuccillo's optimism. "Most baby boomers are now 40 years old," he said. "That means they are entering a decade of high productivity, high earning, high savings and high spending. And, as far as housing is concerned, these folks will be buying up.
"So I think we will be seeing a very strong demand for housing over the next 10 years."
But Susan Wachter, a professor of real estate economics at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, is fatalistic.
"As a business cycle gets old we are vulnerable to negative surprises," she said. "It seems as though we are immune because we don't see them on the horizon, but they are out there. And there will be a downturn."
Somewhere in the middle is Dr. Hughes, who wondered whether a shock must come or, perhaps, the regional real estate market might experience a prudent, sustainable pattern akin to regular respiration.
"You have to be a bit cautious, just because of the length of the expansion, that the law of averages is going to catch up with us," he said. "But there aren't that many imbalances built up, like in the 80's, when we had a huge run-up in prices, undisciplined corporate expansion, great overbuilding in the office sector, undisciplined lending in all types of ventures."
Imbalances in the current market include the potential for overvaluing in the stock market and heavy levels of consumer debt, Dr. Hughes said. "But if they don't cause a problem and the overall economy continues doing well into '99, we could be in striking distance of real estate's equivalent of Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak."

T.G.I. Fifth Avenue Fills a Hungry Hole
 Timed for the onslaught of hungry holiday shoppers, the restaurant franchise T.G.I. Friday's, based in Dallas, opened on Fifth Avenue last month. 
 The new spot, with 400 seats in five stories on 604 Fifth Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets, is run and owned by Riese Restaurants, a corporate group that runs 150 Manhattan restaurants and now owns nine T.G.I. Friday's franchises, all in Manhattan.
"There are no other full-service restaurants between 34th Street and Central Park South on Fifth Avenue," said Don Metznik, vice president of marketing for the Riese Organization.
But to make the space work, the company had to think vertically -- with three floors devoted to dining and two floors for the kitchen.
 
Do You Play 'Feelings'? There May Be a Job for You
 Doug Howard calls himself a hack guitar player and a lounge music enthusiast; he loves listening to Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme. (He's also a devotee of Frank Sinatra and the songs of Cole Porter.)
But Mr. Howard, who is 41, felt there just wasn't enough lounge music out there. So he found two investors, and with $500,000 and office space at 568 Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets, started his own label -- Lodestar Entertainment. He also works as general manager of the East Coast operation of ETV Network, a company that promotes and distributes music videos for public performances (like stores and cruise ships).
The mission of Lodestar: to sign up new "lounge music" talent. The company, with a staff of five, put out two CD's this fall: Joe E. Howard's "From This Moment On" and Scott Gordon's "Something to Remember You By."
Mr. Howard said: "You know, there are those of us who don't want music blasted in our ears. It's a niche market just waiting to be filled."
 
Former Restaurateur Turns From Roasting to Tanning
After catering for years to the Upper East Side, James Oliver, the former director of restaurant operations for the Sign of the Dove, Yellowfingers and Arizona 206, decided to go into business for himself -- but in Brooklyn.
He joined forces with two former Manhattan bartenders who had started a tanning salon business called Beach Bum Tanning, with seven parlors around the city. Mr. Oliver opened Brooklyn's first Beach Bum Tanning this fall, at 530 86th Street, between Fifth Avenue and Fort Hamilton Parkway in Bay Ridge.
Why Brooklyn? "The demographics of this area were right," said Mr. Oliver, who said he looks for places where there are people 18 to 35 years old with a lot of disposable income. "It's a vanity thing," he said.
As for whether this is bad for one's skin, Mr. Oliver said: "Hey, eating will make you fat. It's only bad in excess. You know, we were meant to live outdoors, and it makes you look healthy."
The cost of looking healthy is $5 to $7 for a 20-minute session. You need three to five sessions for a tan, Mr. Oliver said. The first session is free.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Priming the Pump for New Middle-Income Housing

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE tenants living in a year-old apartment building called the Bristol in the Flushing section of Queens include a 26-year-old registered nurse free from the parental nest for the first time, a 45-year-old teacher who left her husband as well as her apartment when she moved to the Bristol with her two young children, and a Chinese astrologer.
The astrologer is Yung Yuan Lai, 63, who moved into a fifth-floor, two-bedroom apartment with his wife, Mei Chu, and two children in their 20's. Astrology is an honored profession in China, Mr. Lai noted, although 30 percent of his clients are Americans or other non-Asians. 
 Those proportions are close to those of the demographics at the Bristol itself, a 60-unit building at 138-49 Barclay Avenue, near Main Street. The Bluestone Organization, the builder-owner, says that 60 percent of the tenants are Asian, mainly of Chinese descent.
The more important tenant characteristic from a housing perspective is that 80 percent of the tenants are middle-income. As a 1990's housing product in New York City, the Bristol is a rare specimen -- a new rental apartment house outside Manhattan. It was built with tax-exempt bond financing, a method typically used only in Manhattan, where market-rate rents are high enough to permit the project to support low-income occupancy. Twenty percent of the tenants must be low income under this "80-20" program.
But now New York City has come forward with a new housing loan program, which, if successful, should generate about a dozen new middle-income apartment buildings outside prime Manhattan locations. Unlike the 80-20 program, it has no requirement for partial low-income occupancy. From the reaction of builders and lenders it could provide the impetus for construction in such locations as Flushing and Forest Hills in Queens, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn, and Manhattan Valley and East Harlem in Manhattan.
The program is run by the city's Housing Development Corporation, a state-chartered public benefit corporation that provides financing for multifamily housing within the city. It was announced in late October, just before the mayoral election. Richard T. Roberts, who is chairman of the board of the corporation as well as Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, called the program a model for future city assistance to new multifamily construction.
The financing, which will come from long-term taxable bonds, will not impinge on the capacity of city agencies to promote economic development through tax-exempt borrowings. And, since H.D.C. bonds have an AA rating from Standard and Poor's, the housing will get the benefit of interest rates somewhat lower than current conventional mortgage rates.
In addition, the development corporation is prepared to offer a direct low-interest loan for each apartment built to further help make the apartments affordable. This subsidy is expected to average $15,000 an apartment and be offered at 1 to 3 percent interest over the term of the loan, which may be as long as 35 years. The amount will vary depending on the location of the project and the rent-generating capacity of the market in that area.
Eligible projects will be those with at least 20 apartments, produced either through new construction, the substantial rehabilitation of an existing residential building or the conversion, on an as-of-right basis, of an existing nonresidential building. In Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx or Staten Island, the property can be in any location where multifamily development is permissible. In Manhattan the site must be north of 110th Street in the case of new construction, or north of 96th Street in a rehabilitation.
The income limits on renters -- or buyers if the project is done as a limited-equity co-op -- are the same as those that apply to Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing, last produced in the late 70's. In households of one or two persons, annual income can be as high as seven times the annual rent, or as much as eight times the annual rent for larger families, up to a maximum of 250 percent of median income in New York City, or $118,500 for a family of four at present.
There are also rent or carrying-charge limits -- $800 for a studio, $1,050 for a 1-bedroom, $1,350 for a 2-bedroom and $1,750 for a 3-bedroom. A family earning as little of $40,000 a year might be able to afford a $1,000-a-month 1-bedroom apartment, paying 30 percent of annual income as rent. But the income limit for eligibility would be much higher, $84,000 a year. Because of the sites that are likely to developed, most tenants will probably be at an income level well below the maximum theoretically allowed.
TO get the program started, the Housing Development Corporation has set aside $15 million, which at an average of $15,000 a unit would finance about 1,000 new middle-income housing units. The money comes from the corporation's reserves built up from housing-finance operations, said Barbara Udell, president of the Housing Development Corporation, and if they are used successfully a second phase will follow.
Charles A. Brass, the corporation's vice president for development, said that preliminary responses from builders who have worked with city programs in the past has been positive. "We're basically looking for housing for families earning from $35,000 to $75,000 a year," Mr. Brass said.
The challenge for builders, several of them said in interviews, will be to find sites at low enough prices that are capable of attracting tenants who can pay, say, $1,300 a month for a 2-bedroom apartment. Most hopeful are those situations where builders already hold the property and are close to feasibility already.
"It's geared toward places where the market is at $1,300 to $1,600 a month and not many neighborhoods have that," said Ronald Moelis, a partner in in L & M Equity Ltd., a developer based in Larchmont, N.Y., that has participated in various city-assisted housing programs.
"If you can find a renovation project you might have a better shot at making the numbers work than in new construction," said Barry Zelikson, director of development at Sparrow Construction Company in the Bronx, another builder.
Michael D. Lappin, president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a major citywide construction lender, predicted the program would provide an opportunity for smaller, efficient builder-owners. "This could produce some affordable housing," he said.
For multifamily housing, that would be progress. Private multifamily housing production outside Manhattan has been nil in the 90's, said Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, although 20,000 units were created by city-assisted rehabilitations of vacant buildings, typically for low-income occupancy. The council's figures are compiled from city agencies. The Department of City Planning, which also reports on housing completions, has not yet released any data for the post-1995 period.
For builders generally, the biggest problem will be finding sites at a low enough cost in neighborhoods capable of attracting people able to pay $1,200 to $1,500 a month in rent. Typically, even when such sites exist owners tend to raise the asking price for land once a new subsidy program becomes available, again throwing feasibility into question. But sometimes builders already own the land. "We've had a site in Park Slope for 12 years where we could do 50 units as of right," said David Gaunt, a principal in Premiere Management and Development Company, based in Manhattan. "It's hard to pencil out a rental project. We're doing an evaluation now to see if this new program will work for us."
One likely user is the Bluestone Organization, the builder-owner of the Bristol in Flushing and nine other rentals in Queens and Great Neck, L.I., over the last 30 years. "We have a site in Forest Hills where we think it will work," said Harold Bluestone, a principal in the organization. "I can't disclose the location yet."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Making It in Manhattan: A Tale of Two Cities

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
WHEN New Yorkers talk about their "neighborhood," they most likely mean the streets filled with the places they patronize -- to buy vegetables, drop off dry cleaning, rent a video, fill a prescription or eat Chinese food. Small businesses, and the familiar faces running them, are a big part of an urbanite's daily life -- and vital to the nation's economic health.
Then there is that other New York "neighborhood," the skyscraper-and-cyberspace precincts that house the city's financial powerhouses. Here, the ZIP code may be local, but the customers and power are global. 
 Both New York worlds, Main Street's purveyors and Wall Street's masters of the universe, are described in fascinating detail in two terrific new books.
"Around the Block: The Business of a Neighborhood" by Tom Shachtman (Harcourt Brace, $28) is a lively, insightful chronicle of a year in the business life of a Manhattan block, specifically the section bounded by West 17th and 18th Streets and Seventh and Eighth Avenues in Chelsea.
The block has roughly 100 small enterprises, more than some midsized towns, the author points out. The mix is typical of a middle-class Manhattan street. Among the businesses are restaurants, dry cleaners, liquor stores, deli-groceries, video stores, plumbing suppliers and a lumber depot.
Although the block's business owners are much like entrepreneurs everywhere, a few trends are distinctly urban: Some businesses cater to gay clients. Many of the entrepreneurs are immigrants; the Korean owner of a liquor store says he took courses to learn the business after the store's former owner balked at selling to him because "I'm Asian and didn't know anything about wine." And a manager of a deli-grocery says there is so much shoplifting -- "and not just kids, people in suits" -- that he wants to stop selling french fries because he has to turn his back to the customers to make them.
At the time of Mr. Shachtman's interviews in 1993 and 1994, the neighborhood was just emerging from a recession that saw 60,000 small businesses close in cities nationwide, the author says.
Still, the block's 2,500 employees had produced a gross annual income of $1.5 billion in 1992. And the author, whose previous books include "Skyscraper Dreams," about New York's real estate empires, wanted to find out whether these -- and therefore other -- small businesses could bounce back and create more jobs. Eventually, they do.
"Around the Block" is a wonderful weave of personal stories and big-picture trends. Mr. Shachtman has mastered the art of the disciplined digression; his side trips into architecture, history and macroeconomics are short and sharply illuminating.
The book unabashedly roots for its entrepreneurs; there are no disgruntled employees or dissatisfied customers in its pages. And as the author vividly illustrates the struggles of keeping a small business alive, he chastises the institutions that, he says, fail to help. Around the block, he writes, "there are almost as many tales of shortsightedness, intransigence and lack of flexibility by banks and governmental loan sources as there are small businesses."
Small businesses are America's hope, he believes. "If capitalism is to retain a human face, and to be viable in our cities," he warns, "we must not permit it to be reduced to a creature of, or the product of, big business alone."
Which brings us to the fascinating 1990's business chronicle in that other New York neighborhood.
"From 1993 to 1995, I sold derivatives on Wall Street," writes Frank Partnoy in the opening lines of his excellent kiss-and-tell tale, "F.I.A.S.C.O.: Blood in the Water on Wall Street" (W. W. Norton, $25).
A derivative is an investment linked in value to another security, say a stock or bond. An option to buy a stock is a simple example of a derivative, the author points out. But Wall Street prefers the complicated examples, he writes, in part because they are so confusing.
At Morgan Stanley, where he worked in the Derivative Products Group for a year starting in 1994, "no one seemed to care about whether clients actually understood what they were buying," he writes.
Some of those clients, at pension funds and insurance companies, were simply in over their heads, he says, when they invested in "complex foreign exchange bets packaged to look like simple and safe bonds." Others, he says, understood the gamble but could point to the tiny reliable-bond ingredient of the currency-and-debt package if regulators came sniffing around. There was, after all, big money to be made in the $55 trillion worldwide market in derivatives.
(In a statement after the publication of "F.I.A.S.C.O.," Morgan Stanley assailed its contents. "The book is clearly a combination of inaccuracies and sensationalism," it said. "Our business is based on consistent and professional service to our clients and customers.")
Mr. Partnoy, now an assistant professor at the University of San Diego School of Law, writes with style and a supple intelligence, and he is a master teacher when it comes to explaining the arcane, mostly unregulated, deals carried out under the derivatives banner.
In the tradition of "Liar's Poker," Michael Lewis's account of a stint at Salomon Brothers, the author, who was 27 when he got to Morgan Stanley, is also entertaining as he tells the book's parallel story: his immersion into a strange, "feral" culture, "half geek, half wolf." It is a world, the author says, where traders and salesmen brag about multimillion-dollar deals that "rip" a client's "face off," quote compulsively from the movie "Caddyshack" and read Guns & Ammo magazine. (The weapons obsession is acted out in a yearly skeet shoot, the Fixed Income Annual Sporting Clays Outing, which gives the book its acronymic title.)
The author acknowledges that he initially hungered for this world, with its promise of millions in salaries and bonuses. "I suppose it is a bit of a character flaw that I beheld the financial orgy of a trading floor with such desire," he writes. "But I did."
Now, in the wake of the derivative debacles suffered by Orange County, Calif., among others, the message from Mr. Partnoy is this: "Wall Street has made, and continues to make, a huge amount of money on derivatives by trickery or deceit."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A New Democratic Leader Sees Bipartisanship

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Despite Governor Whitman's near-defeat last month, New Jersey's Democrats did not make any significant gains in the General Assembly or the Senate. Republicans remain firmly in control of the Legislature. Democrats can accomplish, little, if anything, on their own.
So what role will Democrats now play in Trenton? Will they continue in their role as naysayers or join forces with their Republican colleagues so that lawmakers, and not Mrs. Whitman, wield the most influence over state policy and politics in the coming four years? 
 In the Assembly, Democrats have voted to re-elect Joseph V. Doria, a Democrat from Hudson County, as their leader. Mr. Doria and Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County, have always managed to find ways to do business.
But in the Senate, there has been more political acrimony between Democrats and Republicans in recent years. Republicans rarely brought Democrats to the table to help draw up solutions to difficult problems. And Democrats responded by not cooperating at all under the leadership of the Minority Leader, John A. Lynch, of New Brunswick, who has decided to relinquish his leadership role.
Last week, Senate Democrats elected a new leader, the veteran lawmaker Richard J. Codey, who said was open to the prospect of a more cooperative relationship with Republican leaders. That is, if Republicans are more willing to bring Democrats into the process earlier and not just turn to them for support on bills after learning they don't have enough votes in their own caucus.
"It is a different climate," said Mr. Codey, 51, an insurance broker from West Orange who has served in the Legislature since 1974. "I think that it is more of a climate that lends itself to bipartisanship. The Governor can't run again, so no one can accuse us of being negative because we want her to be defeated. So I think our criticism will be, hopefully, looked at in a nonpartisan way."
He said that he also thinks that Republican legislative leaders and the Governor's office took Democrats for granted, at times, because there was a perception that their votes were not needed. "I am quite sure she won't be able to count on Republicans in the Legislature to advance her agenda with the same certainty as she did in her first term," Mr. Codey said. "In effect, Democrats in the Legislature could break a lot of gridlock created by the Governor's office and legislative Republicans."
Mr. Codey was first elected to the Assembly at the age of 26. He has sponsored numerous laws and bills over the years, including the Casino Control Act in 1977, which created casino gaming in Atlantic City. But he has focused most of his efforts on health care issues and tightening state laws and regulations to improve conditions in the state's mental health system.
In 1987, he took the unusual step of taking a job as an orderly on the night shift at Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital so that he could learn about conditions there. The staff did not know he was a state lawmaker. He told only his family and a few close friends about his plan, disguising his identity at the hospital by using the name of a dead rapist and the Social Security number of a dead armed robber.
"The conditions were unbelievable," he said. "It was mind boggling." Patients were not treated properly. There were no activities organized on their behalf. Medical and psychiatric treatment was inconsistent, at best. Some employees had criminal backgrounds. His findings prompted the resignation of the hospital's president and 34 other employees. He also drafted legislation to improve patient conditions and impose criminal background checks for employees.
Mr. Codey said that he has always believed strongly in the role of watchdog, and he believes that is an important role for members of the minority. "When the majority party is doing something wrong, you have to bark as loud as you can," he said.
But he said that Democrats were prepared to deliver difficult votes "if we can help craft the product of hard decisions."
"They always talk about bipartisanship when they don't have enough votes on that side of the aisle," he said.
The first test to see how closely Democrats and Republicans can work together will come before the end of the year. The state's current system of financing charity care -- paying hospitals for providing free treatment to uninsured individuals -- expires on Dec. 31. Both business groups and organized labor strongly object to proposals that the state continue to rely heavily on paying for charity care with money from unemployment taxes.
Several proposals are on the table, including a 25-cent cigarette tax increase. Democrats, punished by voters for supporting former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990, have rejected past cigarette tax increase proposals. But this time, things could be different. Mr. Codey said that Democrats have been at the table with Republican legislative leaders, from the beginning on this issue.
And there could be movement on other difficult issues, like property taxes, school financing, auto insurance and capital construction costs for schools.
He said that it remains to be seen whether there will be agreement. "We can try to make a good faith effort on all of them," he said. "Obviously, there are times when we are not going to agree. But it will not be because we did not try to reach consensus."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
For Asian-Americans in Flushing, Boom and Maybe Bust: For Shops, Korea's Ills Are Catching

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Beneath the glowing neon and storefront signs on Union Street that offer items from electronic goods to bridal dresses, not a customer could be found last Tuesday night in Koreatown.
"It's going to be a very gloomy Christmas," said Jay Ha, the owner of the Hancook Travel Agency. "Nobody is going back to Korea because they are worried about their businesses and mortgages. And nobody from there can afford to come here." 
 South Korea, which was on the verge of defaulting on billions of dollars in commitments to overseas lenders, has seen its economy plunge in recent weeks. The International Monetary Fund agreed to a $55 billion bailout last week, but in the weeks before that, South Korea's stock market and the value of its currency, the won, went into a tailspin, rattling not only the Korean economy but also the nearly 400 businesses in Flushing owned by Korean-Americans.
Some local enterprises like grocery stores and auto repair shops are sandbagged against the financial tsunami because they do business locally and within the neighborhood. But others, like travel agencies, restaurants and clothing stores that rely on links to the old country, have been hit hard.
"On one hand, the devauled won means that Korean imports are cheaper," said Changsoo Kim, an economic adviser to the New York Society of Korean Businessmen. "On the other hand, many of the retailers have a big problem because they depend on Korean tourists, and suddenly no Korean can afford to be a tourist."
In a subterranean shop along Union Street, Sun Park was counting a small wad of bills, the day's sales at BL Men's Wear. "We have to be down 40 percent this year," Mrs. Park, 33, said glumly. The Italian-style shoes were marked down 50 percent. "We're going to have to have a sale all the way through New Year, because people are worried and have stopped spending their money."
Flushing is the nation's second-largest Koreatown, after Los Angeles, and would appear moderately insulated from the goings-on in South Korea. But the fiscal crisis there has revealed how deeply linked the Korean-American economy is to Asia.
"Besides the tourist dollars and the very new immigrants who still depend on financial help from home, the crisis has a psychological effect on consumption here," said Dr. Pyong Gap Min, professor of sociology at Queens College. "Even if you are well-to-do in America, if your family in Korea is suffering you tend to suffer, too. People worry and become frugal."
Money sent to family members back home may be less this year, as Korean-Americans feel the pinch. On the bright side, the dollars sent back are worth much more in the face of the weak Korean won.
Students also feel the exchange-rate pinch. Chang Han, an engineering student from Seoul, stared into a restaurant with a fully stocked bar. "You must believe things are going to get better," he said. "I hope it happens before Christmas." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Express;
Berthing Those Babies

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
CHEVROLET has presented Kenny and Bobbi McCaughey a 1998 Chevy Express van so they can fetch home their septuplets, Iowa's neo-natal celebrities. My wife said it best: "There must be easier ways to get a free van."
But what a van. The McCaugheys' new ride is simply humongous, an extended-wheelbase version of Chevy's full-size-and-then-some passenger shuttle, nearly 20 feet long and able to carry in almost amniotic comfort 15 people and their luggage -- a claim not even Mother McCaughey can make. 
 Put it another way: On their way home to Carlisle from the hospital in Des Moines, the McCaugheys could stop to pick up a set of hitchhiking quints.
The Express puts up its considerable
avoirdupois against the Ford Club Wagon and the Dodge Ram Wagon in the full-size van market, which comprises the largest road-going vehicles typically available to consumers. Oh, sure, somebody out there may be marketing converted school buses, but they don't count.
The Big Three sell about 350,000 full-size vans a year. Ford has led the way in 1997 with 142,000 sold through October, compared with 88,000 for Chevy and 67,000 for Dodge. Some 20 to 30 percent of Ford's and Dodge's big vans are seat-equipped people haulers, the balance being cargo vans and stripped models destined to become custom conversions and airport buses.
But at General Motors, full-size vans configured for passengers -- the Chevy Express and GMC Savana -- accounted for a piddling 5 percent of big-van sales in the same period. The Express, bigger in several dimensions than its rivals, was redesigned for 1997 to help tilt the scales the other way.
Virtually unchanged for '98, the Express Van is a mechanical twin of the Chevy Van, a windowless cargo hauler upon whose buyers a clever name would seem to be wasted.
The test vehicle, though not as prodigious as the McCaugheys' stretched model, was still big enough to serve as modular housing. It was the standard-wheelbase (135 inches), 12-passenger Express G1500 LS, which I found quite justly named, since it can transport an entire Kinder-Care class 550 miles nonstop on a 31-gallon tank of regular unleaded gas. Its fuel economy rating of 13 m.p.g. in town and 18 on the highway, while seemingly scandalous, is in fact not bad considering the chunk of air it has to displace to make headway. My family of three -- no spectacular gang births are on the horizon, thank you -- nicknamed it "Boxcar Willie."
G.M.'s full-size vans offer a variety of power plants, starting with a workaday V6 of 4.3 liters, producing 200 horsepower and 250 foot-pounds of torque. The test van had the classic 350-cubic-inch (5.7 liter) Chevy V8, which turns out a hearty 245 horsepower and 325 foot-pounds of torque, enough to whip the huge vessel to 60 m.p.h. in less than 10 seconds. A turbo-diesel power plant is also available, churning out 190 horses and 385 foot-pounds. And the top of the line is a big-block, 7.4-liter V8 with 290 horses and 410 foot-pounds of torque, enough raw force to pull parking meters out by their roots.
Which you may be tempted to do when you try to park the Express. A Gulliver on the urban shore, the Express Van dwells in a spatial dimension about a third larger than the world's drive-through windows, parking decks and toll plazas were designed for. The 135-inch wheelbase is longer than a Suburban's (the McCaugheys' is 20 inches longer yet), practically guaranteeing that you'll clip a curb or perhaps a mailbox until, like a truck driver, you learn to wait until you're well into the intersection before you turn the wheel. In a vehicle 6.58 feet high, you'll find yourself ducking and breathing small prayers as you pass under those overhead barriers that say, "No Vehicles Over 7 Feet."
The Express's turning radius of 45.2 to 53.5 feet, depending on the model, can produce comic effects. Attempting to do a 180-degree turn on a narrow side street, I almost managed to get the Express stuck between brick walls, a la Austin Powers.
Visibility is excellent in the Express, practically 360 degrees, since the vehicle's northern hemisphere is almost all glass. But because the gunwales are so high, it's easy to miss a small sports car like a Miata swimming alongside the cetacean side quarters. The Express has good, oversized mirrors, and you need to use them.
For whatever aggravations come to the driver, the passengers enjoy a smooth, stable, spacious ride. The seats are firmly stuffed and dressed with muted fabric upholstery with beige vinyl trimming. The test model had rear air-conditioning with a series of ceiling-mounted climate outlets facing the three rows of bench seats.
There was, however, a surprising dearth of cup holders, which would be heresy in the unquenchable ranks of mini-van shoppers. Also, a wall-covering panel had come loose, the sort of quality-control item that drives consumers nuts.
Access to the seats is achieved through two right-side doors, hinged on the outside so they will swing well out of the way. And because the Express shares its genes with the cargo van, the rear doors are designed to open to 165 degrees, so that the Express can be backed snugly to a loading dock.
In fact, it's pretty easy to convert the Express into a cargo hauler. The rear seats unlatch and roll out easily. But don't try a clean-and-jerk maneuver with the seats on your own unless someone in your family practices sports medicine.
How much can the Express hold? With the rear seats removed, it yawns wide with 267 cubic feet of space. The extended version offers more than 316 cubic feet, enough to hold some 7,584 Pampers -- or roughly four and a half months' worth of nappies for the Clan McCaughey.
The Express is available in 1500, 2500 and 3500 load ratings, the latter able to transport almost two tons of passengers or cargo while towing a 10,000-pound trailer.
If you don't take your youngsters out of school for vacation, you could try dragging the school with you.
After a week in the Express, I'm surprised that full-size vans don't encroach more into the territory of the family mini-van. The Express is conscientiously equipped with dual air bags, daytime running lamps, child safety locks, a theft-deterrent system, four-wheel anti-lock brakes and heavy-duty chassis.
Plus the LS is stocked with creature comforts, from a compact disk player to a six-way power driver's seat, from 12-passenger seating (15 for the McCaugheys' G3500 Extended model) to remote keyless entry. And the price -- with $4,278 in options, the G1500 had a sticker of $29,689 -- is a fastball in the dead center of the mini-van strike zone.
For families living in wide-open spaces who are intent on cultivating their own farm teams, the Chevy Express LS seems, ahem, pregnant with possibilities.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
For Asian-Americans in Flushing, Boom and Maybe Bust: Housing Prices Rise With Immigration

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Eduardo Giago was purchasing three cigars at H & H Meat, a small Latino grocery that has been on the corner of Bowne Street and Franklin Avenue in southern Flushing for 20 years. He bit the end off one of his Te Amos and spat it out the door, his face rippled with concern.
"This used to be the Latin corner of Flushing," he said. "Now I don't think we're going to be able to afford to be here anymore." 
 While Flushing has long been a vibrant home to Asian-Americans, most had made their homes and established their businesses in the neighborhood's northern sectors, mainly above Sanford Avenue. But with immigration from Asia burgeoning, commercial development in northern Flushing is saturated, residential space is at a premium and realtors and developers are turning their attention to the area south of Sanford, bordered by Kissena and Parsons Boulevards and Kissena Park.
The area, once known as Doctors' Row because of the large concentration of physicians who formerly lived and practiced in oversized central-hall colonials there, has become one of the hottest real estate regions in Queens.
"Sanford Avenue was once the dividing line between the rich and the not-so," said Joseph Pistilli of the Pistilli Realty Group, based in Astoria. "Flushing is a boom area for the new Americans -- most of them Asian -- and they are high on property in this neighborhood as an investment."
For example, the Korean American Presbyterian Church of Queens, which is across the street from H & H Meats, already occupies the entire northern side of Ash Street and is currently developing the south side. On nearby Bowne Street, the finishing touches are being put on a large Hindu temple.
The growing Asian population has also increased demand for already scarce housing.
"There is such a lack of housing in Flushing right now that redevelopment is coming to this entire area," said Roger Lo, president of A. O. Realty in Flushing. "In two years, you might not recognize the place. It's going to look like Forest Hills."
With the city currently redoing the streets in southern Flushing, and a swath of large detached turn-of-the-century homes zoned for six- and seven-story residential developments, the real estate boom in the area seems bound to continue, said John Watts, president of the Flushing Local Development Corporation.
"When I was a realtor in the area 10 years ago, I couldn't sell a home there for $100,000," Mr. Watts said. "Some of these places are going for nearly four times that, I'm hearing."
While the recent downturn in Asian economies has rippled as far as Flushing, the relative safety of investing in the United States is likely to strengthen the neighborhood, Mr. Lo said.
"Hong Kong, Korean and Chinese money is flowing into Queens," said Mr. Lo, who recently returned from a month-long scouting trip to China. "It's a safer bet here."
But as in any booming area, the increase in real estate prices has raised concerns among longtime residents who fear they will be priced out of the market.
"That's the way it's been going around here," Mr. Giago said. "We're getting run out." CHARLIE LeDUFF
