HEADLINE: Old Man Bandwidth;
Will Commerce Flourish Where Rivers of Wire Converge?

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Three years ago, Brian Reid came away from a tour of California's missions with an epiphany that today is transforming this cornerstone city of Silicon Valley into the nerve center of cyberspace.
Mr. Reid, a computer scientist with the Digital Equipment Corporation, had done pioneering work in the 1970's on the Arpanet, the computer network that would evolve into the Internet. While playing tourist with his fourth-grade daughter in 1994, he realized that each 16th-century mission he had visited represented an experiment in urban planning; those that combined the right economic, geographic and social factors eventually blossomed into cities. 
 Just as centers of commerce sprang up along navigable rivers, around natural harbors and parallel to railroad tracks and major roads in earlier centuries, Mr. Reid came to believe that the commercial hubs of the next millennium would take root around pipelines that carry torrents of computer data.
"Bandwidth is the delivery vehicle by which these companies sell their goods in the information age," Mr. Reid said last week. "Bandwidth in the late 1990's is important for commerce in the same way that railroads were important in the 1890's and seaports were in the 1790's. It's the way you sell your product."
As applied to the Internet, bandwidth is a measure of how much data can flow between any two computers at any given moment. The Internet can be seen as a system of larger-to-smaller pipes or the branches of a plant's roots. The closer your computer is to the Internet backbone -- that is, to the fattest pipes or roots in the system -- the more data you can send and receive in any given second. And data, whether encoding streams of video or customers' orders, are the raison d'etre of the Internet.
Mr. Reid, who heads a team of network engineers at Digital, is realizing his vision in Palo Alto, where a combination of public and private investment has created the highest-capacity switching point on the Internet. Last spring, the City of Palo Alto completed construction of a $2 million, 15-mile-long fiber optic ring that snakes beneath these suburban streets and culminates in Digital's new Internet Exchange, which the company bills as the world's biggest on-ramp to the Internet.
The combination is proving to be a powerful magnet for bandwidth-starved companies, from start-ups like WebTV Networks and E*Trade Group to established businesses like the venture capital firm Accel Partners. In the process, it is transforming this city into the nation's premier Internet address.
"It's like being right on top of the nexus of five major railroads," said Steven Pearlman, chief executive of WebTV, the Internet television start-up that was acquired earlier this year by the Microsoft Corporation.
As a result, along University Avenue, Silicon Valley's version of Rodeo Drive and the commercial street that connects the city to nearby Stanford University, chic restaurants, furniture and bookstores and latte and burrito stands are bustling with engineers, programmers, venture capitalists and hackers drawn here by the chance to grab a chunk of bandwidth in the land rush of the information age.
At the same time, the rapid growth of Internet commerce is supercharging the economy of Silicon Valley. Technology companies like Dell Computer and Cisco Systems -- each of which expects to sell more than $1 billion of hardware on the World Wide Web in the next year -- are being joined in the rush to electronic commerce by old-line companies like General Motors, which has begun selling cars and trucks on line.
And while Dell and G.M. are not situated in Silicon Valley, it is widely believed that the surge in on-line commerce worldwide increases the economic advantage for this region. Already more than 50 percent of all worldwide traffic on the Internet passes through Northern California.
"Silicon Valley's initial regional advantage is being reinforced through early and massive leading-edge investments in technological infrastructure," said Annalee Saxenian, a University of California at Berkeley professor in the department of city and regional planning. "Through this process, Silicon Valley will compound its advantage relative to competing regions, just as the manufacturing belt did in the late 19th and early 20th centuries."
Palo Alto's investment in a fiber optic infrastructure capable of connecting to Digital's Internet Exchange at blinding speed is attracting companies like Accel Partners, which relocated here in November from San Francisco, leasing a three-story building on University Avenue. Accel's executives said that the availability of high-speed Internet connections was a crucial factor in their decision to move.
"Easy access to state-of-the-art video and data played a central role in how we thought about building our new headquarters," said Jim Breyer, an Accel partner.
Palo Alto's fiber-optic data and voice network comes within one mile of every home and business in the city. It will permit residents, businesses and organizations to link to the global computer network at speeds that will dwarf even today's fastest cable modems.
It will also offer far greater speeds than the fastest digital connections being planned by telephone companies. Symbolically, the ring intersects the Internet in the basement of the building that was once the local telephone company's switching office, just half a block off University Avenue, where Mr. Reid's team installed the world's most powerful private Internet exchange point.
But telephone companies are also players in Digital's exchange: four currently supply a total of 14.9 gigabits a second of data capacity -- the equivalent of 193,500 simultaneous voice telephone calls. What is more, Digital's hub has enormous additional capacity: it can be expanded to support the equivalent of 87 million simultaneous calls.
The building, which was 100 percent occupied in July, just 10 months after opening, now houses the equipment for 35 Internet service providers, including @Home, WebTV Networks, Deutsche Telekom North America, Hongkong Telecom, Internet Initiative Japan and UUNET Technologies. It is also connected to the world's longest OC-3 fiber network link to Asia, a beachhead for Japanese corporations that want to conduct Internet business in the United States. (An OC-3 cable carries 155.5 million bits a second, the equivalent of about 2,016 simultaneous phone calls.)
A primary attraction of this kind of exchange point is that it permits companies conducting sales over the Internet to put their Web servers at the spot where Internet data flows most swiftly, making them easily accessible to millions of customers. (Deutsche Telecom, the German telecommunications giant, also chose this location for its Internet services to experiment with aspects of electronic commerce precluded by heavy regulation in Europe.)
Just as important, the Digital Exchange serves as a neutral meeting ground for the world's largest fiber optic communications companies.
The first Internet exchange points, known as Network Access Points, or Naps, were established in the early 1990's, when the National Science Foundation set out to privatize the Internet. Then, in 1995, a growing traffic jam in Internet data led to the idea of a private exchange service that would bypass much of the congestion at the original Naps.
To be sure, many of the nation's cities and private telecommunications companies are also racing to deploy fiber optic networks. In California, other ambitious fiber optic infrastructure projects are under way in Los Angeles, San Diego and Anaheim. On the East Coast, the City of Winston-Salem, N.C. will complete its own fiber network in January.
But Palo Alto, Mr. Reid said, offers a unique synergy of culture, business and technology. "If you're trying to launch a new business model, you have to do what the padres did," Mr. Reid said, alluding to the Spanish missions that inspired Digital's exchange. "This is the beginning of the infrastructure of the economy of the new millennium."
There is a tremendous commercial advantage to be gained by placing the most popular Internet services directly at the peak of the bandwidth pyramid, Mr. Reid says, since it cuts out the need to push data "upstream" to the exchange.
"Everyone wins because there is half as much traffic on the Internet," he said.
To stress-test the hub's capacity and robustness, Mr. Reid's team using Digital's popular Alta Vista search engine as an "attractive nuisance." Unarguably the most powerful search engine on the Internet, Alta Vista handles 25 million queries a day and delivers 62 million pages to users. Despite those levels of traffic -- about 15 times the traffic for the most popular news and entertainment sites on the Web -- Alta Vista has remained the fastest and most robust search engine on the Net.
But access to the Internet is not the only need that businesses have for bandwidth. High-speed intranets and local area networks also allow companies to unite workers at numerous remote sites into a single "virtual office."
Early on, Mr. Reid also approached the City of Palo Alto, asking that Digital be permitted to run fiber optic cables through city conduits to interlink its nine research laboratories in the downtown area into a single virtual office building. That model helped attract WebTV, which, since it was founded here two and a half years ago, has rapidly spread to 10 office sites in downtown Palo Alto.
The virtual office model is now viewed by economists and Silicon Valley executives as the corporate archetype of the new information economy inspired by Internet commerce.
Harry Saal, chairman of Network General, a Silicon Valley computer networking company, said, "Fiber optic networks have meant that we are able to create distributed network-like businesses without resorting to the high-rise model."
While employment of the new fiber optic infrastructure here has so far been all business, that may change soon.
"Palo Alto is undergoing a transition to an information-based economy," said Van Heimke, the city's telecommunication manager. "The early market is the commercial one, but there will be school and residential markets as well."
About 80 percent of the city's homes have personal computers, and according to PA-COMNET, a local organization pushing for higher speed Internet access for the community, Palo Alto already has the highest per-capita Internet use in the world.
On Dec. 1, Mr. Heimke's department proposed to the City Council that the city enter into negotiations with companies that are developing advanced fiber-optic consumer-oriented Internet technology with the goal of bringing an ultra-high-speed Internet connection to every business and residential address in the city. The proposal will be taken up this week.
The city government has its own reasons for wanting to wire the entire city. It is already moving some of its bureaucratic procedures, like filing building permits, to the Internet, and officials say they expect that this is only the first step.
"We set out to be the first city on the Net," said Liz Kniss, a City Council member and former mayor of Palo Alto. She also predicted that the arrival of residential fiber optic networks would fundamentally alter community life.
"The impact of the Internet has already become so apparent," she said. "The other day I was looking for a local soccer schedule. It's midnight, and who are you going to call?"

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about a new fiber optic network in Palo Alto, Calif., misstated the age of California's historic Spanish missions, which were cited by a Palo Alto scientist as inspirations for his vision of the network. Most missions were built in the 18th century, not the 16th.

SECTION: Section G; Page 12; Column 1; Giving 

LENGTH: 1714 words

HEADLINE: Corporations Adopt a Different Attitude: Show Us the Value

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
AVON PRODUCTS used to support causes that alleviated human suffering. Today, it gives only to programs that relate specifically to women, its primary customers. So March of Dimes and lung cancer associations are out; scholarships for women, and breast and ovarian cancer groups are in. "Our giving has to be in line with our vision for the business," said Marcia L. Worthing, the senior vice president for human resources.
AT&T, which no longer makes phone equipment, has stopped financing charities in foreign countries where it had manufacturing plants. It is funneling the money to Internet-related education programs in California, Illinois and the handful of other states where it has introduced local phone service. "We're investing in communities and causes that represent our primary markets," said Timothy J. McClimon, the executive director of the AT&T Foundation. 
 Say goodbye to the days when corporations blithely wrote checks to many worthy causes -- or to all groups that counted the chairman's spouse on its board. Say hello instead to the new world of "strategic giving," the fancy phrase that corporate-giving gurus use to describe how every dollar or product they give must mesh with the company's markets or employees.
"Corporate philanthropy has always brushed up against marketing, public relations, government relations and human resource management," said Craig Smith, a senior fellow at the Conference Board in New York, which researches corporate trends. "But now companies are far more explicit about using it as a subtle means of manipulation."
Most corporate chiefs would bridle at Mr. Smith's wording, but few would disagree with his premise. "The chief executives are all asking, What kind of value are we getting for our investment?" said Curt Weeden, the vice president of corporate contributions at Johnson & Johnson. Paul M. Ostergard, the head of the Citicorp Foundation, added, "It's a lot easier to persuade top management to increase philanthropic giving when they're certain it addresses the right priorities."
In a sense, the trend is a logical extension of the strategic changes that have swept corporate America in the 90's. One by one, companies have dispensed with sentimentality and shed longtime products and services that no longer provided the best return on investment. Corning no longer makes Corningware; Monsanto has moved out of basic chemicals; Westinghouse is exiting everything but radio and television.
Inevitably, charities have fallen prey to the same paring knife. The Metropolitan Opera or the American Cancer Society or the local Little League club might have been on the giving list for decades. But if the cause does not somehow support the core business, it is out.
Companies have not used strategic giving as a flimsy excuse to get stingy, though. According to the Conference Board, American companies and their foundations donated $8.5 billion in cash and products last year, up from $7.9 billion in 1995. Although a growing number of those dollars are leaving the country as companies try to shore up their images overseas, that still leaves ample sums for American causes.
Chief executives are also proving to have deep pockets. Bill Gates, for example, has earmarked $200 million of his personal money to connect libraries to the Internet. And Ted Turner, the founder of CNN and Time Warner's vice-chairman, has pledged a total of $1 billion to the United Nations.
A growing number of companies match any employee's charitable donation, whether or not the charity is on the strategic list. Many companies also offer grants to causes at which employees -- or, better still, teams of employees -- volunteer.
Take the American Express Foundation. It will give away $23.2 million this year, mostly to historic preservation, arts and education programs that tie in with its financial services or travel and tourism businesses. Yet over the last three years, it has given almost $850,000 to diverse causes that include an organic garden project, a traveling mammography van and a cat rescue program. The unifying theme: American Express employees work as volunteers with the groups sponsoring those programs, and the company sees the program as yet another employee benefit.
"We can't give to everything that comes over the transom," said Mary Beth Salerno, the foundation's president, "but we do want to give to causes that are important to our employees."
But few corporations are as benevolent as their numbers indicate. An increasing chunk of corporate contributions are in the form of products or services, which companies can value at their retail prices but manufacture for far less. Last year's tax-law changes made the economics of that approach even more compelling: companies donating $1 in cash can write off $1; by contrast, companies donating a product that costs $1 to make but sells for $3 can write off $2 -- the cost plus half the difference between the cost and the fair-market value.
To further sweeten the deal, donated products act as a showcase. When Johnson & Johnson sends drugs to a disaster area, more doctors grow familiar with those products. When Avon donates cosmetics to a homeless shelter, the products -- and the company's largess -- are displayed to social workers, family members, doctors and others with more buying power than the immediate recipients.
"We are putting products into the community," Ms. Worthing said. Products accounted for about $6 million of Avon's $18.6 million in contributions last year, she added.
FEW companies are contrite about the tilt toward products. Most insist -- and many nonprofit groups agree -- that the charities would have to buy the products anyway and couldn't care less about how the companies value them on their books.
"We give in ways that help the recipients the most," said Barbara Dingfield, the director of community affairs for Microsoft. Although cash accounted for only about $11.1 million of Microsoft's $73.2 million in contributions last year, Ms. Dingfield noted that the company had given scholarships to women and members of minorities who want to study computer science and given cash grants to libraries nationwide as well as to community programs in the Puget Sound region in Washington, where Microsoft has its headquarters.
Moreover, corporations say that if they are to be castigated for overinflating the dollar value of their gifts, they should also be praised for not quantifying the countless hours of employee time they donate.
"By itself, checkbook philanthropy is going to be ineffective in getting disadvantaged kids on a college-bound track," said Mr. Ostergard of Citibank, whose employees and retirees to mentor children and teach classes in schools that Citibank supports with cash.
General Electric also sends employees and retirees into schools as mentors and tutors and into community groups as team leaders and organizers. It recently committed one million employee-hours to America's Promise, a White House-sponsored program to help troubled children. And it has started a program to send administrators of nonprofit groups through classes in management techniques led by G.E. managers. The aim is to make sure nonprofits get the maximum bang for G.E.'s donated buck. (That's the carrot. The stick is that G.E. cuts off any charity that cannot show that it is putting its money to good use.)
"We are leveraging our grants and gifts of product through our people," said Jane L. Polin, the program manager of the General Electric Fund, which dispenses about $30 million a year.
Add to that "and through the press." Corporations are becoming quite adept at pushing news of their generosity into the papers and onto the airwaves.
"We get a lot of exposure for our work, and that is not accidental," said Mr. McClimon of AT&T. "We write press releases, advertise events and spend a lot of time making sure the publicity machines at the nonprofit organizations are rolling along."
If there is one overarching force driving philanthropic triage at corporations today, it is the chance for good exposure to an important constituency. American Express is helping train welfare recipients for jobs at a Pennsylvania mall. Why? "The retail industry is a very important customer of ours," Ms. Salerno said.
The giving landscape abounds with such examples. Johnson & Johnson, which will give away $52 million in cash and $70 million in products this year, will direct most of the money to hospital-related causes, like medical research and management education for nurses and administrators. But it will also give a large sum to Head Start, which helps disadvantaged youngsters prepare for elementary school.
The link? Head Start has a health-care component, and "our affiliation gives us tremendous good will with doctors and dentists and in Washington," Mr. Weeden said.
Similarly, 80 percent of the $35 million that the Citicorp Foundation will give away this year will go to community development and education programs, particularly those that give lower-income people upward mobility by providing things like loans and schooling. But Citicorp will still give sizable sums to the arts -- including high-profile opera and concert companies that already have wealthy patrons. "That kind of support is pretty important to our private banking customers," Mr. Ostergard said.
Indeed, at some companies the new strategic focus has brought more, not fewer, causes under the philanthropic roof.
BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB, a pharmaceutical and personal-care product company, had for decades directed its donations almost exclusively to medical research. Three years ago, at the behest of a new chief executive, the company's foundation broadened its concept of strategic giving. Now it also gives to women's health- education programs -- a tie-in with its Clairol line of women's products as well as its drug lines -- and to science education programs that might interest children in pursuing research or medical careers.
"We try to identify issues that have an impact on all our divisions," said John L. Damonti, the president of the foundation, which gave out $22 million last year. "We want people to look at our grants and understand what our company is all about."

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Giving

HEADLINE: Why Do We Donate? It's Personal

BYLINE: By SUSAN JACOBY; Susan Jacoby, a writer in New York, is finishing a book about four generations of her family.

 BODY:
Give all thou canst;
high Heaven rejects the lore
Of nicely calculated less or more.
 -- William Wordsworth
WOULDN'T it be pretty to think so? Of course, the calculating begins as soon as a child is old enough to have money of her own. When I was 7, my parents said I must reserve a portion of my weekly allowance for the collection plate at Sunday Mass. But the amount was to remain a secret between God and me. The tabernacles and chalices were made of gold and silver, I reasoned, so God didn't need more than five cents on the dollar. 
 Lest anyone think I was a stingy, selfish child, I want to make one thing clear: I gave lots of money to the March of Dimes because my best friend in second grade had a brother in an iron lung. Every time I saw a canister I would put in a dime or a quarter, not the measly nickel (or penny, if I had incurred heavy expenses that week) I customarily gave in church.
All giving is personal. With the possible exception of sex, no activity offers a clearer reflection of individual affinities, values and neuroses, at age 7 or 70. So it is only fitting that individual, living Americans -- not corporations, not bequests -- account for nearly 80 percent of the whopping amount of money ($150.7 billion in 1996) donated for philanthropic purposes each year.
While patterns of giving and not giving reflect individual preferences, they also illuminate the larger economic pressures shaping the lives of Americans in the mid-90's. Total giving is up, for example, mainly because the bull market has made the richest 20 percent of Americans richer and more willing to dig into their stock portfolios for large gifts. But the percentage of people who give anything to charity has shrunk.
Competition for philanthropic dollars, reflected in mailboxes bulging with fund-raising appeals, has intensified as more nonprofit institutions, under pressure to fill the gap created by government cuts for everything from the arts to food stamps, vie for charitable contributions from fewer donors. Administrators of nonprofits do not even want to think about what could happen if recent stock market tremors scare the wealthy out of the "giving mode," as it is known in Philanthrospeak, the professional lexicon of fund-raisers.
Between 1993 and 1996, while the average donation from contributing households rose to $1,017 from $880, 3.8 million homes vanished from the givers' ranks. A report by Independent Sector, a Washington-based organization that charts long-term philanthropy trends, found in 1995, the last year in which data are available, that more than 30 percent of American households contributed absolutely nothing to nonprofit endeavors. "There's a real danger if giving comes to be perceived as a hobby for the elite rather than the responsibility of everyone," says Virginia A. Hodgkinson, a research professor of public policy at Georgetown University.
Paul Clolery, the editor in chief of The Nonprofit Times, agrees, noting that "while the rich can afford to give more per capita, the middle class has been the backbone of American philanthropy in this century."
Nonetheless, headlines focus on blockbuster gifts from "major donors" (Philanthrospeak again), like the flamboyant Ted Turner. His pledge of $1 billion for United Nations social programs over the next 10 years stands out even among the super-rich. And should the gift work out to less (which it could if the value of the promised Time Warner stock falls), well, never let it be said that cold-hearted calculations outweighed the attention-getting value of the word "billion."
When reporters asked Mr. Turner why he gave to charity, he replied flippantly, "Well, it's 'Just say yes.' " But he then acknowledged the more complicated personal dynamic involved in all charitable contributions. "I've been learning how to give," he admitted. "It's something you have to keep working on because people like money the way they do their homes and their dogs."
With more nonprofits chasing dollars from fewer donors to meet greater needs, it is not surprising that a growing number of academic researchers -- call them "philanthroshrinks" -- are trying to figure out what impels givers to part with their money. What, for example, motivated 89-year-old Oseola McCarty to take $150,000 -- her life savings as a laundrywoman -- and establish a scholarship fund for black students at the University of Southern Mississippi in Hattiesburg, her hometown?
"A lot of people forget the obvious: that unlike taxation, giving is voluntary," says Paul G. Schervish, the director of Boston College's Social Welfare Research Institute.
Thomas B. Murphy, a Michigan philanthropist who sponsors research on giving in the hope of fostering charitable involvement among the wealthy, puts it this way: "Most human beings need to feel that they, their families and their businesses are secure before they're going to be truly comfortable about giving. Only then are they able to look at charitable involvement not as a sacrifice, but as something that adds to their own happiness."
In spite of (or perhaps because of) a tradition of philanthropy unequaled in most other nations, Americans are busybodies when it comes to charity. In interviews for this article, I was astonished at the range of unsolicited aspersions concerning the giving habits of others. Some kindly souls sniffed at "little old ladies who send dollar bills through the mail," while others disapproved "on principle" (the precise nature of the principle wasn't clear) of "sentimentalists" who give to street beggars.
Millionaires who want their names on buildings are criticized by millionaires who consider such behavior tacky. One patron of the arts expressed pity for those foolish enough to give money to such ill-defined "philanthropic products" as drug rehabilitation programs and counseling for troubled families. "They can't really believe their money is doing any good," he sniped.
Then there is the plaintive chorus of the unchosen. Mr. Turner's gift irked certain Atlanta business executives who felt that CNN's hometown deserved more largess. Finally, gifts that are targeted for specific social or political causes draw heavy fire from those who disagree with the donor's views.
While the quirky nature of individual giving fuels second-guessing, there is little evidence that the rich differ substantially from the middle class in charitable motivations.
It may seem comically obvious to point out that giving makes people feel good, but the underlying and less obvious reality is that the feel-good effect involves both selfish and altruistic motives. People give because they are asked to by their peers, whether those peers turn up on a Forbes list, at a P.T.A. meeting or in church. They give out of compassion for the less fortunate and a sense of responsibility to society; as payback for their own good luck; as penance for their sins, even out of a primitive desire to propitiate the gods.
Perhaps the most powerful influence is the intensity of the giver's identification with a cause or a group of people in need.
 
Personal Connection
When We Think It Could Be Me
I still remember the sick feeling in my stomach when my childhood friend told me that his brother had come down with polio after swimming in Lake Michigan. I swam in the lake, too. After that conversation, I simply could not pass up March of Dimes canisters.
"This is my town, that could be my grandmother" is how Marcia Stein, the executive director of Citymeals-on-Wheels in New York, describes the potency of such connections. Citymeals, which receives more than 90 percent of its support from 40,000 donors, is highly visible in that city because New Yorkers -- unlike most other Americans, who depend on cars for transportation -- see the frail elderly making their way around town. And the help delivered, Ms. Stein noted, is "something people can see and touch."
Antoinette Pridmore, a retired high-school physics teacher living in the Bronx, typifies the brand of giver who strongly identifies with the recipients of her annual donations. Ms. Pridmore, managing on a fixed income at age 90, is also the sort of giver who tends to be ignored by fund-raisers pursuing the big score. Her nicely calculated total is $240 a year -- all she feels she can spare.
"I guess I qualify as one of those old ladies who puts dollar bills in envelopes," she says with a laugh, her precise diction recalling her past as a teacher in a more demanding era of public school education.
Although her own sight and hearing remain keen enough for Ms. Pridmore to drive to the grocery store, she reserves $5 a month for Citymeals because she knows that many homebound elderly in her neighborhood rely on the hot food the organization delivers each day. She allots the same sum for Calvary Hospital nearby, known for its humane care of terminal patients, because her sister died of cancer there.
Like Mr. Turner, Ms. Pridmore underscores another truth about charitable giving: personal does not necessarily mean local. She also gives $5 a month to a foundation that is dedicated to preserving the delicate ecology of the Galapagos Islands, which she visited nearly 25 years ago.
"At my age, giving is a way of staying connected to the world," she says. "I would like to be able to give more, but everything I do give is very meaningful to me."
While all giving may be voluntary in theory, peer pressure exerts a huge influence in practice. Consider the fact that Americans give first (and often last) to their churches. Although religious giving has dropped slightly in recent years, churches and synagogues receive nearly half of all charitable donations -- $69.44 billion in 1996.
Education, the second most popular charitable choice ($18.81 billion), depends upon another obvious category of membership: alumni.
The importance of organization affiliation was underlined in the Independent Sector poll, which found that those who belonged to any group were more than twice as likely to give to charity as those who did not. The association between membership and volunteering was stronger: members were nearly three times as likely as nonmembers to devote time to charitable projects.
Of course, both peer pressure and belief in an institution play a role when donors give generously. Yes, you'll be forced to join a synagogue if you want your son to have a proper bar mitzvah, but you would not want your son to become bar mitzvah unless you wished to support Jewish observance.
The combination of motives for giving, and the connections that influence donors large and small, were described by the entrepreneur Michael R. Bloomberg in the September issue of his magazine Bloomberg Personal.
"I didn't give because I expected to get anything back," Mr. Bloomberg wrote in straight-faced fashion, referring to a $55 million donation to his alma mater, the Johns Hopkins University. "I gave because it's a great school and I felt I owed them."
He then confessed cheerfully that the donation had generated "great publicity for my company and the university, yielding rewards in terms of new business and accelerated fund gathering (I was also chairman of the Johns Hopkins capital campaign) that I couldn't have anticipated."
In fact, Mr. Bloomberg could have easily anticipated that his contribution would attract others. "There's a herd instinct in fund-raising," he acknowledged in an interview. "When people see what others have given, they want to match it."
Even without social competitiveness, personal example is a powerful force. Two years ago, for example, Ms. McCarty made her donation to the University of Southern Mississippi. Her gift, a singular act of generosity and selflessness, was soon followed by an extraordinary outpouring of financial support for the institution not only from local business executives but from across the country, and the original endowment quadrupled in just two years.
The stimulation of free-floating guilt simply isn't as effective a fund-raising tactic as either social pressure or personal example (though someone must be responding to the PBS telethons or stations wouldn't broadcast them). In the Independent Sector poll, a request from an acquaintance was rated the most likely to succeed. Mail and telephone solicitations and advertisements in newspapers and magazines were far down the list. (News articles, however, were considered effective.) Television commercials were the least persuasive appeals.
 
Underlying Optimism
Taking Action For a Better World
Optimism may be one of the most underrated emotional components of giving. "Givers are not fatalistic, pessimistic or passive people," says Ervin Staub, a psychology professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst who has conducted extensive research on charitable motivations. "They see a problem, and their response is to figure out a way to fix it."
Mr. Murphy, for example, is a trustee for Volunteers in Prevention, a Michigan project that provides adult mentors to selected juvenile and first-time offenders instead of throwing them into the probation system. The program has cut recidivism among its clients 90 percent and costs only $50 per capita each year because it is operated mainly by volunteers.
"When you see that people who were reached through your efforts are building new lives," Mr. Murphy says, "it makes you want to give more of yourself and your time."
Barbara McKillip, who had no financial resources when she started a foundation to supply children's books to neglected rural communities, embodies the same personal commitment. Ms. McKillip, who grew up in a small Missouri town, was a librarian at a community college in Eugene, Ore., when, appalled by state cuts in library financing, she started the Libri Foundation.
"Actually, my dad is an accountant and it was his idea," she explains. "I was going on and on one day about how if I won the Oregon lottery, I would buy books for kids who didn't have any access to them. My dad said I didn't need the lottery, that I could set up a foundation and see if other people wanted to help. I thought, Why not?"
In the last five years, the foundation, run by Ms. McKillip out of her living room in Eugene, has distributed $250,000 in books to 245 libraries from Alaska to Iowa. Ms. McKillip seeks out tiny communities willing to raise money of their own and matches their donations 2 to 1.
Mary Weiss, the president of a women's club in a retirement community in Walnut Creek, Calif., is the kind of committed small donor whom Ms. McKillip has attracted. The Walnut Creek women raised $850 and recently traveled to the town of Courtland to see the new books their money had purchased and to see the children, mostly sons and daughters of migrant workers, who use the library.
"Courtland is part of the Sacramento library system, which has so little money that it cut the town off altogether," Ms. Weiss says indignantly. "I thought, Well, as citizens it's important for us to do something even if the government isn't meeting its responsibility."
Linda Barbanel, a New York psychotherapist who specializes in the psychology of money, says external forces, like government cutbacks, play a minor role in a giver's behavior. "The real truth is that people who want to give will find a way to give something, regardless of what's going on in society or even in their own financial lives," Ms. Barbanel says, "and those who hate to part with money will find reasons to hang on to every dime."

HEADLINE: A Hands-On Generation Transforms the Landscape of Philanthropy

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
PAUL TUDOR JONES 2d, 43, came to New York in 1978 with $1,700 and a determination to make it big in the commodities markets; he did. Peggy Dulany, 50, who does not use her surname, Rockefeller, always had wealth, but she also had profound convictions about the debilitating effects of poverty, injustice and racial hatred.
Ron W. Burkle, 45, bagged groceries after school in California when he was a boy, but now owns a supermarket empire built with the proceeds of his leveraged-buyout business. In Colorado, Tim Gill, also 45, became one of two openly gay millionaires on the Forbes list of the 400 wealthiest Americans through Quark Inc., the desktop publishing software company he founded in 1981. 
 These intensely private people are giving away millions of their own money. They are also part of a new generation of givers transforming philanthropy in what may be the world's most philanthropic nation.
More hands-on and businesslike in their approach, these boomer philanthropists -- all in their 40's or early 50's -- have a different attitude than many of their elders. Harnessing that attitude to their inherited or newly made millions, or billions in some cases, they have already decided that they must be personally involved in creating more effective charities and communities that will lead to a better nation and world.
In the process, they are expanding what constitutes philanthropy by broadening the targets of their giving to include, for instance, gay rights. And because they already have money, many scholars, policy makers and fund-raisers are looking to them for clues as to how their peers will give when the much heralded transfer of wealth -- some $2 trillion in assets -- occurs as America's middle-aged population inherits it from their parents.
The United States has seen transformations in philanthropy before. At the turn of the century, America entered what many regard as a golden era of giving when New York City became home to banking, railroad and oil barons like Morgan, Vanderbilt and Rockefeller, who used their money to start the foundations and cultural institutions that still bear their names and reflect their influence.
In the Midwest a generation later, the Ford and Chrysler fortunes ushered in a second philanthropy boom. Now a strong economy and stock market (hiccups and all) have increased the nation's wealth -- by $1.4 trillion in the last year alone -- and spawned a new cluster of rich and super-rich.
While most of these younger philanthropists engage in traditional giving -- to their colleges, churches or synagogues and hometown cultural institutions -- students of philanthropy have already noticed generational differences. "Younger generations are widening their circle of giving," said Ann Castle, who helps assemble the lists of the most charitable Americans for Slate, the on-line magazine.
Christopher Mogil, 41, who with his wife, Ann Slepian, also 41, started the Impact Project, a Boston nonprofit organization that helps philanthropists help one another, said that younger givers tend to have a very participatory style. "They want to be involved, not just to write checks," said Mr. Mogil. A result: regular visits to projects they have financed, not standard practice in most family foundations, are very much in vogue.
So is collaborative giving, in which donors support one another's causes, and so are forums where donors can trade information about worthy causes and discuss philanthropic successes and failures.
Mr. Mogil has a trove of tales. Reared in New York, he was working in 1980 for a community development group in Philadelphia when he inherited about half a million dollars from his mother's family. "I had no idea initially how to handle that," he said.
Eventually, he gave away about half of his inheritance and used the rest to create the Impact Project to help young donors chart their own courses. The project sponsors publications, counseling and workshops through which Mr. Mogil and Ms. Slepian have shared their expertise.
Impact's quarterly publication, More Than Money, published with a partner in Eugene, Ore., has 1,000 subscribers, half of whom each have a net worth exceeding a million dollars. Mr. Mogil said that he finances much of the project's $195,000 budget, which will grow to $270,000 next year, "because I don't want to fund-raise."
AMONG baby boomers, Mr. Mogil said, those with inherited wealth tend to be more cautious in their giving than the self-made rich. He explained that beneficiaries of inherited wealth, like lottery winners, "are often slow to ask what their wealth means, how it affects their personal lives and relationships and how they can contribute to the world." But self-made philanthropists "are used to saying, Here's what I want and here's how I can make it happen."
A prime example is Mr. Jones, the Memphis-born commodities broker. Soon after he earned his first million, he said in a recent interview, he was determined to "give back" to the city that had made his fortune possible. "I was and am a walking, talking poster child for New York and its infinite possibilities," he said.
Helping finance college scholarships for disadvantaged high-school students, he said, he quickly realized that the youngsters needed more than money and mentoring to get to college. "Hungry kids can't focus," Mr. Jones said. "And battered teen-agers can't either."
And so in 1988 the Robin Hood Foundation, self-declared "guerrilla philanthropy," was born. Using $3 million of Mr. Jones's own money, along with substantial gifts from two Wall Street colleagues who were also budding givers, the foundation tries to break poverty's stranglehold in New York through innovative projects. Robin Hood, with a $20 million endowment, is among the largest backers, for one, of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, which is trying to rejuvenate eight city blocks in Harlem.
What Mr. Jones calls a "social venture approach" to philanthropy, in which donors seek a real return on philanthropic investments, is common among younger givers, said Craig Smith, a philanthropy expert at the Conference Board, a New York-based business research institute. "The new generation is bringing the perspective of entrepreneurship into the nonprofit world," Mr. Smith said. "Many no longer accept the conventional wisdom that nonprofits are not about competition. They're far more likely to think about how a nonprofit can work as efficiently as their business."
Ms. Dulany agrees. The daughter of David Rockefeller, she recalled that philanthropy was a constant topic of conversation in her home. Her way with it, however, was influenced primarily by the impoverished family in Brazil with whom she lived when she was 19. "That shaped my view that we must look at issues globally, that our greatest allies in solving problems of poverty are those confronted with poverty," she said, "and that we need not just to throw money at the poor but devote our own time, money and energy to working with them and involving them in the solutions."
THE Synergos Institute, the New York-based nonprofit group Ms. Dulany founded, puts that philosophy into practice by mobilizing public and private resources, including the United Nations, to reduce global poverty and inequity. It also tries to strengthen the ability of poor communities to solve their own problems. Bruce Schearer, the institute's chief executive officer, said that with only a $2 million annual budget, Synergos has helped groups in Ecuador, Mexico, Mozambique and Zimbabwe establish foundations to raise money for their projects.
"It's important not only to give money to feed hungry people, but also to create programs to enable people to find jobs and become entrepreneurs and feed themselves," said Ms. Dulany, who is also a board member, among others, of the African-American Institute.
In line with that philosophy, Mr. Burkle in Los Angeles is generous not only with his money but his time. He recently contributed $15 million to help build the new Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, but as chairman of D.A.R.E., an antidrug group, he has educated youngsters about the dangers of drugs and eased the hostility between some minority youths and local police.
Mr. Gill was already dabbling in philanthropy when Colorado voters approved Amendment 2, which prevented municipalities and the state from passing statutes to protect homosexuals from discrimination. "Tim realized that he had to help educate people about gay and lesbian issues," said Katherine Pease, who heads the Gill Foundation, begun in 1994 to do just that.
Next year, the foundation's budget will provide for $3.4 million in grants to help change public attitudes toward gay Americans and protect their rights. This year, the group made a $100,000 contribution to the American Red Cross to help flood victims in Fort Collins, Colo.
While that might seem like tame philanthropy and not too cutting edge, Ms. Pease said it was innovative nonetheless. "By giving to things that advance the community's interests," she explained, "we're trying to persuade people that before we're gay men or lesbians, we are human beings."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Where Image Prevails, Talk About Race Turns Bland

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman 

 BODY:
Who could fault the outpouring of virtue from President Clinton's town hall on race last week? It was a lesson in gentility for afternoon television, a show without raunch or rant, insults or inanities, crackpotism or kookery. One wanted to like it. But when it comes to race, television has moved much beyond the sound bites that filled those two hours of C-Span.
One can imagine a time when television, if there had been television, would have been important for this sort of display, say if in the 1930's a national figure like Eleanor Roosevelt had led an all-American tolerance class. That could have improved benighted attitudes toward minorities. But with the help of television itself, the nation is, happily, well beyond such pleas and admonitions. 
 With Bill Clinton himself playing chief talker for what he called "all this talking stuff," the selected audience was on its best behavior. Clean-cut students delivered mild complaints (the young "biracial" man who is annoyed at having his small checks questioned by his bank) and confessions (the white man who likes Bill Cosby on the tube but becomes uneasy at encountering a certain order of black man in person). An Hispanic woman and an Asian-American man reminded the audience that they had grievances, too. A black-white team of ministers advertised their buddyship in a sort of vaudeville duet. Others were ready with scripted mini-sermons in behalf of mutual understanding, and the pleasure of diversity was on many lips.
But what was it all about? Beyond sending the performers home feeling better, the mission was fuzzy.
We have long since heard them all before, all the complaints and the confessions, the tales of indignities and effusions of guilt. All on television. If television talk could do the job of eradicating vestiges of racism, it would by now have been done. The shows may be vulgar, but when race rears its head, the proprieties are strict: hatred is out. And in the image stakes, television has been considerably in advance of the rest of the nation. The on-screen world is wondrously integrated, from stars to anchors, pretend cops to pretend perps, wholesome families to sitcom clucks.
The President must know that. He must know that anyone who has not yet been brushed by the wings of tolerance, sensitivity, some semblance of good will is probably beyond reach. So in search of something more tangible than further preachments, he proclaims that his televised national conversation (in which no one does much conversing) is meant to produce specific ways of addressing what his predecessor would surely call the race thing. And the Presidential project, which has given little hint of getting anywhere since it started six months ago, turns up as an uplift road show.
Training a camera on several dozen likable folks for a couple of hours in hopes of devising means of dealing with hard problems like rotten schools, unemployment, poverty, crime, family disarray and the other ills that television keeps telling us are embroiled with race is like sending a squad of cheerleaders onto the field and expecting it to score touchdowns.
It may only be a measure of our frustration and scarcity of ideas that we have entered a time of prayerful exhortation to go forth and do better, be it about race or fatherhood or other bafflements. Sure, a televised meeting or march can help promote a cause once it is defined, but it is not much good at formulating or working out any sort of plan for the tangle of matters that have come to define the problem of race. Whatever the President expects from his race initiative, he is not likely to find it via the tube. That's not where serious thinking or serious politicking gets done.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For Bank Mergers, Big Is Not Always Better

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
There is no question that with about $590 billion in assets the bank to be created through the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation will be breathtaking in its size. But does that matter?
As banks in the United States have discovered -- despite the merger boom of the last few years -- size alone does not assure success. Performance is the name of the game, and bigness sometimes can present more problems than it solves. 
 "There are certain instances where being large is helpful for a bank, in areas like risk management, access to capital, cost effective deployment of specialized skills and negotiating," Diane Glossman, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said. "But size alone isn't an end in itself. Banks here have found it more important to have leading market share in a variety of businesses rather than merely having a lot of assets."
American banks, swamped in bad loans just a decade ago, were hardly in a position to offer lessons to their global competitors, but today many of these same banks are considered strategic models by foreign banks.
Citicorp, the second-largest United States bank, long ago stopped emphasizing asset growth and instead focused on profitability -- a fact not lost on the Swiss merger candidates, which said yesterday that they hoped the new bank would achieve a return on equity of 15 percent to 20 percent.
Moreover, despite their size, such large United States banks as the Chase Manhattan Corporation and J. P. Morgan & Company have been trying to fashion themselves as financial service emporiums that offer one-stop shopping to big corporate clients. This places less importance on asset size and more importance on a bank's ability to deliver a variety of client services, from loan syndications and equity underwriting to asset management and advice on mergers and acquisitions.
A merger between Union Bank and Swiss Bank does not guarantee that the new bank will be any more able to compete successfully in these businesses. Indeed, there are already plenty of examples of huge foreign banks that increasingly look like dinosaurs because of their lack of a competitive edge.
Japanese banks have routinely filled most slots on the top-10 lists of international banks of the last decade, their very size inspiring overwrought fears of a Japanese financial invasion. Yet these same banks have proved to be disastrously poor lenders and slow to innovate.
Even Sumitomo Bank Ltd., a behemoth once considered one of the most dynamic and smartest of Japanese banks, has been sideswiped by bad loans and lagging investments in new technology and products.
In Europe, Deutsche Bank A.G. traditionally wielded its mammoth asset base and top-notch credit rating with baronial disdain, accustomed to air-tight corporate relationships and little competition.
But, despite its position as the second-largest bank in the world -- pending the Swiss bank merger -- Deutsche has struggled in recent years with bad real estate loans, lax risk management practices and an inability to take on smaller American rivals in investment banking.
To be sure, size must always be reckoned with. Despite their many shortcomings, Japanese banks are still formidable competitors in such arenas as large-scale project finance. And some international banks, such as ABN Amro Holding N.V. of the Netherlands and HSBC Holdings P.L.C. of Britain and Hong Kong, are considered nimble operators in spite of their size.
But some analysts and academics are wary of the push for size just for size's sake. David Beim, a professor of finance at Columbia University, said the marriage of Union Bank and Swiss Bank created a goliath that might be too large for its own good.
"It now has no serious competition in Switzerland, and I worry about the European tendency to form national champions in certain industries because it removes the competitive pressure," he said. "It may allow them to become either complacent in their business practices or become so dominant in Switzerland that they have too much pricing power."
It is unlikely, however, that concerns about unfettered size will slow the consolidation wave that many bank advisers and analysts expect to sweep through Europe's financial markets in the next couple of years.
In some cases, there is a strong economic rationale for such mergers, particularly in countries such as Britain that have large -- but weak -- banks. And because financial services is a growth industry while traditional banking is not, banks will continue to feel pressure to offer as many products as possible; that too will push mergers along.
But as often as not, combinations will also be driven by the egos of bank executives. "There will be a few very large global banks when the dust settles, and if you're choosing not to grow you're choosing not to play in that stratosphere," said Dwight Crane, a finance professor at Harvard University. "That's a very hard thing to ignore for the managers of any bank."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Two forecasters predict spending on Madison Avenue should remain robust next year.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
TWO executives whose twice-yearly forecasts of advertising spending are closely followed along Madison Avenue see 1998 as a year of somewhat slower -- but still strong -- growth.
Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson U.S.A. in New York, and John Perriss, chairman and chief executive of Zenith Media Worldwide in London, offered their optimistic predictions at the opening session of the 25th annual Paine Webber Media Conference, which began yesterday morning at the McGraw-Hill Building in midtown Manhattan. It continues through Friday. 
 The outlooks of Mr. Coen and Mr. Perriss are important because their forecasts, which they issue every summer and fall, are considered barometers of marketer behavior. The predictions of Mr. Coen are typically more rosy than Mr. Perriss's, but the two executives echoed each other yesterday in declaring that ad spending is likely to remain robust, despite moderation of the American economic expansion and problems in the Asian-Pacific region.
"The momentum is very favorable for another good year for advertising in 1998," said Mr. Coen of McCann, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"It may be tough to make gains on top of the gains made in 1997," he added, "but on balance most of the evidence is that the media marketplace is holding up pretty well."
Mr. Perriss of Zenith, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., said: "Ad spending is slowing down in growth terms, but still growing. We think we've gone through the peak of the current economic cycle. But there are no horror shows anywhere."
One reason for the positive prognostications about next year is the stimulative effect of the Winter Olympics and election campaigns on demand for commercial time and advertising space. Another reason is continuing growth in competitive categories like automobiles, computers, cosmetics and toiletries, drugs and remedies, financial products, liquor and travel. A third reason is an increasing national presence among advertisers that had once been locally focused; among them are retail drug chains and direct response marketers.
Mr. Coen predicted that advertisers would spend a record $198.4 billion in the United States in 1998, an increase of 6.2 percent over the $186.8 billion that he now forecasts for 1997. The 1997 figure represents a 6.6 percent gain from the $175.2 billion that was spent in 1996.
In terms of advertising as a percentage of gross domestic product, $198.4 billion next year would come in just shy of 2.35 percent, which was the record set in 1987 and matched in 1988. That would compare with 2.31 percent for 1997 and mark the sixth consecutive gain since a bottom was touched at 2.12 percent in 1992.
Mr. Coen's figure for 1997 of $186.8 billion has been raised a tad from a forecast of $186 billion he made in June. Mr. Coen, who has been keeping track of media and marketing trends since 1948, changes his figures from one presentation to another, based on updated spending or economic data.
And the American ad spending forecast of $198.4 billion for next year has been increased slightly from an initial estimate of $196.5 billion that Mr. Coen offered in June.
Among the national media that Mr. Coen expects to draw more ad dollars in 1998 are cable television, radio, telephone directories and newspapers. Among the local media, he lists retail and classified newspaper advertising.
Internationally, Mr. Coen forecast ad spending of $236 billion for 1998, up 5 percent from a revised figure of $224.8 billion for 1997. Next year's figure is down from a prediction of $240.5 billion made in June; the decrease was attributable to uncertainties related to the economic problems in Asian-Pacific markets like South Korea and Thailand, which had been growing strongly until recently.
Mr. Coen's worldwide total for 1998, then, is $434.4 billion. That would represent an increase of 5.5 percent from a revised worldwide total of $411.6 billion for 1997 -- the first time it has surpassed the $400 billion milestone. The 1997 figure marks a gain of 5 percent from the $387.3 billion spent in 1996.
Mr. Perriss offered somewhat different totals from Mr. Coen because he focuses his predictions on major media like television, newspapers, magazines and radio.
Ad spending in major North American media will reach $117.3 billion in 1998, Mr. Perriss said, up 5 percent from the $111.6 billion he expects for 1997. For 1999, he projected $122.7 billion, an increase of 4.6 percent from his 1998 figure, and for 2000, he projected $128.2 billion, up 4.5 percent from 1999.
As for overseas ad spending, Mr. Perriss forecast $200.5 billion in major media in 1998, up 7.2 percent from the $187.1 billion he expects for 1997. In the Asian-Pacific region, he said, the banking and currency crisis "is expected to impact on consumer confidence much more than on the economic fundamentals."
Mr. Perriss's prediction for ad spending overseas in 1999 is $214.1 billion, up 6.8 percent from 1998. His prediction for 2000 is $229.3 billion, up 7.1 percent from 1999.
For the worldwide 1998 total, then, Mr. Perriss's forecast is $317.8 billion, an increase of 6.4 percent from $298.8 billion in 1997. His 1999 worldwide total is $336.8 billion, up 6 percent from 1998. And his 2000 worldwide total is $357.5 billion, up 6.1 percent from 1999.

HEADLINE: Bosnia II?

BYLINE: By Misha Glenny; Misha Glenny, author of "The Fall of Yugoslavia," is completing a history of Balkan nationalism.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Ministers and ambassadors from 51 nations gather in Bonn today for their annual review of how successfully the Dayton agreement on unifying Bosnia is being carried out. They will hear complaints that local leaders and international officials have been stalling, sowing confusion, missing deadlines and just plain acting ineptly.
But the senior delegates in Bonn ought to take a few minutes to discuss another Balkan problem: Kosovo. 
 Bosnia is a shocking example of what happens when things go wrong in the Balkans. Kosovo is a disturbing example of where that may well happen again soon.
The province in southern Serbia is home to the former Yugoslavia's most intractable conflict, which has been likened to an unexploded bomb. Ninety percent of Kosovo's more than two million people are Albanians who have suffered discrimination at the hands of the Serbian authorities. Human rights groups cite arbitrary arrests and beatings of Albanians.
In the past, diplomats have dismissed Kosovo as the accident that never happens -- the bomb that never explodes. There has been much tut-tutting and mild pressure, but no real push for a negotiated solution to Kosovo's problems. In the last few months, however, the situation in the province has steadily deteriorated.
Until recently, the Albanians of Kosovo followed the advice of their self-proclaimed President, Ibrahim Rugova, and restricted themselves to peaceful protests. But the last 18 months has witnessed the emergence of the Kosovo Liberation Army, a shady group that has claimed responsibility for dozens of attacks on Serbian police officers and civilians. It has also killed Albanians accused of collaborating with the Serbs.
Members of the Kosovo Liberation Army stepped out of the shadows for the first time nine days ago when three masked men in military fatigues attended the funeral of an Albanian teacher, Halit Geci, who had been killed in a shootout between the group and the Serbian police. Brandishing semiautomatic weapons, the three swore that they would avenge Mr. Geci's death and Kosovo's Albanians.
That finally drew the attention of diplomats. Klaus Kinkel, the German Foreign Minister, last week described the surge in violence in the province as alarming and announced that Germany and France would be urgently looking for ways to contain the problem. The American charge d'affaires in Belgrade, Richard C. Miles, visited Kosovo several days ago to appeal for calm. If Kosovo descends into violence, it may well spill over to neighboring Macedonia, where this year occasional shootouts have punctured the uneasy calm between Albanians and Macedonians.
Mr. Rugova, a moderate, is fast losing support among his own people. Last week, he renewed his appeal for American and European mediation. Unfortunately, the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, still the master of Serb politics, has stated repeatedly that Kosovo is an internal problem and that no outside mediation is necessary.
Serbs say that they cannot make concessions in Kosovo because of its historical importance to them. It contains their most important religious monuments and is the symbol of Serbia's medieval statehood. But they must realize that Kosovo is now of no economic or strategic value to them. For their part, the Kosovo Albanians must appreciate that they are not going to get independence overnight. If the Kosovo Liberation Army begins to dictate politics in Kosovo, there will be large-scale bloodshed.

LENGTH: 998 words

HEADLINE: 56 Troubled Lenders Closed by Thailand

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 8

 BODY:
This country drew cheers from economists today by closing all but two of 58 ailing finance companies, the toughest step yet to address economic problems.
The action, which was unexpectedly forceful, will cost 5,000 to 10,000 jobs and increase Thailand's economic pain. It had been delayed for months as the recently ousted Cabinet shrank from challenging powerful business leaders. 
 "We applaud it because under the circumstances it was a very courageous decision," said Shiva Kumar, a director of the World Bank's office here. "It sends the right signals about the Government's determination to clean up the financial sector."
Action on the finance companies, which had been suspended in June and August, was demanded by the International Monetary Fund as a key step in revamping the country's battered and inefficient banks.
The I.M.F. extended a $17 billion bailout package to Thailand in August after its currency, the baht, and its stock market fell and decade-long growth of 8 percent a year slowed sharply. Exports have fallen, companies are closing, prices are rising and growing numbers of people are losing jobs.
The plunge in the Thai economy set off a chain reaction through the region and rattled world markets, with the I.M.F. extending larger aid packages to Indonesia and South Korea. Economists worried that Thailand might be slow to recover because of political disarray and Government inaction.
Today, the benchmark Stock Exchange of Thailand index rose 3.35 percent, and the baht, which has fallen in value by more than 40 percent since July, rose slightly in Asian trading against the dollar.
The Government's action today cleared the way for release of additional funds by the I.M.F. Bangkok has already tapped $5.47 billion of the bailout money, and the I.M.F. in Washington is scheduled to vote on the release of an additional $3 billion.
In the long term, the action could help put the country on the road to recovery, economists said. If Thailand continues with forceful measures like the one today, it could again become one of Southeast Asia's economic leaders, said Mark Greenwood, representative here of Paribas Asia Equity, a global investment bank. "If Thailand continues down this path of liberalization and letting the markets do their work, it will be hastening the day when it comes out of the current mess that Asia finds itself in -- a leaner and meaner animal than the others," he said.
During a decade of rapid growth, the finance companies had offered easy terms to inefficient industries and unproductive real estate ventures. Accusations of cronyism and corruption were common.
The lenders were left holding an estimated $9 billion in nonperforming loans, most of that in property.
"We hope very much," said Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda, that "our decision to clean up the financial system systematically will signal we are moving in the right direction."
He said that the Government had approved rehabilitation plans for only two of the 58 finance companies, Bangkok Investment and Kiatnakin Finance and Securities P.L.C.
Bangkok Investment intends to sell an 80 percent stake to AIG Consumer Finance, a unit of the American International Group.
Mr. Tarrin is one of the technocrats brought in to manage the economy by the new Government of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, which took office a month ago, after the collapse of Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh's Cabinet.
The Finance Minister said the 56 institutions closed today would be liquidated under a program that would give foreign creditors the same rights as domestic ones. Two new banks will be set up to take over their healthy assets; their troubled assets will be sold later.
In addition to these institutions, Thailand has 15 commercial banks and 33 other financial institutions, which are nonbank lenders forbidden to accept deposits.
"There is still a question mark over the 33 companies that remain," said Stuart Matthews, research chief of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Securities in Thailand. "We saw very tough action today, which did surprise the market. I hope it will result in mergers among those 33."
The heads of the 58 financial institutions had issued a statement last Thursday apologizing for the debacle but blaming the Thai central bank for their problems.
"We feel sorry for depositors, creditors and shareholders who acted in good faith and employees who will lose their jobs," the executives said. But they accused the Bank of Thailand of "sending us the wrong signals and inaccurate economic data, stunting economic growth and causing businesses in several industries to go bankrupt."
One of the institutions, Dynamic Eastern Finance of Thailand, said it would sue the central bank for $126 million.
At a recent finance ministers' meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Mr. Tarrin said that Thailand was "totally committed" to the austerity measures demanded by the I.M.F. and intended to operate under "a new style of transparency," rather than by the back-room deals common in much of Asia.
"We believe this is the only way Thailand can return to restoration of market confidence and financial stability," he said. "I think Thailand, being the first to experience the troubles, hopefully will be the first to get out. We are determined to do this, and we will do it."

Confidence From Toyota
 TOKYO, Dec. 8 (Bloomberg News) -- The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would shift some production from Japan to two plants in Thailand and that they would resume operation in January after a two-month shutdown.
Toyota said it planned to increase the number of vehicles exported from Thailand. Output at the two factories was halted in November because the Thai economic slump was cutting into demand. Production is to resume on Jan. 7.
In addition to the vehicle exports, Toyota will begin exporting diesel engines and parts from Thailand to Japan.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Moscow Restores Benefits to 3 U.S.-Russian Oil Ventures

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 8

 BODY:
When Vice President Al Gore came to Moscow in September he took up the cudgel for American oil companies. The Americans complained that billions in new investment were in jeopardy because of obstreperous local leaders, unreliable Russian partners and a lethargic bureaucracy.
Today, American officials declared they had scored a small but noteworthy victory. 
 After months of importuning, United States officials have persuaded the Yeltsin Government to restore tax and pipeline privileges to three American-Russian joint ventures that extract Russian oil.
"The action on the joint ventures is a positive signal to energy investors in Russia," Jan Kalicki, the Clinton Administration's trouble-shooter on oil and gas issues, said in an interview.
The American partners in the three joint ventures are Anderman/ Smith Overseas Inc.; Conoco, a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, and Phibro Energy Production, a unit of Salomon Smith Barney, which is owned by Travelers Inc. The Conoco venture is called Polar Lights and the Phibro deal White Nights. The three projects were started at the beginning of the decade after the Government gave assurances that they would receive special treatment to enable them to recover their investment costs.
Those expectations were upset when the ventures were saddled with an array of new taxes, undercutting their financial viability. Phibro's joint venture, for example, says that it paid more than $17 million in unexpected new taxes between September 1994 and August 1997.
The aim of the agreement disclosed today is to make good on the Russian Government's promises that the ventures could recoup their investment. No one pretends, however, that the move has transformed Russia's well-deserved reputation as a difficult arena for oil investors. There is still a long list of problems.
The United States, for example, has sought unsuccessfully to persuade the Russian Government to reconsider its decision to revoke the Exxon Corporation's right to develop oil in the far north.
Exxon won that right in an auction only to lose it after Russian companies complained that it received too advantageous a deal. American officials are discussing a compromise: Exxon should have the right to participate in a new auction and match the winning bid.
The Amoco Corporation's vast project to develop the North Priobskoye oilfield in Western Siberia also remains in big trouble. Its new Russian partner, the Yukos oil company, has little interest in sharing the profits with Amoco although it lacks the capital to develop the field on its own.
Both the Exxon and Amoco projects were intended to be carried out under production-sharing agreements, which Western oil executives regard as far superior to traditional joint ventures because they offer more protection.
Under production-sharing accords, foreign companies receive drilling rights and an assurance that taxes will remain stable. And most Western companies are reluctant to invest new money in Russia without them. Still, getting approval for production-sharing agreements in the the Russian Parliament and among local authorities has proved to be a slow and painful process.
American officials still hope that some major new production-sharing deals can be moved forward. They say that the inclusion of new Russian partners will help prospects for two big projects in the northern region of Nenets as well as a new oil drilling venture in Sakhalin in Russia's Far East.
In the meantime, they have sought to iron out the problems that developed with the older joint ventures. The joint ventures account for a relatively small share of prospective investment and oil production but have a high political profile.
The roots of the current dispute go back to the early 1990's when the three joint ventures argued that they needed special privileges to recoup their investment costs because they were developing difficult oil deposits.
In all, the Conoco joint venture amounts to an investment of about $400 million; the Phibro venture has invested approximately $120 million and the Anderman/Smith project about $86 million.
The privileges involved three years of preferential access to Russia's clogged export pipeline and a promise to keep excise tariffs to a minimum for the same period.
But the companies complained that the Government had, in effect, changed the terms of the deal by imposing new taxes after production began. Then the pipeline and excise tax privileges expired on Sept. 1. Access to the pipeline shrank and excise taxes quadrupled. The companies complained that they were still in the hole.
The new decision on joint ventures is intended to address these complaints. It was hammered out by Sergei N. Kiriyenko, the Fuel and Energy Minister, and one of the Russian Government's economic reformers, and Mr. Kalicki as part of a broader review that is still under way on the problem facing American oil investments.
Under the new understanding, the joint ventures will be able to export 100 percent of their production through the pipeline. Excise taxes will be rolled back retroactively. Though details are still being worked out, the privileges are likely to be extended for six to 10 months.
Whether the decision will fully satisfy the joint ventures is unclear. Phibro has told the Government it needs to have its privileges extended for more than a year and a half to recoup its investment costs, as promised. Officials from the joint ventures' Moscow offices did not return phone calls, seeking comment.
Nor is it yet known which companies will lose access to the export pipeline so that the three joint ventures can be accommodated.
It is also not clear whether the decision will augur breakthroughs in the more important area of production-sharing agreements.
