HEADLINE: Muslim Leaders' Talks Hailed by Iran as Rebuff to U.S.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Leaders representing the world's one billion Muslims poured into this capital today for a conference that Iran is hailing as evidence that it has overcome American-led attempts to isolate it as an international pariah.
The gathering is the largest in Iran since the 1979 revolution, with a turnout that is expected to include nearly three dozen heads of state. 
 Among those countries whose delegates arrived today are close allies of the United States, including Egypt and Saudi Arabia, which pointedly stayed away from an American-backed conference last month in Qatar that had been intended to promote economic ties between Israel and Arab nations.
The meeting here of the Organization of the Islamic Conference remains unlikely to produce any kind of wholesale realignment toward Iran's opposition to the American-sponsored quest for a broader peace in the Middle East.
But as Iran assumes the chairmanship of the 55-member group, it has clearly taken major strides toward rehabilitation in the eyes of nations that once viewed the Islamic republic and its calls for the export of revolution with deep foreboding.
And by the time their meeting concludes on Thursday, the assembled Islamic leaders are expected to include at least a strongly worded resolution condemning Israel for "reinstating an atmosphere of war" in the Middle East.
With the many heads of state expected to attend the gathering, President Mohammed Khatami of Iran has declared that the gathering "shows the power and stability" of his country of 60 million people, which the United States has sought to isolate since the revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who had been America's most important ally in the Middle East.
The United States, which prohibits most commerce with Iran, has labeled Iran the greatest threat to security in the Middle East, mostly because of the support it has provided to militant organizations violently opposed to the peace effort.
But European governments, which defend their policies of engaging the Teheran Government in both political and economic terms, have firmly resisted American calls to join in an economic embargo.
And the seal of approval by the high-level Arab turnout this week is merely the most dramatic in a series of steps in which Iran has broken away from its isolation.
These steps include the signing of the biggest foreign investment deal since the revolution, a $2 billion natural gas contract with a French, Malaysian and Russian consortium, and the ending of a diplomatic impasse with the European Union that has brought European ambassadors back to Teheran after a seven-month absence.
At a time when efforts to broker a wider peace in the Middle East have made no headway for nearly a year, Iran has also drawn increasing numbers of Arab states toward its antagonistic view of the American-led effort. And since the election of Mr. Khatami in May, it has signaled a desire to build closer ties with its long-suspicious neighbors, particularly in the Persian Gulf.
Those latter factors have played an important role in allowing Iran to claim center stage now in regional diplomacy, with this week's meeting destined to overshadow the one in Qatar as the year's most important gathering of Arab leaders.
At least in terms of symbolic importance, perhaps the most significant arrival today was that of Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, the highest-ranking Saudi to visit Iran since the revolution.
As the self-styled center of Islamic orthodoxy, Saudi Arabia has for years been among Iran's most ardent critics, and it has repeatedly raised alarms over Iran's support for Shiite Muslim militants in the region.
But in the months since Mr. Khatami's election, Iran has worked assiduously toward reconciliation with the Saudis, and Iran is clearly hoping that the attendance of the kingdom's heir apparent will help to promote closer ties between two of the region's most important military powers.
Others attending the conference include Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, which like Saudi Arabia refused to attend the Qatar conference.
Egypt has similarly expressed recent animosities toward Iran, with some officials accusing the Teheran Government this year of providing support to Islamic militants who are trying to overthrow the secular Government in Cairo.
But anger toward Israel and bitterness toward a United States that is no longer seen as being an evenhanded partner has now led Egypt to swallow whatever distaste remains and join in a conference whose main aim, Iranian organizers say, is to overcome historic divisions and promote Islamic solidarity.
Another delegate whose visit may promote some fence-mending is Vice President Taha Yasin Ramadan of Iraq, its highest-ranking visitor since Iran and Iraq waged their long and gory war from 1980 to 1988.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Greenspan Refrain: That Was Then . . .

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
If you had listened to Alan Greenspan just two months ago and then considered what has happened in the American economy since, you would have to conclude that a Federal Reserve tightening was a sure thing. The fact that few expect it now is a tribute to how rapidly the world can change, and to how fast seers can change their minds.
In Congressional testimony on Oct. 8, Mr. Greenspan was as clear as he has ever been on what would lead the Fed to tighten before inflation indexes began to leap. The economy, he said, could not long sustain the current rate of job creation without a burst of inflation. 
 "The performance of the labor markets this year has been on an unsustainable track," Mr. Greenspan said, pointing to a sizzling annual pace of two million new jobs created. He said there were simply not enough prospective workers without jobs to allow that rate to continue.
"To be sure," he said, "job growth slowed significantly in August and September, but it did not slow enough to close, from the demand side alone, the gap of the demand for labor over the supply from increases in the working-age population."
The message seemed clear, or at least as clear as the Federal Reserve Board chairman ever allows: Either employment growth slows on its own or the Fed will tighten credit to ward off inflation.
So what happened? First, the Government revised the statistics for September, so that the job pace appeared not as slow as Mr. Greenspan had thought. The current estimate for that month is 269,000 net new nonfarm jobs created, up from 215,000. October's figure is now 287,000, and November's is 404,000. The average comes to 320,000 jobs a month, or an annual rate of 3.8 million, nearly twice what Mr. Greenspan deemed unsustainable.
At the same time, there have been indications that wages are starting to rise much more rapidly than they had been, as would be expected when a record percentage of the population is working and the jobless rate has fallen to a 24-year low of 4.6 percent.
What happened in those two months? Asia crumbled. Now, with the International Monetary Fund directing bailouts in some countries, and Japan expected to finally begin dealing with its sick banks, it would seem extremely unfriendly of the Fed to make the international situation even stickier by raising interest rates when its Open Market Committee meets next week. Countries trying to keep their currencies from collapsing against the dollar would not appreciate higher interest rates in this country.
So the consensus is that the Fed will do nothing. Whereas six weeks ago, the markets seemed worried that Asian flu would make the whole world sick, now the belief is that the Asian flu will keep the Fed from doing anything to end Wall Street's party. That has produced a confidence that sent the Standard & Poor's 500 index to a new high Friday, the very day the employment figures were released. It was the first peak since the October panic brought on by Asian concerns.
In recent years, it has almost always been a losing strategy to bet against the stock market's rising. But perhaps, just perhaps, this latest rise is unsustainable.
Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, points out that for several years corporate profits have grown much faster than the economy as a whole, a reflection of rising profit margins. Now, he says, companies may confront a bad combination of factors that squeeze profit margins rather than expand them. The tight labor market threatens to raise wage costs for many businesses, while those that deal in products sold around the world may find it hard to raise prices, given Asian overcapacity and weak currencies. All this could make optimistic profit forecasts look unreachable.
Mr. Barbera also thinks that the Fed will eventually tighten, probably early next year after the Asian situation appears to have stabilized. If that happens, or if his profit-squeeze forecast works out, stock prices could come under pressure.
The best argument against that bearish outlook right now has nothing to do with economic statistics or inflation. It centers on the fact that Wall Street's forecasts tend to mirror the market. Wall Street overcame its worry about Asia not so much because of confidence that the Asian problem will be adequately dealt with -- it is far too early to answer that question -- but because financial markets stabilized and even rallied. That happened largely because individual American investors saw the Asian-induced plunge in American stocks as a buying opportunity.
That could happen again, as a market decline brought on either by poorer profits or a new Fed tightening is greeted by even more buying, and by analysts then finding reasons to believe that higher short-term interest rates and lower profits should not derail the bull market.
Were that to happen, the winners would again be those who bet on higher stock prices. And Mr. Greenspan might dust off his remarks about "irrational exuberance." As it happens, Friday was the first anniversary of his use of that phrase. The S.& P. 500 is up 32 percent since then.

HEADLINE: 3 Companies In U.S. Share Asia's Pain

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Several American companies in widely different industries -- aerospace, soft drinks and computer software -- but with big global presences are beginning to feel negative effects from Asia's financial crisis.
The Boeing Company said yesterday that Asian airlines might delay taking delivery of as many as 60 jetliners over the next three years because economic problems were slowing growth in airline traffic. Securities analysts said profits at Coca-Cola Company would decline in the fourth quarter and in 1998 from a strong dollar, which has risen sharply against Asian currencies. And the Oracle Corporation reported disappointing earnings, also hurt partly by the dollar's strength. 
 Boeing, the world's biggest aircraft maker, could see as many as 20 Asian deliveries a year delayed though 2000, said Gordon McHenry, director of airline industry analysis for Boeing. The company still expects to deliver the jetliners, starting in 2001, when an economic rebound is predicted in the region, he said. The company's stock fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $51.4375.
A loss of 20 deliveries a year would be small compared with the company's expected total worldwide delivery of 550 planes next year, Mr. McHenry said. Yet analysts said Boeing's report did not eliminate their concerns about the uncertainties of doing business in Asia.
The shares of Coca-Cola, which gets 80 percent of its profit from abroad, fell $2.50, to $63.5625, on diminished profit expectations. Coca-Cola gets 17 percent of its profit from Japan, and in the last three months the dollar has gained nearly 8 percent against the yen, reducing the amount of profit in dollar terms.

HEADLINE: Evangelical Protestants Giving Less to Churches, Study Says

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

 BODY:
Evangelical Protestants, whose churches have historically urged members to tithe their incomes, are placing a decreasing percentage of their personal incomes in the collection plate, according to a wide-ranging study released yesterday of giving patterns in 29 Protestant denominations.
A portion of the study, titled, "The State of Church Giving Through 1995," compared personal giving within eight denominations belonging to the National Association of Evangelicals and eight mainline Protestant denominations in the National Council of Churches. From 1968 to 1995, it found a steady narrowing of the difference in giving as a proportion of income between mainline Protestants -- a group that includes most Presbyterians and Lutherans, for example -- and evangelicals, who emphasize a personal conversion experience, or being "born again." 
 The study found that members of the evangelical denominations were giving their churches an average of about 4 percent of their incomes in 1995, down from about 6 percent in 1968. Giving by members of the mainline Protestant denominations -- lower to begin with -- also declined, but less sharply, to 2.9 percent of personal income in 1995, from about 3.3 percent in 1968.
The study was done by Empty Tomb, a Christian research and service organization in Champaign, Ill., that has published an annual survey on church giving since 1988. The organization bases its calculations on financial and membership figures published by 29 Protestant denominations in The Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches (Abingdon). For figures on per capita disposable personal income, the organization relies on annual estimates of the United States Bureau of Economic Analysis.
The current study also reports that while the value of individual church members' donations to the 29 Protestant denominations rose to an average of about $498 in 1995, from about $97 in 1968, that increase was less than the growth in after-tax personal income in the same period.
Referring to the statistics on evangelicals' giving, Sylvia Ronsvalle, Empty Tomb's executive vice president, said she believed that they reflected how evangelicals had become closer to the broader American culture, their economic and political status having risen since the 1960's.
Although he had not seen the statistics, Richard Cizik, a policy analyst in the National Association of Evangelicals' governmental affairs office, said the findings also suggested that evangelicals were increasingly inclined to give to religious causes outside their churches.
The eight evangelical denominations in the study were the Brethren in Christ Church, the Church of the Nazarene, the Conservative Congregational Christian Conference, the Evangelical Congregational Church, the Evangelical Mennonite Church, the Fellowship of Evangelical Bible Churches, the Free Methodist Church of North America and the General Association of General Baptists.
The eight mainline denominations were the American Baptist Churches in the U.S.A.; the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ); the Church of the Brethren; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America; the Moravian Church in America, Northern Province; the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.); the Reformed Church in America, and the United Church of Christ.

HEADLINE: HUD Has An 800 Line To Give Aid To the Needy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
With expectations of a colder winter than usual in many parts of the country, the Department of Housing and Urban Development today announced the creation of a toll-free telephone number to summon aid for homeless people caught without food and shelter.
Department officials said the number would also be used to encourage more Americans to get involved in solving problems that lead to the deaths of several hundred homeless people every year because of exposure. Severe conditions are possible this winter, they said, because of El Nino, the warming of waters in the Pacific Ocean that disrupts normal weather patterns. 
 "This is literally a matter of life and death," Andrew M. Cuomo, the Housing Secretary, said in a speech that was broadcast to groups that work with homeless in 66 cities.
Maria Foscarinis, executive director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, a nonprofit organization, applauded the department's efforts so far as they go. But like others who work to reduce the homeless population, Ms. Foscarinis said she was more concerned about solving economic and social problems that lead to homelessness.
"The important thing," she said, "is educating the public about homelessness and finding solutions. People who see homeless on the street are concerned, and they want to respond. But what's missing is why people are homeless. It's important to look for real solutions."
The initiative is part of the Clinton Administration's continuing efforts to reduce the number of homeless people, officials said, at a time when most major cities cannot provide adequate shelter to meet the nightly demand. The housing department estimates that at least 600,000 Americans are homeless on any given night, and a 1996 analysis of the homeless population by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty found that none of the nation's 50 biggest cities had sufficient beds to accommodate them.
The study found that in many of the bigger cities, including New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, the disparity was especially large. Houston, for example, had 2,238 emergency shelter beds and a homeless population of 12,000.
Mr. Cuomo said the Federal Government had stepped up its efforts for the homeless, with $823 million available for homeless programs as part of the latest budget, compared with the $300 million that was authorized four years ago.
But as part of today's announcement, he gave the equivalent of a national pep talk, imploring the 5,000 service providers who were tuned in around the country to intensify their own efforts by arranging for additional emergency shelter in their communities for the months ahead.
"Resources are one problem we have to deal with," he said. "Do we have enough? No. Can we use more? Yes. Can they be increased? Yes."
Housing officials are planning a dual role for the toll-free telephone number, (800) HUD-1010. Its most urgent use is to allow a caller to summon help for a homeless person in desperate need of shelter or food. The caller will be immediately connected to a local homeless service.
But housing officials said the number would also allow local organizations to engage callers in a wider conversation about homelessness, to explain other ways help was needed.
Thomas J. Knoll, executive director of Community Family Life Services in Washington, said the possibility of recruiting people to help was "what excites me the most about the hot line."
Peg Reece, executive director of Unity for the Homeless in New Orleans, a nonprofit group, said New Orleans already had an elaborate emergency response system in place for severe weather that includes a toll-free number.
"But the H.U.D. number would more likely help people learn how they can get more involved," Ms. Reece said.
Mr. Cuomo disputed the notion that many Americans calling to alert the authorities to a homeless person would feel put off by an extended conversation about social ills and community needs. To the contrary, he argued. "Most people want to help but don't know how to get involved," he said.
Lee Blons, executive director of Caritas, a nonprofit homelessness organization in Richmond, said, "Most people who are concerned enough to pick up the phone would be willing to be asked to do more."
To promote the effort, the housing department intends to distribute 300,000 wallet-sized cards in supermarkets, bookstores and community centers around the country that list the toll-free number as well as 10 suggestions for to volunteer time and money to help eliminate the causes of homelessness.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Falling by 38.29

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed, as some big blue chips fell on concerns that the Asian crisis could hurt earnings while technologies issues gained.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 38.29, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,110.84, its first decline in seven sessions. Coca-Cola led the the decline in the Dow, falling 2 1/8, to 63 9/16. Coca-Cola was responsible for 10.2 points of the Dow's loss. 
 Coca-Cola fell after Andrew Conway at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover and Jennifer F. Solomon at Salomon Smith Barney cut their earnings estimates for the company. Both cited the dollar's strength against the yen, as currency earned overseas will be worth less when converted into dollars.
The Boeing Company fell 15/16, to 51 7/16, after the company said the delivery of as many as 60 of its jetliners would be delayed over the next three years because of slower growth in airline traffic in Asia.
The Standard & Poor's 500 Index, up 33 percent this year, fell 1.42, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 982.37. The Russell 2000 Index, which tracks small- and mid-capitalization companies, rose 3.97, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 442.03.The Nasdaq composite gained 17.64, to 1,651.54.
The Microsoft Corporation led the Nasdaq higher. While Microsoft has been one of the market's stellar stocks, more than quintupling over the last five years, it has lagged of late. It has not set a record since July 17, when it closed at 149 1/2. The Intel Corporation, up 7/8, to 78 7/16, is off 22 percent from its Aug. 20 high.
The Nasdaq, dominated by technology companies, has gained 7.6 percent since the market tumbled Oct. 27. The Dow, meanwhile, filled with huge multinationals, many of them regarded as safe, is up 13 percent. The average is off less than 2 percent from its Aug. 6 high of 8,259.31.
Bank stocks rose after the First American Corporation said it had agreed to buy the Deposit Guaranty Corporation and Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation said they would merge, intensifying speculation that other combinations are in store. "More bank deals are likely to be in the works," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "The focus continues on increasing shareholder value. Low interest rates have prompted them, and more are to come."
The Mellon Bank Corporation rose 4 3/8, to 63, The Banc One Corporation gained 1, to 56 1/2, and the Nationsbank Corporation rose 1 1/8, to 62 1/8.
First American, parent company of First American National Bank, offered 1.17 of its own shares for each Deposit Guaranty share, valuing Deposit Guaranty's stock at $64.06. Deposit Guaranty rose 4 5/8, to 57, and First American fell 5 3/16, to 49 9/16.
America Online Inc., which is up 162 percent this year, rose 2 7/8, to 87 1/4. The stock was rated a new "buy" by Frederick W. Moran, a media analyst at the brokerage firm Furman Selz Inc. Mr. Moran said the Internet service had added capacity to fix a bottleneck that made it hard for subscribers to gain access to AOL last year. AOL's position as the largest provider of Internet access, with 10 million subscribers, sets it up to capitalize on the falling price of personal computers, Mr. Moran said. Fannie Mae fell 1 3/4, to 54 11/16; Freddie Mac lost 1 1/16, to 41 3/4, and Countrywide Credit Industries fell 1/2, to 42 3/16, after the three stocks were reduced to "hold" from "buy" by David Dusenbury, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.

HEADLINE: Auto Business Sold to Rival In Korea Crisis

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Ssangyong Group, one of Korea's biggest family-run businesses, has sold off its automobile company to the rival Daewoo Group in what executives described as the first friendly takeover in the history of Korea's largest conglomerates.
The unusual sale, a step in the consolidation of Korea's overcrowded automobile industry, capped a swirl of activity as Korea Inc. continued the makeover spurred by the nation's economic crisis and the rescue by the International Monetary Fund last week. 
 In addition to its purchase of the automobile company, Daewoo announced on Monday its greatest management reshuffle ever. It will send the 24 chairmen of its major subsidiaries to new overseas posts where they will head regional offices in charge of all Daewoo products.
The giant Hyundai Group, after an arm-pumping rally in its auditorium, said it would cut capital investment next year by 40 percent and mount a big export drive.
Officials at the Ministry of Finance and Economy said they were preparing to inject what could be about $1 billion in Government money into two of the nation's sickest commercial banks -- effectively nationalizing them, analysts said.
Fear that more financial and industrial companies might fail helped send the Korean won free-falling toward another low.
The currency market was also roiled by reports that the South Korean Government might be understating the extent of its financial problems -- leading to fears that more money might be needed than the $57 billion committed by the I.M.F.
South Korea said its short-term foreign currency debt, payable within a year, is about $66 billion. But news reports here say, and a Finance Ministry official conceded, that this figure does not include the debts held by overseas subsidiaries of Korean companies. This amount, which Korea calls spot financing, is about $50 billion, although it cannot simply be added to the $66 billion to get a total because there is some double counting.
Kwak Sang Yong, associate director of the foreign exchange policy division of the finance ministry, said that the $66 billion conforms to the World Bank standard, which is debt owed by residents to nonresidents and is not based on nationality. Overseas subsidiaries tend to borrow locally based on their own assets.
"Do you think the Korean government must include AST's financial liability in our nation's external debt," he said, referring to an American computer company owned by Samsung Electronics. "I don't think any country in the world would do that."
Meanwhile the Chosun Ilbo, the nation's leading newspaper, said on Monday that the Government's foreign currency reserves had droppped to as low as $5 billion by the time the I.M.F. rescue was announced last week, well below the last official reported figure of $30.5 billion at the end of October. Stocks were down more than 6 percent this morning after a 4.8 percent decline on Monday.
The sale of control of the Ssangyong Motor Company to Daewoo, which probably saved the Ssangyong Group from collapse, could set a precedent for restructuring of the family-run conglomerates, known as chaebols, that dominate the economy here. Now highly diversified, they may focus on fewer industries and sell the rest -- either to other chaebol or to foreign companies. Last month Ssangyong sold its paper company to Procter & Gamble.
Until now, the chaebols had easy access to capital and competed for bragging rights by becoming bigger and more diversified -- leading to overcapacity and soaring debts. To give up part of one's empire, especially to a rival family, was a disgrace.
But the financial problems of the chaebol could change that attitude. "The reason the chaebol became so big and fat and diversified was that the more you did the more money you made," said Milton S. Kim, president of the Ssangyong Investment and Securities Company and a member of the family that controls the Ssangyong Group. "Now, the tide has changed. Small is beautiful."
Ssangyong, the sixth-largest chaebol, accumulated too much debt through an ill-conceived expansion into the already crowded passenger car business. Six of the nation's top 30 chaebol have already failed this year, including the Halla Group, which was declared bankrupt on Saturday. Many analysts thought Ssangyong would be No. 7.
"We were understandably on the short list, but this should take us off it," Mr. Kim said. "It gives us a huge breathing space."
The purchase price for Ssangyong Group's 53.5 percent share of publicly traded Ssangyong Motor was not announced but it is expected to be a pittance. What is much more important, Mr. Kim said, is that Daewoo will relieve the Ssangyong group of 2 trillion won -- or about $1.5 billion -- of the 3.4 trillion won in debt of Ssangyong Motor.
Furthermore, the creditors, led by the Cho Hung Bank, will reschedule the debt, giving Daewoo a moratorium on payment of principal for 10 years and Ssangyong for 5 years. Interests rates will also be set at prime rate or slightly above, about half the going rate in Korea.
Ssangyong's tale is typical of the chaebol. With its main strength in cement and oil, the group bought its supplier of cement-mixing trucks in the mid-1980's and became a manufacturer of trucks, buses and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
But a few years ago, Kim Suk Won, the group's chairman at the time and a car enthusiast, decided to enter the passenger car business with technology supplied by Daimler-Benz of Germany. The car, called the Chairman and costing roughly $35,000, went on sale last month as the most expensive passenger car in Korea. But production of a luxury car is not expected to be large enough to cover the investment.
The purchase by Daewoo is the latest step in the consolidation of the overcrowded auto industry. Earlier this year, the Kia Motors Corporation went bankrupt and was taken over by the Government.
The Samsung Group will begin selling cars next year, but has postponed expansion of its capacity.
Already South Korea's industry is operating at well below capacity and auto sales in Korea, down 2.4 percent so far this year, are expected to nose- dive next year because the I.M.F. rescue will result in much slower growth and higher unemployment.
For Daewoo, Korea's No. 2 auto maker, the purchase allows it to have a full product line, from mini-cars to large trucks, to challenge the market leader, Hyundai Motor. Ssangyong's sport utility vehicles and trucks barely overlap the passenger car product line of Daewoo Motor.
Daewoo has been expanding rapidly, both in Korea and around the world, building or buying factories mainly in developing regions like Eastern Europe. It plans to enter the American market with three passenger cars next year and may eventually add Ssangyong's sport utility vehicle to its American lineup.
An official in the Daewoo chairman's office insisted that taking on Ssangyong's debt would not endanger Daewoo. Daimler-Benz, which owns 2.4 percent of Ssangyong Motor and looked at buying the company, is expected to continue technical help, the Daewoo official said.
On the banking front, officials at the Ministry of Finance said that on the Government would inject new equity today into the Korea First Bank and the Seoul Bank, two commercial banks that are now basically insolvent because of their heavy loans to now collapsed chaebols.
While ministry officials said the amount of the infusion had not been decided, Korean news reports indicated the Seoul Bank would get 1.1 trillion won, or about $820 million. The Korea First Bank, which was already given 800 trillion won more than a month ago, will be given an additional 300 billion won, or about $220 million.
The South Korean Government battled fiercely against I.M.F. requests that it shut insolvent banks to speed the restructuring of the financial sector. When they announced the terms of the rescue agreement, South Korean officials did not initially tell the public that they had agreed with the I.M.F. to shut two unnamed commercial banks if the banks did not meet international capital standards after a certain period.
While analysts said the Government would now be the controlling owner of both banks, a Finance Ministry official said "the Government will definitely, as soon as possible, divest" itself of its shares once the banks get back on their feet.
But Kim Chul Jung, banking analyst at Ssangyong Securities, said the new equity was still not enough to erase the two banks' negative book value. He said the banks might be closed or merged eventually.

HEADLINE: Talk in Japan of Selling U.S. Bonds Has Little Effect

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Once again, talk of a Japanese selloff of United States Treasury bonds has been heard, briefly raising the possibility of new market tremors, but this time few investors seemed rattled.
Indeed, it turns out that the Bank of Japan has been quietly selling some Treasury holdings for days, causing barely a stir. 
 The latest speculation about a sale of bonds came on Sunday, when Taku Yamasaki, chairman of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's policy research council, said the Government was considering selling some Treasuries to help troubled Japanese banks raise dollars they needed.
Japanese news reports described Mr. Yamasaki's suggestion as more serious than the offhand comment made six months ago by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on the possibility of such sales, which rattled markets worldwide and sent United States stock prices down.
But today the markets seemed to largely shrug off the possibility of a big Treasury bond sale. In the United States, stocks were mixed and bond prices only dipped.
 Japanese stocks rallied sharply early Tuesday on reports that Mr. Hashimoto favors spending $77 billion to help financial companies write off bad loans. The Nikkei 225-stock index rose 518.16 points, or 3.22 percent, to 16,650.25.
Bankers and foreign-exchange brokers here said even before Mr. Yamasaki's proposal was reported that the nation's central bank had been selling some Treasury holdings to raise dollars in the repurchase market, meaning it has agreed to buy them back later. These sales are essentially loans using Treasury instruments as collateral, and do not increase the supply available.
The central bank has been using the proceeds for loans to banks confronted with high borrowing costs. Lenders have cast an increasingly wary eye upon the health of the entire financial system, afterfour large institutions collapsed last month.
The possibility that Japan might unload United States Treasury holdings, an idea heard from time to time, could have a big impact on the markets. Japan is the largest foreign holder of United States Government debt, and a substantial sale could cause a supply glut that sends prices down and interest rates up.
But Japanese officials said no selloff of Treasury bonds was envisioned. They noted that any money raised would be done through the repurchase market -- the same process the central bank is using.
Behind Mr. Yamasaki's remarks seemed to be the idea that the central bank could temporarily lend the proceeds of bond sales to banks facing difficulty borrowing, thereby alleviating the credit squeeze.
"It's a way for the Government to give cheap financing to Japanese banks in a situation where the market is not judging credit risks in the same way it would under normal conditions," said Robert Alan Feldman of Salomon Brothers Asia.
Foreign-exchange brokers said the central bank had entrusted the proceeds of sales made in recent days to the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi and Sumitomo Bank, which in turn have made loans to their shakier brethren.
A currency broker who spoke on condition of anonymity said some banks pressed for cash last week were now issuing certificates of deposit to other Japanese financial institutions that needed funds. .
In that way, the Bank of Japan has solved the short-term financing problems many commercial banks have confronted. Indeed, the only footprint the central bank has left is in the "Japan premium," the extra tenths of a percentage point that Japanese banks pay to borrow overseas. These premiums have fallen roughly in half.
The central bank does not disclose its total United States bond holdings. All Japanese investors held slightly more than 6 percent, or $330 billion, in Treasuries at the end of 1996, said Ronald Bevacqua of Merrill Lynch.
As such, Japanese investors as a group can influence United States bond prices and yields -- potential leverage in any economic dispute between the two largest economies. But few expect Japan to use it.
Historically, the Japanese have held Treasury bills in times of distress, most recently in 1995, when concerns about the Japanese financial system made credit expensive.
Second, interest rates in Japan are measured in tenths of a percent, rather than full percentage points, making Treasuries about the highest-yielding asset held by Japanese institutional investors.
Third, this coming April 1, longstanding regulations curbing Japanese purchases of investments denominated in currencies other than yen will end, which could cause a flow of capital out of the country..
Already, the Japanese subsidiary of Citibank is reporting a large increase in its deposits.
And Japanese banks, which are large holders of United States assets, cannot afford to cash out their Treasuries. As of March 31, most big banks must meet the Bank of International Settlements' standard that they maintain capital equal to 8 percent of their assets. A reduction in their United States Treasury bills, which are considered virtually risk-free, would make that harder to achieve.
The greatest curb on a Japanese sale of American bonds lies in the global consequences of such an action. "From the Government's perspective, they're well aware of the implications of a large-scale liquidation of U.S. Treasuries, including higher interest rates worldwide and an increase in the Japan premium as well," said Kathy Matsui, Goldman Sachs Japan's chief market strategist here.

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki's Fair Fares

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki put himself behind imaginative discounts in transit fares yesterday when he endorsed unlimited-ride monthly, weekly and daily passes and other breaks for New York City's subway and bus riders. The Governor's plan is sensible and superior to that proposed by city officials. He needs to insure that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board, which he dominates, approves the development of discount options and gives transit executives freedom to experiment and fiddle with fares at the M.T.A.'s next board meeting later this month.
Mr. Pataki's proposal will lessen the transit drain on many riders' wallets, and it suggests that those who share responsibility for governing New York and nurturing its economy want the city and region to offer the array of rapid-transit fares long taken for granted in London, Paris, Tokyo and other world capitals and in U.S. cities as well. 
 The Governor's plan sets out to introduce deep-discount options in exchange for unlimited rides for customers with different needs, desires and incomes: a monthly pass priced at $63 (the cost of 42 rides), a weekly one priced at $17 and a one-day $4 pass, as well as breaks for senior citizens and users of express buses. Equally important, his proposal will allow the transit executives to begin to exploit the Metrocard's vast untapped power to lure different kinds of customers to ride more often. Designing an off-peak fare that can relieve rush-hour overcrowding should be on the M.T.A.'s agenda.
While not much was said about when these fare options will kick in, it appears that the M.T.A. is poised to roll out its set of discounted, unlimited-ride fares next summer. That is too far off. It should only take about 90 days to assess the fare structure's fairness to riders of various incomes, adjust accordingly if necessary, and build customer awareness.
With such a long lead time, transit executives might well seek advice on fine-tuning the pricing from an advisory panel composed of individuals sensitive to the city's social goals and others who are experts at defining the right price points for generating revenues. Few issues have such impact on individuals and businesses as the fares charged for mass transit.

HEADLINE: California G.O.P. Faces a Crisis As Hispanic Voters Turn Away

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The California Republican Party, the mighty army that helped propel Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan to the White House, now finds itself facing a big problem: It is rapidly losing ground among the fastest-growing group in the electorate of the nation's most-populous state, Hispanic voters. Expressed in either English or Spanish, the arithmetic is clear.
By 2025, the Census Bureau projects, the Hispanic share of California's population will rise to 43 percent, from just under 30 percent now, an increase of some 12 million people and the largest such gain in the nation. By 2000, Hispanic residents are expected to account for nearly 30 percent of the voting-age population, though citizenship, voter registration and participation lag well behind that level. 
 Republicans, burned by a backlash against Gov. Pete Wilson's strong stands against illegal immigration and affirmative action, have seen their share of the Hispanic vote slide precipitously. When first elected in 1990, Mr. Wilson won about 44 percent of the Hispanic vote.
That dropped to 25 percent in 1994 when he campaigned for Proposition 187, a measure to cut off public services to illegal immigrants that was passed by voters but has since been blocked in Federal court.
There was a political case to be made for the Governor's stance: Mr. Wilson, his popularity buffeted by the state's economic downturn, was trying to solidify his base among whites in what initially seemed like a close race for re-election against State Treasurer Kathleen Brown. He was also exploring a campaign for President, and his position on illegal immigration was widely considered a potential plus among conservative Republicans in the party primaries.
But now Mr. Wilson's short-term strategy seems to be causing long-term headaches for his party. At least one statewide poll shows State Attorney General Dan Lungren, the Republicans' presumptive nominee for governor next year, drawing the support of only about 14 percent of the Hispanic voters.
That is an ominous prospect for any party in a state that is poised to become the first on the mainland where non-Hispanic whites are a minority. The national implications for the party are also sobering, both because of California's electoral importance as the most-populous state and because of growing Hispanic populations in states like Texas, Florida, New Jersey and Illinois.
"The trend is obvious, and the political danger is real," Stuart Spencer, one of the California's most respected Republican strategists, warned in an open memorandum to party leaders 10 days ago.
Mr. Spencer wrote that the party risked "political suicide and dooms itself to permanent minority status in California" if it did not reach out to Hispanic voters.
"We are dramatically losing market share of the fastest-growing segment of the electorate," he warned. "These are voters who should be with us on the issues of jobs, taxes, Government regulation, education, public safety and the importance of family."
Nationally, about one million more Hispanic voters turned out in 1996 than in 1992, and Mr. Spencer, who worked for Mr. Reagan and Gerald Ford, is not alone in his determination to keep California, so often a national bellwether, from setting the pattern for the national party.
Many Republicans are concerned that a California ballot proposal to end bilingual education in the public schools, which is sponsored by Ron Unz, a multimillionaire and former Republican candidate for governor, will further alienate Hispanic voters. Party regulars endorsed the measure, which is expected to qualify for the ballot next year, at their state convention this fall, but the state Republican chairman, Michael J. Schroeder, actively opposes it and says the party will "not spend a dime" to support it.
The problem is all the more frustrating to many Republicans because the party has shown in recent contests that it can make inroads among Hispanic voters. In Los Angeles, Mayor Richard J. Riordan, a Republican, won re-election last spring with the support of 60 percent of Hispanic voters, who for the first time exceeded black voters as a share of the electorate.
"I do think it's a constituency that we should have a lot of affinity with," said Alex Castellanos, a Cuban-born Republican consultant in Washington who has worked for clients like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. "It's an absolutist culture, very black and white, with strong moral values. I think that's Republican culture. It's a strong Catholic culture, one of the few groups where the abortion issue is not fuzzy."
"It is also, and this is something that's hard to talk about, but it's more of a daddy-bear, father-figure culture, and Republicans have been very successful with crime and other patriarchal issues," Mr. Castellanos said. "At the same time, we're seeing the biggest economic boom in world history, with tremendous opportunity for economic success, and nothing is more likely to make you a Republican than being economically successful and paying a lot of taxes."
At the moment, the gap between the parties here is striking. The chairman of the state Democratic Party is former State Senator Art Torres, while Cruz Bustamante, a Democrat, is the first Hispanic Speaker of the State Assembly. There are five Hispanic Democrats from California in Congress, and no Republicans. There are 17 Hispanic Democrats in the state Legislature and 1 Republican, Rod Pacheco of Riverside, who last year became the first Hispanic Republican elected to the Assembly in 115 years.
Republicans here were concerned enough that they staged a special daylong Latino Summit in September intended to mend fences. Mr. Wilson, who says his opposition to illegal immigration was twisted by Democrats to suggest that he opposed services for legal immigrants, defended his actions and accused his opponents of "a massive disinformation campaign, based on that ugliest of accusations: racism."
But though few Republicans are willing to say so openly, it is clear that Mr. Wilson, who is barred by term limits from seeking re-election, remains highly unpopular among Hispanic voters and is something of an impediment to the party's efforts to reach out to them. His re-election advertisements in 1994 showed grainy black and white footage purporting to depict illegal immigrants streaming from Mexico as a narrator intoned, "They keep coming."
"There were some fundamental miscalculations," said Arturo Vargas, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected an Appointed Officials, a nonpartisan group here. "With the short-term strategy that Wilson implemented for his own re-election, he gambled away the Latino votes of the Republican Party."
By contrast, Mr. Vargas said, another Republican, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who speaks fluent Spanish, has generally good relations with Hispanic voters because "he gets it, he understands what Latinos mean to the future of his state."
Still, 2 of every 3 new Hispanic voters in Texas register Democratic.
Mr. Spencer has been urging California Republicans for years to make more of an effort to appeal to Hispanic voters, and he wrote his memorandum in support of Ruben Barrales, a 35-year-old San Mateo County Supervisor in the San Francisco Bay area who is seeking the Republican nomination for state treasurer next year. "If we cannot even support just one qualified Latino Republican for statewide office, then we deserve the political disaster that awaits us," Mr. Spencer wrote.
Assemblyman Pacheco noted that Mr. Reagan enjoyed the support of almost 50 percent of Hispanic voters, twice the level of last year's Republican Presidential candidate.
Mr. Spencer said Republicans had a history of similar mistakes.
"Our party has a sad (and politically self-defeating) history of alienating immigrant groups and new voters," he wrote. "The G.O.P. closed the door to Irish and Italian immigrants in Massachusetts and New York in the last century. We did the same to Poles and other Eastern Europeans in Chicago and other urban centers. We did it again to Asian-Americans in Hawaii."
Mr. Schroeder, the Republican chairman, has for the first time hired a full-time Hispanic outreach coordinator and has made increasing diversity in the party his top goal.
"The broader challenge for the party is to get the debate back with the issues that work for us: economic opportunity, strong values," Mr. Schroeder said. "Where we got off the beam is that some of the ads run by Republican candidates in recent years conveyed the message that Republicans don't like Hispanics, and to quote Jack Kemp, 'If people don't know that you care, they won't care what you know.' "
There have been a few rough spots on Mr. Schroeder's watch. A "Pride in Diversity" breakfast at the state convention this fall featured Representative Helen Chenoweth of Idaho, who has asserted that "white men are an endangered species."
And as a private lawyer, Mr. Schroeder has drawn Democratic fire for representing former Representative Robert K. Dornan, the Orange County Republican, in his effort to show that voter fraud by Hispanic rights groups was responsible for his narrow loss to Loretta Sanchez, a Democrat, last year. Mr. Schroeder explains that effort by saying "We believe in outreach to Hispanics, not outreach to felons."
Mr. Pacheco said that halting the trend was still possible.
"We do have time to change," he said. "It's got to be done quickly, and sincerely. If it's just done for the next election, nobody's going to buy that."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Blue Chips Fall on Concern Over Impact of Asian Crisis
Concern about Asia's impact on corporate earnings helped pull down the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 38.29 points, or half of 1 percent, at 8,110.84 -- its first decline in seven sessions. Coca-Cola led the decline in the Dow after analysts said that the strong dollar would hurt the company's profits in Asian markets. The S.& P. 500 slipped 1.42 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent.
But technology issues were stronger, and the Nasdaq composite index, led by Microsoft, gained 17.64 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,651.54. D14 

Other companies in the United States are being hurt by the turmoil in Asia. Boeing said Asian airlines might delay taking delivery of as many as 60 jetliners over the next three years because the region's economic problems were slowing growth in airline traffic. Oracle reported disappointing earnings, hurt in part by the strength of the dollar in Asia. D2.
 
Thailand took an unexpectedly forceful step to address its economic problems, closing all but two of 58 ailing finance companies. D10.
 
Swiss Bank Merger Based on Size
By merging to form the world's second-largest bank, Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corporation appear to regard vast size -- the combined institution will have $590 billion in assets -- as critical to competing globally. But analysts caution that size alone cannot guarantee success. D8.
 
State and local government officials supported a temporary easing of sanctions they have imposed on Swiss banks, to help clear the way for a settlement with heirs of Holocaust victims. A8.
 
Japan Selling Some U.S. Treasuries
Talk of a Japanese selloff of United States Treasury bonds reappeared but few investors seemed rattled. Indeed, it turns out that the Bank of Japan has been quietly selling some Treasury holdings for days to provide short-term loans for Japan's troubled banks.. D2.
 
Treasury bond prices fell and sent the long-term bond yield up to 6.13 percent, the highest since Nov. 14, primarily over concern about strong economic growth in this country. D10.
 
Southeast Banking Merger
First American Corporation of Nashville will pay $2.7 billion in stock to buy Deposit Guaranty, the subject of recent takeover speculation. The deal will give First American a big presence in the Southeast. D5.
 
High Court Hears Copyright Case
The Supreme Court began hearing arguments in a complex case concerning the so-called gray market of American goods sold at a discount overseas and reshipped back to this country for unauthorized resale. The outcome of the case could determine whether the gray market continues to thrive. D9.
 
U.S. Appeal Heard on Software
In a case that could have a profound impact on electronic commerce and banking, a Federal appeals court heard the Government's appeal of a December 1996 ruling that Government attempts to control the export of encryption software were an unconstitutional restriction of free speech. D5.
 
Disney Planning 24-Hour Cartoons
Walt Disney will start a round-the-clock cartoon cable television network in April, capitalizing on the more than 2,200 cartoon episodes in its library. Toon Disney, as the new channel will be called, is designed to complement the Disney Channel's broader array of family programs. D6.
 
S.E.C. Accountant Quitting
Michael H. Sutton, the chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said he would resign early next month to pursue personal business interests. The commission is searching for someone to replace Mr. Sutton, who was appointed in June 1995. D5.
 
Russia Restores Pipeline Privileges
United States officials, after months of importuning, have persuaded the Russian Government to restore tax and pipeline privileges to three American-Russian joint ventures that extract Russian oil. D7.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1507 words

HEADLINE: PATAKI ANNOUNCES UNLIMITED PASSES FOR CITY TRANSIT

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki announced a program of monthly, weekly and daily passes yesterday that will give mass transit users unlimited trips for a fixed price and drastically change one of the central aspects of public transportation in New York City.
The passes, which will cost $63 for a month, $17 for a week or $4 for a day, are priced to give the biggest breaks to people who use the system for more than just a five-day-a-week commute: workers who hold two jobs, parents who take their children to school and then go to work, people who go out at night. The plan also calls for half-price passes for people over 65 and a cut in the fares on express buses to Manhattan from $4 to $3. 
 The Governor said the passes would cost the Metropolitan Transportation Authority $236 million a year in revenue it would otherwise collect if pass holders paid the full $1.50 fare. But officials said the cost would be financed by growing farebox and tax revenues that by September had produced a surplus of $128 million, a figure that continues to grow. The remaining money, at least $60 million, officials estimate, would come from unspecified cost-cutting in the transit agency.
Combined with other discounts for users of the Metrocard that have been approved in recent months, the passes, Mr. Pataki said, would help create a more seamless, user-friendly transit system, one that would make New Yorkers considerably more mobile and, in turn, stimulate the economy and cut pollution and traffic by tempting drivers and cab riders back onto mass transit.
But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had urged that the surplus be used to give 12 rides for the price of 10, was disappointed by the announcement. "It does not really help the most typical subway rider, which is the person who uses the subway twice a day to go to work and return from work," he said.
For a transit system that for decades has operated on a one-fare, one-ride philosophy, Mr. Pataki's announcement marked an ambitious change. It also was a remarkable turnaround for the Governor himself, who less than three years ago was painted as the villain who initiated the first subway service cuts in decades and who brought about a 25-cent fare increase. News analysis, page B7.
"The goal here," Mr. Pataki said, "was very simply to empower the rider. Empower the person who takes the subway and the person who takes the bus by giving them the broadest possible range of options as to how they want to choose to use the mass transit system."
The M.T.A. already plans to offer Metrocard users a 10 percent bonuson bulk purchases starting next month -- giving them 11 rides for the price of 10 and effectively rolling the fare back to $1.36. Since July, bus-to-subway transfers have been free.
The passes are expected to increase ridership by up to 100 million passengers a year, the Governor said, a 6 percent increase over the transit system's annual ridership of 1.5 billion. State officials said they expected "hundreds of thousands" of riders to buy both the monthly and weekly passes. The passes would be valid from the date of purchase rather than from the beginning of the month or week, officials said. The millions of dollars in interest the M.T.A. could earn each month from riders who pay for their trips in advance would partly offset the cost of the pass program.
The M.T.A. board, which is controlled by the Governor's appointees, is expected to approve the pass system on Dec. 18. The new passes might be available by next summer, only months before Mr. Pataki seeks re-election.
The passes would not yield savings for everyone. In order to save money beyond the 11-for-10 deal, a cardholder would have to ride the system 47 times a month. That means that someone who uses the system simply to commute to and from work five days a week, or about 40 rides a month, would not benefit. Similarly, to come out ahead on a weekly pass, a Metrocard user would have to take 13 rides.
The package's only flat-out fare cut calls for a decrease to $3, from $4, in the fare on the M.T.A.'s express buses to Manhattan, which are used by 25,000 commuters, 80 percent of them on Staten Island. Another 40,000 commuters ride private express buses regulated and subsidized by the city, and city officials have said they would match any fare cut by the M.T.A. The Governor's plan also calls for a $120 monthly express bus pass that would be good on subways and regular buses as well.
In announcing the transit pass plan, Mr. Pataki rejected a plan pushed by Mayor Giuliani and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, that would have used the transit surplus to offer 12 rides for the price of 10, an idea that would effectively cut the fare to $1.25 -- where it was before the fare increase of 1995. Such a discount, they argued, would give a break to all riders no matter how often they traveled.
"I have no specific objection to the package of benefits that they're talking about," the Mayor said. "But the benefits are going to be given to people who use the subways six or seven days a week, or people who visit the city."
Mr. Vallone said in a statement, "A strategy to increase ridership is smart. A plan that excludes our city's working class is not."
But Mr. Pataki said his plan provided the greatest benefit to the low-income New Yorkers who are most dependent on mass transit. And he dismissed suggestions that he rejected the 12-for-10 proposal in order to deprive Mr. Vallone, who is considering running against him next November, of a political victory.
The transit and environmental advocates who flanked him at a news conference in Manhattan said he chose the best plan.
"The most successful fare programs are the ones that give a variety of discounts because there are different markets," said Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group that has been fighting for monthly passes since the 1970's. "And I haven't been been to a single community forum in 20 years as a transit advocate where someone hasn't asked me how come New York doesn't have a monthly or weekly pass." Many big cities, including London, Paris, Los Angeles and Chicago, have had monthly and weekly transit passes for years.
Mr. Russianoff, who has often criticized Mr. Pataki for cutting state transit subsidies and for presiding over the 25-cent fare increase in 1995, the biggest in the history of the system, praised the Governor's proposal as "bold" and "innovative."
Dennis M. Walcott, the president of the New York Urban League, which sued the M.T.A. unsuccessfully to block the 1995 fare increase on the grounds that it discriminated against minority groups, called the proposal "a very positive step for the working-class citizens of New York City." He added that the weekly passes would be attractive to people who could not afford to spend $63 at once on transit.
Officials said the pass would be a form of the Metrocard, the plastic-coated card with a magnetic strip that allows fares to be deducted electronically at turnstiles.
Riders will be prevented from handing the pass off to others at the turnstile by a feature that will make it impossible to use the card more than once at the same station within a certain period of time, perhaps 20 minutes, officials said. But nothing will stop pass holders from lending their passes to someone else when they were not using the system, and Mr. Pataki said that was fine.
"We would not consider it an abuse," he said, "if someone uses the card Monday through Friday, then gives it to their kid on the weekend to go out. This is a card for the whole family."
Some transit advocates had argued that the surplus should go to rebuild the transit system, or to help pay off its mounting debt, the payments on which are scheduled to hit nearly a billion dollars a year after 2000, which could put pressure on the M.T.A. to raise fares again.
But Mr. Pataki said he felt that the best way to strengthen the system in the long term was to build ridership. Although some subway lines in Manhattan are already jammed during rush hours, Mr. Russianoff said that overall, the subways carry only half as many people as they did 50 years ago and that the passes would go a long way toward making mass transit central to more people's lives.
The pass system would be the shining moment for the Metrocard, which was introduced in 1994, along with a $750 million turnstile system, precisely because it would allow the M.T.A. to offer variable pricing. After initial resistance, it is now used by more than half of riders.
John Orcutt, associate director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a watchdog group, said that the package of discounts represented "sort of the end of the era of transit pessimism" in the city.
"The subway system was this icon of decrepit, crime-ridden New York," he said. "Now that the system is more or less functioning, we can start looking at stuff like ridership incentives. People are going to flood into the system because of these options."
